But, though Antigone has not yet revealed her purpose, too great callousness is ascribed to Ismene if she is supposed to doubt whether her sympathy is invited against or for such an edict.—The act. e)fa/ptein is rare: Tr. 933 tou)/rgon w(s e)fa/yeien, that he had imposed the deed on her (by his fierce reproaches): Pind. O. 9. 60mh\ kaqe/loi nin ai)w
 po/tmon e)fa/yais | o)rfano
 genea=s. Was Porson right in conjecturing ei(/q' a(/ptousa? For it, we may observe:—(1) An opposition of the simple lu/ein and a(/ptein suits a proverbial phrase: (2) h)/ and ei) are elsewhere confused, as O. C. 80 (n.): (3) the single ei)/te is found in O. T. 517 lo/goisin ei)/t' e)/rgoisin, Tr. 236 patrw/|as ei)/te barba/rou; Against the conjecture is the fact that ei)/q' a(/ptousa would have been much less likely to generate the h)\ qa/ptousa of our MSS., since the intermediate ei) qa/ptousa, being obviously unmeaning, would have been likely to cure itself.
prosqei/mhn: cp. O. C. 767 prosqe/sqai xa/rin, n.
ple/on, ‘for thine advantage’: O. T. 37 ou)de\n e)ceidw\s ple/on, n.
cumponh/seis is the more general word,—‘co-operate’; cunerga/sei, the more explicit,—‘help to accomplish the deed.’
poi=o/n ti kindu/neuma, cognate acc. to the verbs in 41: cp. O. C. 344 kaka\ | u(perponei=ton, n.

Read pou= gnw/mhs...ei)= (from ei)=nai): cp. El. 390 pou= pot' ei)= frenw=n. The question between pou= and poi= here is one of sense, not of idiom. poi= gnw/mhs ...ei)= (from i)e/nai) would mean, ‘to what thought will you have recourse?’ Cp. O. C. 170 poi= tis fronti/dos e)/lqh|; (n.), Tr. 705 ou)k e)/xw...poi= gnw/mhs pe/sw. But the meaning here is, ‘what can you be thinking of?’
ei) sc. sko/pei.—Join cu\n th=|de xeri/: she lifts her hand.
koufiei=s, take up for burial: cp. Ai. 1410 pleura\s su\n e)moi\ | ta/sd' e)pikou/fiz' (the dead Ajax): and the common phrase a)nairei=sqai nekrou/s.
h)= ga\r marks surprise (O. C. 64). The absence of caesura in the first three feet allows each of the two important words (noei=s qa/ptein) to fall slowly from the astonished speaker's lips.
sfe = au)to/n, as 516, 1226. sfe can be s. or pl., m. or f.: nin, s. or pl., m., f. or n.
a)po/rrhton, acc. neut. in appos. with qa/ptein sfe: Plat. Gorg. 507E e)piqumi/as...plhrou=n, a)nh/nuton kako/n.
po/lei, ‘to’ or ‘for’ (dat. of interest), not ‘by’ (dat. of agent), though the latter might be supported by Eur. Phoen. 1657 e)gw/ sfe qa/yw, ka)\n a)penne/ph| po/lis.

to
 gou=n e)mo
 k.t.l. To the question—‘Do you really mean to bury him?’—the simple answer would have been, to
 gou=n e)mo
 a)delfo/n, ‘I certainly mean to bury my own brother.’ But the word e)mo/n—reminding her that he is equally Ismene's brother—prompts the insertion of the reproachful clause, kai\ to
 so/n, h)
 su\ mh\ qe/lh|s. Thus the contrast between to
 e)mo/n and to
 so/n anticipates the emphasis on the word a)delfo/n. The whole thought is,—‘I will certainly do my duty,—and thine, if thou wilt not,—to a brother.’ Since o( e)mo/s is the same person as o( so/s, this thought can be poetically expressed by saying, ‘I will certainly bury my brother,—and thine, if thou wilt not’: for the tribute rendered to him by one sister represents the tribute due from both. Remark that gou=n often emphasises a pers. or possessive pron. (as here e)mo/n): 565 soi\ gou=n: Ai. 527 pro\s gou=n e)mou=: O. T. 626 to\ gou=n e)mo/n: El. 1499 ta\ gou=n s'.— Two other versions are possible, but less good. (1) Taking to
 … e)mo
 kai\ to
 so/n as=‘him who is my brother and thine,’ and h)
 as=‘even if.’ But for this we should expect to
 gou=n e)mo/n te kai\ so/n, and ka)/n. (2) Taking kai\ with h)/n, ‘I will bury my brother, even if thou wilt not bury thine.’ But (i) the separation of kai/ from h)/n is abnormal: (ii) the mode of expression would be scarcely natural unless o( e)mo/s and o( so/s were different persons.

a)delfo\n … a(lw/somai. Didymus (circ. 30 B.C.) said this verse was condemned as spurious ‘by the commentators’ (u(po\ tw=n u(pomnhmatistw=n). I believe it to be undoubtedly genuine. One modern argument against it is that Antigone should here speak only one verse. But these two verses express the resolve on which the action of the play turns: it is an important moment in the dialogue. And, at such a moment, Soph. often allows a stichomuthia to be broken by two or more verses for the same speaker. See the stichomuthia in 401—406, broken by 404 f.: O. T. 356-369, broken by 366 f.: ib. 1000—1046, broken by 1002 f. and 1005 f.: O. C. 579-606, broken by 583 f. and 599 ff. Further, verse 46 is Sophoclean in three traits: (a) a)delfo/n emphasised by position as first word, with a pause after it: cp. 72, 525: O. T. 278 dei=cai: O. C. 1628 xwrei=n. (b) ou) ga\r dh/ in rejecting an alternative: O. T. 576 e)kma/nqan': ou) ga\r dh\ foneu\s a(lw/somai. Cp. O. C. 110 n. (c) The phrase with the aor. part.: Ai. 1267 xa/ris diarrei= kai\ prodou=s' a(li/sketai. Lastly, v. 45, if alone, would be too bald and curt.

w)= sxetli/a, ‘over-bold.’ The word primarily means ‘enduring’ (&\sqrt;sxe, sxeqei=n). Hence: (1) Of persons, (a) ‘unflinching,’ in audacity or cruelty,—the usu. Homeric sense, as Od. 9.494 sxe/tlie, ti/pt' e)qe/leis e)reqize/men a)/grion a)/ndra; So Ph. 369, Ph. 930w)= sxe/tlie, Eur. Alc. 741

sxetli/a to/lmhs. (b) ‘Suffering,’=tlh/mwn, as Aesch. PV 644 (of Io), Eur. Hec. 783. Neither Homer nor Soph. has this use. (2) Of things, ‘cruel,’ ‘wretched,’—a use common to all the poets: so Ai. 887 sxe/tlia ga/r (‘'tis cruel’), Tr. 879.

ou)de/n, adv.: me/ta = me/testi: tw=n e)mw=n (masc.) with ei)/rgein only: cp. El. 536 a)ll' ou) meth=n au)toi=si th/n g' e)mh\n ktanei=n. Plat. Apol. 19 C e)moi\ tou/twn... ou)de\n me/testi. For the plur. cp. O. T. 1448 o)rqw=s tw=n ge sw=n telei=s u(/per (‘thou wilt meetly render the last rites to thine own,’—Iocasta).

nw=|n ethic dat. with a)pw/leto (cp. O. C. 81 be/bhken h(mi/n). a)pexqh/s, hateful to mankind for his involuntary crimes. a)pw/leto, ‘died,’ not merely ‘was disgraced’ (cp. 59 o)lou/meq'): she is speaking of the deaths which had left them alone. But e)/peita in 53 is merely ‘then,’ ‘in the next place,’ and need not mean that Oedipus died before Iocasta. Here Soph. follows the outline of the epic version, acc. to which Oed. died at Thebes: see Introd. to Oed. Tyr. pp. xvi ff. The poet of the Odyssey (11. 275) makes him survive his consort's suicide, and no version appears to have assumed the contrary. The Antigone knows nothing of his exile from Thebes, or of the sacred honour which surrounded the close of his life, as the story is told in the later Oedipus at Colonus.
pro\s … a)mplakhma/twn … a)ra/cas, ‘impelled by them to strike his eyes’: cp. O. T. 1236 (te/qnhke) pro\s ti/nos pot' ai)ti/as;

au)tofw/rwn = a(\ au)to\s e)fw/rasen (cp. fr. 768 ta\ plei=sta fwrw=n ai)sxra\ fwra/seis brotw=n), detected by himself, when he insisted on investigating the murder of Laïus (cp. O. T. 1065). Elsewhere au)to/fwros = fwraqei\s e)p' au)tw=| tw=| e)/rgw|, ‘taken in the act’: Thuc. 6.38 kola/zwn, mh\ mo/non au)tofw/rous (xalepo\n ga\r e)pitugxa/nein), a)lla\ kai\ w(=n bou/lontai me/n, du/nantai d' ou)/: and so in the adv. e)p' au)tofw/rw| lamba/nein etc.
a)ra/cas, with the golden brooches (pero/nai): O. T. 1276 h)/rass' e)pai/rwn ble/fara.

au)to\s au)tourgw=| xeri/, emphatic, like au)to\s pro\s au(tou= (1177), but not strictly pleonastic, since au)to/s=‘by his own act,’ i.e. ‘of his free will,’ while au)t. xeri/ refers to the instrument, ‘with hand turned against himself.’ Cp. on 56.

diplou=n e)/pos, a two-fold name (for the same person): as conversely Aesch. PV 209 e)moi\ de\ mh/thr...*qe/mis | kai\ *gai=a, pollw=n o)noma/twn morfh\ mi/a. Valckenär on Eur. Phoen.p. 153 cites Heracleitus Alleg. Hom. 21 (of Hera) diplou=n o)/noma fu/sews kai\ sumbiw/sews, ‘a name signifying at once birth and marriage’ (since she was coniunx lovis et soror). Seneca Oed. Tyr. 389 mixtumque nomen coniugis, nati, patris. (The feeble v. l. pa/qos for e)/pos meant, ‘a double calamity,’ since both mother and wife perished.)
a)rta/naisi: cp. O. T. 1264 plektai=sin ai)w/raisin e)mpeplegme/nhn.
du/o … mi/an: see on 13.

au)toktonou=nte is not literally, ‘slaying themselves,’ or ‘slaying each other,’ but, ‘slaying with their own hands’: the context explains that the person whom each so slew was his own brother. So either (1) suicide, or (2) slaying of kinsfolk, can be expressed by au)qe/nths, au)tokto/nos, au)tosfagh/s, au)tofo/nos, etc. The compound merely expresses that the deed is done with one's own hand, implying that such a use of one's own hand is unnatural. The object of the deed may be one's own life, or another's. This ambiguity of the compound is illustrated by 1175 f. au)to/xeir d' ai(ma/ssetai.—XO. po/tera patrw/|as h)\ pro\s oi)kei/as xero/s; ‘by his father's hand, or by his own?’

kateirga/sant', plur. verb with dual subject, as oft., even when another verb with the same subject is dual, as Xen. Cyr. 6.1.47 w(s ei)de/thn...h)spa/santo: Plat. Euthyd. 294E o(/te paidi/a h)/sthn ...h)pi/stasqe: see O. C. 343 n.

e)pallh/loin xeroi=n, ‘with mutual hands,’—each brother lifting his hands against the other. It is hard to believe that Soph. would here have written e)p' a)llh/loin, ‘against each other,’ when xeroi=n would seem a weak addition, and the double oin would be brought into harsh relief by the independence of the two words. The verse is in every way better if we can read e)pallh/loin as an epithet of xeroi=n. Now we know that the word e)pa/llhlos was in common use at least as early as the 2nd century B.C. In the extant literature it seems always to correspond with e)p' a)llh/lois as=‘one on top of another’ (Od. 23.47 kei/at' e)p' a)llh/loisi), being used to mean, ‘in close order’ or ‘in rapid sequence’ (as Polyb. 11. 11 e)n e)pallh/lois ta/cesi, in close ranks: Alciphro Epp. 3. 6 ta\s e)pallh/lous plhga/s, the showers of blows). An exception might, indeed, be supposed in Philo Judaeus De Mose 3, p. 692, where he is saying that the continuity of human record has been broken dia\ ta\s e)n u(/dasi kai\ puri\ genome/nas sunexei=s kai\ e)pallh/lous fqora/s: which Adrian Turnebus rendered, propter illas eluvionum et exustionum continuas et alternas (‘mutual’) interneciones. But Philo was evidently (I think) using e)pa/llhlos in its ordinary sense, and meant merely, ‘owing to the continuous and rapid succession of calamities by flood and fire.’ It by no means follows, however, that a poet of the 5th cent. B.C. could not have used e)pa/llhlos in a sense corresponding with e)p' a)llh/lois as= ‘against each other,’—the more frequent and familiar sense of the words, as in the Homeric e)p' a)llh/loisin i)o/ntes, e)p' a)llh/loisi fe/ron polu/dakrun *)/arha (Il. 3.132): cp. Aristoph. Lys. 50 e)p' a)llh/loisin ai)/resqai do/ru. The use of e)pa/llhlos here may have been partly prompted by a reminiscence of Aesch. Theb. 931 e)teleu/|tasan u(p' a)llalofo/nois xersi\n o(mospo/roisin (cp. Xen. Hier. 3. 8a)delfou\s... a)llhlofo/nous).

nu=n d' au)=. Though in L d' has been inserted by a later hand, it is found in A, and its omission by the first hand in L (which has made other such oversights) cannot weigh much against it. Some of the recent edd. omit it: but the effect of nu=n au)= without it would here be intolerably abrupt. For au)= (‘in our turn’) cp. 7.
mo/na dh/, ‘all alone’: Tr. 1063 mo/nh me dh\ kaqei=le: Ai. 992 a(pa/ntwn dh/: so esp. with superlatives, ib. 858 panu/staton dh/: Thuc. 1.50 megi/sth dh/.

yh=fon, the pebble used in voting, then, the vote; here (as below, 632) applied to the resolve or decree of an absolute monarch. Cp. O. T. 606 mh/ m' a(plh=| kta/nh|s | yh/fw|, diplh=| de/, i.e. not by thine own royal voice alone, but by mine also.
tura/nnwn, i.e. Creon: allusive plur., as 67: O.T. 366 n.

kra/th, the powers of the king, as 173 (cp. O. C. 392 n.). The disjunctive h)\ (for which Axt proposed kai\) means: ‘if we offend against this edict, or (in any way) against the royal powers.’ It could not mean: ‘if we infringe his edict, or (by persistence after warning) come into conflict with his power.’

tou=to me\n is not governed by e)nnoei=n, but is adv., ‘on the one hand,’ answered by e)/peita d' (63) instead of tou=to de/, as elsewhere by tou=t' au)=qis (167), tou=t' a)/llo (O. T. 605), ei)=ta ( Ph. 1346), or de/ (O. C. 441).

w(s, with ou) maxoume/na, marks the intention of nature as expressed in sex,—‘showing that we were not meant to strive with men.’ This might be illustrated by Arist. 's phrase, bou/letai h( fu/sis poiei=n ti, in regard to nature's intention or tendency (De Anim. Gen. 4. 10, etc.).
ou(/nek', ‘that’ (as O. T. 708, O. C. 1395, and oft.): not, ‘because,’ as some take it, supplying xrh/ with a)kou/ein.
e)k, as from the head and fount of authority; so El. 264 ka)k tw=nd' a)/rxomai: cp. O. C. 67 n.

a)kou/ein, infin. expressing consequence (‘so that we should hearken’), without w(/ste, as 1076 lhfqh=nai. We find a)kou/w tino/s, ‘to obey a person,’ but not a)kou/w ti, as ‘to hear (and obey) a command.’ Here tau=ta and a)lgi/ona are accusatives of respect, ‘in regard to these things,’ as pa/nta in El. 340, tw=n kratou/ntwn e)sti\ pa/nt' a)kouste/a, ‘I must obey the rulers in all things.’ If the accusatives were objective, the sense would be, ‘to hear these taunts’ (or, ‘to be called these names’): cp. Ph. 607, Ai. 1235.

e)gw\ me\n ou)=n. me/n (with no answering de/) emphasises e)gw/ (see on 11), while ou)=n has its separate force, ‘therefore,’ as in O. T. 483, O. C. 664. The composite me\n ou)=n (‘nay rather’) would be unfitting here.

tou\s u(po\ xqono/s, the gods below (451), and also the departed spirit of Polyneices,—which, like the spirit of the unburied Patroclus (Il. 23.65), can have no rest till sepulture has been given to the corpse. Cp. O. C. 1775 tw=| kata\ gh=s (Oedipus): for the allusive plur., El. 1419 zw=sin oi( ga=s u(pai\ kei/menoi (Agamemnon). In ref. to the nether world, Attic writers regularly join u(po/ with gen., not dat.: El. 841 u(po\ gai/as... a)na/ssei: Tr. 1097 to/n q' u(po\ xqono\s | *(/aidou...sku/laka: Phaedr. 249 A ta\ u(po\ gh=s dikasth/ria. Indeed u(po/ with dat. is altogether rare in Attic prose, except as meaning (a) under an authority, as u(po\ no/mois, or (b) under a class, as Plat. Symp. 205B ai( u(po\ pa/sais tai=s te/xnais e)rgasi/ai. In poetry, Attic and other, it is freq. also in the local sense: cp. 337 u(p' oi)/dmasin.
bia/zomai ta/de, pass. with cogn. acc., as 1073 bia/zontai ta/de. Cp. Ph. 1366ka)/m' a)nagka/zeis ta/de; and below, 219.

toi=s e)n te/lei bebw=si = tura/nnwn in 60, i.e. Creon. bebw=si, as El. 1094 moi/ra| me\n ou)k e)n e)sqla=| | bebw=san: O. C. 1358 e)n po/nw| | tau)tw=| bebhkw/s. Elsewhere Soph. has the simple phrase: Ai. 1352 klu/ein...tw=n e)n te/lei, and so Ph. 385, 925.oi( e)n te/lei are ‘those in authority,’ —te/los meaning ‘final or decisive power,’ as Thuc. 4.118 te/los e)/xontes i)o/ntwn, ‘let the envoys go as plenipotentiaries.’ Pindar's te/los dwdeka/mhnon (‘an office held for a year’), N. 11. 10, is perh. poetical. As synonyms for oi( e)n te/lei we find (1) oi( ta\ te/lh e)/xontes, Thuc. 5.47, and (2) ta\ te/lh simply,—‘the authorities,’ sometimes with masc. part., as Thuc. 4.15 e)/docen au)toi=s...ta\ te/lh kataba/ntas bouleu/ein. Hellen. 6. 5 has ta\ me/gista te/lh, ‘the highest magistrates’ (like Thuc. 1.10 e)/cw tw=n basile/wn kai\ tw=n ma/lista e)n te/lei: cp. 2. 10).
to\ ga\r | ...pra/ssein: for the art. in the 6th place, with its noun in the next v., cp. 78: O. T. 231: O. C. 265, 351: Ph. 674.
perissa\ pr.: cp. 780: so Tr. 617 perissa\ dra=n, = polla\ pra/ttein, polupragmonei=n.
ou)k e)/xei nou=n ou)d. = a)no/hto/n e)sti: prop. of persons, as Tr. 553 gunai=ka nou=n e)/xousan.
e)/ti, ‘yet,’—at some future time: so El. 66 (ka)/m' e)pauxw=) a)/stron w(\s la/myein e)/ti: Tr. 257 doulw/sein e)/ti (he vowed that he would yet enslave him).

pra/ssein … drw/|hs (instead of pra/ssois): for such substitution of a synonym cp. O. T. 54 a)/rceis...kratei=s (n.): O. C. 1501 safh\s ...e)mfanh/s. With drw/|hs we have a double a)/n, the first after the negative, the second after the emphatic e)mou= g': cp. O. T. 339 n.—Objection has been made to h(de/ws on the ground that it ought to mean, ‘with pleasure to yourself.’ Wecklein, indeed, takes that to be the sense, supposing ge to be misplaced; i.e. the proper order would have been, h(de/ws ge a)
 e)mou= k.t.l.: but the position of <)mou= in the verse sufficiently shows that ge must go with it. e)moi/ g' (Meineke) would leave me/ta awkward: and a)sme/nhs (Lehrs) would not have been displaced by h(de/ws, which the old scholia confirm. All the difficulty has arisen from failing to distinguish between (1) ou)k a)
 h(de/ws drw/|hs, and (2) ou)k a)
 meta\ e)mou= h(de/ws drw/|hs. In (1) h(de/ws could mean only, ‘agreeably to yourself.’ But in (2) it is ambiguous; for the statement is equivalent to saying, ‘your co-operation with me would not be agreeable’; i.e. to you, or to me, or to either of us,—as the context may imply. Here, as the emphatic e)mou= ge indicates, she means h(de/ws e)moi/. Cp. Plat. Rep. 426C o(\s...a)
 sfa=s...h(/dista qerapeu/h|, i.e. ‘whoever serves them most acceptably’ (not, ‘most gladly’). Aristoph. Nub. 79 pw=s dh=t' a)
 h(/dist' au)to
 e)pegei/raimi; (i.e. most pleasantly for him).

i)/sq' from ei)mi/: ‘be such as thou wilt,’—show what character thou wilt. Cp. Ph. 1049ou(= ga\r toiou/twn dei=, toiou=to/s ei)m' e)gw/: ib. 1271 toiou=tos h)=sqa toi=s lo/goisi: El. 1024 a)/skei toiau/th nou=n di' ai)w=nos me/nein: O.T. 435 h(mei=s toioi/d' e)/fumen.

o/poi/a soi dokei==(toiau/th) o(poi/a| (or o(poi/an) ei)=nai dokei= soi, the relative being attracted into the case of the suppressed antecedent. This was the more natural since o(poi/a soi dokei=, ‘of any kind you please,’ was felt as almost one word, o(poiadh/pote; just so o(\s bou/lei (quivis), instead of ou(=tos o(\n bou/lei, Plat. Gorg. 517A mh/pote/ tis tw=n nu=n e)/rga toiau=ta e)rga/shtai oi(=a tou/twn o(\s bou/lei ei)/rgastai: Crat. 432 A w(/sper au)ta\ ta\ de/ka h)\ o(/stis bou/lei a)/llos a)riqmo/s.—Those who read i)/sq' (from oi)=da) o(poi=a/ soi dokei= compare El. 1055 a)ll' ei) seauth=| tugxa/neis dokou=sa/ ti | fronei=n, fro/nei toiau=ta. But ei)de/nai is not fronei=n. In Attic, i)/sq' o(poi=a/ soi dokei= could mean nothing but ‘know such things as seem good to thee.’ It could not mean (a) ‘Have such sentiments as seem good to thee’: nor (b) ‘Be wise in thine own wisdom.’ The Homeric phrases, pepnume/na ei)dw/s (‘wise of heart’), a)qemi/stia ei)dw/s, h)/pia oi)=de (‘he has kindly feelings,’ Od. 13.405), etc., have no counterpart in the Attic usage of ei)de/nai. In 301 dusse/beian ei)de/nai, and in Ph. 960dokou=ntos ou)de\n ei)de/nai kako/n, the verb means simply ‘to know.’
qa/yw, emphatic by place and pause: see on 46 a)delfo/n.
fi/lh … fi/lou, loved by him, as he is loved by me: Ai. 267 koino\s e)n koinoi=si: ib. 620 a)/fila par' a)fi/lois.

met' au)tou= kei/somai, i.e. in the same world of the dead (76). The repetition of meta/ serves to bring out the reciprocity of love more strongly: fi/lh met' au)tou= kei/somai, meta\ fi/lou (keime/nh),— instead of the simpler fi/lh meta\ fi/lou kei/somai.

o(/sia panourgh/sas': having broken a human law in a manner which the gods permit,—viz., in order to observe a divine law. Creon uses the word panourgi/as below, 300. o(/sia is peculiarly appropriate since the word was familiar where duty to heaven was distinguished from duty to man: cp. Polyb. 23. 10 parabh=nai kai\ ta\ pro\s tou\s a)nqrw/pous di/kaia kai\ ta\ pro\s tou\s qeou\so(/sia. The phrase is an o)cu/mwron (a paradox with a point), like ‘splendide mendax’; i.e. the qualification (o(/sia) seems contrary to the essence of the thing qualified. Cp. Milton (Tetrachordon), ‘Men of the most renowned virtue have sometimes by transgressing most truly kept the law’; which is not an oxymoron, because the words, ‘most truly,’ suggest an explanation by showing that ‘kept’ is not used in its ordinary sense.
e)pei\ k.t.l.: (I will obey gods rather than men), for the other world is more to me than this.
tw=n e)nqa/de = h)\ toi=s e)nqa/de: O. C. 567 th=s e)s au)/rion | ou)de\n ple/on moi s ou= (=h)\ soi\) me/testin h(me/ras (n.).

kei/somai, though we have had the word in 73. For other examples of such repetition, see n. on O. C. 554, and cp. below 163 w)/rqwsan, 167 w)/rqou: 207 e)/k g' e)mou=, 210 e)c e)mou=: 613, 618 (e(/rpei): 614, 625 (e)kto\s a)/tas).

soi\ d' is better than Elmsley's su\ d', since the primary contrast is between their points of view: ‘if it seems right to thee, dishonour the dead,’ rather than, ‘do thou, if it seems right, dishonour the dead.’ Remark, too, that the simple ei) dokei= (without dat. of pron.) is usually a polite formula, ‘if it is pleasing to you (as well as to me)’: Ph. 526a)ll' ei) dokei=, ple/wmen: ib. 645 a)ll' ei) dokei=, xwrw=men: ib. 1402 ei) dokei=, stei/xwmen.

ta\ tw=n qew=n e)/ntima, the honoured things of the gods; the laws which are theirs (454 qew=n no/mima), held in honour (by them and by men). ta\ toi=s qeoi=s e)/ntima (25, El. 239 e)/ntimos tou/tois) would have presented the gods only as observers, not also as authors, of the laws.
a)tima/sas' e)/xe (cp. 22), ‘be guilty of dishonouring’: cp. Ai. 588 mh\ prodou\s h(ma=s ge/nh|, and n. on O. T. 957.
e)gw\ is slightly emphasised by me/n (see on 11), which goes closely with it, and does not here answer to the following de/.
a)/tima poiou=mai = a)tima/zw: cp. O.C. 584 di' ou)deno\s poiei=.

to\ de\ | ...dra=n: see on 67 to\ ga\r | ...pra/ssein. The inf. with art. is strictly an acc. of respect (‘as for the acting..., I am incapable of it’), but is practically equiv. to the simple inf., a)mh/xanos dra=n: see n. on O. C. 47 ou)d' e)moi\...tou)canista/nai... | ...e)sti\ qa/rsos.

ta/d' a)\n prou)/xoio, ‘thou canst make these excuses’ (sc. ei) bou/loio): Aesch. Ag. 1394 xai/roit' a)/n, ei) xai/roit': e)gw\ d' e)peu/xomai. For proe/xesqai as=profasi/zesqai cp. Thuc. 1.140 o(/per ma/lista prou)/xontai. So pro/sxhma = pro/fasis (El. 525).
dh\, ‘now,’ as the next thing to be done: cp. 173.

ta/fon xw/sous', prop. to raise a mound on the spot where the remains of the dead had been burned: Il. 7.336 tu/mbon d' a)mfi\ purh\n e(/na xeu/omen. So Il. 24.799 sh=m' e)/xean,—after placing the bones in an urn (la/rnac), and depositing this in a grave (ka/petos). She speaks as if she hoped to give him regular sepulture. This is ultimately done by Creon's command (1203 tu/mbon...xw/santes), though the rites which Antigone herself is able to perform are only symbolical (255, 429).

Join oi)/moi talai/nhs, ‘alas for thee, unhappy one’: O. C. 1399 oi)/moi keleu/qou th=s t' e)mh=s duspraci/as, | oi)/moi d' e(tai/rwn: but the nom. when the ref. is to the speaker, as El. 1143 oi)/moi ta/laina th=s e)mh=s pa/lai trofh=s.

mh\ 'mou= prota/rbei (or, as some write it, mh\ e)mou=) is clearly right. If we read mh/ mou prota/rbei, then the emphasis is solely on the verbal notion. ‘I fear for thee.’—‘Fear not so: make thine own fate prosperous.’ But the stress on to\n so/n renders it certain that the poet intended a corresponding stress on the preceding pronoun: ‘Fear not for me— make thine own fate prosperous.’ And mh\ 'mou= is no more objectionable than mh\ 'gw/ in El. 472. prota/rbei, as Tr. 89 (with gen. patro/s). Distinguish prodei/sas, ‘afraid beforehand,’ O. T. 90 (n.).

e)co/rqou here=‘straighten out,’ i.e. guide in a straight or prosperous course: cp. 167 w)/rqou po/lin, 675 o)rqoume/nwn. Elsewhere e)corqo/w is usu. ‘to correct, amend’ (Plat. Tim. 90D); more rarely, like a)norqo/w (O. T. 51), ‘to set upright’ (to\ peso/n, Plat. Legg. 862C). In the figurative uses of o)rqo/s and its derivatives the context must always guide our choice between the notion of ‘upright’ and that of ‘straight.’

a)ll' ou)=n … ge. In this combination a)lla/ is like our ‘well’; ou)=n=‘at any rate’ (i.e. if you must do it); and ge emphasises the word which it follows. Cp. El. 233 a)ll' ou)=n eu)noi/a| g' au)dw=, ‘well, at any rate (i.e. though you will not listen to me) it is with good-will that I speak.’ Ph. 1305.
krufh= de/: here de/ = a)lla/: Thuc. 4.86 ou)k e)pi\ kakw=|, e)p' e)leuqerw/sei de/.
su\n d', adv., sc. keu/sw: cp. Ai. 1288 o(/d' h)=n o( pra/sswn tau=ta, su\n d' e)gw\ parw/n.
au)/tws (adv. of au)to/s, see on O.T. 931), in just that way—‘likewise’: Tr. 1040 w(=d' au)/tws w(/s m' w)/lese.

katau/da, sc. to\ e)/rgon, ‘denounce it.’ The word occurs only here, the pres. used in this sense being katagoreu/w (Thuc. 4.68 katagoreu/ei tis cuneidw\s toi=s e(te/rois to\ e)pibou/leuma): aor. katei=pon.

pollo/n: this Ionic form occurs also Tr. 1196 pollo\n d' a)/rsen' e)ktemo/nq' o(mou= | a)/grion e)/laion, though in no other places of tragedy. And Soph. also used the epic form poulu/pous in a trimeter, fr. 286 no/ei pro\s a)ndri/, sw=ma poulu/pous o(/pws | pe/tra|, k.t.l. Porson on Eur. Hec. 618 wished to read in our verse either plei=on (which is inadmissible, as Nauck observes, Eur. Stud. 2. 27), or ma=llon, which some edd. receive. But pollo\n is manifestly better than ma=llon.
sigw=s' is explained by e)a\n … ta/de, while the thought is strengthened by pa=si: she is to tell the news to all.

qermh\n e)pi\ yuxroi=si k.t.l.: ‘thou hast a hot heart for chilling deeds’; i.e. in thy rash enthusiasm thou art undertaking deeds which might well chill thy soul with a presage of death. e)pi/ with dat. here=‘with a view to’ (Xen. Anab. 3.5.18 e)pi\ tou/tois e)qu/santo): not ‘in,’ like e)p' e)/rgois pa=si O. C. 1268 (n.). Cp. 157. qermh/n has suggested yuxra/, and the thought of the dead has helped (cp. O. C. 621 ne/kus yuxro/s). In Aesch. PV 693 dei/mata are said a)mfa/kei ke/ntrw| yu/xein yuxa/n (to chill,—where Meineke's yh/xein, ‘to wear,’ is improbable). Cp. Aristoph. Ach. 1191 stugera\ ta/de kruera\ pa/qea: Eur. fr. 908 kruera\ *dio/qen | qana/tou pemfqei=sa teleuth/. For the verbal contrast, Schütz cp. Ad Herenn. 4. 15. 21 in re frigidissima cales, in ferventissima friges, and A. P. 465 ardentem frigidus Aetnam Insiluit. He thinks that Ismene (hurt by vv. 86 f.) implies, ‘and a cold heart for thy living sister,’ to which Ant. rejoins by v. 89. But qermh/n is not ‘affectionate,’ and Ant. seems to mean simply, ‘love and piety banish fear.’— Some understand, ‘with a view to joyless things’ (cp. on 650): but this would be weak.

a(dei=n, an aor. inf. used in Il. 3.173, as also by Solon (fr. 7 e)/rgmasin e)n mega/lois pa=sin a(dei=n xalepo/n), Her., and This Pind. is the only place in classical Attic where any part of the aor. e(/adon occurs.

ei) kai\ dunh/sei g', yes, if (besides having the wish to please them) you shall also have the power. kai\ goes closely with dunh/sei: cp. O. T. 283 ei) kai\ tri/t' e)sti/. Such cases must be carefully distinguished from those in which ei) kai/ form a single expression; see O. T. p. 296.
Since ou)kou=n (‘well, then’) precedes, dh\ is best taken as giving precision to o(/tan,—‘so soon as.’
pepau/somai, ‘I will cease forthwith’: so Tr. 587. Cp. the perf., Ph. 1279ei) de\ mh/ ti pro\s kairo\n le/gwn | kurw=, pe/paumai, ‘I have done.’

a)rxh/n, adv., ‘to begin with,’ ‘at all,’—in negative sentences; often placed, as here, before the negative word; El. 439 a)rxh
 d' a)
...ou)k a)
...e)pe/stefe: Ph. 1239a)rxh
 klu/ein a)
 ou)d' a(/pac e)boulo/mhn: Her. 3.39 e)/fh xariei=sqai ma=llon a)podidou\s ta\ e)/labe h)\ a)rxh
 mhde\ labw/n. In affirmative sentences the art. is usually added: Andoc. or. 3 § 20 e)ch=n ga au)toi=s kai\ th
 a)rxh
 e)w=sin *)orxomeni/ous au)tono/mous ei)rh/nhn a)/gein: so Isocr. or. 15 § 272.

e)xqarei=, pass.: so, from liquid stems, 230 a)lgunei=: O. T. 272 fqerei=sqai: Ai. 1155 phmanou/menos. The ‘midd.’ fut. in s affords numerous examples, as below, 210, 637, 726: see n. on O. T. 672 and O. C. 1185.
e)c e)mou=, ‘on my part’ (cp. 95), rather than simply ‘by me’ (cp. 63).

e)xqra\...tw=| qano/nti proskei/sei di/kh|, ‘thou wilt be subject to the lasting enmity of the dead.’ The word proskei/sei means literally, ‘wilt be attached to...,’ i.e., ‘wilt be brought into a lasting relation with’; and e)xqra/ defines the nature of that relation. The sense is thus virtually the same as if we had, o( qanw
 e)xqro/s soi proskei/setai, ‘the enmity of the dead will cleave to thee.’ The convertible use of proskei=seqai is illustrated by 1243 a)ndri\ pro/skeitai kako/n, as compared with El. 1040 w(=| su\ pro/skeisai kakw=|, and ib. 240 ei)/ tw| pro/skeimai xrhstw=|. Here, proskei/sei expresses merely the establishment of the permanent relation between the two persons. It does not mean, ‘you will be brought, as his foe, into dependence on him’ (i.e. under the power of his curse); as in Eur. Tro. 185 tw=| pro/skeimai dou/la tla/mwn; ‘to whom have I been assigned as a slave?’ (i.e. by the casting of lots:— the answer is, e)ggu/s pou kei=sai klh/rou). Nor, again, ‘you will press upon the dead as his foe,’ i.e. be hostile and grievous to him: for, as di/kh| shows, the punishment is to be hers, not his. The idea might have been expressed in a converse form by to
 qano/nta e)xqro
 prosqh/sei (cf. Xen. Cyr. 2.4.12).

Lehrs proposed *di/kh|, i.e. ‘you will fall under the chastisement of justice.’ Donaldson, following Emper, reads e)xqra=|... di/kh|, as iure inimicorum apud mortuum eris: i.e. on the part of the dead you will be deemed to have only the rights of a foe. This is impossible. The ordinary reading is sound.
e)/a, one syll. by synizesis, as O. T. 1451 (n.).

th
 e)c e)mou= dusbbouli/an, the folly proceeding from me, the folly on my part, for which I bear the sole blame: El. 619 a)ll' h( ga e)k sou= dusme/neia kai\ ta\ sa\ | e)/rg' e)canagka/zei me, ‘it is the enmity on thy part,’ etc. Tr. 631 mh\ prw\| le/gois a)
 to
 po/qon to
 e)c e)mou=, | pri
 ei)de/nai ta)kei=qen ei= poqou/meqa. Cp. O. C. 453 n.
to\ deino\n tou=to, ironical: cp. El. 376 (Electra in answer to her sister's warnings) fe/r' ei)pe\ dh\ to\ deino/n.

pei/somai ga\r ou): for the position of the negative (which belongs to the verb, not to tosou=ton), cp. 223, O. C. 125 prose/ba ga\r ou)k a)/n. We still write ou) here, not ou)/, because the sentence runs on without pause: but 255 tumbh/rhs me\n ou)/, Ai. 545 tarbh/sei ga\r ou)/, since in each case a comma can follow the negative.

mh\ ou), not mh/, because the principal verb pei/somai is negatived: O.T. 283 n. She means, ‘even if I have to die, at least I shall not suffer the worst of evils; which is not death, but an ignoble death.’ Cp. frag. adesp. 61 ou) katqanei=n ga\r deino/n, a)ll' ai)sxrw=s qanei=n.

toi=s fi/lois d' o)rqw=s fi/lh, ‘but truly dear to thy friends,’—i.e. both to the dead brother and to the living sister. The words are especially a parting assurance (i)/sqi) that Ismene's love is undiminished. o)rqw=s = a)lhqw=s, as Diphilus frag. incert. 20 to\n o)rqw=s eu)genh=. Others make fi/lh active,—‘a true friend to thy friends’ (i.e. to Polyneices): which is certainly the fittest sense in Eur. I. T. 609 w(s a)p' eu)genou=s tinos | r(i/zhs pe/fukas, toi=s fi/lois t' o)rqw=s fi/los (Orestes, when he devotes his life to save his friend's). But here the other view is decidedly preferable.

div2.p: Parodos. For the metres see Metrical Analysis. The framework is as follows. (1) 1st strophe, 100 a)kti/s to 109 xalinw=|=1st antistrophe, 117 sta\s to 133 a)lala/cai. (2) 2nd strophe, 134 a)ntitu/pa| to 140 decio/seiros=2nd antistrophe, 148 a)lla\ ga\r to 154 a)/rxoi. Each strophe and each antistrophe is followed by an anapaestic system (su/sthma) of seven verses, recited by the Coryphaeus alone, in the pauses of the choral dance. The fourth and last of these systems, following the second antistrophe, announces the approach of Creon.

The Ajax is the only play of Sophocles which has a Parodos beginning, in the older style, with a regular anapaestic march. But something of the same character is given to this ode by the regularity of the anapaestic systems. In the Parodos of the O. C., on the other hand, though anapaests similarly divide each strophe from each antistrophe, the systems are of unequal lengths, and the general character is wholly different, being rather that of a kommo/s: see n. on O. C. 117.

The fifteen Theban elders who form the Chorus have been summoned to the palace by Creon,—they know not, as yet, for what purpose (158). They greet the newly-risen sun, and exult in the flight of the Argives.

The ode vividly portrays the enormous sin of Polyneices against his country, and the appalling nature of the peril which Thebes has just escaped. We already know Antigone's motive. This is a dramatic prelude to the announcement of Creon's.

div3.p: a)eli/ou, Dor. for the epic h)eli/ou, with a_ as usu. (808, O. C. 1245), though it is sometimes used with ă, as Tr. 835, Eur. Med. 1252.

to\ ka/lliston ...fa/os. Two constructions are possible; I prefer the first. (1) *qh/ba| fane
 to\ ka/lliston fa/os, the art. going with the superlative, which it emphasises,—‘the very fairest,’—a common use, as Hipp. 289B ou)x h( kalli/sth parqe/nos ai)sxra\ fanei=tai; Od. 17.415 ou) me/n moi doke/eis o( ka/kistos *)axaiw=n. (2) to\ *qh/ba| fane
 ka/lliston fa/os, the art. going with fane/n. This seems awkward. When a voc. is followed by a noun or partic. with art., this is normally in direct agreement with the voc., as w)= a)/ndres...oi( paro/ntes (Plat. Prot. 337C), as if here we had h( fanei=sa. The Schol., who prefers this constr., shirks the difficulty by his paraphrase, w)= th=s a)kti=nos tou= h(li/ou fw=s, to\ fane
 k.t.l.
e(ptapu/lw|: epithet of *qh/bh in Od. 11.263, Hes. Op. 161, as e(kato/mpuloi in Il. 9.383 of *qh=bai *ai)gu/ptiai.

tw=n prote/rwn: cp. 1212f.: Thuc. 1.10 stratei/an...megi/sthn...tw=n pro\ au)th=s. Tacitus Hist. 1. 50 solus omnium ante se principum. Milton P. L. 4. 322
Adam, the goodliest man of men since born, | His sons, the fairest of her daughters Eve. Goethe Hermann und Dorothea 5. 101 Von ihren Schwestern die beste.
e)fa/nqhs with an echo of fane/n (parh/xhsis): cp. O.C. 794 sto/ma | ...sto/mwsin.

xruse/as, with u^ as O.T. 157, 188. So Pind. Pyth. 4.4 e)/nqa pote\ xru^se/wn *dio\s ai)htw=n pa/redros. The u^ was admitted by the lyrists, and from them borrowed by the dramatists, though only in lyrics, and even there only occasionally. Homer never shortens the u: for, as xruse/w| a)na\ skh/ptrw| (Il. 1.15) shows, the Homeric xruse/hs (etc.) must be treated as disyll. by synizesis.
ble/faron = o)/mma: Eur. Phoen. 543 nukto/s t' a)fegge\s ble/faron (the moon). Cp. Job iii. 9 (Revised Version), ‘neither let it behold the eyelids of the morning.’

*dirkai/wn. The Dircè was on the w. of Thebes, the Ismenus on the E. : between them flowed the less famous Strophia: Callim. Hymn Del. 76 *di/rkh te *strofi/h te melamyhfi=dos e)/xousai | )*ismhnou= xe/ra patro/s (alluding to their common source S. of the town). Though the Ismenus, as the eastern stream, would have been more appropriately named here, the Dircè is preferred, as the representative river of Thebes: so Pindar, ‘the Dircaean swan,’ expresses ‘at Thebes and at Sparta’ by r(ee/qroisi/ te *di/rkas...kai\ par' *eu)rw/ta| ( Pind. Isthm. 1. 29). Cp. 844.

to\n leu/kaspin...fw=ta, in a collective sense: so o( *pe/rshs, the Persian army, Her. 8.108, etc. Cp. Aesch. Theb. 90 o( leu/kaspis lew/s (Dind. leukopreph/s): Eur. Phoen. 1099 leu/kaspin ei)sorw=men *)argei/wn strato/n. The round shield, painted white, which the Argive soldier carried on his left arm, is the leukh=s xio/nos pte/ruc of 114. The choice of white as the Argive colour may have been prompted by a popular association of *)/argos with a)rgo/s.

The words to\n leu/kaspin *)argo/qen answer metrically to 123 peuka/enq' *(/hfaiston e(lei=n. Instead of *)argo/qen (¯˘¯) we therefore require ¯˘˘¯. The short final of leu/kaspin is legitimate, the metre being Glyconic (see Analysis Metr.). In the antistrophic verse, the H of *(/hfaiston is ‘irrational,’ i.e. is a long syllable doing duty for a short: and Nauck is incorrect in saying that the metre ‘requires’ (though it admits) a choriambus beginning with a consonant. The simplest remedy is to read *)argo/qen e)k | ba/nta fw=ta, and to suppose that, after the loss of e)k, ba/nta and fw=ta were accidentally transposed. Cp. O. C. 1088 where sqe/nei 'pinikei/w| is certainly the right order, but the MSS. reverse it. (See also above on v. 29.) Dindorf reads e)k fw=ta ba/nta, assuming tmesis: but tmesis of e)k in Soph. occurs elsewhere only before me/n (Tr. 1053) or de/, and there was no motive here for interposing fw=ta. Hermann reads *)argo/qen e)/k as=e)c *)argo/qen: but elsewhere e)k comes before, not after, such forms (e)c *ai)su/mhqen, Il. 8.304: e)c a(lo/qen, e)c ou)rano/qen, etc.). If *)argo/qen is not genuine, then it was probably a gloss on some other form in -qen. Had ga=s *pe/lopos (or *danaou=) been in the text, a scholiast would have been more apt to paraphrase with a)p' or e)c *)/argous. This is against such conjectures as *)arge/i+on, *)argogenh=, *)argoliko/n, *)inaxi/dan, *)ina/xion, as is also the fact that ba/nta suggests a mention of ‘the place whence.’ *)apio/qen (Ahrens) would mean ‘from *)/apios,’ but we require ‘from *)api/a’ sc. (gh=, the Peloponnesus, O. C. 1303 n.), i.e. *)api/a_qen: cp. *)olumpi/aqen. I had thought of *)inaxo/qen, which Mekler, too, has suggested, though he has not supported it by argument. The points in its favour are: (a) the order fw=ta ba/nta can be kept: (b) after ‘Dircè's streams’ in v. 105 a reference to the Argive river would be appropriate: (c) a)rgo/qen might have come in either as a gloss, or a corruption of the letters axo/qen, if in had dropped out after leu/kaspin. But I hesitate to displace *)argo/qen, esp. when a direct mention of Argos here so naturally corresponds with the direct mention of Thebes in v. 101.

pansagi/a| (only here)=panopli/a|, modal dat. sa/gh (for accent, cp. Chandler § 72)=‘what one carries,’ and so, generally, ‘equipment’ (Aesch. Cho. 560 ce/nw| ga\r ei)kw/s, pantelh= sa/ghn e)/xwn), or, specially, body-armour: Aesch. Pers. 240 e)/gxh stadai=a kai\ fera/spides sa/gai (opp. to the light equipment of the toco/ths).
fuga/da pr., proleptic, with kinh/sasa, ‘having stirred to flight,’ etc. cp. O. C. 1292 e)celh/lamai fuga/s.
pro/dromon, ‘running forward,’ i.e. ‘in headlong haste’: Aesch. Th. 211e)pi\ daimo/nwn pro/dromos h)=lqon a)r|xai=a bre/th. In prose, always of precursors (as heralds, or an advanced guard).

o)cute/rw|...xalinw=|, ‘in swifter career,’ dat. of manner with fuga/da pro/dromon. Cp. O. C. 1067 (where the Attic horsemen are described rushing in pursuit of the Thebans), pa=s ga\r a)stra/ptei xalino/s, ‘the steel of every bridle flashes,’—as they gallop on with slack reins. So here, the xalino/s, which glitters as the horse rushes along, is poetically identified with the career itself, and thus is fitly joined with o)cu/teros. The phrase seems happy in this context. The Argives began their retreat in the darkness (16): when the sun rises, the flashing steel of their bridles shows them in headlong flight.

o)cute/rw| does not mean (1) ‘in flight swifter than their former approach’; nor (2) that the reins are shaken ever faster on the horses' necks. o)cuto/rw| (L) was a mere blunder: it could only mean ‘piercing’ (the horse's mouth), not, ‘giving a sharp sound,’ when the reins are shaken.—Cp. Aesch. Th. 122(describing the Argive besiegers) dia/detoi de/ toi genu=n i(ppia=n | kinu/rontai (minu/rontai L. Dind.) fo/non xalinoi/. Ib. 152 o)/tobon a(rma/twn a)mfi\ po/lin klu/w. Our passage suggests horsemen rather than drivers of war-chariots: perh. the poet imagined both, as in O. C. 1062 pw/loisin h)\ r(imfarma/tois | feu/gontes a(mi/llais.

The MSS. have o(
...*polunei/khs. If this were sound, it would be necessary to suppose that after a)mfilo/gwn a dipodia has been lost, such as Nauck supplies by <h)/gagen: e)xqro\s d'> o)ce/a kla/zwn. For (1) a verb is wanted to govern o(/n, and (2) the description of the eagle, beginning with o)ce/a kla/zwn, clearly refers to the Argive host, not to Polyneices only. But if, with Scaliger, we read o(\s ...*polunei/kous, no such loss need be assumed. The correspondence between anapaestic systems is not always strict, and the monometer o)ce/a kla/zwn could stand here, though the anti-system has a dimeter in the same place (129). The MS. reading o(
...*polunei/khs probably arose from a misunderstanding of the scholium:—o(/ntina strato
 *)argei/wn, e)c a)mfilo/gwn neike/wn a)rqei/s, h)/gagen o( *polunei/khs, oi(=on a)mfilogi/a| xrhsa/menos pro\s to
 a)delfo/n: dia\ braxe/wn de\ ei)=pen au)to/, w(s gnwri/mou ou)/shs th=s u(poqe/sews. The Schol. wrote a)rqei/s, to agree with *polunei/khs, and not a)rqe/nta, to agree with strato/n, because it suited the form of his paraphrase, oi(=on a)mfilogi/a| xrhsa/menos pro\s to
 a)delfo/n. By dia\ braxe/wn de\ ei(=pen au)to/, the Schol. meant not merely the indefiniteness of neike/wn e)c a)mfilo/gwn, but also the compactness of *polunei/kous | a)rqei\s e)k neike/wn for o(/ntina strato
 h)/gagen o( *polunei/khs. But a transcriber, noticing that the Schol. joined a)rqei/s with *polunei/khs, might easily infer that o(
...*polunei/khs ought to stand in the text, and might take dia\ braxe/wn as meaning that the verb h)/gage could be understood.—L has the Doric ga=|, and presently ga=n, u(pere/pta, which I keep: see Appendix.

*polunei/kous … neike/wn, playing on the name, like Aesch. ( Aesch. Th. 577, Aesch. Th. 658, Aesch. Th. 829): as elsewhere on that of Ajax (Ai. 432 ai)a/zein), and of Odysseus (fr. 877, polloi\ ga\r w)du/santo dusmenei=s e)moi/, have been bitter).

a)rqei/s, ‘having set forth’: so Her. 1.165 a)erqe/ntes e)k tw=n *oi)nousse/wn e)/pleon: 9. 52 (of a land-force) a)erqe/ntes ...a)palla/ssonto. Attic prose similarly uses the act. a)/ras, either absolutely, or with dat. (tai=s nausi/, tw=| stratw=|), or, more rarely, with acc. (ta\s nau=s Thuc. 1.52). Here the choice of the word suits the image of an eagle soaring.

neik. e)c a)mfilo/gwn, lit. in consequence of contentious quarrels, i.e. his claims to the Theban throne, against his brother Eteocles. Eur. Med. 636 a)mfilo/gous o)rga\s (contentious moods) a)ko/resta/ te nei/kh: Ph. 500a)mfi/lektos...e)/ris. The prep. as O. C. 620 e)k smikrou= lo/gou.
o)ce/a kla/zwn: Homeric, Il. 17.88 (of Hector) o)ce/a keklhgw/s: Il. 16.429 mega/la kla/zonte (of vultures fighting): so Aesch. Ag. 48 (the Atreidae) me/gan e)k qumou= kla/zontes *)/arh.

ai)eto\s ei)s ga=n w(\s u(pere/pta seems clearly right. If w(/s is omitted, we have a metaphor instead of a simile, with harsh effect. If we read ai)eto\s w(/s, and omit ei)s, ga=n u(pere/pta could mean only, ‘flew over the land,’ not, ‘flew over the border into the land.’ Further, it is better that the flow of these descriptive verses should not be broken by a paroemiac before v. 116. No argument either way can be founded on v. 130 (where see n.), since, even if it were a paroemiac, that would not require a paroemiac here.

u(pere/pta. The act. strong aor. e)/pthn (as if from i(/pthmi) occurs simple only in the Batrachomyomachia (210, if sound) and the Anthol.: compounded, only in the tragic lyrics and in late prose. Cp. 1307.

leukh=s xio/nos pt., ‘a wing white as snow’ (the white shield, see on 106); genitive of quality (or material), equiv. to an epithet: cp. O. T. 533 to/lmhs pro/swpon (a bold front): El. 19 a)/strwn eu)fro/nh (starry night): Eur. Phoen. 1491 stoli/da...trufa=s (a luxurious robe): ib. 1526 ga/laktos...mastoi=s (milky breasts).
stegano/s, pass. here, ‘covered’; but act. in Aesch. Ag. 358 stegano\n di/ktuon: cp. Xen. Cyr. 7.1.33 ai( a)spi/des...stega/zousi ta\ sw/mata.

o(/plwn … koru/qessi. The image of the eagle with white wings, which suited the Argive descent on Thebes, here passes into direct description of an invader who comes with many o(/pla and ko/ruqes,—the shield, spear, and helmet of heavy-armed troops. For the dat. in -essi cp. 976 xei/ressi. i(ppoko/mois, ‘with horse-hair crest’ (Il. 13.132 i(. ko/ruqes). For cu/n denoting what one wears or carries, cp. O. T. 207, O. C. 1258, Ai. 30 phdw=nta pedi/a cu\n neorra/ntw| ci/fei. There is no real difference here between meta/ and cu/n: Donaldson refines too much in suggesting that meta/ means merely ‘by their sides,’ while cu/n ‘denotes a closer union’ (i.e. ‘on their heads’).

In sta\s d' u(pe\r mela/qrwn there is a momentary return to the image of the flying eagle,—‘having stayed his flight above my dwellings,’—before swooping. The words do not mean that the Argive army was posted on hills around Thebes: the only hills available were to the N. of the town. The *)ismh/nios lo/fos (Paus. 9.10.2), on which Donaldson places the Argives, was merely a low eminence close to one of the city gates. Thebes stood on a low spur of ground projecting southward, and overlooking the plain. Sophocles has elsewhere described the Argive besiegers, with topographical correctness, as having ‘set their leaguer round the plain of Thebes’ (O. C. 1312 to\ *qh/bhs pedi/on a)mfesta=si pa=n). Struve's pta/s (a participle not found elsewhere except in composition with a preposition) seems improbable, and also less forcible.

The words fonw/saisin a)mfixanw\n... lo/gxais once more merge the image of the eagle,—as at v. 115,—in literal description of a besieging army, save in so far as the figurative a)mfixanw/n suggests a monster opening its jaws. The word was perh. suggested by Il. 23.79 e)me\ me\n kh\r | a)mfe/xane stugerh/ (hath gaped for me—i.e. ‘devoured me’). These transitions from clear imagery to language in which the figure is blurred by the thought of the object for which it stands, are thoroughly Sophoclean: cp. n. on O. T. 866.
fonw/saisin: the word is not rare in later writers, but in classical Greek occurs only here and Ph. 1209fona=|, fona=| no/os h)/dh. Cp. toma/w (Ai. 582).

e(pta/pulon sto/ma, prop. the access afforded by seven gates: fr. 701 *qh/bas le/geis moi ta\s pu/las e(ptasto/mous (sevenmouthed as to its gates). Nauck changes sto/ma to po/lism' to avoid hiatus: but cp. O. T. 1202 basileu\s kalei= | e)mo/s, n.
e)/ba, emphatic by place: cp. 46.

pri/n poq', ‘or ever,’ as Tr. 17.
ai(ma/twn, streams of blood, as Aesch. Ag. 1293 ai(ma/twn eu)qnhsi/mwn | a)porrue/ntwn (with ref. to one person). Soph. has the plur. only here: Aesch. and Eur. use it several times each, either in this sense, or as=‘deeds of bloodshed’ (once as=‘slain persons,’ ai(/mata su/ggona, Eur. Phoen. 1503).

ge(nusin might be locative dat., ‘in’; but seems rather instrumental, ‘with.’ After plhsqh=nai the missing short syllable is best supplied by te (Triclinius). The constr. is, pri\n (au)to/s) te plhsqh=nai, kai\ *(/hfaiston stefa/nwma pu/rgwn e(lei=n. For te irregularly placed, cp. O. T. 258 n.
stefa/nwma: Eur. Hec. 910 (of Troy) a)po\ de\ stefa/nan ke/karsai | pu/rgwn: cp. n. on O. C. 15.
peuka/enq' *(/hfaiston, the flame of pine-wood torches (Verg. Aen. 11. 786 pineus ardor). Cp. 1007, Il. 2.426. spla/gxna d' a)/r' a)mpei/rantes u(pei/rexon *(hfai/stoio.
toi=os, introducing the reason; O. C. 947 n.

e)ta/qh, lit. ‘was made intense,’ here suggesting both loud sound and keen strife. Cp. Il. 12.436 e)pi\ i)=sa ma/xh te/tato pto/lemo/s te: 23. 375 i(/ppoisi ta/qh dro/mos: Aesch. Pers. 574 tei=ne de\ dusba/u+kton | boa=tin ta/lainan au)da/n.

pa/tagos, clatter of arms (a word expressive of the sound), as distinguished from boh/, a human cry; cp. Her. 7.211 oi( de\ ba/rbaroi o(re/ontes feu/gontas boh=| te kai\ pata/gw| e)ph/i+san. The Argives began to retreat in the night: at dawn, the Thebans made a sally in pursuit of them, and turned the retreat into a rout.

a)ntipa/lw| dusxei/rwma dra/kontos, a thing hard to vanquish for him who was struggling against the (Theban) dragon, —i.e. for the Argive eagle. The two readings between which the MSS. fluctuate, viz., a)ntipa/lw| ... dra/konti and a)ntipa/lou … dra/kontos, arose, I feel sure, from a)ntipa/lw| … dra/kontos (V has a)ntipa/lw...dra/kontos). For the gen. after this adj., cp. Pind. O. 8. 94me/nos gh/raos a)nti/palon, a spirit that wrestles with old age: Eur. Alc. 922 u(menai/wn go/os a)nti/palos, wails contending with marriagesongs.
The interpretation of the passage turns primarily on two points.

(1) The dra/kwn certainly means the Thebans,—the spartoi/ (O. C. 1534) sprung from the dragon's teeth sown by Cadmus, and thence called drakontogenei=s (schol.), Ovid's anguigenae ( Met. 3. 531): cp. 1125 e)pi\ spora=| dra/kontos. Poetry often represented a struggle between an eagle and a dragon or snake (dra/kwn could mean either, the ‘dragon’ being conceived as a sort of huge python); as Il. 12.201, Od. 4.4. 11.

(2) The dus in dusxei/rwma must refer to difficulty experienced by the vanquished Argives, not by the victorious Thebans. The word must mean, then, ‘a thing hard to overcome,’ not, ‘a victory won with difficulty.’ So dusxei/rwtos is ‘hard to subdue’ (Her. 7.9), as a)xei/rwtos is ‘unsubdued’ (Thuc. 6.10), and eu)xei/rwtos ‘easy to subdue’ (Xen. Hellen. 5.3.4). Cp. duspa/laistos, duspa/lamos, du/smaxos, etc., used with poetical irony to express the irresistible. In O. T. 560 qana/simon xei/rwma is a deed of deadly violence: in Aesch. Th. 1022tumboxo/a xeirw/mata are works of the hand in mound-making. In itself, dusxei/rwma might mean ‘a thing achieved with difficulty’; but here the irony is clearly pointed against the routed Argives: the poet does not mean that the Thebans won with difficulty. Thus dusxei/rwma is here the opposite of what Aesch. calls eu)mare\s xei/rwma, a thing easily subdued: Aesch. Ag. 1326dou/lhs qanou/shs, eu)marou=s xeirw/matos. The Theban pa/tagos *)/areos was a thing which the Argives could not overcome.

Those who read a)ntipa/lw| … dra/konti explain either (a) ‘a hard-won victory for the dragon foe’: but this gives a wrong sense to dusxei/rwma: or (b) join the dat. with e\ta/qh: ‘a din was raised by the dragon foe (cp. Il. 22.55 *)axilh=i+ damasqei/s), a thing hard (for the Argive) to subdue.’ But dusxei/rwma, placed as it is, cannot be thus dissociated from the dat. a)ntip. dra/konti and mentally referred to another dat. which is left to be understood.

Those who read a)ntipa/lou … dra/kontos understand (a) a thing on the part of the dragon foe which was hard (for the Argive) to overcome; i.e. ‘an irresistible onset of the dragon foe.’ But such a construction of dusxei/rwma with the gen. seems impossible, esp. when there is no dat. to help it out. Or (b) ‘a hard-won victory of the dragon foe’; which gives a wrong sense to dusxei/rwma.—The form of the word is in one respect unique. Every similar neuter noun compounded with dus is from a verb so compounded: as duse/rghma, dushme/rhma, duspra/ghma, dusse/bhma, dustu/xhma, dusfh/mhma, dusxe/rasma, dusxrh/sthma, dusw/phma. But there is no such verb as dusxeiro/w, ‘to subdue with difficulty.’ The noun has been boldly coined to express dusxei/rwton pra=gma.
mega/lhs: 1350 mega/loi... lo/goi: Plat. Phaedo 95B mh\ me/ga le/ge: Verg. Aen. 10. 547 Dixerat ille aliquid magnum.

r(eu/mati: Aesch. Pers. 88 mega/lw| r(eu/mati fwtw=n (so ib. 412 r(eu=ma *persikou= stratou=). Eur. I. T. 1437 pau=sai diw/kwn r(eu=ma/ t' e)cormw=n stratou=. The transposition r(eu/mati pollw=| is unnecessary. In the same dipodia an anapaest must not precede a dactyl, nor a dactyl an anapaest; but a spondee can be followed by a dactyl, as O. C. 146 dhlw= d'. ou) ga\r a)\n w)=|d' a)llotri/ois.

xrusou= kanaxh=s u(peropli/ais, ‘in the haughty pride of clanging gold.’ u(peropli/ais seems a certain correction of u(peropti/as (see cr. n.), and has justly won its way with recent edd. The word is fitting, since u(peropli/a is prop. ‘overweening confidence in arms’; and Soph. has used the epic plur. with the epic i_, Il. 1.205 h(=|s u(peropli/h|si: so too Theocr. 25. 138 sqe/nei+ w(=| | h)d' u(peropli/h| *fae/qwn

me/gas. In post-Homeric poetry u(pe/roplos is a freq. epith. of overweening strength (h)nore/h, bi/h, h(/bh, etc.).—Other readings are:—(1) xrusou= kanaxh=| q' u(pero/ptas, ‘and haughty in the clang of gold.’ This involves an improbable change; the subst. u(pero/pths, too, is unsuitable here, and cannot be defended by Theocr. 22. 58 pro\s pa/nta pali/gkotos h)d' u(pero/pths. Wecklein, reading u(pero/ptas, keeps kanaxh=s in the sense, hoffärtig auf: but a genit. after u(pero/pths could not denote that in which one takes pride. (2) xrusou= kanaxh=s u(pero/pths, or -o/pta, i.e., ‘Zeus, a despiser of the clang of gold.’ (3) xrusou= kanaxh=s u(pe/ropta, adv. neut. plur. (as O. T. 883), ‘advancing haughtily in a great stream of clanging gold.’ But the adv. comes weakly at the end, and xrusou= k. is harshly joined with p. r(eu/mati.—Aesch. , too, gives prominence to gold in picturing the Argive chiefs: Capaneus has golden letters on his shield ( Aesch. Th. 434), Polyneices has the image of a warrior in golden armour, with a golden legend (644, Aesch. Th. 660).
kanaxh=s, of metal, as Il. 16.105 ph/lhc ballome/nh kanaxh\n e)/xe.
paltw=| puri/, i.e. with the thunderbolt which Zeus brandishes in his hand before hurling it: Aristoph. Av. 1714 pa/llwn kerauno/n, pterofo/ron *dio\s be/los.

balbi/dwn e)p' a)/krwn, at his topmost goal, i.e. at his goal on the top of our walls. a)/krwn might mean merely ‘uttermost,’ but is rather associated in the poet's mind with the object meant by balbi/dwn. In Eur. Phoen. 1180 Capaneus is struck by Zeus at the moment that he is surmounting the gei=sa teixe/wn, the coping of the walls. The balbi=des were the posts, to which a rope was attached, marking the point from which runners in the double foot-race (di/aulos) set out, and to which they returned: hence both starting-point and goal.

o(rmw=nta: for the partic. as subst., without either art. or tis, cp. El. 697 du/nait' a)\n ou)d' a)\n i)sxu/wn fugei=n: Plat. Gorg. 498A *k*a*l. ei)=don. *s*w. ti/ de/; nou=n e)/xonta lupou/menon kai\ xai/ronta; The name of Capaneus could be left unmentioned, since the story was so famous. No leader of the Argive host, except Polyneices, is named in this play. The attack of Capaneus was said to have been made at the *)/hlektrai pu/lai on the s. side of Thebes ( Aesch. Th. 423, Paus. 9.9.8). His fall from the scaling-ladder, as the lightning struck him, was often represented in art.
ni/khn, cogn. acc. with a)lala/cai, to raise the cry a)lalai/ for victory: Aristoph. Av. 1763 a)lalai/, i)h\ paih/wn, | th/nella kalli/nikos.

a)ntitu/pa|, restored by Porson (Aav. p. 169) for a)nti/tupa, is certainly right. Adjectives in os, compounded with a prep., are oft. of three terminations in epic poetry, as a)mfieli/ssh, a)mfiru/th, a)ntiqe/h (Od. 13.378), a)mfibro/th (Il. 2.389), u(podeci/h (Il. 9.73), etc. The dramatists could admit some such forms, esp. in lyrics; thus they have h( e)nali/a as well as h( e)na/lios, h( e)nnuxi/a as well as h( e)nnu/xios.

As regards the sense, a)nti/tupos was regularly used of hard surfaces, which, as it were, repel that which strikes them (for the accent a)nti/tupos, not a)ntitu/pos, though the sense is act., see on O. T. 460). Probl. 5. 40 oi(...e)n a)ntitu/pois peri/patoi. Lucian Amor. 13 th\n a)nti/tupon ou(/tw kai\ kartera\n tou= li/qou fu/sin. So, fig., Plat. Crat. 420D to\...a)nagkai=on kai\ a)nti/tupon, what is necessary, and what resists us.

tantalwqei/s, ‘swung,’ that is, sent flying through the air from the edge of the wall on which he was just setting foot. The word expresses the force with which the thunderbolt struck him, just as a)ntitu/pa| expresses the crash when he struck earth. This form of the verb occurs only here. Arist. uses both talanteu/omai (pass.) and talanteu/w (act. intr.) as ‘to sway to and fro.’ The Schol., explaining by diaseisqei/s (i.e. ‘with a rude shock,’ which is substantially right) quotes Anacreon 78 [e)n] melamfu/llw| da/fna| xlwra=| t' e)lai/a| tantali/zei (where the subject was perh. a god, or the wind).

purfo/ros, ‘torch in hand’: so of Prometheus (O. C. 55, where see n.) and Artemis (O. T. 207). Aesch. Th. 433fle/gei de\ lampa\s dia\ xerw=n w(plisme/nh: | xrusoi=s de\ fwnei= gra/mmasin, prh/sw po/lin.
bakxeu/wn: so oft. Eur. as H. F. 898 *lu/ssa bakxeu/sei: but this is the only place where Soph. connects evil frenzy with the name of a god whom this same Ode invokes (154).
r(ipai=s...a)ne/mwn. Capaneus, breathing fury and slaughter, is likened to a deadly tempest. For r(ipai/, ‘blasts,’ cp. 929 and O. C. 1248 n. So Aesch. Th. 63pri\n kataigi/sai pnoa\s | *)/arews.

ei)=xe d' a)/lla| ta\ me/n, ‘but those things indeed’ (the threats of Capaneus) ‘went otherwise’ (than he had expected): a)/lla d' e)p' a)/llois me/gas *)/arhs e)penw/ma, ‘while to others great Ares assigned various dooms,’ etc. The poet has described how Zeus smote the most formidable foe. As to the other Argive chiefs, he briefly adds that Ares struck them down by various deaths: i.e. they perished, not by a stroke from heaven, but in the course of battle. In L's reading, ei)=xe d' a)/llai ta\ me\n a)/llai ta\ d' e)p' a)/llois, one cause of corruption has evidently been a confusion between alternative modes of expressing ‘some’ and ‘other,’ viz. (1) by doubled a)/llos, (2) by ta\ me/n, ta\ de/. It is in favour of our reading (Erfurdt's) that it helps to account for this, since it supposes that ta\ me/n was answered by a)/lla de/. Cp. O. C. 1671 ou) to\ me/n, a)/llo de\ mh/: Il. 6.147 ta\ me/n t' a)/nemos xama/dis xe/ei, a)/lla de/ q' u(/lh | thleqo/wsa fu/ei. It is immaterial that, here, ta\ me/n means, not, ‘some things,’ but, ‘those things’; since the latter is its first sense also where we render it by ‘some.’ Further, with regard to a)/lla|, remark that this form of adverb is used elsewhere also in ref. to the course ordained by gods or fate: O. C. 1443tau=ta d' e)n tw=| dai/moni, | kai\ th=|de fu=nai xa(te/ra|: Aesch. PV 511 ou) tau=ta tau/th| moi=ra/ pw telesfo/ros | kra=nai pe/prwtai. For other proposed readings, see Appendix.

e)penw/ma: Aesch. Eum. 310 la/xh ta\ kat' a)nqrw/pous | w(s e)pinwma=| sta/sis a(ma/, apportions.— stufeli/zwn (stu^felo/s, ‘firm,’ stu_/fw, to compress), ‘striking heavily’: Il. 1.581 e)c e(de/wn stufeli/cai.

decio/seiros, ‘right-hand trace-horse,’ here means a vigorous ally, who does more than his own share of the work. Ares has brought the Theban chariot victoriously through the crisis of the race against its Argive rival. In the fourhorse chariot-race the four horses were harnessed abreast: the two in the middle were under the yoke (zu/gioi), being called o( me/sos decio/s and o( me/sos a)ristero/s (schol. Aristoph. Nub. 122): the two outside horses drew in traces (seirai=oi). The chariot went down the right-hand side of the course, turned sharply from right to left at the distance-post (kampth/r, nu/ssa), and came back down the left side. Hence, at the turning-point, the right-hand tracehorse had most work to do; and the best horse was put in that place. Cp. El. 721 (at the turning-post) decio/n t' a)nei\s | seirai=on i(/ppon ei)=rge to
 proskei/menon. Plat. Symp. 4. 6a(rmathlatou=nta dei= e)ggu\s me
 th=s sth/lhs ka/myai, quoting from Il. 23.336 the precept to
 decio
 i(/ppon | ke/nsai o(moklh/sant', ei)=cai/ te/ oi( h(ni/a xersi/n. Cp. Aesch. Ag. 842 zeuxqei\s e(/toimos h)=n e)moi\ seirafo/ros (said by Agam. of Odysseus): and cp. ib. 1640.

The old v.l. decio/xeiros, explained by the schol. gennai=os kai\ parade/cios, is read by Musgrave, Hartung, and Pallis. Hartung A. renders it ‘der Starke,’—understanding it as ‘the strong and deft striker.’ Neither decio/xeiros nor decio/xeir seems to occur, though a)ristero/xeir (left-handed) is found in late Greek.

e(pta\ loxagoi/. In O. C. 1313 ff. the list agrees with that of Aesch. ,— Amphiaraus, Tydeus, Eteoclus, Hippomedon, Capaneus, Parthenopaeus, Polyneices. (Adrastus, who escaped, is not counted as one of the seven.) Capaneus, though not slain by human hand, is included, since he was vanquished. Amphiaraus, according to the legend which Soph. recognises in El. 837, was swallowed up by the earth, but seems here to be reckoned among those who fell in fight (cp. n. on O. C. 1313).

i)/soi pro\s i)/sous, instead of saying simply pro\s e(pta/,—a common idiom: Eur. Phoen. 750 i)/sous i)/soisi polemi/oisin a)ntiqei/s: Her. 1.2 i)/sa pro\s i)/sa: 9. 48 i)/soi pro\s i)/sous: Plat. Legg. 774C i)/sa a)nti\ i)/swn.

*zhni\ tropai/w|, to Zeus who makes a troph/, or rout, of enemies. Eur. El. 671 w)= *zeu= patrw=|e kai\ tropai=' e)xqrw=n e)mw=n. So he is invoked after a victory, Her. 867.(In Tr. 303 w)= *zeu= tropai=e is usu. taken as=a)potro/paie, ‘averting.’) In his relation to war, Zeus was worshipped also as *)agh/twr (esp. at Sparta), *)/areios (at Olympia, etc.), *stra/tios, *xrusa/wr (in Caria), *sth/sios or *)epista/sios (the Roman stator, stayer of flight).

pa/gxalka te/lh, ‘tributes of panoplies,’ as Tr. 238 Heracles dedicates bwmou\s te/lh t' e)/gkarpa *khnai/w| *dii/+, i.e. ‘dues of fruits,’—alluding to the te/menos of which the produce was given to the god (ib. 754). Not, (1) ‘complete suits of armour’: nor (2) o(plitika\ ta/gmata, ‘troops of warriors,’ as Eustath. took it (p. 686. 16), led perh. by Aesch. Pers. 47 di/rruma/ te kai\ tri/rruma te/lh.

It was the ordinary practice to set up a tro/paion (old Att.tropai=on) after a victory, on the spot where it had been won, or, in the case of a sea-fight, on the nearest land (Thuc. 2.92). Such a trophy ordinarily consisted of shields, helmets, and weapons, conspicuously displayed on wooden supports, and dedicated, with an inscription, to a deity. Cp. Eur. Phoen. 1473 (of the Thebans after the victory) oi( me\n *dio\s tropai=on i(/stasan bre/tas (i.e. a wooden image of *zeu\s *tropai=os), | oi( d' a)spi/das sulw=ntes *)argei/wn nekrw=n | skuleu/mat' ei)/sw teixe/wn e)pe/mpomen. Part of the armour would be affixed to the walls of Theban temples (cp. Aesch. Ag. 577, Th. 276).

plh\n t. stugeroi=n, ‘wretched’ (as Ph. 166): not, ‘hateful,’ nor, ‘filled with hate.’ Of the seven Argive leaders, Polyneices was the only one who could not properly be said to have been vanquished, since he was not more vanquished than victorious. But, in excepting him, the poet associates him with the brother who was his victim as well as his conqueror. Thus e(pta\...e)/lipon..., plh\n toi=n stugeroi=n, is a lax way of saying, ‘defeat befell each of the seven Argive leaders, except in the case of the two brothers,’—in which an Argive leader and a Theban leader slew each other.— patro/s, etc., gen. of origin (38).
kaq' au(toi=n = kat' a)llh/loin. Cp. Dem. or. 40 § 29 w(=n a)\n e)n au(toi=s dienexqw=si gunh\ kai\ a)nh/r. Plat. Prot. 347D le/gonta/s te kai\ a)kou/ontas e)n me/rei e(autw=n.

dikratei=s lo/gxas, two spears, each of which was victorious over the wielder of the other. So Ai. 251 dikratei=s *)atrei=dai, two Atreidae, each of whom is a king. That is, dikratei=s is equiv. to two distinct epithets (du/o and kratou=sai): cp. O. C. 1055 disto/lous...a)delfa/s, two journeying sisters: ib. 17 pukno/pteroi = many, and feathered (n.): see O.T. 846 n.
sth/sante, having set in position, levelled, against each other. The Homeric do/ru was chiefly a missile; here the lo/gxh is used for thrusting.

a)lla\ ga/r, like a)ll' ou) ga/r (O.C. 988 n.), can be used with or without an ellipse. Here there is no ellipse, since e)pe/lqwmen follows (153), and ga/r, introducing the reason given by h)=lqe,= ‘since.’ Below, 155, there is an ellipse, —‘But (let us cease), for Creon comes’; where ga/r might be rendered ‘indeed.’
megalw/numos: schol. h( mega/lhn peripoiou=sa do/can: the personified Nikè is ‘of great name,’ because victory is glorious.

poluarma/tw| implies warlike renown, as well as wealth and splendour (cp. 845). Already in Il. 4.391 the Cadmeans are ‘urgers of horses’ (ke/ntores i(/ppwn): so Scut. Herc. 24 *boiwtoi\ plh/cippoi: Pindar Ol. 6. 85 has pla/cippon...*qh/ban, Isthm. 7. 20filarma/tou po/lios (as elsewhere xrusa/rmatos, eu)a/rmatos). Critias , speaking of the inventions for which various cities were famous, says (fr. 1. 10) *qh/bh d' a(rmato/enta di/fron suneph/cato prw/th.

a)ntixarei=sa, with gladness responsive to that of Thebè. The goddess Nikè has come to meet the victors, and their joy is reflected in her radiant smile. (We can imagine her descending towards them from the sky, like the winged Nikè of Paeonius found at Olympia.) The doubts which have been felt as to a)ntixarei=sa disappear if it is observed that xarei=sa here refers to the outward manifestation of joy, not merely to the feeling in the mind. Thus a)nti/ expresses the answer of smile to smile, as in a)ntila/mpw of light to light, or in a)ntifqe/ggomai of sound to sound. I do not take a)nti/ here to mean merely ‘over against,’ as when Pind. Ol. 3.19 says h)/dh ga\r au)tw=|... | ...o)fqalmo\n a)nte/flece *mh/na, the (mid-month) moon showed the light of her eye over against him. —Not (1) i)/son au)th=| xarei=sa (schol.), i.e. merely, ‘rejoicing as Thebes does,’ which extenuates a)ntixarei=sa into sugxarei=sa. Nor (2) a)nti\ tw=n kakw=n xarei=sa, i.e. rejoicing in requital of past troubles.

e)k...pole/mwn tw=n nu=n, ‘after the recent wars.’ For e)k, cp. Ph. 271 e)k pollou= sa/lou | eu(/dont', sleeping, after long tossing on the sea. For nu=n referring to the recent past (=‘just now’), cp. Dem. or. 18 § 13 h(li/ka nu=n e)tragw/|dei kai\ diech/|ei: Xen. Anab. 7.1.26 a)namnhsqe/ntas ta\ nu=n h)/dh gegenhme/na (i.e. the events of the Peloponnesian war, which had ended four years before).

qe/sqai (L), as infin. for imperative (O. C. 481 n.), has a certain solemnity which seems to make it better here than qe/sqe, though the latter is not excluded by e)pe/lqwmen. The last syll. of qe(sqai answers to the second of e)xqi/stwn in 137; each is an ‘irrational’ syllable (- for ˘): see qew=n, monosyll. by synizesis (O. C. 964 n.).— pannuxi/ois, since a pannuxi/s was esp. grateful to the city's tutelar god Dionysus (1147), whose rites are nu/ktwr ta\ polla/ (Eur. Bacch. 486).
o( *qh/bas (gen. sing.) e)leli/xqwn, = o( th\n *qh/bhs xqo/na e)leli/zwn, shaking the ground of Thebes (with his dances): for the objective gen., cp. O. C. 333 lo/gwn au)ta/ggelos.
*ba/kxios = *ba/kxos, as Eur. Bacch. 225 th\n d' *)afrodi/thn pro/sq' a)/gein tou= *bakxi/ou, and oft.
a)/rxoi sc. th=s xorei/as (schol.). Cp. 1146.
a)lla\ … ga/r: see on 148.— *kre/wn, monosyll. by synizesis, as ple/wn Od. 1.183; in Aesch. Ag. 1493 e)kpne/wn is a spondee. Cp. O. C. 1073 *(pe/as, a monosyll.
*menoike/ws,=˘¯¯, as O. C. 1003 *qhse/ws (¯¯), and so oft.

neoxmo\s nearai=si. Neither adj. is suspicious; new events have made a new ruler; and the doubled adj. is quite in the poet's manner. Cp. 1266 ne/os ne/w| cu\n mo/rw|: Ai. 735 ne/as | boula\s ne/oisin e)gkatazeu/cas tro/pois: O. C. 475 oi)o\s...neara=s neopo/kw| mallw=|: ib. 1259 ge/rwn ge/ronti sugkatw/|khken pi/nos: Tr. 613 kainw=| kaino\n e)n peplw/mati, etc. Though nearo/s usu.= ‘young,’ it occurs also in the sense of ‘novel,’ as in Pindar's neara\ e)ceurei=n (N. 8. 20). Three views of the metre have been taken. (1) That v. 156 should be enlarged to a dimeter by supplying one anapaest or its equivalent. (2) That v. 156 should be reduced to a monometer by omitting neoxmo/s or *menoike/ws. (3) That both v. 156 and v. 160 should be made dimeters by supplying three anapaests or

their equivalents. See Appendix I prefer the first of these views. An anapaest or spondee, meaning ‘ruler,’ has probably dropped out before neoxmo/s. Seyffert's krei/wn is at first sight attractive, as accounting for its own disappearance; but, since it is the same word as *kre/wn— which had an epic form *krei/wn, as conversely Pind. and Aesch. use kre/wn—this would be rather a feeble pun than a strong parh/xhsis. Either a)/rxwn or tago/s is possible.

qew=n … suntuxi/ais, fortunes sent by the gods,—the possessive gen. denoting the authors, just as it can denote the parents: cp. Ph. 1116po/tmos...daimo/nwn: Aeol. fr. 37 ta\s de\ daimo/nwn tu/xas | o(/stis fe/rei ka/llist', a)nh\r ou(=tos sofo/s. (In O. T. 34 daimo/nwn sunallagai=s is different.) e)pi\ suntuxi/ais means that the fortunes are the conditions which have made Creon king: this e)pi/ with dat. of attendant circumstance sometimes=our ‘in,’ as O. C. 1268 e)p' e)/rgois pa=si (n.), sometimes ‘for,’ as Aristoph. Eq. 406 pi=n' e)pi\ sumforai=s (i.e. to celebrate them), cp. El. 1230: here we could say, ‘under the new dispensations of the gods.’ (Distinguish 88 e)pi\ yuxroi=si as =‘for’ in the sense ‘with a view to.’)

mh=tin e)re/sswn, consilium animo volutans, ‘turning it over’ busily in the mind. e)re/ssein, to ply the oar, is fig. said of putting a thing in lively motion, as Eur. I. A. 139 e)re/sswn so\n po/da. Then also of activity in speech, as Ai. 251 e)re/ssousin a)peila/s, ‘they ply threats’ (utter them repeatedly and loudly): or, as here, in thought. Cp. 231.—(Not, ‘speeding his counsel hitherward,’ i.e. coming to disclose it: ‘advolvens, i.e. patefacturus,’ Ellendt.)

su/gklhton, specially convoked;—implying that there were other and regularly appointed seasons at which the king met the ge/rontes in council. At Athens four meetings of the e)kklhsi/a were regularly held in each prutanei/a (a period of 35 or 36 days): these were kuri/ai (though the term may once have been restricted to the first of them), or no/mimoi. An extraordinary meeting was su/gklhtos or kata/klhtos. Pollux 8. 116 su/gklhtos e)kklhsi/a h(\n e)cai/fnhs e)poi/oun mei/zonos xrei/as e)pilabou/shs: e)kalei=to de\ kai\ kataklhsi/a, o(/ti kai\ tou\s e)k tw=n a)grw=n kateka/loun (down to the a)/stu). Arist. Pol. 3.1. 10 e)ni/ais ga\r ou)k e)/sti dh=mos, ou)d' e)kklhsi/an nomi/zousin a)lla\ sugklh/tous: ‘in some States there is no popular body, and they have no regular assembly, but only meetings on special occasions.’ su/gklhtos is one of those words which, though a technical term at Athens, could still be used by Attic poets without any prosaic local allusion being felt,— just as they used pru/tanis, e)pista/ths, a)/rxwn, yh/fisma, etc.

prou)/qeto is another example. The presidents of the ecclesia were said gnw/mas proqei=nai when they invited a discussion. Thuc. 6.14 w)= pru/tani ... gnw/mas proti/qei au)=qis *)aqhnai/ois, ‘lay the question again before the assembly.’ Id. 3. 42 tou\s proqe/ntas th\n diagnw/mhn. Cp. Xen. Mem. 4.2.3 th=s po/lews lo/gon peri/ tinos protiqei/shs. Lucian Menipp. 19 has prou)/qesan oi( pruta/neis e)kklhsi/an, ‘gave notice of’: but for this the usual phrase was that of Aeschin. or. 2 § 60 progra/yai tou\s pruta/neis e)kklhsi/as du/o. Here, le/sxhn is

not the meeting, but the discussion which is to take place there: thus the poet's phrase, true to Attic usage, corresponds with gnw/mas proqei=nai rather than with e)kklhsi/an proqei=nai. Herod. uses le/sxh of a public discussion (9. 71): cp. O. C. 167. The midd. prou)/qeto suggests Creon's personal interest in the question: the active would denote the mere act (see on 8 qei=nai). Cp. 1249. proti/qesqai more oft. denotes what one proposes to oneself.

koinw=| k. pe/myas, lit. having sent (notice of the meeting) by means of a summons addressed to each of us. The kh/rugma is the mandate which kh/rukes carried to each of the fifteen elders,—not, of course, a public proclamation: cp. 164. For the absolute pe/mpw, cp. Thuc. 5.43 pe/mpei eu)qu\s e)s *)/argos i)di/a|: and so oft. (Not, ‘having sent for us,’ metapemya/menos: cp. on 19.)

div2.p: First e)peiso/dion. Creon, the new king, enters from the central door of the palace. Recognising the loyalty which the elders had shown to his predecessors, he expresses his own conception of the duty which a king owes to the State. He then announces the edict which, in accordance with that conception, he has published concerning the two brothers. The Chorus submissively acknowledge his right to do so, but express no approval. A guard now arrives (223), and announces that the king's edict has already been violated by an unknown hand, which has strewn dust upon the corpse of Polyneices. Creon dismisses him with threats of a dreadful death for him and for his fellows, if they fail to discover and produce the offender.

div3.p: There is a general dramatic analogy between this speech and that of Oedipus in O. T. 216—275. In each case a Theban king addresses Theban elders, announcing a stern decree, adopted in reliance on his own wisdom, and promulgated with haughty consciousness of power; the elders receive the decree with a submissive deference under which we can perceive traces of misgiving; and as the drama proceeds, the elders become spectators of calamities occasioned by the decree, while its author turns to them for comfort.
ta\ me\n dh\ po/leos . . u(ma=s d'. The perils of the war are now over; the affairs of civil government claim my next care; and I have therefore sent for you, the nearest supporters of my throne.

po/leos occurs only here in Soph. , but twice in the trimeters of Aesch. ( Aesch. Th. 218, Suppl. 344), and thrice in those of Eur. ( Eur. Or. 897, El. 412, Ion 595). Eur. has also in trimeters o)/feos ( Eur. Bacch. 1027, Eur. Bacch. 1331, Suppl. 703), and ko/neos ( Cycl. 641). In Comedy we find u(/breos ( Ar. Th. 465, Plut. 1044), and fu/seos (Vesp. 1282, 1458). Such forms, which metrical convenience recommended to Attic poets, must not be confounded with the Ionic genitives in i, such as po/lios. The gen. po/leus, contracted from po/leos, is used by Theogn. 776 etc.— pollw=| sa/lw| sei/santes. Cp. O. T. 22.

The image of the State as a ship dates in Greek literature from Alcaeus (whom Horace copied, Carm. 1. 14), fr. 18. The ship of Alcaeus is labouring in the trough of a wild sea,—water is coming in,—the sail is torn,—the anchor will not hold: na=i+ forh/meqa su\n melai/na| | xei/mwni moxqeu=ntes mega/lw| ma/la, k.t.l. It is only through Heracleides Alleg. Homer. 5 that we know the meaning of Alcaeus to have been figurative and political. Aesch. often uses the image ( Aesch. Th. 2, Aesch. Th. 62, Aesch. Th. 208 etc.). Creon returns to it at 189. It is peculiarly well suited to his point,—the unity of the public interest.
w)/rqwsan, made upright, ‘righted’: but below 167, w)/rqou=was keeping straight: cp. on 83.

e)k pa/ntwn, (chosen) out of all, di/xa adv. (with i(ke/sqai) apart from them: cp. 656 po/lews . . e)k pa/shs mo/nhn, 1137 ta\n e)k pasa=n tima=|s: El. 1351 o(/n pot' e)k pollw=n e)gw\ | mo/non proshu=ron pisto/n. In other places, where di/xa is prep. with gen., we find it similarly connected with another expression of like purport, as Ai. 749 e)k...ku/klou | . . metasta\s oi(=os *)atreidw=n di/xa.

e)/steil' i(ke/sqai: lit., by means of messengers I caused you to set forth, so that you should come (epexeg. inf.): Ph. 60oi(/ s' e)n litai=s stei/lantes e)c oi)/kwn molei=n. But ste/llesqai (midd.) ‘to summon to oneself’ (O. T. 434): cp. n. O. T. 860.— tou=to me/n, answered by tou=t' au)=qis: see 61 n.
se/bontas, like me/nontas (169), part. of the imperf.,=o(/ti e)se/bete: so 1192: O. T. 835 tou= paro/ntos (n.): and cp. on O. C. 1565 f.
qro/nwn . . kra/th, powers belonging to the throne: cp. 60, 173.

h(ni/k' *oi)di/pous k.t.l. The only obscurity arises from the use of the plur. kei/nwn in 168. kei/nwn pai=das ought to mean, ‘the descendants of Laïus and Oedipus,’ viz. Eteocles and Polyneices. But, as the sentence stands, it must mean, ‘the offspring of Laïus and of Oedipus respectively’; viz. Oedipus, the son of Laïus; Eteocles and Polyneices, the sons of Oedipus. The relative clause, h(ni/k' . . w)/rqou po/lin, induced the poet to add immediately the other relative clause to which the same person is subject, viz. e)pei\ diw/leto, instead of inserting, after w)/rqou po/lin, words expressing their loyalty to Oedipus. We might, indeed, suppose that, after w)/rqou po/lin, we were intended to supply mentally, kai\ ta\ e)kei/nou qro/nwn kra/th se/bontas. But against this is the fact that, after tou=to me/n . . tou=t' au)=qis,—‘in the first place’ . . ‘in the second place,’
kai/ (in ka)pei\) would scarcely have been thus used to introduce a distinct third clause. Evidently kai/ links h(ni/ka w)/rqou to e)pei\ diw/leto.

e)mpe/dois fronh/masin, with steadfast sentiments (of loyalty), modal dat., as oft. proqumi/a|, eu)noi/a|, fronh/mati (Thuc. 2.62), etc. Hartung, whom some recent editors follow, adopts e)mpe/dous on the strange ground that Soph. must otherwise have written e)mme/nontas. But me/nontas a)mfi\ tou\s kei/nwn pai=das=‘remaining around them,’ and the modal dat. is added no less legitimately than the causal dat. in Eur. Her. 701 deili/a| me/nein, ‘to remain through cowardice.’ Soph. could have said e)mpe/dous fronh/masin, as he has said suntro/fois | o)rgai=s e)/mpedos (Ai. 639): but e)mpe/dois is better here, both (a) because a series of accusatives has preceded, and (b) because, as me/nontas has already marked their constancy, we now want an epithet for their fronh/mata.
o(/te causal, O. T. 918 n.
pro\s diplh=s m.: cp. 14 n.: for pro\s, 51 n.: for diplh=s . . mi/an, 13 n.

pai/santes . . plhge/ntes. In Attic prose the verb ‘to strike’ usu. had as pres. tu/ptw (or pai/w), fut. tupth/sw (or pata/cw), aor. e)pa/taca, aor. pass. e)plh/ghn. The aor. of pai/w is mainly a poetical word, used in tragedy, more rarely in comedy, and by Xenophon. In Attic prose e)/paisa is usu. the aor. of pai/zw. Meineke proposed plh/cantes here, but that aor. (except in comp. with a prep.) is almost unknown to classical Attic. paisqe/ntes, again, though that aor. pass. occurs twice in Aesch. , is very rare.

au)to/xeiri … mia/smati, the stain of a kinsman's murder (see on 51, and cp. 1176): cp. Aesch. Th. 849kaka\ | au)tofo/na. su/n, as 1266 ne/w| cu
 mo/rw|: O. C. 1663, su
 no/sois: Pind. O. 2. 42su
 a)llalofoni/a|.
e)gw\ . . dh/, I now: where dh/ nearly=h)/dh, O. T. 968 n. Aesch. Eum. 3 (after Gaia came Themis) h(\ dh\ to\ mhtro\s deute/ra to/d' e(/zeto | mantei=on.
kra/th: cp. 166.

ge/nous kat' a)gxistei=a tw=n o)l., by nearness of kinship to the dead, ge/nous a)gxistei=a forming one notion, on which the genit. tw=n o)l. depends, as on words meaning ‘near.’ The neut. plur. a)gxistei=a (only here) would most properly mean ‘rights’ or ‘privileges’ of such nearness (cp. a)ristei=a, prwtei=a, etc.), but seems here to be merely a poetical equiv. for the abstract a)gxistei/a. In Attic law a)gxistei/a was any degree of relationship on which a claim to an inheritance could be founded in the absence of a will otherwise disposing of it. To claim an inheritance under a will was a)mfisbhtei=n kata\ diaqh/khn: to claim on the ground of relationship, a)mfisbhtei=n kat' a)gxistei/an. sugge/neia, consanguinity, might, or might not, constitute a)gxistei/a: e.g. Isaeus says of the relationship of mother to son that it is suggene/staton me\n th=| fu/sei pa/ntwn, e)n de\ tai=s a)gxistei/ais o(mologoume/nws ou)k e)/stin (or. 11 § 17), since a mother could not inherit from her son. (See Selections from the Attic Orators, pp. 331, 344.) Creon succeeds as the nearest male relative. Aesch. , Soph. , and Eur. ignore the Boeotian legend which gave a son, Laodamas, to Eteocles (Her. 5.61), and a son, Thersander, to Polyneices (id. 4. 147, etc.). The sisters represent the e)sxa/th r(i/za (599).

a)mh/xanon de/. ‘You were loyal to the kings whose successor I am. Now (de/) a man cannot be really known until he has been tried in office. (I do not, therefore, ask you to pledge your loyalty to me until I have been so tested.) I will, however, tell you the principles which I intend to observe.’ Thus de/ merely marks the transition to a new topic.
