It is not directly adversative, as if he meant: ‘You were loyal to my predecessors, but I do not yet ask you to be loyal to me.’ On that view, however, the general connection of thoughts would remain the same.
Demosthenes, in his speech on the Embassy (343 B.C.), quotes this passage (vv. 175—190) as illustrating maxims
which Aeschines had violated, though, accustomed as he had been to play tritagonists' parts, he ought to have known them by heart (or. 19 § 247).

yuxh/n, ‘soul,’ the man's moral nature generally: fro/nhma, the ‘spirit’ of his dealing in public affairs, according as his aims are lofty or mean, his policy bold or timid (cp. 207 toio/nd' e)mo
 fro/nhma): gnw/mhn, the intellectual aspect of the man, his ability and judgment. In Her. 5.124 yuxh
 ou)k a)/kros, 3. 14 diepeira=to au)tou= th=s yuxh=s, the word=‘fortitude.’ But the usage of Soph. favours the more general sense here: cp. 227, 929, Ai. 1361 sklhra
...yuxh/n, El. 219 sa=| dusqu/mw| ti/ktous' ai)ei\ | yuxa=| pole/mous. Plato has the phrase th=s yuxh=s th
 gnw/mhn for ‘the intellect’ (Legg. 672 B).

a)rxai=s, duties of administration. It might be explained as a generic plur. of a)rxh/, in the sense of ‘sovereignties,’ as Isocr. or. 3 § 15 ai( monarxi/ai, § 16 ta\s turanni/das, etc.: but it seems truer to say that the Athenian poet was thinking of public offices or magistracies. no/moisin has a general sense: the king is concerned with no/moi both as nomofu/lac and as nomoqe/ths: but, as the context suggests, it is of law-giving that Creon is more particularly thinking. Tournier has suggested a)rxh=| te kai\ qro/noisin, but we must recollect how largely the language of Attic tragedy is tinged with democratic associations.
e)ntribh/s, exercitatus: Plat. Legg. 769B e)ntribh/s ge ou)damw=s ge/goia th=| toiau/th| te/xnh|.

fanh=| ‘be found,’ without w)/n, as Pind. P. 5. 107pe/fantai/ q' a(rmathla/tas sofo/s: Thuc. 1.8 *ka=res e)fa/nhsan (were found to be). Not: ‘be revealed, by being conversant.’ Cp. Arist. Eth. Nic. 5.3 polloi\ ga\r e)n me\n toi=s oi)kei/ois th=| a)reth=| du/nantai xrh=sqai, e)n de\ toi=s pro\s e(/teron a)dunatou=sin. kai\ dia\ tou=to eu)= dokei= e)/xein to\ tou= *bi/antos, o(/ti a)rxh\ a)/ndra dei/cei: pro\s e(/teron ga\r kai\ e)n koinwni/a| h)/dh o( a)/rxwn. Besides Bias of Priene, others of the e(pta\ sofistai/,—as Chilon, Pittacus, Solon,—had this saying ascribed to them. Plut. Sull. 30(Sulla ) ei)ko/tws prosetri/yato tai=s mega/lais e)cousi/ais diabolh\n w(s ta\ h)/qh me/nein ou)k e)w/sais e)pi\ tw=n e)c a)rxh=s tro/pwn (as not allowing characters to be constant under the influence of habits formed in office), a)ll' e)/mplhkta kai\ xau=na kai\ a)pa/nqrwpa poiou/sais. Shaksp. Jul. Caes. ii. 1. 12 He would be crown'd:— How that might change his nature, there's the question....The abuse of greatness is, when it disjoins | Remorse from power.

e)moi\ ga/r. A ground for the preceding statement is introduced by ga/r, though the compression of the thought slightly obscures the connection. ‘A man cannot be known until he has been tested in power. For (ga\r) a man in power may easily be deterred, by fear of unpopularity, from pursuing the counsels best for the State: and if he is so deterred, I think him worthless.’ pa=san … po/lin, the whole city, as 656 po/lews ... e)k pa/shs, 776 pa=sa...po/lis, Ai. 851 e)n pa/sh| po/lei (in the hearing of all the city). In prose the art. would have been added (cp. Thuc. 7.29 th=| po/lei pa/sh|, 4. 87 cumpa/sh| th=| po/lei, 2. 65 h( cu/mpasa po/lis); but its omission in poetry being so common, it is strange that pa=san should have been suspected here.

mh\ … a(/ptetai, not ou), since the relative clause is general (‘such an one as does not...,’ Lat. qui with subjunct.): cp. O. C. 1175 a(\ mh\ | xrh/|zeis. Instead of o(/stis mh\ a(/ptetai we should more often find o(/stis a(\n mh\ a(/pthtai: yet the instances of the indic. after o(/stis in general statement are not rare even in prose; cp. Thuc. 2.64 oi(/tines...h(/kista lupou=ntai, e)/rgw| de\ ma/lista a)nte/xousin: ib. o(/stis lamba/nei.
e)k f. tou: cp. 111 neike/wn e)c a)mfilo/gwn.
e)gklh/|sas e)/xei (cp. 22),=a perf., in the sense ‘has shut once for all,’ ‘keeps shut.’ Distinguish the prose idiom, Dem. or. 9 § 12 *fera\s...e)/xei katalabw/n, has seized, and keeps.

nu=n te kai\ pa/lai, an emphatic formula (‘seems, and has always seemed’), El. 676, Ph. 966: cp. El. 1049 pa/lai de/doktai tau=ta kou) newsti/ moi: Il. 9.105 oi(=on e)gw\ noe/w, h)me\n pa/lai h)d' e)/ti kai\ nu=n.

mei/zon': whoever recognises a friend more important than his country, —i.e. with stronger claims upon him: a)nti\ th=s...pa/tras instead of the simple gen., or h)/ with accus., as Tr. 576 w(/ste mh/tin' ei)sidw
 | ste/rcei gunai=ka kei=nos a)nti\ sou= ple/on. Cp. 638 (ga/mos) mei/zwn fe/resqai, more important to win: O. T. 772 tw=| ga a)
 kai\ mei/zoni | le/caim' a)
 h)\ soi/..., ‘to whom more important,’ i.e. with a better claim on my confidence,— nearer and dearer. mei=zon (which was written by the first hand in L) is specious, —‘a more important thing,’ a greater good: cp. Eur. Or. 784 me/ga ga hu(ge/neia/ sou, Andr. 209h( *la/kaina me
 po/lis | me/g' e)sti/. But Demosthenes, at least, seems to have read mei/zon': for, in applying the verses to Aeschines, he paraphrases thus (or. 19 § 248): tou/twn ou)de
 *ai)sxi/nhs ei)=pe pro\s au(to
 e)n th=| presbei/a|, a)ll' a)nti\ me
 th=s po/lews th
 *fili/ppou ceni/an kai\ fili/an pollw=| mei/zona h(gh/sato au(tw=| kai\ lusiteleste/ran, e)rrw=sqai polla\ fra/sas tw=| sofw=| *sofoklei=.

ou)damou= le/gw: Aesch. Pers. 497 qeou\s de/ tis | to\ pri\n nomi/zwn ou)damou=, to/t' hu)/xeto. Eur. Andr. 210 *sku=ron ou)damou= ti/qhs (nullo in numero habes). Xen. Mem. 1.2.52 w(/ste mhdamou= par' au)toi=s tou\s a)/llous ei)=nai pro\s au)to/n, ‘so that the rest were nowhere with them in comparison to him.’ So ou)deno\s lo/gou (or e)n ou)deni\ lo/gw|) poiei=sqai, e)n ou)demia=| moi/ra| a)/gein, etc.

e)gw\ ga/r. Here, as in e)moi\ ga/r above (178), ga/r introduces a reason; but here, again, the connection is obscured by the form of the sentence. The reason is contained in tou=to gignw/skwn k.t.l. (188). ‘I have no esteem for a man who prefers popularity or private friendship to the good of the State (178— 183); for (184) I well know that all private welfare depends on the welfare of the State; and so I should never commit the faults which I have just condemned in others.’—i)/stw is confirmed against the conjecture i)/stwr (or i(/stwr) by those passages in which it is joined with an accus., as Il. 7.411 o(/rkia de\ *zeu\s i)/stw, 15. 36 i)/stw nu=n tode *gai=a, etc.

ou)/t' a)\n siwph/saimi. Applied to the actual case, Creon's words mean, ‘I should never be deterred by fear of popular murmurs (cp. 692 ff.) from publishing such an edict as this against burying Polyneices, when I clearly saw that otherwise a disastrous precedent would be set. And though Polyneices was my nephew, I should never allow myself to recognise as friend or kinsman a man who had borne arms against the country.’

stei/xousan a)stoi=s. Demosthenes paraphrases this by stei/xousan o(mou= (or. 19 § 248); whence Dobree and Shilleto surmised that he read a)=sson (cp. O. C. 312 stei/xousan h(mw=n a)=sson). Now I think that I can explain why Demosthenes so paraphrased. He is applying the verses to Aeschines (see above, n. on 182): th\n de\ a)/thn o(rw=n stei/xousan o(mou=, th\n e)pi\ *fwke/as stratei/an, ou) proei=pen ou)de\ proech/ggeilen. The a)/th which Aeschines saw approaching was the interference of Philip in the Sacred War,—his action against the Phocians. If Demosthenes had said stei/xousan a)stoi=s, this must have seemed to refer to the fellow-citizens of Aeschines, —the Athenians. The orator therefore modified the poet's phrase by substituting o(mou=,—a word vague enough to suggest the concern of other Greek states besides Phocis in the peril.

a)nti\ th=s swthri/as, added for emphasis; ‘ruin, and not welfare, which a king is bound to promote.’ (The art. th=s is merely generic, as in th\n a)/thn.) So Tr. 267 fanei\s de\ dou=los a)ndro\s a)nt' e)leuqe/rou, a slave, and not a free man (as he ought to be): O. T. 1490 keklaume/nai | pro\s oi)=kon i(/cesq' a)nti\ th=s qewri/as.

a)/ndra dusmenh= xqono/s; cp. Plat. Lysis 213 B to\ fi/lon a)\n ei)/h fi/lon tou= filoume/nou...to\ misou=n a)/ra pa/lin e)xqro\n tou= misoume/nou. Andoc. or. 1 § 96 (in a no/mos) pole/mios e)/stw *)aqhnai/wn.

e)mautw=| with fi/lon. Some MSS. of Dem. (or. 19 § 247) give e)mautou= in the quotation, but here the dat. is clearly better. qei/mhn ‘hold’ (rather than ‘make’): cp. Tyrt. 12. 1ou)/t' a)\n mnhsai/mhn ou)/t' e)n lo/gw| a)/ndra tiqei/mhn.

h( sw/|zousa, ‘who bears us safe.’ sw/|zein was esp. said of a ship or its captain: cp. Plat. Gorg. 511D e)a\n.. e)c *ai)gi/nhs deu=ro sw/sh|, if she (h( kubernhtikh/) has carried us safely from Aegina to Athens.

tau/ths k.t.l. It is only while she remains upright, as we sail on board of her, that we can make real friends. o)rqh=s (like w)/rqwsan in 163) refers to the ship maintaining a safe stability, as opposed to capsizing: the contrast is given by u(pti/ois..se/lmasin..nauti/lletai in 716 (where see n.). So Ep. ad Fam. 12. 25. 5 ut rectam teneamus (navem).

tou\s fi/lous poiou/meqa, we make the friends (whom we really make): since friends made at the cost of endangering or wrecking the ship of the State cannot properly be considered friends at all: they are fi/loi a)/filoi. For the use of the art., cp. Thuc. 2.40 ou)..pa/sxontes eu)= a)lla\ drw=ntes ktw/meqa tou\s fi/lous. The thought is like that ascribed to Pericles by Thuc. 2.60, e)gw\ ga h(gou=mai po/lin plei/w cu/mpasan o)rqoume/nhn w)felei=n tou\s i)diw/tas h)\ kaq' e(/kaston tw=n politw=n eu)pragou=san a)qro/an de\ sfallome/nhn. kalw=s me
 ga fero/menos a)nh to\ kaq' e(auto
 diafqeirome/nhs th=s patri/dos ou)de
 h(=sson cunapo/llutai, kakotuxw=n de\ e)n

eu)tuxou/sh| pollw=| ma=llon diasw/|zetai. ‘Pericles Thucydidis 11. 60 Sophoclem videtur respexisse, vel eum Sophocles,’ is Dobree's remark (Adv. 2. 37); but there is no adequate ground for such a view. The verbal coincidence of o)rqh=s with o)rqoume/nhn may well have been accidental. What is really common to poet and historian is the general sentiment of Periclean Athens. For another example of this, cp. O. C. 116 n.
no/moisi, here, rules of conduct, principles, as El. 1043; cp. O. C. 907.

au)/cw, pres. (used also in Attic prose): the Attic fut. was au)ch/sw. The pres. here expresses purpose (‘I intend to make Thebes prosperous’). Cp. Plat. Legg. 731A filoneikei/tw de\ h(mi=n pa=s pro\s a)reth/n: o( ga\r toiou=tos au)/cei ta\s po/leis.
a)delfa\ tw=nde, the more usu. constr.: but O. C. 1262 a)delfa\ tou/toisin (n.). This use of the word is freq. in Attic prose, as Phaedr. 276 D o(/sa tou/twn a)delfa/.

tw=n a)p' *oi)di/pou. In regard to origin, e)k is properly said of parents, a)po/ of ancestors: Isocr. or. 12 § 81 tou\s me\n a)po\ qew=n tou\s d' e)c au)tw=n tw=n qew=n gegono/tas. Cp. 466, 471, 1066; Ph. 260pai= patro\s e)c *)axille/ws. Ai. 202 xqoni/wn a)p' *)erexqeida=n. But poetry oft. has a)po/ of the parent, as O. C. 571 ka)f' o(/tou patro\s gegw/s: while, again, e)k oft. denotes merely the stock (including progenitors above the parent): cp. 1056: so a)gaqoi\ kai\ e)c a)gaqw=n (Phaedr. 246 A), etc. The poetical indifference on this point is well seen in fr. 104, where tou\s me\n dussebei=s kakw=n t' a)/po | blasto/ntas is opposed to tou\s d' o)/ntas e)sqlou\s e)/k te gennai/wn a(/ma | gegw=tas.
dori/ was the ordinary Attic form, occurring in prose (as Thuc. 1.128, 4. 98), and was prob. used by Soph. as well as do/rei, which metre requires in O. C. 620 (n.), 1314, 1386: cp. n. on O. C. 1304.

ta\ pa/nt' e)fagni/sai, to perform all due rites over the grave; i.e. to make the proper offerings to the dead (e)nagi/smata, O. C. 402 n.), esp. libations, xoai/. For e)pi/ in the compound cp. El. 440 xoa\s | ou)k a)/n poq', o(/n g' e)/kteine, tw=|d' e)pe/stefe: O. C. 484 ta/sd' e)peu/xesqai lita/s, i.e. ‘over’ the rite. e)fagni/sai is the reading of L; the force of the prep. is rightly given in the glosses, e)pi\ tw=| ta/fw| a(gni/sai ta\ pa/nta, and e)pi\ tw=| ta/fw| o(si/ws poih=sai. Though e)fagni/zein is not elsewhere extant, there seems no reason to question it. a)fagni/sai has been preferred by some, merely because that compound is recognised by the old grammarians (Suid. , Hesych., Phrynichus in Bekk. Anecd. 26). But a)fagni/zein meant esp. to purify from guilt (expiare): Paus. 2.31.8 (of Orestes at Troezen) e)ka/qairon kai\ ei(sti/wn, e)s o(\ a)fh/gnisan, ‘until they had purged him.’ Similarly in midd., Eur. Alc. 1145 pri\n a)\n qeoi=si toi=si nerte/rois | a)fagni/shtai, until she has made expiatory offerings to them. So a)fagneu/w in Plut. Mor. 943C (the souls of the good are to suffer only so long) o(/son a)fagneu=sai kai\ a)popneu=sai tou\s a)po\ tou= sw/matos..miasmou/s (‘to purge away’: perh. we should read a)fagni/sai). The force of a)po/ is thus the same as in a)fosiou=sqai, and in a)fierw/meqa as used by Aesch. Eum. 451 (‘I have been hallowed,’ i.e. purified). The case of ka)fagisteu/sas below (247) is different from that of e)fagni/sai here: it is, I think, for kai\ a)fagisteu/sas.

toi=s a)ri/stois, implying that, in his case, the au)to/xeir mi/asma (172) is to make no difference. Cp. Ai. 1379, where Odysseus offers to join in funeral honours to Ajax (notwithstanding his offence), mhde\n e)llei/pein, o(/son | xrh\ toi=s a)ristoi=s a)ndra/sin ponei=n brotou/s.

e)/rxetai ka/tw: the xoai/ were supposed to pass through the earth, and to be drunk by the spirits of the dead: Aesch. Ch. 164e)/xei me\n h)/dh gapo/tous xoa\s path/r: cp. Od. 10.94, Eur. Hec. 535 ff. The dat., as O. T. 711 xrhsmo\s..h)=lqe *lai/+w|.

L has *polunei/khn here, but *polunei/kh in O. C. 375. Both forms are sound. From about 400 B.C. the Attic tendency of proper names in -hs was to pass from the 3rd to the 1st declension. Attic inscriptions of circ. 410—350 B.C. give the acc. in -hn more often than that in -h. From c. 350 to 30 B.C. the gen. in -ou is far more frequent than that in -ous. Even proper names in -kle/hs, which kept the acc. in -kle/a to c. 300 B.C., afterwards formed it in -klh=n. (No Attic inscript. gives -klh=.)
le/gw: see n. on 32 le/gw ga\r ka)me/.

gt=n patrw/|an . . kai\ qeou\s . . prh=sai: cp. Aesch. Th. 582(of Polyneices) po/lin patrw/|an kai\ qeou\s tou\s e)ggenei=s | porqei=n, stra/teum' e)pakto\n e)mbeblhko/ta. But pe/rsai, for prh=sai, would be a needless change here. ‘To burn his country’ means ‘to burn his native city’: so O. C. 1421 pa/tran kataska/yanti, when thou hast laid thy native city in ruins. qeou\s prh=sai is to burn the gods' temples and the ancient wooden images (bre/th) therein: cp. Her. 8.109 e)mpimpra/s te kai\ kataba/llwn tw=n qew=n ta\ a)ga/lmata. Aesch. Pers. 809 ou) qew=n bre/th | h)|dou=nto sula=n ou)de\ pimpra/nai new/s.

q. tou\s e)ggenei=s, of the race, here in a large sense, of the Cadmean stock: while qeoi\ patrw=|oi are usu. rather the gods of one's own family (O. C. 756 n.). Cp. El. 428 pro/s nun qew=n se li/ssomai tw=n e)ggenw=n.
katelqw/n, not kataxqei\s u(po\ th=s po/lews: on the shield of Polyneices, Dikè was portrayed saying, kata/cw d' a)/ndra to/nde ( Aesch. Th. 647).
g)qe/lhse me/n … h)qe/l. de/, rhetor. epanaphora (O. C. 610 fqi/nei me/n . . fqi/nei de/). Since pa/sasqai cannot govern gh=n . . kai\ qeou/s, h)qe/lhse me\n should in strictness have preceded gh=n.
prh=sai. Prose would have used e)mprh=sai, though Thuc. has the pres. part. of the simple form (6. 94 pi/mprantes).
kat' a)/kras, here in its proper sense, of a town being sacked ‘from top to bottom’ (Il. 13.772): cp. O. C. 1241 n.

ai(/matos k. pa/sasqai (pate/omai), denoting the extreme of savage hatred; Il. 4.35 w)mo\n bebrw/qois *pri/amon: 24. 212 tou= e)gw\ me/son h(=par e)/xoimi | e)sqe/menai: Theogn. 349 tw=n ei)/h me/lan ai)=ma piei=n.

tou\s de\ … a)/gein, as if tw=n me/n had preceded ai(/matos. O. T. 1228 o(/sa | keu/qei, ta\ d' au)ti/k' ei)s to\ fw=s fanei=. Tr. 117 stre/fei, to\ d' au)/cei. Il. 22.157 paradrame/thn, feu/gwn, o( d' o)/pisqe diw/kwn.

The traditional e)kkekhru=xqai ta/fw| can be explained only by supplying le/gw or the like. But in 196 kru/yai and e)fagni/sai depended on khru/cas e)/xw in 192 (I have proclaimed to the people). It would be intolerably awkward to communicate the second part of the proclamation in an oblique form with the principal verb unexpressed: —‘(I tell you that) it has been proclaimed.’ The choice lies between (1) Musgrave's e)kkekh/ruktai ta/fw|, and (2) Nauck's e)kkekhru=xqai le/gw. In favour of (1) remark:—(a) ta/fw| is not, indeed, necessary with kteri/zein, which can be used absolutely; as Il. 11.455 au)ta\r e)pei/ ke qa/nw, kteriou=si/ me di=oi *)axaioi/, ‘will give me funeral honours’: but, as the main point is that a ta/fos is given to one brother and refused to the other, the addition of ta/fw| to the more general term kteri/zein is plainly desirable here. (b) The misplacement of mh/te is due to the thought of kwku=sai having come only after ta/fw| had been uttered (mh/te kteri/zein mh/te having been preferred to mh\ kteri/zein mhde/), and is not bolder than (e.g.) the misplacement of te in Ph. 1411 f. au)dh\n th\n *(hrakle/ous | a)koh=| te klu/ein leu/ssein t' o)/yin. (c) The MS. error may have arisen from a reminiscence of e)kkekhru=xqai in 27. The line of Carneades ( L. Diog. 4. 64), tou=ton sxolh=s th=sd' e)kkekhru=xqai le/gw, is no argument for le/gw in the text of Sophocles. What could the parodist have made of ta/fw|? The tragic solemnity of the decree was the point of the parody, which uses e)kkek. in a different sense from the poet's (‘I proclaim that he is banished from this school’: see on 27).

e)a=n d': see on 29. Construe, a)/qapton, ai)kisqe/nt' i)dei=n, mangled for all to see, de/mas kai\ pro\s oi)wnw=n kai\ pro\s kunw=n e)desto/n, in the body (acc. of respect) which birds and dogs devour. L favours ai)kisqe/nt': but this is a point on which our MSS. have little weight. Reading ai)kisqe/nt', it would be also possible to take e)desto/n as masc., with a slight pause after it; but this seems less good. With ai)kisqe/n t', de/mas is accus. in appos.: leave him unburied, a body eaten (etc.), and mangled. Some recent edd. prefer this.
de/mas of a corpse, as 903, El. 756, Eur. Or. 40 etc.: in Hom. always of the living, who has sw=ma only of the dead: in Attic sw=ma is said of either.
i)dei=n: the aor. inf., as in the epic qau=ma i)de/sqai, since the aor. suggests the moment at which the startling sight catches the eye, whereas the pres. inf. would suggest continued gazing.
fro/nhma: on 176.
e)/k g' e)mou=, by an act of mine (cp. 63, 93), while e)/n g' e)moi/ in a negative sentence=(not) if I can help it (O. C. 153).

The MSS. have timh\n proe/cous' ..tw=n e)nd., shall have honour before the just, schol. e(/cousi pro\ tw=n dikai/wn. Such a constr. of proe/xw occurs nowhere else. But the objection to rendering, ‘shall have the advantage of the just in honour’ (timh/n as acc. of respect) is that, after proe/xein in this sense, the point of advantage was regularly expressed by the dat.: see examples on O. C. 1007. timh= ( PallisA. ) is most probable, since either TIMHI or timhi might easily have become the accus. before the verb. Hermann read prose/cous' (which I do not understand) because of the hiatus (but cp. O. T. 351 proei=pas, ib. 107 au)toe/ntas); and because the honours claimed for Polyneices are only equal, not superior. But Creon's meaning is explained by vv. 514 ff.: the honour is greater for a public foe than for a patriot.
timh/setai: cp. on 93.

I print Dindorf's ka)s for kai\ in v. 212, not as thinking it certain, but because, with the least change, it gives a satisfactory construction. Soph. has this crasis in fr. 428 fi/lwn te me/myin kei)s qeou\s a(marta/nein. Cp. Plat. Rep. 538B para/nomo/n ti dra=sai h)\ ei)pei=n ei)s au)tou/s (‘with regard to them’). For the place of the prep., cp. 367, O. T. 734 *delfw=n ka)po\ *dauli/as. With the MS. reading, the accusatives in v. 212 must be governed by soi\ tau=t' a)re/skei as=su\ tau=ta dra=sai dianoei=. Greek was bold in constructions kata\ su/nesin, and might possibly have tolerated this: but it seems improbable. In the apparently similar instances the periphrasis for the transitive verb always contains a noun directly suggestive of that verb: as Eur. Ion 572 tou=to ka)/m' e)/xei po/qos = tou=to ka)gw\ poqw=: Aesch. Ag. 814 fqora\s... yh/fous e)/qento: Suppl. 533 ge/nos...ne/wson ai)=non: Theb. 289zwpurou=si ta/rbos ...lew/n: Dem. or. 19 § 81 teqna/nai tw=| fo/bw|...ce/nous. Nor can the accusatives in v. 212 be explained as mere accus. ‘of respect’; nor as if, by a euphemism, paqei=n were understood.—There is much in favour of the view that *kre/on in v. 211 has displaced an infin., such as paqei=n, labei=n, laxei=n, poiei=n, or to\ dra=n. In v. 1098 L has eu)bouli/as dei=, pai= *menoike/ws, labei=n, where later MSS. have *kre/on in place of labei=n: see n. there. If *kre/on is not genuine in v. 211, then it is much more likely to have been a mere gloss on pai= *menoike/ws than a corruption of a similar word. The conjecture kurei=n, then, merits no preference; though the acc. tau=ta could stand with it ( Aesch. Ch. 714kurou/ntwn...ta\ pro/sfora, Eur. Hec. 699 e)p' a)ktai=s nin kurw=).—Brunck wrote tau)/t', understanding a)re/skei (me) tau)ta\ soi/, ‘my view is the same as yours.’ But tau=t' is right. The Chorus say—‘Such is my lord's pleasure. And, of course, he can do as seems him good.’ Their tone is sufficiently interpreted by vv. 216, 220, 278. Cp. Her. 1.119 (Harpagus to Astyages) e)/fh... a)resto\n ei)=nai pa=n to\ a)\n basileu\s e)/rdh|. The Chorus do not oppose Creon; but they feel a secret misgiving; they wish at least to remain passive.

In panti/ pou/ g' the enclitic pou closely adheres to panti/, and ge emphasises the whole expression; as in El. 1506, o(/stis pe/ra pra/ssein ge tw=n no/mwn qe/lei, the ge emphasises the whole phrase pe/ra pra/ssein. The transposition soi/ g' … pou is open to the objection that panti/, not soi/, claims the chief emphasis. panti/ pou pa/resti has also been proposed. But e)/nesti is slightly more suitable to this context, because more suggestive of tacit disapproval. ‘It is possible for you’ (‘but we doubt whether it is expedient’). pa/resti/ soi is generally said rather when the speaker means, ‘it is easy for you,’ or ‘it is open to you,’— in seconding a wish of the other person, or in making an offer to him. Ph. 364ta)/lla me\n pa/resti/ soi | patrw=|' e(le/sqai. Cp. O. T. 766. — panti/ pou me/testi/ soi, which some prefer, is still less suitable here. It would imply a right shared by the King with some other man or men (cp. on 48).—Though the antecedent (h(mw=n) to xw(po/soi zw=men is understood, pe/ri can stand at the end of the verse, since such a relative clause was felt almost as a noun-case: see on 35. Cp. Eur. Ion 560 h)= qi/gw dh=q' oi(/ m' e)/fusan; (=tw=n fusa/ntwn).

w(s a)
 … h)=te can be explained only by an ellipse of e)pimelei=sqe or the like. After verbs of ‘taking care,’ the usu. constr. is o(/pws with fut. indic.; but w(s a)/n with subj. is sometimes found, as Hipparch. 9. 2e)pimelei=sqai w(s a)
 praxqh=|...h)
 mh/ tis e)pimelh=tai w(s a)
 tau=ta perai/nhtai. In elliptical phrases, where a precept or charge is given (o(/ra, etc., being understood), the regular constr. is o(/pws with fut. ind., as Lys. or. 1. 21 o(/pws toi/nun tau=ta mhdei\s a)nqrw/pwn peu/setai. The elliptical o(/pws mh/ with subjunct. is different,—‘take care lest,’ —a deferential way of hinting an objection (Plat. Crat. 430D), like the simple elliptical mh/ with subjunct. O. C. 1180. Since, however, e)pimelei=sqai could be followed by w(s a)/n with subjunct., it is conceivable that Soph. should write w(s a)
 skopoi\ h)=te instead of the usual o(/pws skopoi\ e)/sesqe. I cannot think, with Wecklein, that the sentence is broken off, as though Creon said,—‘In order that ye may be watchers of my mandate,’—being about to add, mh\ e)pixwrei=te.—Dindorf's pw=s a)
 … ei)=te is supported by usage, as O. T. 765 pw=s a)
 mo/loi dh=q' h(mi
 e)n ta/xei pa/lin; Nauck (Cur. Eur. 11. 79) refuses ei)=men and ei)=te to tragedy, but is not convincing. In O. T. 1046 ei)dei=t' (for ei)dei/hte) is certain: and ei)=te for ei)/hte is strictly parallel. ei)=te occurs in Od. 21.195 poi=oi/ k' ei)=t' *)odush=i<*> a)mune/men, ei)/ poqen e)/lqoi; In Eur. Alc. 921 h)=men might replace ei)=men: though in Hipp. 349, at least, the opt. ei)=men seems required. But pw=s a)
 ei)=te is here less fitting than w(s a)
 h)=te, because a request is less suitable than an injunction.
skopoi/, fu/lakes, who watch to see that no one breaks the edict.
nun is better than nu=n.
tw=n ei)r., the commands: cp. Aesch. Ag. 1620 swfronei=n ei)rhme/non, Her. 7.26 ei)/rhto sulle/gesqai...strato/n.

pro/qes tou=to, set him this as a task (cp. 1249), basta/zein, for him to take in hand (suscipiendum); the act. inf. as O. C. 231 po/non...a)ntidi/dwsin e)/xein. For the lit. sense of the verb cp. Ai. 827 w(/s me basta/sh| | peptw=ta (raise me).
tou= nekrou= g': but e)pi/skopoi tw=n a)stw=n are still needed.

ti/ dh=t' a)
 … e)pente/llois = ti/ dh=t' a)
 ei)/h...o(\ e)pente/lleis; cp. O. C. 647 me/g' a)
 le/gois dw/rhma: Ph. 26.
The reading a)/llw| is a bad one, for the contrast is between commands, not persons; and an awkward ambiguity would arise, since tou=to might then seem to mean the watching of the corpse.

e)pixwrei=n, accedere, to join their side: Thuc. 4.107 deca/menos tou\s e)qelh/santas e)pixwrh=sai... kata\ ta\s sponda/s. Mirab. 133 tou/tw| tw=| e)pigra/mmati e)pexw/rhse kai\ o( to/pos e)kei=nos (corroborated it).
a)pistou=sin = a)peiqou=sin: 381, 656.
ta/de, cogn. acc.: cp. 66.

o(\s (instead of w(/ste) e)ra=|, a constr. most freq. in negative sentences, usu. with o(/stis (Dem. or. 1 § 15 ti/s ou(/tws eu)h/qhs e)sti
...o(/stis a)gnoei=), or o(\s a)/n and opt. (Plat. Rep. 360B ou)dei\s a)
 ge/noito ou(/tws a)dama/ntinos, o(\s a)
 mei/neien). But it occurs also in affirmative sentences, as Eur. Andr. 170 e)s tou=to d' h(/keis a)maqi/as ...h(\...tolma=|s. Cp. Her. 4.52.

kai\ mh\n (lit., ‘and verily’) here confirms the last speaker's remark by adding an assurance that disobedience does indeed mean death; while ge after misqo/s emphasises that word. ‘And I can tell you that the
requital of disobedience is that.’ For kai\ mh/n so used, cp. O. T. 836, 1004 f., El. 556.
to\ ke/rdos, ‘gain,’ i.e., as e)lpi/dwn shows, the prospect of gain, with the generic art. (cp. 1242): so fr. 749 to\ ke/rdos h(du/, ka)\n a)po\ yeudw=n i)/h|.
diw/lesen, gnomic aor.
e)rw= me\n ou)x: cp. on 96.

o(/pws = o(/ti, as O. T. 548: cp. El. 963 mhke/t' e)lpi/sh|s o(/pws | teu/cei. This use is rare in Attic prose (for after qauma/zw, etc., o(/pws =‘how’), though freq. in Her., as 2. 49 ou)de\ fh/sw o(/kws...e)/labon. Yet cp. Plat. Euthyd. 296 E ou)k e)/xw u(mi=n pw=s a)mfisbhtoi/hn...o(/pws ou) pa/nta e)gw\ e)pi/stamai.

ta/xous u(/po is the reading of the MSS. Aristotle quotes this verse as an example of a prooi/mion used by the speaker to avert a danger from himself, and gives it thus:—a)/nac, e)rw= me
 ou)x o(/pws spoudh=s u)/po ( Rhet. 3. 14§ 10). Hence some edd. adopt spoudh=s, as coming from a source older than our MSS. But, since ta/xous is free from objection, such a change is unwarrantable. Aristotle's quotations seem to have been usually made from memory, and his memory was not infallible. To take only three examples cited by Bellermann, we find: (1) El. 256 a)ll' h( bi/a ga tau=t' a)nagka/zei me dra=n, quoted Metaphys. 4. 5 a)ll' h( bi/a me tau=t' a)nagka/zei poiei=n: (2) O. T. 774 e)moi\ path me
 *po/lubos h)=n, quoted Rhet. 3. 14§ 6 e)moi\ path h)=n *po/lubos: (3) Ant. 911 mhtro\s d' e)n *(/aidou kai\ patro\s kekeuqo/toin, quoted Rhet. 3. 16§ 9 with bebhko/twn as last word. So Il. 9.592 kh/de' o(/s' a)nqrw/poisi pe/lei tw=n a)/stu a(lw/|h: a)/ndras me
 ktei/nousi, is quoted Rhet. 1. 7§ 31 with o(/ssa ka/k' substituted for the first two words, and laoi\ me
 fqinu/qousi for the last three.
e)ca/ras (a_), aor. part., not pres., because, as e)c- shows, the notion is, ‘having set in nimble movement’ (at starting). Cp. Eur. Tro. 342 mh\ kou=fon ai)/rh| bh=m' e)s *)argei/wn strato/n.

fronti/dwn, possessive gen. with e)pista/seis, halts belonging to thoughts, i.e. caused by them. Others understand, ‘halts for thought’ (made in order to reflect),— which is less simple. Cp. De Anim. 1. 3 (p. 407a 32) h( no/hsis e)/oiken h)remh/sei tini\ kai\ e)pista/sei (halt) ma=llon h)\ kinh/sei.
o(doi=s, locative dat.; cp. O. C. 553 o(doi=s | e)n tai=sd', ‘in this my coming.’
kuklw=n = peristre/fwn.

yuxh\ ga\r hu)/da k.t.l. The naïveté consists in the direct quotation of what his yuxh/ said, rather than in the statement that it spoke; thus Hor. Sat. 1. 2. 68 (quoted by Schneid.) is really similar,—Huic si...Diceret haec animus. Take polla\ with muqoume/nh only. I do not think that hu)/da...muqoume/nh was meant to mark garrulity; the language is not homely enough: rather it is simply,— ‘found a voice, speaking many things.’ e)/fh le/gwn is not similar (Ai. 757).—Cp. Launcelot Gobbo in Shaksp. Merch. 2. 2: Certainly my conscience will serve me to run from this few my master. The fiend is at mine elbow and tempts me...My conscience says, ‘Launcelot, budge not.’ ‘Budge,’ says the fiend. ‘Budge not,’ says my conscience.
ta/las … tlh/mwn, nom., not voc., because each is rather a comment (‘hapless that thou art!’) than properly an address: so O. C. 185 w)= tla/mwn, ib. 753 w)= ta/las e)gw/, Eur. Med. 61 w)= mw=ros.

me/neis is better than menei=s, since, ‘are you tarrying again?’ (his halts having been frequent, 225) is more graphic than, ‘will you tarry again?’— au)= cannot mean here, ‘on the contrary’ (i.e. instead of going on).
pw=s … ou)k, as O. T. 937, 976, etc.
a)lgunei=, pass.: cp. on 93 e)xqarei=.
e(li/sswn, turning over and over in the mind: cp. on 158 e)re/sswn.

h)/nuton (sc. th\n o(do/n), gradually made my way (impf.); whereas h)/nusa would have suited a quick journey. Cp. this impf. in Plat. Symp. 127C ou)damh=| tau/th| h)/nuton, ‘they could make no progress by that means.’ Soph. has this tense also in Tr. 319 (e)/rgon h)/nuton): cp. below, 805. In Dem. or. 21 § 104 our MSS. give ou)de\n h)/nue. For the use of the verb in ref. to journeys, cp. Thuc. 2.97 (o(do\s) h(merw=n a)ndri\ eu)zw/nw| triw=n kai\ de/ka a)nu/sai. The Attic pres. seems to have been a)nu/tw as=‘to accomplish,’ or ‘to make way,’ but a)nu/ein as=‘to hasten.’ Plut. 413 mh/ nun dia/trib' a)ll' a)/nue: Ran. 606a)nu/eton: though in Plut. 606 ou) me/llein | xrh/ s', a)ll) a)nu/ein, some MSS. have a)nu/tein (see Pors. on Phoen. 463). This is the distinction meant by the grammarian in Bekk. Anecd. 411. 28 a(nu/ttein (sic) oi( *)attikoi\ o(/per h(mei=s, a(nu/ein de\ to\ speu/dein. (The aspirated forms lack good evidence.) Cp. a)ru/w, Attic a)ru/tw.

sxolh=| bradu/s, reluctantly and slowly; the opposite of su\n spoudh=| taxu/s ( Ph. 1223), with eagerness and speed. sxolh=| oft.=‘at a slow pace’ (poreu/esqai, Xen. Anab. 4.1.16; u(poxwrei=n, Thuc. 3.78). As bradu/s could mean ‘sluggish’ (O. C. 306), we might here refer sxolh=| to pace, and bradu/s to reluctance; but, though the common use of sxolh=| in regard to pace helps to make it suitable here, it is better, in this context, to give sxolh=| the moral and bradu/s the physical sense. For sxolh=| combined with another word in such an expression, cp. Polyb. 8. 30 sxolh=| kai\ ba/dhn poiei=sqai th\n porei/an. There is no lack of point. Such a messenger ought to have come spoudh=| taxu/s.—The conjecture spoudh=| bradu/s is (I think) not only wrong but bad. It would mean, ‘slow in my haste’; eager to arrive, yet moving slowly. speu=de brade/ws, to which it is supposed to allude, meant, ‘never remit your efforts, but advance circumspectly towards your aim’: festina lente (on which see Erasmus in the Adagia); Eile mit Weile; Goethe's Ohne Hast, ohne Rast. (speu=de brade/ws was a favourite maxim of Augustus, Suet. Aug. 25; Gellius 10. 11 § 5, on whom, as often, Macrobius has drawn, Sat. 6. 8. 9.) The frightened and irresolute fu/lac, —sent, sorely against his will, on a hateful errand,—had no more spoudh/ than Mr Facing-both-ways. Wecklein, keeping sxolh=|, supposes the Guard to mean, ‘this was a case of sxolh=| bradu/s, not spoudh=| bradu/s,’—an improbably obscure and feeble jest at such a critical moment. The variant given by the schol., sxolh=| taxu/s, would be an oxymoron, designedly comic; ‘I took my time about hurrying,’ ‘'twas but a laggard haste that I made.’ A cheerful epigram of this sort would better suit a mind more at ease.
te/los ge me/ntoi, at last, however; ge emphasising the word before it: O. T. 442 n.
e)ni/khsen, impers., as Thuc. 2.54 e)ni/khse de\...loimo\n ei)rh=sqai (the opinion prevailed that...): Her. 6.101 e)ni/ka mh\

e)klipei=n th\n po/lin. That molei=n should not be regarded as the subject to e)ni/khse, is shown by such an example as Her. 8.9 e)ni/ka th\n h(me/rhn e)kei/nhn au)tou= mei/nanta/s te kai\ au)lisqe/ntas mete/peita nu/kta me/shn pare/ntas poreu/esqai, where the length of the interval excludes such a view. The personal constr. occurs below, 274; cp. Thuc. 2.12 h)=n...*perikle/ous gnw/mh...nenikhkui=a.

soi/ with molei=n. In Attic prose a dat. of the person after e)/rxomai is freq., and oft. can be rendered (as here) only by ‘to,’ though it is properly rather a dat. of interest. Thus Thuc. 1.13 *)ameinoklh=s *sami/ois h)=lqe=‘ A. came to the Samians,’ though the primary notion is, ‘the Samians enjoyed the advantage of A. 's coming’ (to build triremes for them). So id. 1. 27 w(s au)toi=s...h)=lqon a)/ggeloi: Plat. Prot. 321C a)porou=nti de\ au)tw=| e)/rxetai *promhqeu/s. In poetry this dat. is freely used after verbs of motion, but the idea of interest is always traceable; cp. 186 n. Aesch. PV 358 a)ll' h)=lqen au)tw=| *zhno\s a)/grupnon be/los. So here, molei=n soi/ is not strictly a mere equiv. for molei=n pro\s se/, but implies Creon's interest in the news. The notion is, ‘to come and place myself at your disposal.’ For the emphatic place of soi/, cp. 273 (and 46 n.): for the pause after the first syllable of the verse, 250, 464.—kei), ‘and if’: not ‘even if.’ If kai/ were taken as=‘even,’ there would be a very harsh asyndeton, whether the stop were at soi/, or (as Nauck places it) after molei=n. It is true that kai/ could mean ‘even,’ without causing an asyndeton, if we adopted Wecklein's tempting fra/swn for fra/sw d': but the latter is confirmed by O. T. 302 ei) kai\ mh\ ble/peis, fronei=s d' o(/mws (where see n.),—de/ introducing the apodosis after a concessive protasis. For kei) as=‘and if,’ cp. Ai. 447, 1057. The transposition kei)/ soi is improbable, as destroying the significant emphasis and pause on soi/.

to\ mhde/n, what is as nought, — a tale of simple discomfiture: since he can only report the deed, without giving any clue to the doer. Cp. Tr. 1107 ka)
 to\ mhde
 w)=: Ai. 1275 h)/dh to\ mhde
 o)/ntas e)n troph=| doro/s.
th=s e)lpi/dos, not ‘hope,’ but ‘the hope’—defined in next v.

dedragme/nos is certain. Il. 13.393 ko/nios dedragme/nos (and 16. 486). Diod. 12. 67dra/casqai kairou=. (Cp. Shaks. Per.f. 1. 49 Gripe not at earthly joys.) Here the phrase is meant to be homely. The v.l. pefragme/nos was simply an attempt to mend L's pepragme/nos. We should require the dat. with it. The gen. cannot be justified by instances in which poetry uses a gen. of the agent without u(po/, after pass. part., as Ai. 807 fwto\s h)pathme/nh, Eur. Or. 497 plhgei\s qugatro/s, etc.
to\ mh\ paqei=n a)/n = o(/ti ou)
pa/qoimi a)/n, depending on e)lpi/dos...dedr. as=e)lpi/zwn: for the art. with infin., cp. 78 n.
to\ mo/rsimon: i.e. if you do kill me, then it was my destiny to be killed.
a)nq' ou(=, on account of which: O. T. 264 a)nq' w(=n: El. 585 a)nq' o(/tou.
to\ ga\r | pra=gm': cp. on 67. ga/r prefaces the statement: O. T. 277 n.: cp. below, 478, 999.

eu)= ge stoxa/zei k.t.l.: ‘yes, you take your aim well, and seek to fence yourself round against the charge.’ The mark at which the man aims is his own safety; and this is explained by the next phrase. Commentators have made difficulties by assuming that the metaphors of stoxa/zei and a)pofra/gnusai must be harmonised into a single picture,—as of an archer shooting from covert. But in fact there is a rapid transition from one to the other; the second interprets the first; and all that is common to them is their military source. stoxa/zomai was familiar in a sense akin to that which it has here: cp. Plat. Lach. 178B stoxazo/men oi tou= sumbouleuome/nou a)/lla le/gousi para\ th\n au(tw=n do/can (trying to hit the thought of the person who consults them): Polyb. 6. 16 o)fei/lousi de\ a)ei\ poiei=n oi( dh/marxoi to\ dokou=n tw=| dh/mw| kai\ ma/lista stoxa/zesqai th=s tou/tou boulh/sews. So here the verb suggests a designing person, whose elaborate preamble covers a secret aim. Creon is quick to suspect bribery (221). Cp. 1033 w(/ste toco/tai skopou= | toceu/et' a)ndro\s tou=de. Schneidewin thought that stoxa/zei might here be a term of hunting or war, with ref. to the erecting of nets on poles, or of palisades. stoixi/zein was so used, of nets in hunting ( Cyneg. 6. 8). But stoi=xos is from rt stix, while sto/xos is from a probably distinct rt stax (sta/xus), stex (perhaps lengthened from sta). In Aristot. Rhet. 3. 14§ 10 the citation of v. 223 is immediately followed by the words ti/ froimia/zh|; which Nauck (with Bergk) substitutes for eu)= ge stoxa/zei here. But, though the schol. there says that Creon spoke them, they evidently belonged to some other passage, which Arist. cites as a second example: perh. to Eur. I. T. 1162 ti/ froimia/zei neoxmo/n; e)cau/da safw=s. A schol. on Arist. l. c. says, to\ de\ ti/ froimia/zh| e)n tisi\ tw=n a)ntigra/fwn ou) kei=tai (i.e. in some MSS. of Arist. ); which looks as if the words had been deleted, in such copies, by readers who could not find them in

ka)pofra/gnusai. Inscriptions of the 5th cent. B.C. show fa/rcai (not fra/cai) to have been the old Attic aor. (Meisterhans p. 89), and so nau/farktos, etc.: but the analogy of the pres. fra/ttw recommends fra/gnumi rather than fa/rgnumi. For the constr., cp. Thuc. 8.104 e)bou/lonto a)pofa/rcasqai au)tou\s oi( e)nanti/oi (to shut them off).
to\ pra=gma, so soon after 239: cp. on 76.
dhloi=s d' w(/s ti s.: see on 20.
ta\ deina/, dangers,—i.e. the kaka\ e)/ph (277) which he brings: ga/r (yes, I am cautious) for, etc.
pot', tandem aliquando, O. T. 335 n.
a)pallaxqei/s, ‘having been removed,’ i.e. ‘having taken yourself off’; cp. Aristoph. Vesp. 484 a)=p' a)/n, w)= pro\s tw=n qew=n, u(mei=s a)pallaxqei=te/ mou;
kai\ dh/, without more ado: O. C. 31 n.

qa/yas, because the essential rite was the throwing of earth on the body: cp. on 80, and below, 256.—The kai/ in ka)pi/ is ‘and’ (rather than ‘both,’ answering to kai/ in 247); it introduces an explanation of qa/yas.
diyi/an, as Aesch. Ag. 495 phlou= cu/nouros diyi/a ko/nis: Lucr. 2. 376 bibula...arena.

ka)fagisteu/sas (kai\ a).) a(\ xrh/, i.e. having made the due offerings, perh. flowers (El. 896), or ste/fh of wool. We may doubt whether the poet thought of any xoai/ as having been poured by Antigone at this first visit; see n. on 429.—a)fagisteu/sas and e)fagisteu/sas are equally possible; but I prefer the former, because here, as v. 256 suggests, the idea is that of a)fosiwsa/menos,—having avoided an a)/gos by satisfying religion: see on 196 e)fagni/sai.
a)ndrw=n: he does not think of women.

ou)/te tou genh=|dos … ou) dike/llhs. For the enclitic tou so placed, cp. 20 n.: for ou)/te … ou), O. C. 972 n. genhi/+s, genh/s (only here), is prop. an adj., an implement with a ge/nus (jaw), or blade: El. 485 a)mfa/khs ge/nus, the two-edged blade (of a bronze axe). Hesych. genh=|da: a)ci/nhn, pe/lekun (referring, as the acc. shows, to some other passage): and here the genh/|s is prob. the same as the a)ci/nh below (1109), which was to be used in raising the mound (1203). We may render ‘pickaxe,’ since this properly has a blade as well as a point. The genh/|s would break the hard surface. Then the earth would be thrown up (e)kbolh/) with the di/kella, which was a sort of heavy two-pronged hoe, used, like the Roman ligo or bidens, in hoeing up soil: the ma/kella (mi/a, ke/llw to drive forward) being a like tool with one prong. The sminu/h was like the di/kella, a two-pronged hoe. ‘Mattock’ is the nearest word for it. ‘Spade’ would better suit a)/mh (or the Homeric li/stron), though this was prop. rather a shovel. For the combination cp. Shaks. Tit. Andr. 5. 3. 11 'Tis you must dig with mattock and with spade.

dik. e)kbolh/, throwing up of earth by mattock (possessive gen. denoting the subject, gh= h(\n h( d. e)kba/llei): e)kb., abstract for concrete, like trofh/ for qre/mma (O. T. 1 n.). In Greek Mod. e)kbola/des is a mining term, ‘out-put.’— The epithets stu/flos (‘hard,’ cp. 139), and xe/rsos ‘dry,’ tell something which the preceding words, and the following a)rrw/c, would not alone have told; viz. why no foot-prints were traceable.

e)phmaceume/nh, lit. ‘traversed (i.e. furrowed) by a carriage’ with its (four) wheels, =troxoi=s a(ma/chs kexaragme/nh: e)p-, not e)f-, since as Eusth. says (on Il. 18.485) to\...a(/maca oi( me\n palaioi\ yilou=si, oi( me/ntoi new/teroi *)attikoi\ e)da/sunan. (Cp. n. on a)ph/nh, O. T. 753.)

a)ll' o( e)rga/ths a)/shmo/s tis h)=n: for tis added to the predicate, where the subject has the art., cp. O. T. 618, Aesch. Theb. 491 o( shmatourgo\s d' ou)/ tis eu)telh\s a)/p' h)=n: Aristoph. Pl. 726 w(s filo/poli/s ti/s e)sq' o( dai/mwn kai\ sofo/s. Not: o( e)rga/ths tis (the doer, whoever he is) a)/shmos h)=n, like o( ku/rio/s tis (O. C. 288 n.).

It is still the early morning of the day on which the drama opens. The Argives having fled in the night, Creon had published his edict shortly before dawn. Antigone had done her deed in the short interval between the publication of the edict and the beginning of the watch over the corpse. o( prw=tos h(merosko/pos, the man who took the first watch of this day, was the first who had watched at all. If a sentinel had been near the body, Ant. must have been seen. The other men were somewhere near. (Afterwards, they all watched, Ant. 413.) h(merosk., in prose h(merofu/lac (Xen. Hellen. 7.2.6), as opp. to nuktofu/lac (id. An. 7. 2. 18).
dei/knusi … parh=n: historic pres. combined with past tense; cp. Lys. or. 1 § 6 e)peidh\ de/ moi paidi/on gi/gnetai, e)pi/steuon h)/dh kai\ pa/nta ta\ e)mautou= e)kei/nh| pare/dwka.
dusxere/s, not merely ‘perplexing,’ but ‘distressing’ (Ai. 1395), since they foreboded punishment. So dusxe/reia, molestia ( Ph. 473).
o( me\n answered by shmei=a d' (257).

tumbh/rhs me\n ou)/ (cp. on 96), not entombed: i.e. there was no tu/mbos, indicating that the ashes had been buried beneath it (1203): the body itself lay there, though covered over with dust. tumb., prop., ‘provided with a mound,’ but below, 946, merely=‘tomb-like’; and so in Ar. Th. 889Euripides says tumbh/reis e(/dras, ‘seat on a tomb.’—lepth\ d' … e)ph=n, instead of le/pth| de\ ko/nei kekalumme/nos (as in Soph. Ph. 545doca/zwn me\n ou)/, | tu/xh| de\...o(rmisqei/s): for this introduction of a new finite verb, where a participial clause was expected, cp. 813 ff.

a)/gos feu/gontos w(/s sc. tinos (O. T. 629 ou)/toi kakw=s g' a)/rxontos, n.): the gen. is not absol., but possessive, denoting the author: ‘as of (i.e. from) one avoiding.’ a)/gos, the guilt incurred by one who passed by an unburied corpse without throwing earth on it: oi( ga nekro
 o(rw=ntes a)/tafon, kai\ mh\ e)pamhsa/menoi ko/nin, e)nagei=s ei)=nai e)do/koun. Aelian Var. Hist. 5. 14 no/mos kai\ ou(=tos *)attiko/s, o(\s a)
 a)ta/fw| peritu/xh| sw/mati a)nqrw/pou pa/ntws e)piba/llein au)tw=| gh=n: qa/ptein de\ pro\s dusma\s ble/pontas. So, too, Aelian says of the hawk, Hist. Anim. 2. 49, nekro
 de\ a)/nqrwpon i)dw
 i(e/rac, w(s lo/gos, pa/ntws e)piba/llei gh=n tw=| a)ta/fw|: kai\ tou=to me
 au)tw=| ou) keleu/ei *so/lwn, w(s *)aqhnai/ous e)pai/deuse dra=n (though our schol. ascribes the precept to a prehistoric *bouzu/ghs): and of the elephant, H. A. 5. 49 to
 e)le/fanta qeasa/menos e)le/fas nekro
 ou)k a)
 pare/lqoi, mh\ th=| proboski/di gh=n a)rusa/menos kai\ e)pibalw/n, o(si/an tina\ a)po/rrhton u(pe th=s koinh=s fu/sews telw=n (‘fulfilling some mysterious law of piety imposed by Nature’), kai\ feu/gwn a)/gos: ei)=nai ga to\ mh\ dra=sai tou=to e)nage/s. It was remembered as a disgrace to Lysander that, having put to death some prisoners of war, ou)de\ a)poqanou=sin e)ph/negke gh=n (Paus. 9.32.6). Cp. id. 1. 32. 5 pa/ntws o(/sion a)nqrw/pou nekro
 gh=| kru/yai. Hor. Carm. 1. 28. 33precibus non linquar inultis, Teque piacula nulla resolvent...licebit Iniecto ter pulvere curras.
qhro/s, here a wild beast, as dist. from domesticated animals (cp. 1081): more often the term excludes only birds and fishes.
tou with qhro/s also: Eur. Hec. 370 ou)/t' e)lpi/dos ga\r ou)/te tou do/chs o(rw= | qa/rsos par' h(mi=n.

ou) spa/santos. The negatives in 257 affect e)lqo/ntos: and ou) stands with spa/santos as if we had simply ou)k e)lqo/ntos, ou) spa/santos, shmei=a h)=n. ou) is not here an irregular substitute for ou)/te, as in 250: this would be so only if we had ou)/t' e)lqo/ntos. Either ou)de\ sp. or ou)/te sp. would be correct, but the latter would suppose an ou)/te understood before e)lqo/ntos. For spa/santos of rending, cp. 1003. It could not mean, ‘having cast up earth’ over the body (as Triclinius took it). The point is that the body must have been covered before the beasts had had time to come. The poet has preferred this order to spa/santos ou)d' e)lqo/ntos (i.e. ‘or even having come’), because, ei) h)=lqon, kai\ e)/spasan a)/n.

lo/goi d' … fu/laka. The regular form would be, lo/gois kakoi=s e)rroqou=men e)n a)llh/lois, e)le/gxontes fu/lac fu/laka (or a)/llos a)/llon), fu/lac being the part in apposition with the whole (h(mei=s). The irregularity of the form in the text is threefold. (1) For lo/gois kakoi=s e)rroqou=men we have an equiv. in sense, though not in grammar, lo/goi kakoi\ e)rro/qoun. (2) In spite of this, e)n a)llh/loisin is retained, whereas e)n h(mi=n is now needed. (3) As a plur. part. would have been awkward after lo/goi, we have fu/lac e)le/gxwn fu/laka, which thus is virtually equiv. to a gen. absol., fu/lakos e)le/gxontos fu/laka. Remark that, even in regular examples of partitive apposition, a participle, describing what all do, is sometimes thus made singular; Xen. Anab. 7.3.47 oi/ i(ppei=s oi)/xontai/ moi a)/llos a)/llh| diw/kwn (instead of diw/kontes). It is only the first of these three points that this passage has in common with others to which it has been compared. ‘They disputed, some saying this, some that,’ often appears in Greek as ‘there was a dispute,’ etc., without causing oi( me
...oi( de/ to be changed into the gen. absol. Her. 8.74 polla\ e)le/geto,...oi( me
 w(s...xre/on ei)/h a)pople/ein, *)aqhnai=oi de/ etc. Thuc. 4.23 u(p' a)mfote/rwn...e)polemei=to, *)aqhnai=oi me
 periple/ontes..., *peloponnh/sioi de/ etc. Aesch. PV 200 sta/sis t' e)n a)llh/loisin w)roqu/neto, | oi( me
 qe/lontes...oi( de/ etc. (This illustrates the use of e)n a)llh/l. here, but is less bold, since the noun is sing.) Eur. Phoen. 1462 h)=n d' e)/ris strathla/tais, | oi( me
 pata/cai...oi( de/ etc. Bacch. 1131h)=n de\ pa=s' o(mou= boh/, | o( me
 stena/zwn... ai( de/ etc. For e)rro/qoun, of a confused noise of angry tongues, cp. 290. r(o/qos (onomatop.) is said of a rushing noise of waves, or of oars dashed into them, etc.: then, fig., Aesch. Pers. 406 *persi/dos
glw/sshs r(o/qos, of an unintelligible jargon.
e)le/gxwn, questioning (434, O. T. 333, 783: El. 1353), here, in the sense of ‘accusing.’
ka)\n e)gi/gneto: and blows would have come at last,—had not the matter been settled by the proposal mentioned at 268. (Not, ‘blows would come,’ i.e. were often exchanged, as Nauck takes it.)
teleutw=s', ‘at last,’ the adverbial use, found even with another partic., as Thuc. 6.53 turanni/da xaleph\n teleutw=san genome/nhn.
o( kwlu/swn: cp. O. T. 297.
h)=n … ou(ceirg., was the doer (in the belief of his comrades).
e)nargh/s, manifestus facti: O. T. 535 lh|sth/s t' e)nargh/s.

a)ll' (e(/kastos), evolved from ou)dei/s: fr. 327 e)moi\ d' ou)dei\s dokei= | ei(=nai, pe/nhs w)/n, a)/nosos, a)ll' a)ei\ nosei=n. Dem. or. 20 § 74 mhdei\s fqo/nw| to\ me/llon a)kou/sh|, a)ll', a)\n a)lhqe\s h)=|, skopei/tw.

e(/feuge mh\ ei)de/nai, ‘pleaded in defence that he knew nothing of it.’ For this pregnant use of feu/gein cp. Aesch. Suppl. 390, where the Argive king says to the Danaides, whose cousins threaten to seize them under Egyptian law, dei= toi de\ feu/gein kata\ no/mous tou\s oi)/koqen | w(s ou)k e)/xousi ku=ros ou)de
 a)mfi\ sou=: you must plead, in accordance with Egyptian law, that they have no right over you. So defendere, In Pison. 10. 5 si triumphum non cupiebas, cuius tandem rei te cupiditate arsisse defendes? (‘will you plead?’) Note that this use (like the absol. legal sense, ‘to be a defendant,’ from which it comes) was necessarily restricted to pres. and impf. Hence we must not cite, with Donaldson, Dem. or. 27 § 1 ou(=tos tou\s ue
 safw=s ei)do/tas ta\ h(me/tera e)/fuge mhde
 diagnw=nai peri\ au)tw=n, ei)s d' u(ma=s tou\s ou)de
 tw=n h(mete/rwn a)kribw=s e)pistame/nous e)lh/luqen (which means: ‘he has avoided any decision on the case being given by those who knew our affairs thoroughly, but has come to you,’ etc.): nor, with Paley, Xen. Hellen. 1.3.19 u(pago/menos qana/tou...a)pe/fugen, o(/ti ou) prodoi/h th
 po/lin a)lla\ sw/sai, i.e. ‘being put on trial for his life, he was acquitted, (on the plea) that he had not betrayed the city,’ etc.

mh\ (not ou)k) ei)de/nai, as after verbs of denying, Aristoph. Eq. 572 h)rnou=nto mh\ peptwke/nai.—Only one other version is tenable, viz., ‘shrunk from knowing it’; but this could hardly be said in the sense, ‘shrunk from confessing that he knew it.’—Others understand tou\s a)/llous as subject to ei)de/nai, ‘shrunk from (the others) knowing it’ (‘entzog sich dem Wissen der anderen’), which is impossible. So also is Campb.'s version, ‘always escaped, so that we could not know him,’ which would, in the first place, require e)/fuge.

mu/drous, lumps of red-hot iron. mu/dros=a molten mass, from rt mud, whence mu/dos, ‘moisture,’ muda/w, etc. Cyril Adv. Iulian. 359 quotes this verse, after referring to a Chaldean custom of making an oath more solemn by causing those who took it to pass between the severed portions of a victim (dia\ me/swn... dixotomhma/twn). It is probably the oldest trace in Greek of ordeals analogous to the medieval ‘judgments of God.’ The word mu/dros occurs elsewhere in connection with a solemn sanction for an oath. In Her. 1.165 the Phocaeans mu/dron sidh/reon katepo/ntwsan, swearing not to return till it should float. Aristid. 25 o( d' *)aristei/dhs w(/rkise me
 tou\s *(/ellhnas kai\ w)/mosen u(pe tw=n *)aqhnai/wn (to observe the defensive league against Persia, 479 B.C., Grote 5. 257), mu/drous e)mbalw
 e)pi\ tai=s a)rai=s (in sanction of the curses on traitors) ei)s th
 qa/lattan. I conceive that in these passages, as elsewhere, mu/dros has its proper sense,

a red-hot mass of metal, and that the custom was symbolical of an older use of the mu/dros in ordeals by fire. This would explain how the Alexandrian poets of the 3rd cent. B.C. (Lycophron, Callimachus) came to use the word mu/dros, in defiance of its etymology, as simply ‘a lump’ (or even ‘a stone’). They supposed that the mu/droi had been cold masses.

pu=r die/rpein must here refer to a definite ordeal, by walking through a fire. The idea, at least, of such an ordeal appears in the familiar Attic phrase dia\ puro\s i)e/nai (‘to go through fire and water’); Plat. Symp. 4. 16e)/gwg' ou)=n meta\ *kleini/ou ka)\n dia\ puro\s i)oi/hn, Aristoph. Lys. 133 dia\ tou= puro\s | e)qe/lw badi/zein. But it is doubtful whether the actual use of any such ordeal in the historical age can be inferred from Dem. or. 54 § 40 a)ciopisto/teros tou= kata\ tw=n pai/dwn (by the lives of one's children, cp. or. 29 § 26) o)mnu/ontos kai\ dia\ tou= puro/s, i. e. swearing that one is ready to undergo the test by fire. It has been suggested that i)o/ntos has fallen out after puro/s, which seems improbable. But the phrase may be rhetorical. Cp. Verg. Aen. 11. 787 (the Hirpi): medium freti pietate per ignem Cultores multa premimus vestigia pruna.—Becker Char. 183 notices some other ordeals. There was a temple in Achaia, the priestess of which, before election, was proved by drinking ball's blood; if impure, she died (Paus. 7.25.13). Perjury, and some other crimes, were assayed by the accused mounting the steps of an altar for burnt sacrifice (e)sxa/ra): if he was guilty, flames appeared ( Aeth. 10. 8). Incontinence was tried by the test of entering a grotto of Pan at Ephesus (Achilles Tatius 8. 6).
qeou\s o(rk., to swear by the gods; the acc. is cognate (the god being identified with the oath), like o(/rkon o)mnu/nai: Xen. Cyr. 5.4.31 tau=ta...o)/mnumi/ soi qeou/s.
to\ mh/te dr.: for the art., cp. 236.
mh/t' ei/rgasme/nw|: the conjecture mhd' is needless, since mh/te can be understood before bouleu/santi: see O. T. 239 n.
ple/on: cp. 40.
le/gei, between two past tenses: cp. 254.

tis ei(=s. It is at first sight tempting to write tis, ei(=s o(\s pa/ntas. But such emphasis on the idea of ‘one against all’ seems hardly appropriate here. And tis ei(=s sometimes = ei(=s tis: Thuc. 6.61 kai/ tina mi/an nu/kta kai\ kate/darqon: Plat. Soph. 235B (ou)ke/t' e)kfeu/cetai) to\ mh\ ou) tou= ge/nous ei)=nai tou= tw=n qaumatopoiw=n tis ei(=s: Parm. 145D e)/n tini ga\r e(ni\ mh\ o)\n ou)k a)\n e)/ti pou du/naito e)/n ge a(/pasin ei)=nai.
prou)/treyen, impelled, here =h)na/gkase: cp. O. T. 358 n.
ou) ga\r ei)/xomen k.t.l.: ‘for we did not know how to gainsay him, nor how, if we did the thing (advised by him), we could prosper.’

As a)ntifwnei=n means opposing his suggestion, so drw=ntes means acting on it. Others join o(/pws drw=ntes, ‘by what course of action.’ Since, however, a definite proposal was before them—viz., reference to Creon—we must then understand, ‘by what other course’ (than the proposed one). But the sense is, ‘We could not refute him, and, on the other hand, we dreaded your anger if we followed his advice.’ ei)/xomen has the same sense in both clauses. e)/xw, as=‘to know how,’ takes (1) an infin., or (2) a relat. clause with subjunct., as 42, Tr. 705 ou)k e)/xw...poi= gnw/mhs pe/sw. This is merely an indirect form of the deliberative subjunct., poi= gnw/mhs pe/sw; So here, pra/caimen would be pra/cwmen if the principal verb were in a primary tense. The direct question would be, pw=s kalw=s pra/cwmen; Carefully distinguish o(/pws (or pw=s) a)/n with optat. after this ou)k e)/xw, as Tr. 991 ou) ga\r e)/xw pw=s a)\n | ste/rcaimi, I know not how I could. The two constructions are combined again in Ai. 428 ou)/toi s' a)pei/rgein ou)d' o(/pws e)w= le/gein | e)/xw.

soi/ (cp. 234), rare for ei)s se/. After a)nafe/rw ti the pers. is usu. expressed by ei)/s tiva (less oft. by e)pi/ or para/ tiva). But Lysias has the dat. in or. 12. 84 oi(=s ta\s a)pologi/as a)noi/sei, ‘to whom he will carry back his defensive pleas’ (i.e. ‘on whom he will lay the blame,’ and so, again, in or. 7 § 17): yet ib. § 64 ta\s... a)pologi/as ei)s e)kei=non a)naferome/nas. In Mod. Greek a)nafora/ is used of an official ‘report.’
tau=t' e)ni/ka: see on 233: the impf. differs from the aor. only as e)do/kei (‘seemed good’) from e)/doce (‘was resolved’).
pa/los, perh. taken by shaking lots in a helmet (cp. 396, Ai. 1285): kaqairei=, reduces, i.e. ‘condemns’: Lys. or. 13 § 37 th\n...yh=fon...th\n...kaqairou=san, the vote of condemnation.

ta)gaqo/n, iron., whereas his second errand is a true e(/rmaion (397).—a)/kwn ou)x e(kou=sin: cp. Tr. 198 (the herald detained against his will by a throng of questioners) ou)x e/kw\n e(kou=si de\ | cu/nestin.—oi)=d' o(/ti, adverbial (‘doubtless’), like dh=lon o(/ti, cp. 758: so used even in the middle of a clause, as Dem. or. 9 § 1 pa/ntwn, oi)=d' o(/ti, fhsa/ntwn g' a)/n (‘when all, I know, would certainly admit,’ etc.).

e)moi/, ethic dat., ‘for me,’ rather than dat. with bouleu/ei as=‘advises’; the latter dat. is rare (Aesch. Eum. 697 a)stoi=s...bouleu/w se/bein); in Tr. 807, Ai. 1055 the dat. with bouleu/w is a dat. of interest (to plot against one). In poetry the act. can mean, not only ‘to form a plan’ (O. T. 619), or to give counsel (ib. 1417), but also, like the midd., to deliberate.—With mh/ supply e)sti/; cp. 1253; Plat. Theaet. 145C o(/ra mh\ pai/zwn e)/legen, look whether he did not speak (i.e. I suspect that he spoke) in jest. To supply h)=| is also possible (cp. O. C. 1180), but less fitting here.
ti, adv., ‘perchance’: O. T. 969.

qeh/laton, sent by gods (O. T. 992 qeh/laton ma/nteuma), i.e. wrought by them (cp. 285), since there was no trace of human agency (249): not, imposed upon a human agent by a divine commission (as O. T. 255 pra=gma qeh/laton). So in Il. 16.667 Zeus provides supernaturally for the burial of Sarpedon. Cp. O. C. p. xxxv.
h( cu/nnoia, the art. being equiv. to a possessive pron., as 1089 f. th\n glw=ssan, to\n nou=n. Cp. Plat. Rep. 571E ei)s su/nnoian au)to\s au(tw=| a)fiko/menos.
pa/lai, i.e. ever since the fu/lac spoke (249). Cp. 289.

pri
 o)rgh=s kai/ me mestw=sai, ‘before thou hast actually filled me with anger’: kai/ has nothing to do with pri/n, but belongs solely to mestw=sai, a strong word, the stress on which makes it easier for the force of kai/ to pass over the enclitic me. Cp. O. T. 772 tw=| ga a)
 kai\ mei/zoni | le/caim' a)/n: ib. 989 poi/as de\ kai\ gunaiko\s e)kfobei=sq' u(/per; where in each case kai/ goes with the verb. We must distinguish the ordinary combination pri
 kai/, ‘before even,’ which would be in place here only if Creon meant, ‘Cease, before you have so much as angered me’: cp. Tr. 396 a)/|sseis, pri
 h(ma=s ka)nnew/sasqai lo/gous (before we have even renewed our talk): Aristoph. Av. 1033 pe/mpousin h)/dh 'pisko/pous | e)s th
 po/lin, pri
 kai\ tequ/sqai toi=s qeoi=s: Plat. Gorg. 458B pa/lai..., pri
 kai\ u(ma=s e)lqei=n,... epedeica/mhv.
ka)me/ would be unmeaning: no one else is angry.
mestw=sai: Plat. Rep. 330E u(poyi/as...kai\ dei/matos mesto/s, and so often.

po/teron k.t.l. Did they think him good? Or, thinking him bad, did they yet honour him?—e)/krupton (sc. gh=|) = e)/qapton: the word is specially suitable here to the covering with dust (256). Cp. O. C. 621 kekrumme/nos ne/kus: El. 838 krufqe/nta (of Amphiaraus swallowed up by the earth). Bellermann cites an inscr. from Smyrna (Rhein. Mus. 1872, 27 p. 465) pai/dwn se fi/lai xe/res, w(s qe/mis e)sti/, | kru/yan. The impf. (‘were for burying’) refers to the motive present to the agent's mind when the act was undertaken: cp. 19 e)ce/pempon n.

a)mfiki/onas naou/s, temples surrounded by columns, an epith. marking their stateliness and splendour, as Eur. Andr. 1099 e)n peristu/lois do/mois (of a temple), I. T. 406 periki/onas naou/s. The nao\s peri/stulos or peri/pteros (so called because the ceiling of the colonnade projected like a wing, from the cella) had a colonnade on each of its four sides: the nao\s a)mfipro/stulos, only on two (front and back): but, though the latter would satisfy the word a)mfiki/onas, the poet doubtless meant the former.
ka)naqh/mata, votive offerings, such as gold and silver vessels of all kinds; statues; bronze tripods, etc. (Cp.

Her. 1.50; Thuc. 6.46; Isae. or. 7 § 41.) The wealth of Delphi in a)naqh/mata is already proverbial in Il. 9.404; at Thebes the *)ismh/nion (O. T. 21) also seems to have been rich in them. After a)na/qhma the gen. denotes either o( a)naqei/s (as more oft.), or, as here, the divine owner.
gh=n e)kei/nwn (depending on purw/swn), i.e. the territory of Thebes (cp. on 199), since the land belongs to the qeoi\ e)gxw/rioi and poliou=xoi: not merely the teme/nh attached to their shrines.

no/mous diaskedw=n, to scatter the laws abroad, i.e. to shatter the fabric of civil order: cp. Tennyson, Red ruin, and the breaking up of laws. Cic. Agr. 2. 37disturbare... legem. So diasked. of breaking up a treaty (O. C. 620), or a king's power (ib. 1341).
diaskedw=n would suit a)naqh/mata, but could not possibly be joined with gh=n (as if the latter meant ‘State’): hence it must be taken with no/mous only.

tou\s kakou\s timw=ntas … qeou/s; owing to the natural emphasis on tou\s kakou/s, the ambiguity is only grammatical. Cp. Her. 7.150 e)pei\ de/ sfeas paralamba/nein tou\s *(/ellhnas, oblique for e)pei\ de/ sfeas parela/mbanon oi( *(/ellhnes.
tau=ta, the edict, depending on mo/lis fe/rontes (aegre ferentes): kai\ pa/lai, even from the moment when it was proclaimed; cp. 279, where pa/lai only refers back to 249.
po/lews a)/ndres, like gh=s th=sde/ tis (O. T. 236 n.).
e)rro/qoun, muttered: 259n.
e)moi/, against me, dat. of object, as after xalepai/nw, me/mfomai, etc.

ka/ra sei/ontes, ‘tossing the head,’ in defiant menace (so caput quassans, Verg. Aen. 12. 894), instead o going quietly under the yoke. Mor 170 E tou\s tura/nnous a)spa/zontai,...a)lla\ misou=si sigh=| ka/ra sei/ontes (alluding to this v.). So, acc. to Suidas, s.v., Soph. used a)naxaiti/zein (prop. said of a horse throwing the mane back, rearing) as=a)peiqei=n kai\ a)ntitei/nein, ‘to be restive.’
u(po\ zugw=|. Cp. Aesch. Ag. 1639 zeu/cw barei/ais (zeu/glais).

lo/fon, the back of the neck, a word used of draughtanimals (of the human nape, perh. only once, Il. 10.573): hence, fig., Eur. fr. 175 o(/stis de\ pro\s to\ pi=pton eu)lo/fws fe/rei | to\n dai/mon', ou(=tos h(=sso/n e)st' a)no/lbios. id. Eur. Tro. 302ka/rta toi tou)leu/qeron | e)n toi=s toiou/tois duslo/fws fe/rei kaka/, ‘impatiently.’ (Shaksp. Henry VI. Pt. III. 3. 1. 16 yield not thy neck To fortune's yoke.)—Nauck writes the verse thus, nw=ton dikai/ws ei)=xon eu)lo/fws fe/rein, because Eustathius, in alluding to it, once represents it by nw=ton eu)lo/fws ei)=xon (on Od. 5.285), and twice by nw=ton eu)lo/fws fe/rein (on Il. 10.573, Od. 10.169). But Eustath. was quoting, or rather paraphrasing, from memory, and confused our verse with Eur. fr. 175 (quoted above); also, perhaps, with Lycophron 776 eu)lo/fw| nw/tw| fe/rein. His references to Sophocles are often loose and inexact. See Appendix.
dikai/ws, loyally. Donaldson had a too ingenious view that the word here meant, ‘with
equal poise’ (New Crat. 371).—w(s = w(/ste (O. T. 84): ste/rgein, tolerare: Tr. 486(Lichas advising Deianeira with regard to Iolè) ste/rge th\n gunai=ka, be patient of her.
tw=nde, masc., the malcontents (for e)k, cp. 63).
tou/tous, the watchers of the corpse: the pronouns joined as in 39 (n.).

ei)rga/sqai is best taken with e)cepi/stamai: cp. 1092 e)pista/mesqa...au)to\n...lakei=n. The inf., instead of the partic., with e)pi/stamai, seems unknown in Attic prose, except, of course, where the sense is ‘to know how.’ Cp. 472. The inf. might, indeed, depend on parhgme/nous, as e)pa/gw (to induce) oft. takes an inf.: but (a) as a matter of fact, an infin. seems not to occur after para/gw in this sense: and (b) it may be noticed that Attic idiom often prefers the form, ‘induced by them, he did it,’ to, ‘he was induced by them to do it’: e.g. Xen. Mem. 4.8.5 pollou\s...lo/gw| paraxqe/ntes a)pe/kteinan: Dem. or. 5 § 10 oi(=s e)paxqe/ntes u(mei=s...proei=sqe *fwke/as. For this participial expression of the leading idea, see n. on O. C. 1038.

no/mism', institutum. This primary and general sense of the word was almost confined to poetry ( Aesch. Th. 269*(ellhniko\n no/misma qusta/dos boh=s), the special sense, ‘current coin,’ being the ordinary one. For the other sense, the usual word was no/mimon (or no/mos). Hence in Aristoph. Nub. 247, when Socrates says, qeoi\ | h(mi=n no/mism' ou)k e)/sti, Strepsiades rejoins, tw=| ga\r o)/mnut'; h)\ | sidare/oisin, w(/sper e)n *buzanti/w| (i.e. if gods are not current with you, do you swear by iron coin?): where the schol. remarks that no/misma meant pote\ me\n to\ no/mimon e)/qos, pote\ de\ to\ ko/mma tou= tetupwme/nou xalkou=.
e)/blaste: cp. O. C. 611 blasta/nei d' a)pisti/a.

porqei=, ‘sacks’ (not merely, in a general sense, ‘ruins’): money invites attack, and often purchases betrayal: cp. Hor. Carm. 3. 16. 13diffidit urbium Portas uir Macedo et subruit aemulos Reges muneribus.

to/d' (after tou=to: cp. 39) a)/ndras, individual citizens, as distinguished from po/leis. e)cani/st. do/mwn, drives them from their cities by corrupt intrigue,—for which the sta/seis of democrat and oligarch in Greek cities gave many openings. The phrase is strikingly illustrated by the verses in which Timocreon of Rhodes, when an exile, assailed Themistocles ( Plut. Them. 21), as tou\s me\n kata/gwn a)di/kws, tou\s d' e)kdiw/kwn, tou\s de\ kai/nwn, | a)rguri/wn u(po/plews.

to/d' e)kd. kai\ paralla/ssei, this trains and perverts good minds of men, i(/stasqai pro\s ai)sxr. pra/gm., to address themselves to base deeds. paralla/ssei=‘alters sideways’; i.e. causes to turn out of a straight course into an oblique course; hence, like para/gei, parastre/fei, perverts. Cp. Arist. Pol. 8. 7§ 7 ai( yuxai\ parestramme/nai th=s kata\ fu/sin e(/cews (their minds being warped from their natural condition). Since paralla/ssei implies a bad training, it can be followed, like e)qi/zei and like words, by an infin.: it is unnecessary, then, to make i(/stasqai, in its relation to paralla/ssei, merely epexegetic (‘so that they set themselves’); though it might, of course, be so. Wecklein takes kai\ paralla/ssei as parenthetic = paralla/ssousa: but this, too, is needless, nor is it supported by 537 (where see n.).

i(/stasqai pro/s ti means here, ‘to set oneself facing it,’ so ‘to turn to it, address oneself to it,’ just like tre/pesqai pro/s ti: cp. Plat. Rep. 452E pro\s a)/llon tina\ skopo
 sthsa/menos h)\ to
 tou= a)gaqou=, ‘having set himself to some other aim,’ etc. Distinguish some other phrases with i(/stasqai and pro/s which are not really similar: Thuc. 3.11 pro\s o(/ ti xrh\ sth=nai (a power to which they could rally): 4. 56 pro\s th
 e)kei/nwn gnw/mhn a)ei\ e(/stasan (they had always sided with the Athenian policy): 6. 34 pro\s ta\ lego/mena kai\ ai( gnw=mai i(/stantai (men's minds adapt their attitudes to what is said).

panourgi/as … e)/xein: showed men how to practise villanies. For e)/xein of the moral habit, cp. Od. 1.368 mnhsth=res u(pe/rbion u(/brin e)/xontes: Il. 9.305 lu/ssan e)/xwn o)loh/n. The inf. might be epexegetic, but really depends on e)/deicen as implying ‘taught’: cp. Eur. Med. 195 ou)dei\s lu/pas | hu(/reto... | w)|dai=s pau/ein (has found out how to...). dei/knumi of invention, as Ai. 1195 ds stugerw=n e)/deicen o(/plwn | *(/ellasi koino\n *)/arh: fr. 396. 6 stratou= fruktwri/an | e)/deice, ka)ne/fhnen ou) dedeigme/na (Palamedes).

ei)de/nai, ‘to know,’ i.e. to be conversant with (cp. on 71) panto\s e)/rgou dusse/b., impiety of (shown in) any deed,=pa=n dussebe\s e)/rgon (cp. 603 lo/gou t' a)/noia): for pa=s, cp. O. C. 761 n. Note panto\s e)/rg. after panourgi/as: the familiar use of panourgi/a extenuates the force to which etymology entitles it, while in pa=n e)/rgon that whole force is felt: so pa=n poiei=n is stronger than panourgei=n, and pa=n le/gein than parrhsia/zesqai ( Plat. Apol. 39A e)a/n tis tolma=| pa=n poiei=n kai\ le/gein). Cp. Soph. Ph. 407panto\s a)\n lo/gou kakou= | glw/ssh| qigo/nta kai\ panourgi/as, where pa/shs must be supplied, showing how panourgi/a could be used without direct reference to its derivation.
h)/nusan: cp. 231.
xro/nw| pote/, at some time or other: i.e. they will be caught sooner or later. With dou=nai di/khn: Ph. 1041ti/sasqe, ti/sasq' a)lla\ tw=| xro/nw| pote/.

e)ce/pracan w(s (=w(/ste, 292), as Aesch. Pers. 723 kai\ to/d' e)ce/pracen, w(/ste *bo/sporon klh=|sai me/gan; The verb is here ironical; cp. Plat. Gorg. 479A to\ au)to\ diapepragme/noi ei)si\n w(/sper a)\n ei)/ tis toi=s megi/stois nosh/masi sunisxo/menos diapra/caito mh\ dido/nai di/khn .. toi=s i)atroi=s, mhde= i)atreu/esqai.
*zeu/s, in his quality of *basileu/s (Xen. Anab. 3.1.12), is fitly invoked by a king who vows that he will uphold the royal authority. Cp. 487.
o(/rkios, adverbial: O. C. 1637 kath/|nesen ta/d' o(/rkios (n.). Cp. 823 (lugrota/tan).

to\n au)to/xeira, the very man (248) whose hand strewed the dust, said with an emphasis corresponding to that with which the Guard had insisted on the absence of any clue (249). For au)to-, cp. 56, 172. ta/fou = tafh=s, as 490, 534, O. T. 1447: in a symbolical sense like that of qa/yas (246).

mou=nos: cp. O. T. 304 n.— ‘Death alone shall not suffice for you,’ already implies a threat of torture. To make this threat explicit, pri
 a)
 . . dhlw/shte is added, as if merely ou) qanei=sqe had preceded. ‘(You shall not die,) until you have first been hung up alive, and have revealed (the authorship of) this outrage.’ They are to be suspended by the hands or arms, and flogged. Cp. Ai. 106 qanei=n ga au)to
 ou)/ ti/ pw qe/lw . . pri
 a)
 deqei\s pro\s ki/on' e(rkei/ou ste/ghs . . ma/stigi prw=ton nw=ta foinixqei\s qa/nh|. Phorm. 1. 4. 43 ego plectar pendens. In Plat. Legg. 872B a slave who has slain a free man is to be flogged, and then (if he does not die under the lash, e)a/nper biw=| paio/menos) put to death by other means. Other views of kremastoi/ refer it to (1) mere suspension, as a torture, like that of Melanthius in Od. 22.175: (2) stretching on a cross-like frame; cp. Alexis ap. Athen. 134 A h(/dist' a)naph/caim' au)to
 e)pi\ cu/lou labw/n. Impalement (a)nastauro/w, a)naskolopi/zw) is certainly not meant.— zw=ntes kremastoi/, ‘suspended alive,’ as zw=n is oft. joined with another partic.: Xen. Anab. 2.6.29 ou)x w(/sper oi( a)/lloi . . a)potmhqe/ntes ta\s kefala/s, o(/sper ta/xistos qa/natos dokei= ei)=nai, a)lla\ zw=n ai)kisqei\s e)niauto/n.

dhlw/shq': as to the belief that torture was sure to wring the truth from slaves, cp. Isae. or. 8. 12 o(po/tan dou=loi kai\ e)leu/qeroi parage/nwntai, . . ou) xrh=sqe tai=s tw=n e)leuqe/rwn marturi/ais, a)lla\ tou\s dou/lous basani/zontes ou(/tw zhtei=te eu(rei=n th\n a)lh/qeian tw=n genome/nwn. (Cp. Selections from the Attic Orators, p. 358 n.)
u(/brin, in concrete sense (O. C. 1029).

i(/n' … a(rpa/zhte, with grim irony, since they are to die before they can apply the lesson. So O. C. 1377 (Oed. calls down destruction upon his sons) i(/n' a)ciw=ton tou\s futeu/santas se/bein, where see n. Cp. below, 716.
to\ ke/rdos, accus. (cp. 1242): e)/nqen oi)ste/on (e)sti/).
ma/qhq', aor., learn once for all: but a(rpa/zhte, pres., go on stealing.
e)c a(/pantos, from every source, with to\ kerdai/nein: Xen. Mem. 2.9.4 ou) ga\r h)=n oi(=os a)po\ panto\s kerdai/nein: Ar. Th. 735w)= poti/statai | ka)k panto\s u(mei=s mhxanw/menai
piei=n. In O. C. 807 e(c a(/pantos eu)= le/gei =speaks well on any theme (starting from anything).
ti suits a timid appeal: cp. O. C. 1414 i(keteu/w se peisqh=nai/ ti/ moi.
de/ (Boeckh), though favoured by L, could not be justified as an expostulatory ‘now.’ dw/seis: O. C. 1287 didou\s e)moi\ | le/cai.
ou(/tws, ‘without more ado,’ w(/sper e)/xw: Ph. 1066ou)de\ sou= fwnh=s e)/ti | genh/somai prosfqegkto/s, a)ll' ou(/tws a)/pei; Phaedr. 237 C nu=n me\n ou(/tws ou)k e)/xw ei)pei=n (‘off-hand’).
i)/w, delib. subjunct., somewhat rare in pres. (O. T. 651).

kai\ nu=n w(s = w(s kai\ nu=n: for the hyperbaton of w(s, cp. Ai. 590, El. 949, 1243, etc.— a)niarw=s, with i_: but Eur. , like Ar. , has a)ni^aro/s ( Eur. Or. 230 etc.): Aesch. does not use the adj., though he has a)/ni^os. a)ni/a (i_) is used by Soph. , but not by Aesch. or
e)n with w)si/n, through association with such phrases as Aesch. Pers. 605 boa=| d' e)n w)si\ ke/lados.
e)pi/ with th=| yuxh=| denotes the seat, and, equally with e)n, here=our ‘in’: cp. Il. 1.55 tw=| ga\r e)pi\ fresi\ qh=ke qea/.
ti/ de\ is right, not ti/ dai\ (L): see Appendix.

r(uqmi/zeis, bring under r(uqmo/s, i.e. reduce to a clear form, define, o(/pou (e)sti/), with respect to its seat (i.e. whether it is in the ears or in the mind). Cp. Metaphys. 11. 10 e)a\n mh\ r(uqmi/sh| tis, unless one reduce (the opinions) to a clear form, or method. So he oft. associates r(uqmo/s with sxh=ma, as Phys. Ausc. 8. 3 to\ sxhmatizo/menon kai\ r(uqmizo/menon, what is being reduced to form and system. For the epexegetic o(/pou cp. Ai. 103 h(= tou)pi/tripton ki/nados e)ch/rou m' o(/pou; ib. 890 a)/ndra mh\ leu/ssein o(/pou.—Cp. Shaksp. Troil. 4. 5. 244 That I may give the local wound a name, And make distinct the very breach whereout Hector's great spirit flew.
ta\s fre/nas...ta\ d' w)=t', acc. defining se: Ph. 1301me/qes me xei=ra: cp. on O. C. 113.
oi)/m' w(s, impatient, as Aristoph. Ach. 590 oi)/m' w(s teqnh/ceis: elsewhere in Soph. it expresses pity or grief (1270, Ai. 354, 587).

la/lhma suits Creon's contemptuous impatience. The schol. (see crit. n.) prob. read a)/lhma (‘a knave,’ lit., ‘fine meal,’ from a)le/w): cp. Au. 430 paipa/lhm' o(/lon. But if Creon used that word, he would seem to give the man credit for real subtlety: he would be taking him too seriously. Thus a)/lhma is the word applied by Ajax to his mortal foe, Odysseus (Ai. 381, 389), who is similarly called pa/nsofon kro/thma in fr. 827: cp. Ph. 927panourgi/as | deinh=s te/xnhm' e)/xqiston (Neoptolemus). Cp. 756 dou/leuma: O. T. 85 kh/deuma (n.).
dh=lon, like e)narge/s (cp. on 263).

‘At any rate (ou)=n—babbler or not) I certainly have not done this deed.’ ei)mi/ is supplied with poih/sas. For ou)/koun … ge cp. 993, Ph. 907NE. ai)sxro\s fanou=mai . . *f*i. ou)/koun e)n oi(=s ge dra=|s: e)n oi)=s d' au)da=|s, o)knw=: and so oft., as O. T. 565, 1357, O. C. 848.

‘Yes, (you have done it,) and that, too, at the cost of betraying,’ etc. The particle ge implies the contradiction, e)poi/hsas: kai\ tau=ta goes with the participle (prodou/s): cp. O.T. 37, El. 614 th\n tekou=san u(/brisen, | kai\ tau=ta thlikou=tos. So Lat., hominem . . studiis optimis deditum, idque a puero ( Cic. Fam. 13. 16).

h)= deino/n. Creon has pronounced the Guard guilty on mere do/ca, without proof. The Guard says, ‘It is grievous that, when a man does harbour suspicions (w(=| dokei= ge), those suspicions should at the same time (kai\) be false.’ ge means that, in such a matter, hasty do/ca should be avoided altogether. It is always bad to assume a man guilty without proof; it is worse when the rash assumption is also erroneous. Cp. do/khsis a)gnw/s, ‘a blind suspicion’ (O. T. 681), and ib. 608 gnw/mh| d' a)dh/lw| mh/ me xwri\s ai)tiw=. Eur. Bacch. 311 mhd' h)\n dokh=|s me/n, (h( de\ do/ca sou nosei=,) | fronei=n do/kei ti.—Nauck supposes a play on two senses of dokei=n, w(=| dokei= (or, as he reads, dokh=|) having been suggested by e)/doce tw=| dh/mw|, etc.: ‘'Tis monstrous that he who decides should have false views.’ But, even if the absolute w(=| dokei= could be thus used, the colloquial frequency of dokei= (moi poiei=n ti) in Aristophanes suffices to show that w(=| dokei= could not, to an Athenian ear, have suggested ‘the ruler’ or ‘the judge’: it would have seemed to mean merely one who ‘proposes,’ not ‘disposes.’—Schütz makes dokei=n depend on dokei=: ‘'Tis grievous when a man is resolued to believe even what is false’ (if only he wishes to believe it). A bold speech for the Guard to Creon; nor does it satisfy either ge or kai/.

ko/myeue . . th\n do/can, make neat sayings about it,—referring to the rhetorical form of the last verse, with its parh/xhsis, dokei=...dokei=n. Not necessarily, ‘quibble upon it,’—as if dokei=n had been used in two different senses,—a view of ko/myeue which has been brought to support the interpretations of v. 323 mentioned above. The verb is usually midd., often with acc., as Eur. I. A. 333 eu)= keko/myeusai ponhra/ (‘thou hast given subtle form to wicked pleas’): Plat. Lach. 197D pre/pei...sofisth=| ta\ toiau=ta ma=llon komyeu/esqai.

th
 do/can, that do/ca of yours: cp. 96: El. 1110 ou)k oi)=da th
 sh
klhdo/n' (the klhdw/n of which you speak), not merely, ‘the word do/ca.’ If the v. l. to\ do/can (see cr. n.) was intended to mean the latter, it should have been to\ do/ca.

nun (‘very well,’ like ou)=n) is better than nu=n, which would mean ‘for the present’ (as opposed to the near future).— tau=ta … tou\s drw=ntas = tou\s tau=ta drw=ntas: cp. 384: the pron. gains emphasis by its place.
deila/, as involving mean treachery towards king and city. Theognis 835 a)ll' a)ndrw=n te bi/h| kai\ ke/rdea deila\ kai\ u(/bris | pollw=n e)c a)gaqw=n e)s kako/tht' e)/balen (sc. h(ma=s).

deina/ (L) is defended by Seyffert as=‘flagitious,’ by Whitelaw as=‘clever’ (iron.), ‘your wondrous winnings.’ In some forms of minuscule writing l and n could easily be confused: cp. O. T. 1130 cunalla/cas, where the first l has been made from n: and O. C. 1164, where mo/non has been restored from molo/nt'.

a)ll' prefacing the wish (O. C. 421): eu(reqei/h sc. o( drw=n (319): ma/list', denoting the best thing that could happen (O. T. 926 n.).—ka)
 for kai\ is needless. We find kai\ e)a/n...kai\ e)a/n: e)a/n te...e)a/n te: but, as a rule, e)a/n (or e)a/n te)...kai\ [not kai\ e)a
] mh/: e.g. Eur. Hec. 751 ka)
 tu/xw ka)
 mh\ tu/xw: Plat. Legg. 660E e)a/n te me/gas...e)a/n te smikro\s...h)=, kai\ (‘and’) e)a
 plouth=| kai\ mh/. For the conjunctive form in stating alternatives, cp. O. C. 488 n.
kai\ with nu=n, not with ga/r.
gnw/mhs, of reasonable forecast, cp. O. T. 1087.

div2.p: First sta/simon. 1st strophe (332—342)=1st antistrophe (343—353): 2nd strophe (354—364)=2nd antistr. (365 —375). For the metres see Metrical Analysis.

The Chorus had not thought it possible that any one should brave death to bury the corpse (220). But the deed has been done, and without leaving a trace (252). And Creon has silenced the suggestion that gods did it (278). The train of thought is continued in this ode. Its theme is man's daring,—his inventiveness, and the result to his happiness.

Man is master of sea and land; he subdues all other creatures; he has equipped his life with all resources, except a remedy against death. His skill brings him to prosperity, when he observes divine and human laws, but to ruin when he breaks them.—At that moment Antigone is led in, and the coryphaeus speaks the closing anapaests (376—383).

div3.p: polla\ … kou)de/n. Schol. e)n sxh/mati ei)=pen, a)nti\ tou=, pollw=n o)/ntwn tw=n deinw=n, ou)de/n e)stin a)nqrw/pou deino/teron. The sxh=ma is the rhetorical parataxis,

kai/ being equiv. to ‘and yet’: cp. Tr. 1046 w)= polla\ dh\ kai\ qerma\ kou) lo/gw| kaka/ | … moxqh/sas e)gw/: | kou)/pw toiou=ton ou)/t' a)/koitis h( *dio\s | prou)/qhken k.t.l. It is stronger to say, ‘they are great; and he is greater’: than, ‘though they are great, he is greater.’

ta\ deina/, not ‘dread,’ nor ‘able,’ but ‘wonderful.’ There is a certain resemblance to Aesch. Ch. 585 ff. polla\ me\n ga= tre/fei | deina\ deima/twn a)/xh...a)ll' u(pe/rtolmon a)ndro\s fro/nhma ti/s le/goi; but there deina/=‘dread,’ and the scope is limited to the violence of human passion.

tou=to, sc. to\ deino/n, this wondrous power, man. The schol. quotes Theocr. 15. 83 sofo/n toi xrh=m' a)/nqrwpos. Not adverbial with xwrei=, ‘so’ (in a way corresponding with his deino/ths), as Bellermann takes it, comparing O. T. 1005 (tou=t' a)fiko/mhn), where see n.— pe/ran, properly, ‘to the further side of’ (trans). The point here is that man dares to cross the sea. pe/ra (ultra), which Blaydes prefers, would imply wanderings (not merely over, but) beyond sea.
