A European visitor to New York goes pe/ran po/ntou: to San Francisco, pe/ra. Cp. O. C. 885 and p. 279.

xeimeri/w| no/tw| with xwrei=, goes (driven) by it: cp. Od. 14.253 e)ple/omen *bore/h| a)ne/mw|, and ib. 299 (of the ship) h( d' e)/qeen *bore/h| a)ne/mw|. The dat. might be merely ‘with’ (dat. of circumstance), but is better taken as instrumental. Cp. 588 pnoai=s. Some make xeimeri/w| no/tw| a temporal dat., like w(/ra| xeimw=nos, which it can hardly be.— Soph. is thinking of the Aegean, where the prevailing winds were from the N. or N.W. in spring and summer, while stormy south winds were associated with winter: Hesiod warns a man with a voyage before him not to await xeimw=n' e)pio/nta no/toio/ te deina\s a)h/tas, | o(/s t' w)/rine qa/lassan o(marth/sas *dio\s o)/mbrw| | pollw=| o)pwrinw=|, xalepo\n de/ te po/nton e)/qhken. The epithet xeimeri/w| aptly distinguishes this wintry no/tos from that gentle south breeze (now called the ‘embates’) which regularly sets in at sunset in the fair season (cp. Curt. Hist. Gr. 1. 14).

peribr … u(p' oi)/dmasin, passing under swelling waters which open depths around: i.e. he is in the trough of a heavy sea, while on each side the waves rise above his ship, threatening to engulf it. Verg. Aen. 1. 106 his unda dehiscens Terram inter fluctus aperit. bru/xios, ‘of the depths’ (bruxi/a...h)xw\ bronta=s, Aesch. PV 1082), is formed as if from bru/c, of which Oppian uses acc. bru/xa (‘depth of the sea,’ Hal. 2. 588). u(pobru/xios=‘under water,’ and so neut. pl. adv. u(po/bruxa (Od. 5.319 etc.). peribru/xios occurs only here. For the i_ before br cp. 348, 1104, 1117. The schol.'s h)xw/desi means that peribru/xios was taken as' ‘roaring around’ (bru_xa/omai), where the u would be long, against metre (cp. 347). The Homeric a)mfi\ de\ ku=ma | be/bruxen r(o/qion (Od. 5.411) might suggest this view.
u(perta/tan, highest, as eldest, pammh/twr (Aesch. PV 90), and pambw=tis (Ph. 392): Plat. Tim. 40C gh=n... prw/thn kai\ presbuta/thn qew=n o(/soi e)nto\s ou)ranou= gego/nasi.

a)kama/tan: this form of the fem. occurs only here, unless a)kama/th|si (and not a)kama/toisi) xe/ressin be right in Hes. Th. 747, but is warranted by similar epic forms in tragedy, as a)qana/tas (gen.) Aesch. Ch. 619, Eur. Phoen. 235: a)dmh/tan El. 1238 (and -hs in dial. O. C. 1321). For the initial a_, cp. the epic a)qa/natos, a)gora/asqe, etc. (and see Introd. to Homer, Appendix, note 5, p. 195): but in El. 164 we find 'a^ka/mata.

a)potru/etai, prop., wears away for his own purposes (midd.), —fatigat, vexes (with constant ploughing). Earth is ‘immortal,’ and not to be exhausted; but man's patient toil subdues it to his use. Cp. Tr. 124 a)potru/ein e)lpi/da, to wear it out.—Not, ‘wearies himself by tilling’ the soil.

i)llome/nwn a)ro/trwn, as the ploughs go backwards and forwards,— turning at the end of one furrow, and going down the next. Cp. Nicander Ther. 478 feu=ge d' a)ei\ skolih/n te kai\ ou) mi/an a)trapo\n i)/llwn, ‘in flying (from the snake), always make your course wind (i)/llwn) from side to side, instead of keeping it straight.’ Xen. Cyn. 6. 15ku/nes e)ci/llousai ta\ i)/xnh, ‘puzzling out the tracks,’ i.e. going backwards and forwards till they have found a clue. As to the spelling i)/llw uersus ei)/llw, see Appendix. It is needless to write a)ro/twn, ‘ploughingseasons’ (Tr. 825), and to take i)llome/nwn as=peritellome/nwn. The picture of the ploughs at work is more vivid; and, with a)ro/twn, e)/tos ei)s e)/tos would be feebly redundant.

e)/tos ei)s e)/tos, an adverbial phrase, like ‘year in, year out’: for the use of the simple acc. in temporal adverbs (like a)wri/an) see O. T. 1138 n.; for ei)s, Od. 9.134 ma/la ken baqu\ lh/i+on ai)ei\ | ei)s w(/ras a)mw=|en (‘as each year comes round’): Theocr. 18. 15 kh)s e)/tos e)c e)/teos: so ei)s ne/wta (next year), and the Gk Mod. xro/no se\ (=ei)s) xro/no, ‘year after year.’

i(ppei/w| ge/nei, the ‘offspring of horses,’ meaning ‘mules’; which are ‘far better than oxen to drag the jointed plough through the deep fallow’ (Il. 10.352). Arist. Rhet. 3.2 § 14 o\ *simwni/dhs, o(/te me
 e)di/dou misqo
 o)li/gon au)tw=| o\ nikh/sas toi=s o)reu=sin, ou)k h)/qele poiei=n w(s dusxerai/nwn ei)s h(mio/nous poiei=n: e)pei\ d' ikano
 e)/dwken, e\poi/hse, xai/ret', a)ellopo/dwn qu/gatres i(/ppwn. As this story suggests, the very fact that the ordinary Attic word for ‘mule’ was h(mi/onos (adj. o)riko/s) might lead an Attic poet to prefer such a periphrasis as i(/ppeion ge/nos. The objections to taking i(ppei/w| ge/nei as simply =i(/ppoisare,that (1) Greek ploughmen used oxen or mules more than horses, and (2) the achievement of taming the horse (350) is thus anticipated. Some understand both horses and mules, giving ge/nei a double sense—rather awkwardly, I think.

poleu/wn, kata\ su/nesin after tou=to. Cp. Od. 11.90 h)=lqe d' e)pi\ yuxh\ *qhbai/ou *teiresi/ao, | xru/seon skh=ptron e)/xwn: 16. 476 mei/dhsen d' i(erh\ i)\s *thlema/xoio, | e)s pate/r' o)fqalmoi=sin i)dw/n: Il. 11.690 e)lqw\n ga\r e)ka/kwse bi/h *(hraklhei/h. But as Soph. would write *p*o*l*e*u*o*n, it was the easier to read po/leuon.

Man's conquests over the animal world are here taken in two groups. First, those of which the primary aim is to kill or to capture. Here the means is netting (a)mfibalw\n spei/raisi diktuoklw/stois), in its threefold sporting use, as applied to fowling (o)rni/qwn), hunting (qhrw=n), and fishing (po/ntou fu/sin). Secondly, those conquests which aim at reducing wild animals to man's service. These are effected by mhxanai/ (349),— arts of taming and training. And their result is aptly expressed by the word
kratei=: here, man is not merely the slayer or captor; he becomes the master of docile toilers. The horse and the bull are types.

Thus, in this ode, the scale of achievement ever ascends: man (1) conquers inanimate nature: (2) makes animals his captives: (3) trains them to be his servants: (4) develops his own social and intellectual life.

koufono/wn is merely a general epithet, ‘light-hearted,’ ‘blithe and careless’; Theognis 580 smikrh=s o)/rniqos kou=fon e)/xousa no/on: cp. the proverbial phraseology of Athens, a)/nqrwpos o)/rnis, a)sta/qmhtos, peto/menos, | a)te/kmartos, ou\de\n ou)de/pot' e)n tau)tw=| me/nwn ( Au. 169). The epithet is given to e)/rwtes below (617), and to eu)hqi/a in Aesch. PV 383.— Not, ‘quick-witted’ (and therefore harder to catch).
a)mfibalw\n with spei/raisi d.: it can precede the dat. by so much, because its meaning is already clear, and the dat. is merely a poet. amplification.

po/ntou … ei)nali/an fu/sin, a brood living in the waters of the sea, the tautology being only of the same order as in po/ntos a(lo/s, a(lo\s e)n pela/gessin, pe/lagos qala/sshs, etc.—spei/raisi diktuokl., instr. dat. with a)mfibalw/n, in the coils of woven nets: for the adj. compounded with a subst. (di/ktuon) cognate in sense to spei=ra, see n. on O. C. 716 eu)h/retmos pla/ta.— Au. 528 mentions e(/rkh, nefe/las, di/ktua, phkta/s as nets used by the fowler (o)rniqeuth/s). In hunting the lion, bear, boar, deer, hare, etc., various nets were used; the di/ktuon, to enclose large spaces; the e)no/dion, to close passages; the a)/rkus (cassis) or tunnel-net. The chief fishing-nets were the a)mfi/blhstron (castingnet), and the sagh/nh (drag-net, whence seine, sean).

perifradh/s. Eustath. p. 135, 25 fradh/s...o(/qen su/nqeton o( para\ *sofoklei= a)rifradh\s a)nh/r. This was evidently a mere slip of memory. Neither Soph. nor Eur, uses any compound with a)ri or e)ri, though Aesch. has a)ri/dakrus, e)ri/dmatos, e)riku/mwn.

mhxanai=s. maxanai=s in Ai. 181 and maxana=| in Aesch. Th. 133 are the only instances in which Tragedy gives a Doric form to words from this stem.— a)grau/lou, having his au)lh/, or dwelling, in the open country, as opposed to a domesticated animal: Eur. Bacch. 1187 pre/pei g' w(/ste qh\r a)/graulos fo/bh|. For the combination with o)ressiba/ta cp. Plat. Crat. 394E to\ qhriw=des th=s fu/sews kai\ to\ a)/grion au)tou= kai\ to\ o)reino/n.
lasiau/xena/ q'. The elision at the end of the verse (e)pisunaloifh/) is comparatively rare in lyrics, as in dialogue (1031); but cp. 595 pi/ptont', 864 au)toge/nnht'.

o)xma/zetai, he tames, a)mfi\ lo/fon zugw=n, putting the yoke about its neck. o)xma/zw (prop., ‘to get a firm hold upon’) was esp. used of breaking horses: Eur. El. 816 (Thessalians honour a man) o(/stis tau=ron a)rtamei/) (cuts to pieces) kalw=s, | i(/ppous t' o)xma/zei. Schol. on

Rhod. 1. 743 kuri/ws e)sti
 o)xma/sai to\ i(/ppon u(po\ xalino
 a)gagei=n h)\ u(po\ zugo/n. The midd. voice does not occur elsewhere; but this cannot be regarded as an objection, when we remember how many rare middle forms occur in the dramatists. Thus prosorwme/na in O. C. 244 is a solitary example of that verb in the midd., and if the license could be taken with so common a word, much more might it be allowed with a comparatively rare one. Blaydes writes o)xma/zei u(p' a)mfi/lofon zugo/n: but the Ms. e(/cetai indicates that the verb, whatever it was, was of the midd. form. o)xma/zetai was published by G. Schöne in 1833, and by Franz in 1846: they appear to have made the conjecture independently. Donaldson (1848) printed o(xma/zetai a)mfi\ lo/fon zugw=n, and seems to ascribe zugw=n to Franz and Schöne; though Franz, at least, proposed a)mfi\ lo/fon zugw=|. zugw=n has been revived (seemingly without knowledge of a predecessor) by H. Schütz (1886). Sophocles would write *a*m*f*i*l*o*f*o*n*z*u*g*o*n, and thus zugw=n changes no letter. Aesch. used the fut. zugw/sw (fr. 110), and Soph. has the verbal zugwtw=n (El. 702). To a)mfilo/fw| zugw=| it may be objected that, being clear, it was not likely to become -on -o/n: but, when a)mfi/lofon had once been written, zugw=n (or zugw=|) would easily become zugo/n. As to the schol. on a)mfi/lofon,—a)nti\ tou=, peribalw
 au)tw=| zugo
 peri\ to
 lo/fon, u(pa/gei,—it cannot fairly be urged for zugw=n (or for any partic.), since it may be merely a paraphrase of a)mfi/lofon.—Schütz's e)fe/zetai is attractive; for the acc. he cp. Aesch. Eum. 409 bre/tas...e)fhme/nw|, Eur. Helen 1493 *eu)rw/tan e)fezo/menai. Add Aesch. Ag. 664 nau=n qe/lous' e)fe/zeto. The sense would be, ‘seats himself behind the horse’ (in a chariot): cp. Il. 5.46 i(/ppwn e)pibhso/menon, etc. But, though oxen were used for draught, e)fe/zetai suits tau=ron less well. The sense, ‘tames,’ is clearly that which we require. See Appendix.

fqe/gma k.t.l. The phrase, ‘man has taught himself speech,’ should not be pressed as if the poet was thinking of a theory on the origin of language. It was the Eleatic view that language came qe/sei, not fu/sei, and Soph, may have known that; but by his e)dida/cato he meant simply, ‘developed for his own benefit, by his own effort.’ So Isocrates (or. 3 § 6) conceives primitive man as living in a brutal state, and emerging from it by the development of speech and thought,— lo/gos being one of the human faculties (tw=n e)no/ntwn e)n th=| tw=n a)nqrw/pwn fu/sei), and the distinctive one:—e)ggenome/nou d' h(mi=n tou= pei/qein a)llh/lous kai\ dhlou=n pro\s h(ma=s au)tou\s peri\ w\=n a)\n boulhqw=men, ou) mo/non tou= qhriwdw=s zh=n a)phlla/ghmen, a)lla\ kai\ sunelqo/ntes po/leis w)|ki/samen kai\ no/mous e)qe/meqa kai\ te/xnas eu(/romen. Cp. Hor. Sat. 1. 3. 103 (men fought,) Donec verba, quibus voces sensusque notarent, Nominaque invenere: dehinc absistere bello, Oppida coeperunt munire et ponere leges. The Aeschylean Prometheus ( P. V. 444) claims to have made men e)/nnous...kai\ frenw=n e)phbo/lous, but not (like Shelley's Prometheus) to have also given them language. Cp. Peile's chapter ‘On the Nature of Language’ (Primer of Philology), p. 156: ‘In this way then we may conceive of the
beginnings of speech...Speech is the development, through imitation, of a capacity of man—the capacity of making a noise.’ This is quite compatible with e)dida/cato.

a)nemo/en fro/nhma: cp. Il. 15.80 w(s d' o(/t' a)\n a)i/+ch| no/os a)ne/ros...| w(\s kraipnw=s memaui=a die/ptato: Od. 7.36 tw=n ne/es w)kei=ai w(sei\ ptero\n h)e\ no/hma: O. C. 1081 a)ellai/a taxu/rrwstos peleia/s: fr. 621 a)ella/des fwnai/. Not ‘lofty,’ in which sense a)nemo/en could be said only of a high place. Cp. Shelley, Prometheus: ‘He gave man speech, and speech created thought, Which is the measure of the universe.’ Soph. does not imply that speech created thought; he is rather thinking of them as developed (in their riper forms) together.

a)stuno/mous o)rga/s, ‘such dispositions as regulate cities’; i.e. those feelings which lead men to organise social life, and to uphold the social order by their loyalty. For o)rga/s, cp. Ai. 639 suntro/fois | o)rgai=s, the dispositions that have grown with his growth: Eur. Tro. 53 e)ph/|nes' o)rga\s h)pi/ous. The relation of fqe/gma to a)stuno/moi o)rgai/ is illustrated by Arist. Pol. 1.2 § 12, where he is showing that man, more than any other a)gelai=on zw=|on, is politiko/n: ‘Speech is intended to explain what is expedient and what is hurtful,—and so also what is just and unjust. It is characteristic of man, as compared with other animals, that he alone has a sense of good and evil, just and unjust; and it is the association of beings with this sense that make a Family and a State.’

e)dida/cato here=simply au)to\s e(auto
 e)di/dace. The notion, ‘men taught each other,’ ‘learned by mutual converse,’ cannot be extracted from it. The passive dida/skomai as=manqa/nein is freq., but I can find no parallel for the use of the aor. midd. here. For the ordinary use, cp. Plat. Menop. 93 D to
 ui(o
 i(ppe/a...e)dida/cato (had his son taught to ride): so Plat. Rep. 467E (didacame/nous, ‘when we have had them taught’); [Plat. ] Plat. Theag. 122E, De Virt. 377 B; Xen. Cyr. 1.6.2, Mem. 4. 4. 5; Aristoph. Nub. 1338. Once or twice e)didaca/mhn is merely e)di/daca with the idea of the teacher's interest superadded: Pind. O. 8. 59to\ dida/casqai | ei)do/ti r(a/|teron: so Simonides fr. 145 (of himself) didaca/menos xoro/n (unless he meant, ‘caused to be trained’). In Aristoph. Nub. 783 dida/caim' a)/n (Elmsley) should prob. be read. It is rare for any midd. form, without a reflexive pron., to denote that the subject acts on (and not for) himself: thus, ‘he kills himself’ is not a)poktei/netai, but a)poktei/nei e(auto/n (Plat. Phaedo 61E). The exceptions are chiefly words of the toilet, as lou/omai. The dative of the reflexive can be more easily understood, as Thuc. 6.40 po/lis...ou)k...au)qai/reton doulei/an e)pibalei=tai, sibi imponet.

pa/gwn k.t.l. Construe: kai\ (e)dida/cato) feu/gein e)nai/qreia be/lh dusau/lwn pa/gwn, kai\ du/sombra be/lh. He learned to build houses, to shelter himself from frost and rain. pa/goi du/sauloi=frosts which make it unpleasant to bivouack in the open: cp. Aesch. Ag. 555 dusauli/as.

e)nai/qreia=under a clear (frosty) sky: cp. fr. 154 o(/tan pa/gou fane/ntos ai)qri/ou (‘a clear frost’) xeroi=n | kru/stallon a(rpa/swsi. Nauck takes dusau/lwn pa/gwn as ‘inhospitable hills,’ citing Moschion fr. 7. 5 (Frag. Trag. p. 633), who describes primitive man as inhabiting o)reigenh= sph/laia: but the context is against this. As corrections of the MS. ai)/qria, there is little to choose between e)nai/qreia and u(pai/qreia: Aesch. Ag. 335 has u(paiqri/wn pa/gwn: but after pa/gwn the loss of e)n would be easier than that of u(p. The i of ai)qri/a could be long (as Solon 13. 22): but i_ is not elsewhere found in the derivatives; for in Cratinus *dhlia/des fr. 5 we must read *(uperborei/ous ai)/qria timw=ntas ste/fh (not, as Blaydes gives it, *(uperbore/ous ai)/qri_a). The spelling e)nai/qreia is conjectural, but in O. C. 1088 L has e)pinikei/w|, as metre requires, for e)piniki/w|. Below, v. 814, e)pinu/mfeios has been conjectured: see n. there.

be/lh, the ‘shafts’ of piercing cold, or of lashing rain. Cp. Plat. Legg. 873E kerauno/s, h)/ ti para\ qeou= toiou=ton be/los i)o/n (some such swift and sudden visitation): Aesch. PV 371 be/lesi purpno/ou za/lhs (sent forth from Aetna): Il. 1.53 kh=la qeoi=o (of the pestilence).

pantopo/ros is at once a comment on the achievements already enumerated (cp. perifradh/s in 348), and a general expression absolving the poet from further detail: ‘yes, there is nothing that he cannot provide.’ Isocr. may have had this passage in mind in or. 3 § 6 (quoted on 354), where an enumeration parallel with that of Soph. is closed by a phrase answering to pantopo/ros,—kai\ sxedo\n a(/panta ta\ di' h(mw=n memhxanhme/na lo/gos h(mi=n e)stin o( sugkataskeua/sas. We must not point thus: be/lh: pantopo/ros, a)/poros k.t.l., when the sense would be weakened, and the construction perplexed (‘all-providing, and in no case without resource, he meets the future’).

ou)de
 … to\ me/llon = ou)de
 o(\ me/llei (e)/sesqai), nothing that is to be (cp. the absolute to\ me/llon, ta\ me/llonta). So Plat. Lach. 197A e)/gwge a)ndrei=a kalw= ou)/te qhri/a ou)/te a)/llo ou)de
 to\ ta\ deina\ u(po\ a)gnoi/as mh\ fobou/menon = ou)de
 o(\ mh\ fobei=tai. This negative form is as correct as (though actually rarer than) the positive pa=n to\ kalw=s e)/xon (Plat. Rep. 381A) for pa=n o(\ kalw=s e)/xei. Donaldson took to\ me/llon adverbially: ‘in regard to the future, he comes to nothing without resources.’ Cp. 728, mhde
 to\ mh\ di/kaion, where mhde/n is subst., not adv.

mo/non and mo/nou are alike admissible; mo/non means, ‘the only thing that he will not achieve is to escape death’; mo/non, ‘the only thing that he will not escape is death.’ In this general view of human achievement, mo/non seems a little the better. feu=cin — e)pa/cetai, procure means of escape from death. e)pa/gesqai, prop. ‘to bring into one's own country’; usu. said of calling in allies to help one; or of importing foreign products: Thuc. 4.64 cumma/xous de\ ou)de/pote ...e)paco/meqa: id. 1. 81 e)k qala/sshs w(=n de/ontai e)pa/contai. Then often fig., of calling in anything to one's aid: Plat. Legg. 823A to\ de\ dh\ paro
 h(mi=n ta\ nu=n oi(=on ma/rtura e)pago/meqa: dhloi= me
 a)
 o(\ boulo/meqa: ‘we call to our help, as a witness, the example which is actually present with us; it will show what we mean.’ Gorg. 492B au)toi\ e(autoi=s despo/thn e)paga/gointo to
 tw=n pollw=n a)nqrw/pwn no/mon te kai\ lo/gon kai\ yo/gon (‘call in to rule them’). Menander *(udri/a fr. 2 ge/ronta dustuxou=nta, tw=n q' au(tou= kakw=n | e)pago/menon lh/qhn, a)ne/mnhsas pa/lin (‘seeking to procure forgetfulness of his troubles’). The word is admirably suitable and vivid here: man looks to every side for succour against the foe that is ever in the land,—Death; but from no quarter can he find help. It is surprising that so many recent critics should have confidently condemned e)pa/cetai, and sought to replace it by conjectures (see cr. n.).
a)mhxa/nwn, such as seem to baffle all treatment: El. 140 a)mh/xanon | a(/lgos: Simonides ap. Plat. Prot. 344C a)mh/xanos sumfora/.
fuga/s, like feu=cin: Eur. Helen 799 le/ktrwn...fuga/s, means of escape from the union; cp. Aristoph. Eq. 759 ka)k tw=n a)mhxa/nwn po/rous eu)mhxa/nous pori/zwn.
cumpe/frastai, here midd., as Aesch. Suppl. 438 kai\ dh\ pe/frasmai: cp. O. C. 1016 n.

The ode closes with a more direct reference to the incident which suggested its theme. The daring ingenuity shown by the unknown breaker of Creon's edict is an instance of the subtlety which leads to ruin. The implied contrast with Creon—u(yi/polis by his care for the laws—is effective in view of the destined peripe/teia.

sofo/n ti … e)/xwn: lit., possessing, in his resourceful skill, a thing subtle beyond belief: sofo/n ti is predicate, and in apposition with to\ mhxano/en te/xnas. Cp. Thuc. 2.89 me/ga ti th=s dianoi/as to\ be/baion e)/xontes a)ntitolmw=sin: ‘they are strong in the confidence of their spirit when they confront the foe.’ There is no ground for altering sofo/n into deino/n, toi=on, or the like.

to\ mhxano/en t., the inventive quality in his skill: for te/xnas, cp. O. T. 380 n.; for the absence of ta=s, cp. above, 10 (kaka/). Cp. Thuc. 1.90 to\...boulo/menon kai\ u+popton th=s gnw/mhs: 2. 61 e)n tw=| u(mete/ry a)sqenei= th=s gnw/mhs.

tote\ me
 … a)/llot'. L has tote\ here: cp. El. 739 to/t' (i.e. tote\) a(/llos, a(/lloq' a+teros: Phaedr. 237 E tote\ me
 h( e(te/ra, a(/llote de\ h( e(te/ra kratei=. Cp. O. C. 1745 n. There is no reason, then, for reading pote\ me/n here with inferior MSS., though it is equally good (Plato has pote\ me
 answered by pote\ de/, by e)ni/ote de/, or by au)=qis de/).
e)p' with kako/n as well as e)sqlo/n: cp. 212 n. on ka)s.

gerai/rwn, ‘honouring,’ is in my belief a certain correction of the MS. parei/rwn. The latter=‘weaving in,’ as a thread into a texture, or a flower into a wreath: for the genuine fig. use of it, see Plat. Symp. 6. 2metacu\ tou= u(ma=s le/gein ou)d' a)\n tri/xa, mh\ o(/ti lo/gon, a)/n tis parei/reie: ‘while you are speaking, one could not put in a hair, much less a speech’ (so close and continuous is the texture of your speaking). Here, parei/rwn has been explained as, ‘weaving the laws (etc.) into the texture of his life’; but, even if we grant that so strange a phrase would be possible with words added to express ‘the texture of his life,’ it is certainly impossible without them. Dindorf proposed parairw=n as=‘wresting,’ ‘violating’ (a strange sense), and pointed at di/kan: ‘he comes to evil (though at other times to good) when he violates the laws,’ etc. *g*e*p*a*i*p*o*n could easily generate *p*a*p*e*i*p*o*n. gerai/rein, prop. to distinguish by gifts of honour, is also a general poet. synonym for tima=n: cp.
5. 67 e)ti/mwn to\n *)/adrhston kai\ dh\ pro\s ta\ pa/qea au)tou= tragikoi=si xoroi=si e)ge/rairon. Ar. Th. 960ge/nos *)olumpi/wn qew=n | me/lpe kai\ ge/raire fwnh=|.
qew=n t' e)/norkon di/kan, Justice, which men swear to observe, taking oaths by the gods (o(/rkoi qew=n: O. T. 647 n.): =o(/rkois qew=n kekurwme/nhn.

u(yi/polis seems best taken as =u(yhlh\n po/lin e)/xwn: cp. Pind. P. 8. 22a( dikaio/polis...na=sos (Aegina). In Pind. O. 2. 8Theron, tyrant of Acragas, is called o)rqo/polis in an active sense, as=o)rqw=n th\n po/lin. In O. T. 510 a(du/polis = a(nda/nwn th=| po/lei: but it is harder to suppose that u(yi/polis could have been intended to mean, ‘standing high in his city.’ Nor would that be the fittest sense. The loyal citizen makes the prosperous city; and her prosperity is his. See on 189. In this clause the Chorus thinks especially of Creon (191 toioi=sd' e)gw\ no/moisi th/nd' au)/cw po/lin).

a)/polis. Where the typical citizen is a law-breaker, the city is ruined, and the evil-doer is left citiless. So Creon had described law-breaking as a)/thn...a)stoi=s (185). The contrast with u(yi/polis shows that the sense is not merely, ‘when a man breaks the law he becomes an exile’ (Lys. or. 21 § 35 a)nti\ ...politw=n a)po/lidas). The central thought is the power of human wit to make or mar the po/lis, according as the man is moral or immoral.

to\ mh\ kalo/n, the generic mh/, such a mood as is not good.— to/lmas xa/rin, by reason of (‘thanks to’) his audacity, with cu/nesti, not with a)/poli/s (e)sti). In O. T. 888 duspo/tmou xa/rin xlida=s is not precisely similar, since it goes with kaka/ nin e(/loito moi=ra. Others point at cu/nesti, taking to/lmas xa/rin with mh/t' e)moi/ k.t.l.: but mh/t' should clearly be the first word in that sentence.

pare/stios. Cp. O. T. 249 n., where Oed. invokes a curse on himself, should the murderer become cune/stios with him: also ib. 240 n. Hor. Carm. 3. 2. 26vetabo, qui Cereris sacrum Vulgarit arcanae, sub isdem Sit trabibus, fragilemve mecum Solvat phaselon. Schneidewin cp. also Eur. fr. 848 (the dishonourer of parents) mh/ moi ge/noito mh/te sunqu/\ths pote/, k.t.l., and Callim. Hymn. 6. 117 (to Demeter) mh\ th=nos e)mi\n fi/los, o(/s toi a)pexqh/s, | ei)/h, mh/q' o(mo/toixos.

i)/son fronw=n, ‘may he not become like-minded with me,’ is another way of saying, ‘may I never come to share his sentiments.’ Cp. Il. 15.50 i)=son e)moi\ frone/ousa, ‘likeminded with me’: Aristoph. Av. 634 e)moi\ fronw=n cunw|da/. In a narrower sense (not intended here) ta\ au)ta\ fronei=n was said of agreement in politics, idem sentire de republica: Her. 1.60 tw)uto\ fronh/santes, ‘having made common cause’ (the stasiw=tai of Megacles and Lycurgus).

e)/rdei, L's reading, should be kept. The indic. is, of course, compatible with generality: for such an indic. after an optative, cp. Dem. or. 4. 51 nikw/|h d' o(/ ti pa=sin u(mi=n me/llei sunoi/sein. It is also rather in favour of the indic. that the speaker is here thinking of an actual case. The optat. e)/rdoi would be abstract, ‘any one who should conceivably do these things,’ and would be equally correct: cp. on 666.

The choral ode has closed with an allusion to the unknown man (o(/s: cp. 248 ti/s a)ndrw=n, 319 o( drw=n). At this moment Antigone is led in by the Guard.— a)mfinow=: cp. O. C. 316 (where Antigone can scarcely believe her eyes, on seeing Ismene,) a)=r' e)/stin; a)=r' ou)k e)/stin; h)\ gnw/mh plana=|; For e)s, cp. fobei=sqai ei)/s ti, O. T. 980 n.
daimo/nion te/ras, a portent sent by gods,—so astounding as to require a supernatural cause. Xen. Mem. 1.3.5 ei) mh/ ti daimo/nion ei)/h.

pw=s ei)dw\s k.t.l.: ‘How, when I know (that she is Antigone, sc. o(/ti e)sti/), shall I maintain that she is not?’ (ou)k ei)=nai = o(/ti ou)k e)sti/). A simple verb of ‘saying’ regularly takes ou) with inf. in oratio obliqua: le/gw ou)k ei)=nai = o(/ti ou)k e)sti/. If this verb of saying is negatived, the negative with the inf. is still ou): pw=s le/cw ou)k ei)=nai; Here, a)ntiloge/w has the construction of a simple verb of saying: pw=s a)ntilogh/sw ou)k ei)=nai; Hermann conjectured mh\ ou) th/nd' ei)=nai (which is palaeographically very improbable). mh\ ou)k ei)=nai would be the normal constr. after pw=s a)ntilogh/sw, if a)ntiloge/w were viewed in its special quality as a verb of ‘denying.’ a)rnou=mai mh\ ei)=nai: pw=s a)rnh/somai mh\ ou)k (or simply mh/, O. T. 1388 n.) ei)=nai; Cp. below, 443 n. It may be noted that, when a)ntile/gw means to ‘deny,’ it is more often followed by w(s (or o(/ti) ou) with the finite verb; when followed by mh/ and inf., it more often means ‘to protest against’ a measure; Thuc. 3.41 a)nte/lege...mh\ a)poktei=nai *mutilhnai/ous: Xen. Cyr. 2.2.20 ai)sxro
 o)
 (=ou) dei=) a)ntile/gein to\ mh\ ou)xi\ to
 plei=sta ponou=nta...megi/stwn a)ciou=sqai.
a)ntilogh/sw might be deliberative aor., but is rather fut. ind. (cp. O. T. 1419, O. C. 310).
w)= du/sthnos: nom. for voc., O. C. 185 n.
d. patro/s, gen. of origin: O. C. 214 n.
*oi)dipo/da_ occurs as gen. in O. T. 495, but as voc. ib. 1194.
ti/ pot'; Cp. Ph. 1210.
ou) dh/ pou: cp. O. T. 1472 ou) dh\ klu/w pou...;
a)pistou=san = a)peiqou=san, cp. 219, 656.

a)/gousi. It is far more probable that the final in of basilei/oisin should have dropped out in L (see cr. n.) than that Soph. should have written a)pa/gousi. At Athens a)pa/gw and a)pagwgh/ were technical terms for a process of summary arrest by which any citizen could bring before the magistrates a person taken in a criminal act (e)p' au)tofw/rw|). We have seen (on v. 158) that a word with a technical Attic sense was not necessarily excluded from Attic poetry. But a)pa/gw would surely jar here. Allowing for the difference between a technicality and a
colloquialism, it would be nearly as bad as, ‘Have they taken you up?’
kai\ connects a)pistou=san with kaqelo/ntes (not with e)n a)frosu/nh|): cp. O. C. 737 n.

Second e)peiso/dion. Antigone, brought before Creon, avows and justifies her deed. Creon declares that she shall die. Ismene, when led in (531), associates herself with the act, but is not permitted by her sister to claim any part in it. Creon orders that both sisters shall be kept prisoners.
e)kei/nh, she whom we sought: cp. O. C. 138 o(/d' e)kei=nos e)gw/, n.
tou)/rgon h( 'ceirg.: for the order, cp. 324.

e)s de/on: cp. O. T. 1416 e)s de/on pa/resq' o(/de | *kre/wn: so ib. 78 ei)s kalo/n: Ai. 1168 e)s au)to\n kairo/n. L has ei)s me/son, i.e. ‘he comes forth in public’ (so that you, and all, can speak with him). The phrase occurs elsewhere in Soph., but never with ref. to entrance on the stage: Soph. Ph. 609e)/deic' *)axaioi=s e)s me/son (showed him publicly); Ai. 1285 to\n klh=ron e)s me/son kaqei/s (i.e. among the others): Tr. 514 i)/san e)s me/son (into the arena). Here, e)s de/on is not only far the better phrase, but is confirmed by Creon's question in the next v., poi/a| cu/mmetros... tu/xh|; A, and almost all the later MSS., have ei)s de/on, which may, doubtless, have been a conjecture suggested by O. T. 1416, —as is held by those who believe all our MSS. to have come from L; but it looks more like a true reading which L has somehow missed. Cp. on 831.
cu/mmetros, commensurate with, i.e. here, opportune for. O. T. 84 cu/mmetros ga\r w(s klu/ein: ib. 1113 cuna/|dei tw=|de ta)ndri\ su/mmetros.

a)pw/moton, abiurandum: there is nothing, the possibility of which men ought to deny on oath: ou)k e)/stin o(/ ti a)pomnu/nai xrh\ brotou\s mh\ ou)k a)\n gene/sqai. Archilochus fr. 76 xrhma/twn a)/elpton ou)de/n e)stin ou)d' a)pw/moton | ou)de\ qauma/sion. Eupolis *i*io/leis fr. 25 ti/ d' e)/st' *)aqhnai/oisi pra=gm' a)pw/moton;
yeu/dei=falsifies (like yeudopoiei=n): Thuc. 3.66 th\n...yeusqei=san upo/sxesin.

h( 'pi/noia, here, the after-thought, ai( deu/terai fronti/des. But usually the e)pi/ in e)pinoe/w, e)pi/noia, denotes advance,— ‘forming a design,’ or ‘inventing’: Aristoph. Eq. 90 oi)=non su\ tolma=|s ei)s e)pi/noian loidorei=n; Cp. Lucian *promhqeu\s ei(= e)n lo/gois 7 to/ ge metabouleu/esqai *)epimhqe/ws e)/rgon, ou) *promhqe/ws e)sti/n.

e)chu/xoun a)/n, I could have vowed, sxolh=| h(/cein pote\ deu=ro, that it would be long before I ever came hither. Cp. Eur. Helen 1619 ou)k a)/n pot' hu)/xoun ou)/te s' ou)/q' h(ma=s laqei=n | *mene/laon, w)=nac, w(s e)la/nqanen pa/rwn: ‘I should never have expected that he would escape us’; where (as the order of words shows) a)/n goes with hu)/xoun,—the suppressed protasis being, as here, ei) h)rw/ta tis, ‘if any one had asked me.’ So Lys. or. 12 § 22 e)gw\ d' e)boulo/mhn a)\n au)tou\s a)lhqh= le/gein, ‘I could wish’ (the ref. there being to present time), sc. ei) dunato\n h)=n. Cp. Soph. Ph. 869 n. The needless emendations of this verse have aimed at disjoining a)/n from e)chu/xoun and attaching it to the infin., or else at removing it altogether. But, though the fu/lac had actually said (in the ‘aside’ at 329) that he did not mean to come back, he was not therefore debarred from using this turn of phrase; ‘I could have vowed that I would not come back.’
sxolh=| (cp. 231), here iron., ‘not in a hurry’ (O. T. 434 n.); Shaksp. Tit. Andron. 1. 2. 301 ‘I'll trust by leisure him that mocks me once.’

tai=s sai=s a)peilai=s, ‘by reason of thy threats’: cp. 335 (no/tw|) n, 588 (pnoai=s), 956 (o)rgai=s). Here, the causal dat. seems also to suggest occasion (‘at the time of your threats’): see on 691 lo/gois.
e)xeima/sqhn: Ph. 1460xeimazome/nw| (e)moi/), in my sore trouble.

h(...e)kto\s (tw=n e)lpi/dwn) kai\ para\ e)lpi/das. I cannot parallel this zeugma of preps. with a case suited only to the second (in Il. 17.760 peri/ t' a)mfi/ te ta/fron both preps. take acc.): and yet it seems to be genuine, the phrase being so energetic and compact. e)kto/s is certainly supported by 330, while a)/topos, a)/logos, and ei)ko/s are all very improbable substitutes. Nor can I think, with Schütz, that e)kto/s is here adverb: ‘the outside joy’ (i.e. outside of one's calculations).

ou)de\n e)/oike mh=kos, is not at all (adv.) like in greatness, a+llh| h(donh=|, to any other pleasure; i.e. is vastly greater than any other. For the adv. ou)de/n, cp. Lys. 220 C to\ fi/lon...ou)de\n tou/tois e)/oike. For mh=kos=amplitudo, Empedocles 15 e)c oi(/hs timh=s te kai\ o(/ssou mh/keos o)/lbou: so Pindar speaks of makro\s o)/lbos (P. 2. 26), makrote/ra a)reta/ (I. 4. 21), Aristotle of makra\ timh/mata ( Pol. 3. 5. 6, opp. to braxe/a ib. 4. 4. 24), makra\ ou)si/a (ib. 4. 4. 5), and Soph. himself of makro\s plou=tos (Ai. 130). For e)/oike Wolff-Bellermann cp. Thuc. 7.71 o(...fo/bos h)=n... ou)deni\ e)oikw/s (‘great beyond example’), De Vect. 4. 31 ou)deni\ tw=n parelhluqo/twn e)oiko/s (‘far greater than any of the past’); and for the sentiment, Eur. fr. 554 e)k tw=n a)e/lptwn h( xa/ris mei/zwn brotoi=s | fanei=sa ma=llon h)\ to\ prosdokw/menon.— Nauck's treatment of this verse and the next has no justification: see cr. n.
di' o(/rkwn … a)pw/motos, though I had sworn with oaths (sworn solemnly) not to come. Cp. Ai. 1113 o(/rkwn oi(=sin h)=n e)nw/motos: Aristoph. Ran. 150 e)pi/orkon o(/rkon w)/mosen.
kaqh|re/qh (cp. 383 kaqelo/ntes) is clearly better here than L's kaqeure/qh: and the compound kaqeuri/skw is nowhere found in classical

ta/fon kosmou=sa, paying the due rites of burial (ta/fon = tafh/n, cp. 490), by sprinkling the dust and pouring the libations on the corpse. kosme/w was specially said of obsequies: cp. 901, El. 1139 loutroi=s e)ko/smhs'.

e)pa/lleto, as when lots were shaken in a helmet (Ai. 1285; cp. El. 710). His e(/rmaion is the luck of being the first to bring the glad tidings,—as his former mission was ironically called tou=to ta)gaqo/n (275). In the discovery and seizure of Antigone he had no greater share than his comrades (432).
kri=ne = a)na/krine, question: Ai. 586 mh\ kri=ne, mh\ 'ce/taze.

di/kaio/s ei)mi: the only certain instance in Tragedy of the personal constr. (Thuc. 1.40 di/kaioi/ g' e)ste...i)e/nai); for in Eur. Hipp. 1080 pollw=| ge ma=llon sauto\n h)/skhsas se/bein | h)\ tou\s teko/ntas o(/sia dra=n, di/kaios w)/n, the latter words are more pointed if ironical (‘just man though thou art’): and Aesch. Eum. 55 kai\ ko/smos ou)/te pro\s qew=n a)ga/lmata | fe/rein di/kaios is different (‘proper to bring’). But Ar. has this use, Nub. 1283 a)polabei=n...di/kaios ei)=, and ib. 1434.
a)phlla/xqai, perf., for good and all: O. T. 1050.
Observe the order of the words as marking his amazement. For the double interrog. cp. Il. 21.150 ti/s po/qen ei<*>=s a)ndrw=n; Ph. 243ti/ni | sto/lw| prose/sxes th/nde gh=n, po/qen ple/wn;

pa/nt' e)pi/stasai: one of the formulas which often close a messenger's speech, as Tr. 484 pa/nt' e)pi/stasai lo/gon: Ai. 480 pa/nt' a)kh/koas lo/gon: ib. 876 pa/nt' a)kh/koas: Ph. 241oi)=sqa dh\ to\ pa=n.
h)= kai\, O. T. 368 n. The first kai\ here is not ‘both.’
o)rqw=s, ‘rightly’: i.e. do your words express what you really
mean to say? (Not, merely, ‘truly,’ i.e. in accordance with the fact: cp. 99 n.)
to\n nekro/n: antecedent with art. drawn into relative clause: O. C. 907 n. nu=n d' ou(/sper au)to\s tou\s no/mous ei)sh=lq' e)/xwn, | tou/toisin k.t.l.
a)=r' e)/ndhla: said triumphantly: Aesch. Ag. 268 *x*o. pw=s fh/s...; *k*l. *troi/an *)axaiw=n ou)=san: h)= torw=s le/gw; Cp. Ai. 1158 ou)dei/s pot' a)/llos h)\ su/. mw=n h)|nica/mhn;
o(ra=tai...h(|re/qh: historic pres. combined with aor., as Ai. 31 fra/zei te ka)dh/lwsen: cp. 419, Tr. 359 ff., O. T. 118 f.

e)pi/lhptos, seized in the act=e)p' au)tofw/rw|. Her. 3.69 e)pi/lamptos... a)fa/ssousa (ta\ w)=ta) e)/stai, ‘will be caught feeling the ears.’ [Dem. ] or. 25 § 80 tou\s e)pilh/ptous (the epileptic) fhsi\n i)a=sqai, au)to\s w)\n e)pi/lhptos pa/sh| ponhri/a|.

h(/komen. The occupation of the guards was temporarily gone when they perceived that the burial, which they had been set to prevent, had been effected (255). Creon, speaking to their deputy, sent them back to their post, with orders to discover the culprit (306). h(/komen (imperf.) simply refers to their taking up their station again near the body. It need not imply that they had escorted their comrade on his way to Creon. We could not take h(/komen...e)phpeilhme/noi as merely plur. for sing., and then refer sh/rantes, etc., to the guards collectively. Nor is the conject. i(ko/mhn needed.
ta\ dei/n' e)kei=n'. Creon's threats were addressed to all the guards: cp. 305 ff.

to
 | ne/kun: so O. C. 351 ta\ th=s | oi)/koi diai/ths: Ph. 263o(
 oi( | dissoi\ strathgoi/: El. 879 ka)pi\ toi=s | sauth=s kakoi=si. So Aristoph. Eccl. 452 ou)de\ to
 | dh=mon. Aesch. places the art. thus only when it is a pronoun ( Aesch. Ag. 7tw=n: Aesch. Theb. 385, Aesch. Eum. 137tw=|). In Eur. no instance seems to occur.

kaqh/meq' is better taken as plpf. than pf., for, though h(/komen is ambiguous, we have a series of historical tenses in 415—421. Ar. sometimes uses and sometimes omits the augment, as Ar. Ach. 638e)ka/qhsqe, Ar. Eccl. 304kaqh=nto (both proved by metre); and if our MSS. can be trusted, classical prose, too, admitted both forms, as Aeschin. or. 2 § 89 e)kaqh/mhn, Dem. or. 18 § 169 kaqh=to. In the five pluperfects furnished by Attic inscriptions of 428— 325 B.C. the syllabic augment is always added, but there is no epigraphic evidence in the particular case of e)kaqh/mhn (see Meisterhans, p. 77).

a)/krwn e)k pa/gwn, with kaqh/meqa, ‘on the hill-top.’ The corpse lay on the highest part of the Theban plain (1110, 1197), with rising ground (pa/goi) behind or around it. The guards post themselves on this rising ground, facing the corpse, and with their backs to the wind. The use of e)k (or a)po/), with a verb denoting position, occurs only in a few places of poetry; but it is certainly genuine, and deserves attention, for its true force has not (I think) been observed. (1) Il. 14.153 *(/hrh d' ei)sei=de xruso/qronos o)fqalmoi=sin | sta=s'

e)c *ou)lu/mpoio a)po\ r(i/ou. Here, a)po\ r(i/ou goes with ei)sei=de: but e)c *ou)lu/mpoio, however much ei)sei=de may have influenced it, at least cannot be disjoined from sta=s'. (2) Eur. Phoen. 1009 a)ll' ei)=mi kai\ sta\s e)c e)pa/lcewn a)/krwn | sfa/cas e)mauto
 shko
 ei)s melambaqh= | dra/kontos, e)/nq' o( ma/ntis e)chgh/sato, | e)leuqerw/sw gai=an. It is impossible to sever sta/s from e)c e)p., even if we partly explain e)c by sfa/cas. (3) ib. 1224 *)eteokle/hs d' u(ph=rc' a)p' o)rqi/ou staqei\s | pu/rgou keleu/sas si=ga khru=cai stratw=|. The position of staqei/s forbids us to sever it from a)p' o)rq. p., even though u(ph=rce or keleu/sas is used to explain a)po/. (4) Eur. Tro. 522 a)na\ d' e)bo/asen lew\s | *trw|a/dos a)po\ pe/tras staqei/s. A similar case. In all these passages, a picture is presented, and we have to glance from a remoter to a nearer object. The mental eye is required to measure the space between Hera on the peak of Olympus, and Poseidon on the plain of Troy; between Megareus on the walls of Thebes, and the cavern into which his corpse is to fall. And, in each case, e)k or a)po/ denotes the quarter in which the remoter object is to be looked for. This, which might be called the ‘surveying’ use, is distinct from that in which the prep. has a pregnant force, as being directly suggestive of motion (oi( e)k *sikeli/as h(/cousi); but it springs from the same mental tendency,—viz., to take a rapid glance over the dividing interval. Cp. i(/stasqai pro/s tinos (‘on his side’). So here: in the foreground of the picture is the corpse, which they have just laid bare. Now look to the hillocks behind it; in that quarter you will see the guards at their post.—I have not cited Od. 21.419 to/n r(' e)pi\ ph/xei e(lw
 e(/lken neurh
 glufi/das te | au)to/qen e)k di/froio kaqh/menos, because there e)k di/froio goes with e(/lken, not with kaqh/menos (he drew the bow, just from the chair, where he sat).

u(ph/nemoi, under the wind, i.e., so that it blew from behind them, not in their faces, as the next v. explains. (At v. 421 the dust is blown in their faces, but that is by the sudden, gusty skhpto/s.) The idea of ‘sheltered,’ which u(ph/nemos usu. implies, is less prominent here, yet quite admissible, if we suppose them to sit just below the summits of the pa/goi. Cp. Xen. Oec. 18. 6e)k tou= proshne/mou me/rous, on the side towards which the wind blows, opp. to e)k tou= u(phne/mou, to windward. Theophr. Causs. Plantt. 3.6.9 opposes pneumatw/dhs kai\ prosh/nemos to/pos to ta\ u(ph/nema: and Hist. An. 9. 15 e)n proshne/mw| to e)n e)piskepei=.

ba/lh|, the ‘vivid’ subjunct. (instead of ba/loi), after a secondary tense; while in v. 414 we have the normal optat. (a)khdh/soi). For this combination cp. Xen. Anab. 3.5.17 parh/ggeilan, e)peidh\ deipnh/seian,...a)napau/esqai, kai\ e(/pesqai h(ni/k' a)/n tis paraggei/lh|.
e)gerti/: see on a)stakti/, O. C. 1251. Each man was careful to keep wide awake, and also to see that his comrades did so.

kinw=n, urging to vigilance. Plat. Rep. 329D boulo/menos e)/ti le/gein au)to\n e)ki/noun kai\ ei)=pon, w)= *ke/fale, k.t.l. The conject. neikw=n is needless. For the sing. instead of the plur. (kinou=ntes) in partitive apposition, see on fu/lac e)le/gxwn fu/laka, 260.
e)pirro/qois kakoi=sin, lit., with obstreperous taunts,

the adj. expressing the loud, continuous noise of tongues. The e)pi- does not mean ‘bandied to and fro’: see Tr. 263 polla\ me\n lo/gois | e)perro/qhse. In fr. 521 e)pi/rroqa dw/mata=‘open to reproach.’ Elsewhere (as with Aesch.) e)pi/rroqos= ‘helper’ (e)pirroqe/w, to come with shouts to the rescue). Cp. e)rro/qoun 259 n., Aesch. 290.

a)khdh/soi: fut. opt. in orat. obliqua; the direct form of the threat would be (klau/sei) ei) a)khdh/seis (or e)a\n a)khdh/sh|s). Cp. Ph. 374h)/rasson kakoi=s | toi=s pa=sin... | ei) ta)ma\ kei=nos o(/pl' a)fairh/soito/ me: he said (o)/loio), ei) a)fairh/sei. Ai. 312 dei/n' e)phpei/lhs' e)/ph, | ei) mh\ fanoi/hn (he said, ei) mh\ fanei=s). a)khde/w had been used by Hom. Il. 14.427, 23. 70, Aesch. PV 508, and recurs in later poetry. The MS. a)feidh/soi cannot be defended as=‘play the prodigal with,’ i.e. ‘be careless of.’ a)feidei=n po/nou could mean only to be unsparing of labour. In Thuc. 4.26 a)feidh\s o( kata/plous kaqeisth/kei is explained by the next words, e)pw/kellon ga\r ta\ ploi=a tetimhme/na xrhma/twn: they were ‘unsparing’ of their boats, since a value had been set on the latter. Bonitz, to whom a)khdh/soi is due, refers to Apoll. Rhod. 2. 98 ou)d' a)/ra *be/brukes a)/ndres a)fei/dhsan basilh=os, where Choeroboscus has preserved the true a)kh/dhsan. In the schol. on Ai. 204 feido/menoi occurs by error for khdo/menoi.

The incident of the storm was a dramatic necessity, to account for Antigone reaching the corpse unobserved. A powerful picture is compressed into seven lines. (Cp. O. C. 1315 ff. for a like instance of self-restraint in description.)

kate/sth, prop., had taken its place. There is a Homeric echo here: Il. 8.66 o)/fra me
 h)w\s h)=n kai\ a)e/ceto i(ero
 h)=mar, | to/fra ma/l' a)mfote/rwn be/le' h(/pteto, pi=pte de\ lao/s: | h)=mos d' h)e/lios me/son ou)rano
 a)mfibebh/kei, | kai\ to/te dh\ xru/seia path e)ti/taine ta/lanta.
xqono\s (from the ground) with a)ei/ras: cp. O. T. 142 ba/qrwn | i(/stasqe, n.

tufw/s, the whirlwind: the skhpto/s is the storm of dust (koniorto/s) which it lifts from the ground. The word skhpto/s usu.=‘a thunderbolt,’ and by its deriv. ought at least to mean a storm swooping on the earth from the sky; but the schol. attests its use in a larger sense; skhpto\s de\ le/getai pa=n pneu=ma quellw=des, o(/tan sunerei/dh| th=| gh=|, kai\ pa/lin a)/nw ai)/rh:| to\ de\ toiou=to kai\ stro/bi_lo/n tines kalou=si, para\ to\ strobei=n.

ou)ra/nion a)/xos, a trouble in the sky (cp. O. C. 1466 ou)rani/a...a)straph/), since the cloud of dust darkened the sky: schol. to\ lupou=n to\n ai)qe/ra, kaqo\ tara/ssei au)to/n: only a)/xos is rather what annoys us than what annoys the (personified) ou)rano/s. In these lines the poet describes the actual physical effects produced by the storm. He mentions the destruction of foliage; and we need some reference also to the main point of all—the obscuring of the air. Therefore I should not take ou)ra/nion a)/xos as=‘a heaven-sent plague’; that is presently said by qei/an no/son (421). A third version—‘a trouble rising high as heaven’ (like ou)ra/nion ph/dhma, etc.)—is also possible, but less suitable here than either of the others. In Aesch. Suppl. 809 i)/uze d' o)mfa\n ou)rani/an, the adj. clearly=ou)ranomh/kh, and so perh. in Pers. 572a)mbo/ason ou)ra/ni' a)/xh, though there (as in Ai. 196 a)/tan ou)rani/an fle/gwn) ‘heaven-sent’ is at least equally fitting.—For the tribrach in the 5th place, see O. T. 719 n.

pi/mplhsi (histor. pres., between e)/qalpe and e)nemestw/qh, cp. 406), viz., with dust and scattered leaves.— ai)ki/zwn, maltreating, lumaino/menos, by breaking the branches and tearing off the leaves.
e)n d' e)mest., tmesis: cp. 1274, El. 713 e)n de\ pa=s e)mestw/qh dro/mos. Distinguish the adv. e)n de/ (and withal), O. T. 27 n.

mu/santes. mu_/w (from mu=, a sound made with closed lips)=‘to be shut,’ said of the eyes, the lips, or any opening (Il. 24.637 ou) ga/r pw mu/san o)/sse): but the aor. part. regularly meant, ‘with eyes shut’: Plat. Gorg. 480C pare/xein mu/santa kai\ a)ndrei/ws w(/sper te/mnein kai\ ka/ein i)atrw=|. There was a proverb, mu/santa fe/rein (‘to grin and bear it’), Meineke Com. 3, p. 4.
no/son, the scourge of the storm: cp. 1141.
e)n xr. makr.: for the prep. see O. C. 88 n.

pikra=s, in its bitterness. Elsewhere pikro/s, said of persons, means ‘embittered,’ and so ‘hostile,’ etc. (as Ai. 1359). But there is no reason why pikro/s should not also mean ‘embittered’ in the sense, ‘with a bitter feeling of anguish.’ There is a pathos in this which is lost by reading pikrw=s, ‘shrilly.’ Nor could pikra=s mean merely ‘piercing,’ as if the epithet of the cry were given to the bird itself. In O. C. 1610 fqo/ggos pikro/s, and in Ph. 190pikra\ oi)mwgh/, mean not merely a ‘shrill,’ but a ‘bitter,’ cry; and so conversely here, the epithet pikra/, while primarily denoting anguish, also suggests the shrill sound.

eu)nh=s...le/xos would be a weak pleonasm for ‘nest’; it is better to take eu)nh=s as the nest, and le/xos as the restingplace of the young birds within it. The phrases le/ktrwn eu)nai/, le/ktrwn koi=tai, koi/ths le/ktron, etc., said of the marriagebed, are not properly similar, meaning rather, ‘the bed on which they slept,’ etc.: i.e. eu)nai/ or koi=tai refer to the act of sleeping. kenh=s is certainly pleonastic with neossw=n o)rfano/n (cp. Ph. 31kenh\n oi)/khsin a)nqrw/pwn di/xa, and O. T. 57n.), yet hardly anticipates it; the bird, approaching its nest, feels that it is kenh/, then peeps in, and, sure enough, the le/xos is o)rfano/n.

ou(/tw de/, ‘so, I say, she’: for de/ introducing the apodosis in a simile cp. El. 25 w(/sper ga\r i(/ppos eu)genh/s...qumo\n ou)k a)pw/lesen | ..., w(sau/tws de\ su\ | h(ma=s t' o)tru/neis k.t.l.: so Tr. 112 ff., polla\ ga\r w(/st'...ou(/tw de\ to\n *kadmogenh=.
yilo/n, sc. ko/nios, stripped of the dust which she had sprinkled on it (409). Cp. O. C. p. 279.
go/oisin e)cw/|mwcen: cp. O. T. 65 u(/pnw| g' eu(/donta, n.
e)k d' … h)ra=to, tmesis: cp. n. on 106.
diyi/an: cp. 246.

fe/rei ko/nin. A difficulty presents itself. The essence of the symbolical rite was the sprinkling of dust. She had done that (245). Was it not, then, done once for all? In Horace (C. 1. 28. 35) the passer-by is free when the dust has been thrown; he can go his way. I have never seen this question put or answered. The only answer which I can suggest is that, at her first visit, she had not brought the xoai/. (Cp. on 245 ff.) Perhaps the rite was considered complete only if the xoai/ were poured while the dust still covered the corpse.

The pro/xous, or ‘out-pourer,’ was a jug, especially a water-jug, with a handle, and had, of course, various forms; some of the types given by Guhl and Koner (p. 147, fig. 198, 26—31) resemble modern water-jugs for washing.
eu)kro/thtos, ‘well-hammered,’ and so ‘wellwrought,’ is the epith. of a knife (dwri/s, sc. kopi/s) in Eur. El. 819.

a)/rdhn (for a)e/rdhn, from ai)/rw) is found with phda=n (Ai. 1279) and fe/rein (Eur. Alc. 608), but is usu. fig., as with a)pollu/nai. Here, a)/rdhn e)k pro/xou ste/fei = a)/rasa to\n pro/xoun ste/fei.
xoai=si. In Od. 10.519 the three xoai/ to the dead are of (1) hydromel, (2) wine, (3) water: see O. C. 479 n.

trispo/nd., instead of the simple trisi/n: cp. on 346 sp. diktuoklw/stois. xoai/ were to the ne/rteroi, as spondai/ to the u(/patoi: loibai/ could mean either (O. C. 477).— ste/fei: El. 51 tu/mbon... | loibai=si prw=ton kai\ karato/mois xlidai=s | ste/yantes.
i(e/mesqa, pres.: for the i_, cp. O. C. 1279 n.

su
 de\ … qhrw/meq', tmesis, as El. 746 su
 d' e(li/ssetai | tmhtoi=s i(ma=si. But su/n is adv. ib. 299 su
 d' e)potru/nei: cp. above, 85.

h)le/gxomen, proceeded to prove against her, i.e. taxed her with, her past and present deeds. We should not supply au)th/n: the verb governs ta\s pra/ceis only: cp. Plat. Theaet. 161E e)le/gxein ta\s a)llh/lwn fantasi/as te kai\ do/cas (examine into). It would be natural to say, tau=ta e)le/gxw au)th/n, but hardly ta\s pra/ceis e)le/gxw au)th/n.
a)/parnos … ou)deno/s = ou)de\n a)parnoume/nh, the gen. with the adj. corresponding to the acc. with the verb; cp. kwlutiko/s, poihtiko/s tinos etc.

kaqi/stato, she did not take up the position of denying anything. Her attitude towards the charge was one of simple confession. kaqi/stasqai with a predicative adj. expresses definite assumption of a character, or complete attainment of a state; Thuc. 3.102 cu/mmaxon kaqesth/cei (will have definitely allied itself): 6. 15 pole/mioi kaqe/stasan: 4. 78 toi=s pa=si...u(/popton kaqesth/kei: 2. 59 a)/poroi kaqestw=tes: 4. 26 a)feidh\s...kaqesth/kei: 6. 59 xalepwte/ra...h( turanni\s kate/sth. So Ai. 306 e)/mfrwn...kaqi/statai: O. T. 703 fone/a...kaqesta/nai.

a(/m' for the MS. a)ll' (*a*m for *a*l*l) is certain; kaqi/st. would be unmeaning with the adverbs, and we cannot supply a new verb. Cp. Thuc. 7.77 § 6 siti/a a(/ma komi/zein, where a(/ma (for the MS. a)/lla) is due to Reiske. Besides a(/ma me\n ...a(/ma de/ (‘partly’...‘partly’), we also find double a(/ma, (a) wherethe clauses are linked by kai/, as here; Plat. Gorg. 496B w(=n a(/ma te a)palla/ttetai a)/nqrwpos kai\ a(/ma e)/xei (cp. ib. 497 A): (b) with partic. and finite verb: id. Tim. 38 B i(/na a(/ma gennhqe/ntes a(/ma kai\ luqwsin. Verg. G. 3. 201 simul arva fuga, simul aequora verrens. Cp. Hor. S. 1. 7. 11Inter | Hectora Priamiden animosum atque inter Achillen.
fi/lous fhsi/, dia\ to\ ei(=nai th\n *)antigo/nhn tou= basilikou= ge/nous (schol.): he is a dou=los of the family. Cp. Eur. Med. 54 xrhstoi=si dou/lois sumfora\ ta\ despotw=n | kakw=s pi/tnonta.

pa/nta tau=q' refers to e)s kako
 de\...a)lgeino/n: ‘all these things’=‘all such objects as the safety of friends.’ labei=n, ‘to obtain,’ epexeg. of h(/ssw: cp. 638: Ph. 81: El. 1015 pronoi/as ou)de
 a)nqrw/pois e)/fu | ke/rdos labei=n a)/meinon: where, as here, we have a gen. depending on the comparat., instead of h)/ with nom.— Semitelos takes labei=n as=u(polabei=n: ‘all these considerations are naturally lower in my estimate than my own safety.’ Similarly Campbell; ‘It is in my nature’ (e)moi\ pe/fuke—a questionable sense) ‘to take less account of all this than of my own safety.’ But such a use of lamba/nein does not seem warranted by Thuc. 2.42. th
 timwri/an...poqeinote/ran labo/ntes, or by such phrases as lamba/nein ti e)n po/qw| (O. C. 1679).—Blaydes's ta)/ll' … tau=t' is attractive, but unnecessary; and palaeographically it is not probable.

se\ dh/, k.t.l. sc. kalw=. Eur. Helen 546 se\ th
 o)/regma deino
 h(millwme/nhn | tu/mbou 'pi\ krhpi=d' e)mpu/rous t' o)rqosta/tas, | mei=non. Aristoph. Av. 274 *e*u. ou(=tos, w)= se/ toi. *p*e. ti/ bwstrei=s; The abrupt acc. calls the person's attention in a rough and harsh way. A governing verb is sometimes added, as El. 1445 se/ toi, se\ kri/nw, nai\ se/, th
 e)n tw=| pa/ros | xro/nw| qrasei=an. Ai. 1226 se\ dh\ ta\ deina\ r(h/mat' a)gge/llousi/ moi | tlh=nai... | se/ toi, to
 e)k th=s ai)xmalwti/dos le/gw. Eur. Med. 271 se\ th
 skuqrwpo
 kai\ po/sei qumoume/nhn, | *mh/deian, ei)=pon, etc. Antigone has her eyes bent on the ground: she is neither afraid nor sullen, but feels that Creon and she can never come to terms. There is nothing in common between their thoughts. Cp. 499.

fh\s dedrake/nai, h)\ katarnei= mh\ dedr., a zeugma. katarnei=. In this compound (found only here) kata/ gives the notion of ‘downright,’ ‘explicit’: cp. katafa/nai (to affirm), kata/dhlos. mh/ regularly precedes the inf. when a)rnei=sqai means ‘to deny,’ but not when it means ‘to refuse’: Phaedr. 256 A a)parnhqh=nai to\ au(tou= me/ros xari/sasqai.
kai\......kou)k, corresponding with the alternatives in Creon's question : for the conjunctive form, cp. 1192: [Eur.] Rhes. 164 nai/, kai\ di/kaia tau=ta kou)k a)/llws le/gw.
to\ mh/: for the art., cp. 78. to\ mh\ ou)k is unnecessary, though it would be normal: cp. O. T. 1387 ou)k a)\n e)sxo/mhn | to\ mh\ 'poklh=|sai, n.

su\ me/n. If she had denied the charge, the fu/lac must have been detained; now, he can go. komi/zois a)
 s. gives a contemptuous permission. So in gentle command, Ph. 674xwroi=s a)
 ei)/sw, Tr. 624 stei/xois a)
 h)/dh. Cp. Eur. Phoen. 1636 ko/mize sauth
...do/mwn e)/sw.
e)/cw with b. ai)ti/as, after which e)leu/qeron is pleonastic: cp. Ai. 464 gumno\n fane/nta tw=n a)ristei/wn a)/ter: and see n. on kenh=s above, v. 424.

mh=kos, adv., ‘at great length,’ like makra/n, te/los, etc. If we read su/ntomon or su/ntoma, mh=kos might be obj. acc. to ei)pe/, but sunto/mws seems right. Cp. Aesch. Pers. 698 mh/ ti makisth=ra mu=qon a)lla\ su/ntomon le/gwn | ei)pe\ kai\ pe/raine pa/nta.

h)/|dhsqa, not h)/|dhs ta\, is certainly right. This 2nd pers. occurs in seven places of drama, two of which require it (Eur. El. 926, Cycl. 108), while the other five admit it (this v., Tr. 988, Aristoph. Nub. 329, Th. 554, Eccl. 551). Similarly h)=sqa is either necessary or admissible whenever it occurs in Attic drama. Aristoph. Lys. 132 has e)/fhsqa, and e)/fhs nowhere: but the case for e)/fhsqa as the sole classical form seems less strong than for h)/|dhsqa and h)=sqa. e)/fhsqa is required in four Homeric passages (Il. 1.397, 16. 830: Od. 3.357, 23. 71), but e)/fhs in one, Il. 22.331 *(/ektor, a)ta/r pou e)/fhs *patroklh=' e)cenari/zwn, and in another it is traditional, 22. 280 h)=toi e)/fhs ge (where e)/fhsqa is unlikely). The ending is -sqa, not -qa, s being an integral part of it: Curtius compares Lat. -sti (dedi-sti), and Gothic -st (saisô-st, thou sowedst), Gk Verb pp. 34 ff. Besides oi)=sqa, h)/|dhsqa, h)=sqa, and e)/fhsqa, the forms which take sqa are the Hom. ei)=sqa (‘thou wilt go’); the presents indic. didoi=sqa (Il. 19.270) and ti/qhsqa (Od. 9.404, 24. 476); and a few subjunctives and optatives (as ba/lh|sqa, ba/loisqa).
khruxqe/nta, the plur. partic. impersonal, as 570 h(rmosme/na, 576 dedogme/na: a use more freq. with adjectives, as a)du/nata, di/kaia (cp. O.C.485n.), esp. verbals (below, 677).
h)/|dh: on the form cp. O. T. 1525 n.

ti/ d' ou)k e)/mellon, sc. ei)de/nai: ‘why was I not likely to know it?’=‘of course I knew it.’ Plat. Rep. 605C pa/ndeino/n pou (e)sti/). ti/ d' ou) me/llei (sc. ei)=nai), ei)/per ge dra=| au)to/; Xen. Hellen. 4.1.6 to\n d' ui(o\n... e(w/rakas au)tou= w(s kalo/s e)sti;—ti/ d' ou) me/llw (sc. e(wrake/nai);

e)mfanh=. I prefer this to L's e)kfanh=, not because Soph. does not elsewhere use e)kfanh/s, but because, in the two places where Aesch. has used it, it has the sense of emerging into view ( Aesch. Pers. 398, the Greeks going into action at Salamis, or of standing out among other objects which are less distinct (a)ndro\s e)kfane\s te/kmar, Aesch. Eum. 244). The sense required here is simply, ‘public.’
kai\ dh=t', ‘And you indeed dared ...?’ Not, ‘And then’ (i.e. with that knowledge), which would be ka)=|ta.

*zeu/s is opposed to Creon's edicts, not only as supreme god and therefore guardian of all religious duty, but also in each of his two special qualities,—as xqo/nios (O. C. 1606 n.),—and as ou)ra/nios, since the denial of burial pollutes the realm of oi( a)/nw qeoi/ (1072).

tw=n ka/tw qew=n. For this rare gen. (instead of the regular dat.) with cu/noikos, cp. Lycurgus In Leocr. § 145 ou(=tos e)n tau/th| th=| xw/ra| su/noikos u(mw=n genh/setai. So O. C. 1382 *di/kh cu/nedros *zhno/s. ‘The Justice that dwells with the gods below’ is their personified right to claim from the living those religious observances which devote the dead to them. A person who omits such observances is defrauding Hades of his own: see 1070. This Justice, then, ‘has not ordained such laws’ as Creon's; it has not forbidden kinsfolk to bury their dead; on the contrary, it has bound them to do so. toiou/sd' … w(/risen is a certainly true correction of the MS. oi(\ tou/sd' … w(/risan. With the latter, oi(\ are either Zeus and *di/kh,—which would be the natural sense,—or oi( ka/tw qeoi/: and tou/sde no/mous are the laws of sepulture. But, after ta/de in 450, referring to Creon's edicts, the demonstrative pronoun here also should refer to them. Creon has just called his own laws tou/sde no/mous (449). If Antigone, immediately afterwards, used tou/sde no/mous to describe the divine laws, the stress on tou/sde would be extremely awkward. Further, toiou/sd' w(/risen has a pathetic force which renders it incomparably finer here than the somewhat tame statement of fact, ‘who have appointed the laws of burial among men.’

a)/grapta … no/mima. Arist. Rhet. 1.13 § 2 distinguishes (1) i)/dios no/mos, the particular law which each community defines for itself, which is partly written, partly (so far as consisting in custom) unwritten: (2) koino\s no/mos, the universal, unwritten law of nature (o( kata\ fu/sin). e)/sti ga/r, o(\ manteu/ontai/ ti pa/ntes, fu/sei koino
 di/kaion kai\ a)/dikon, ka)
 mhdemi/a koinwni/a pro\s a)llh/lous h)=| mhde\ sunqh/kh, oi(=on kai\ h( *sofokle/ous *)antigo/nh fai/netai le/gousa, o(/ti di/kaion, a)peirhme/non (=in spite of the edict), qa/yai to
 *polunei/kh, w(s fu/sei o)
 tou=to di/kaion. (Here he

quotes vv. 456 f.) Cp. O.T. 865 ff. no/moi... | u(yi/podes, ou)rani/an | di) ai)qe/ra teknwqe/ntes, with notes there. Thuc. 2.37 (no/moi) o(/soi a)/grafoi o)/ntes ai)sxu/nhn o(mologoume/nhn fe/rousi. When ‘the unwritten laws’ are thus called no/moi, the latter word is used figuratively. no/mima, observances sanctioned by usage, is the more correct word: so Plat. Legg. 793A observes that ta\ kalou/mena u(po\ tw=n pollw=n a)/grafa no/mima cannot properly be called no/moi, but still must be taken into account: desmoi\ ga\r ou(=toi pa/shs ei)si\ politei/as, metacu\ pa/ntwn o)/ntes tw=n e)n gra/mmasi teqe/ntwn te kai\ keime/nwn kai\ tw=n e)/ti teqhsome/nwn.
a)sfalh=, they stand fast for ever, like the qew=n e(/dos a)sfale\s ai)ei/ (Od. 6.42).

qnhto\n o)/nt', ‘one who is a mortal,’—i.e. Creon; but it is needless to supply se/ from ta\ sa/: the expression is the more forcible for being general. Cp. Eur. fr. 653 ou) qau=m' e)/lecas, qnhto\n o)/nta dustuxei=n: Eur. Alc. 799o)/ntas de\ qnhtou\s qnhta\ kai\ fronei=n xrew/n. Bothe's qnhta\ fu/nq', rashly adopted by Nauck, is a wanton change, which the ambiguity of the neut. pl. makes still worse.

u(perdramei=n, out-run, and so fig., prevail over: Eur. Phoen. 578 h)\n d' au)= krathqh=|s kai\ ta\ tou=d' u(perdra/mh|, and his cause prevail (Canter's certain corr. of u(pekdra/mh|): Ion 973kai\ pw=s ta\ krei/ssw qnhto\s ou)=s' u(perdra/mw; (prevail against Apollo). Ithas been proposed to refer qnhto\n o)/nq' to Antigone: but if she said, ‘I did not think your edicts so strong that I, a mortal, could prevail over divine law,’ du/nasqai would rather imply that, if she had been able, she would have been willing to do so. Besides, u(perdramei=n is more naturally said of the law-giver who sets his law above the other law.

nu=n ge ka)xqe/s. Cp. Her. 2.53 me/xri ou(= prw/hn te kai\ xqe/s. Plat. Legg. 677D w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n, xqe\s kai\ prw/hn gegono/ta (where the phrase is presently strengthened into to\n a)texnw=s xqe\s geno/menon). The usu. Attic form was xqe\s kai\ prw/hn, though prw/hn kai\ xqe/s also occurs. Cp. Catullus 61. 137 hodie atque heri. So heri et nudius tertius. Tryphon, an Alexandrian grammarian of the Augustan age, is quoted by Apollonius De Adverb. p. 556, 32 as saying, xqe\s a)ttikw/teron tou= e)xqe/s: but the reverse seems to be the case. Attic Comedy supports e)xqe/s against xqe/s in a majority of cases; though xqe/s may have been preferred, even in prose, after a vowel.
zh=|: cp. O. T. 482 zw=nta (of the oracles which are operative, effectual), and ib. 45 n.
'fa/nh, with prodelision of the temporal augment in the 6th place, as w(s e)gw\ 'fa/nhn O. C. 974 n.
tou/twn (sc. tw=n nomi/mwn)... th\n di/khn, the penalty belonging to these laws: i.e. the penalty of breaking them. The emphasis on tou/twn
shows that, like tau=ta just before, it refers to the no/mima: we cannot, therefore, render, ‘the penalty of such an act’ (sc. tou= u(perdramei=n).

e)n qeoi=si, the forensic e)n, denoting the tribunal: Plat. Legg. 916B diadikaze/sqw de\ e)/n tisi tw=n i)atrw=n: Gorg. 464D ei) de/oi e)n paisi\ diagwni/zesqai: Lys. or. 13 § 35 o( de\ dh=mos e)n tw=| dikasthri/w| e)n disxili/ois e)yhfi/sato (sc. poiei=n th\n kri/sin). Cp. O. T. 677 e)n...toi=sd', n.
dw/sein. The fut. inf. and the pres. inf. are equally common after me/llw in Soph. (O. T. 967 n.).

qanoume/nh ga/r introduces the reason for her conduct. ‘It was not likely that I should obey your edicts, and thereby incur punishment after death, for the sake of avoiding immediate death. For, as to death, I knew already that I must die some time or other; and if it is to be a little sooner, so much the better.’
ti/ d' ou)/; sc. e)/mellon e)ceide/nai (448).

kei) mh\ su\ prou)kh/rucas: Even if thou hadst not proclaimed death as the penalty of infringing the edict. The apodosis might be either (a) e)ch/|dh a)/n, implied in ti/ d' ou)/; or (b) e)/dei a)/n me qanei=n, implied in qanoume/nh. But (a) is best: ‘I should have known it, even if you had not brought it publicly to my knowledge.’ For kai\ ei) cp. O. T. 305 n.
tou= xro/nou, the natural term of life (cp. O. T. 963): expressed below by pri/n moi moi=ran e)ch/kein bi/ou (896).

au)/t', i.e. au)to/. Cp. El. 1267 ei)/ se qeo\s e)po/risen | a(me/tera pro\s me/laqra, daimo/nion | au)to\ ti/qhm' e)gw/: fr. 154 e)/xoim' a)\n au)to\ mh\ kakw=s a)peika/sai. au)=te (L) would mean, ‘again,’ ‘on the other hand’ (so far from thinking it a loss). The epic au)=te is used by Soph. in one lyric passage (Tr. 1010); by Aesch. both in lyrics and in trimeters; never by The Eur. simpler au)to/ is more probable here.

fe/rei = fe/retai (O. C. 6 n.).—The woman uses the masc. gender in putting the general case. Cp. Eur. Med. 1017 ou)/toi mo/nh su\ sw=n a)pezu/ghs te/knwn: | kou/fws fe/rein xrh\ qnhto\n o)/nta sumfora/s.

Kvičala and Wecklein reject these four verses, despairing of the difficulties found in vv. 466, 467, which have been variously amended; see Appendix. The alleged difficulties are, (1) par' ou)de\n a)/lgos: (2) the mention of the mother only: (3) the position of qano/nt', which might suggest the sense, ‘slain by my mother’: (4) hi)sxo/mhn (as L has it). Before dealing with these points, I would call attention to a trait which the impugners of these verses have overlooked, and which speaks strongly for the genuineness of the passage as a whole, corrupt though it be in certain words. That trait is the clause toi=sde d' ou)k a)lgu/nomai in 468, returning upon the thought par' ou)de\n a)/lgos in 466. This series of three clauses, in which the second is opposed to the first, and the third re-iterates the sense of the first, is peculiarly Sophoclean: cp. Ai. 1111 ou) ga/r ti th=s sh=s ou(/nek' e)strateu/sato | gunaiko/s,... | a)ll' ou(/nex' o(/rkwn oi(=sin h)=n e)nw/motos, | sou= d' ou)de/n: similar instances are O. T. 337 f., Tr. 431 ff. This touch would hardly have come from an interpolator.
a)/lgos, nom., sc. e)sti/: par' ou)de/n,

adv.: ‘is a pain in no appreciable degree,’ is a pain not worth a thought: as he might have said, ou)damou= a)/lgos e)sti/. The normal use of par' ou)de/n, ‘of no account,’ is either (a) with the verb ei)=nai, as O. T. 982 tau=q' o(/tw| | par' ou)de/n e)sti, or (b) with a verb meaning ‘to esteem,’ as above, v. 34, to\ pra=gm' a)/gein | ou)x w(s par' ou)de/n. The only peculiarity here is that, instead of a word in the general sense, ‘is esteemed’ (a)/getai), we have a virtual equivalent, tinged with the special thought of the moment, viz., ‘is a pain.’ Exactly so in El. 1327 we have po/tera par' ou)de
 tou= bi/ou kh/desq' e)/ti, instead of po/tera par' ou)de
 to
 bi/on a)/gete. Thus the suspicions as to the genuineness of par' ou)de
 a)/lgos are illusory.

a)ll' a)/n. For the position of a)/n (to which objection has been taken) cp. El. 333 a)lgw= 'pi\ toi=s parou=sin: w(/st' a)/n, ei) sqe/nos | la/boimi, dhlw/saim' a)\n oi(=' au)toi=s fronw=: ib. 439 a)rxh\n d' a)/n, ei) mh\ tlhmonesta/th gunh\ | pasw=n e)/blaste, ta/sde dusmenei=s xoa\s | ou)k a)/n poq', o(/n g' e)/kteine, tw=|d' e)pe/stefe.

a)/qapton h)nsxo/mhn ne/kun, had allowed him to be an unburied corpse. For a)/qapton without o)/nta, cp. Hist. An. 8. 8 du/natai d' a)/potos a)ne/xesqai (sc. w)/n): and O. T. 412 n. L has hi)sxo/mhn, and h)nsxo/mhn appears only as one of several readings in the later MSS.,—the other readings being manifestly impossible. The first question is, Could an Attic poet have used h)nsxo/mhn for h)nesxo/mhn? We can only say that we find nothing really like it, and that no support for it can be drawn from the Homeric forms in which a)na/ suffers apocope, viz., a)/nsxeo = a)nasxou= (Il. 23.587 etc.), a)nsxh/sesqai (Il. 5.104), a)nsxeta/ (Od. 2.63), a)nsxeqe/ein (Od. 5.320). Still, there is force in Prof. Tyrrell's remark (Classical Review, vol. 11. p. 140) that ‘h)nsxo/mhn is just the form in which an Attic poet would have applied apocope of a)na/, inasmuch as he would have felt that he was only sacrificing the redundant augment.’

In my first edition I placed in the text the emendation of Semitelos (1887) h)/|sxunan ku/nes. Cp. Il. 22.74 a)ll' o(/te dh\ polio/n te ka/rh polio/n te ge/neion | ai)dw= t' ai)sxu/nwsi ku/nes ktame/noio ge/rontos. If the es of ku/nes had been obliterated, ne/kun would easily have arisen (esp. after n); and a change of u into o would have taken h)/|sxunan far towards hi)sxo/mhn. But, while I still hold that this brilliant conjecture has no small degree of probability, I also recognise the justice of the criticism that the context here decidedly favours a verb in the first person.

Other emendations will be found in the Appendix. Most of them assume that we must have h)nesxo/mhn (or a)nesxo/mhn), and therefore alter the words qano/nt' a)/qapton and ne/kun in various ways, —usu. omitting ne/kun. The verses produced by these processes are wretched, while, from a palaeographical point of view, they are pure conjectures, which do not attempt to account for the tradition in L.—Two points remain. (1) to\n e)c e)mh=s | mhtro/s. This is like saying, ‘the son of the same womb.’ Cp. Eur. I. T. 497 po/teron a)delfw\ mhtro/s e)ston e)k mia=s; Yet it has been seriously urged by many critics, as a ground for change, that a mention of the father was indispensable. e)mh=s need not be altered to o(mh=s (Seyffert)

or mia=s (Meineke). (2) to\n e)c e)m. | mhtros qano/nt'. It is quite true that, when written, these words have an awkward ambiguity; but they would have had none when spoken, since a slight pause after mhtro/s would have been required to bring out qano/nt'. This is the right test to apply in the case of a play written to be acted.

sxedo/n ti, ‘almost,’ iron., ‘it might perhaps be said that...’: so El. 608 (also at the close of a defiant speech), ei) ga\r pe/fuka tw=nde tw=n e)/rgwn i)/dris, | sxedo/n ti th\n sh\n ou) kataisxu/nw fu/sin. Cp. ib. 550 ei) de\ soi\ dokw= fronei=n kakw=s | gnw/mhn dikai/an sxou=sa, tou\s pe/las ye/ge (end of a speech): also Ai. 1038, O. C. 1665.
mw/rw| mwri/an: cp. 754. The parh/xhsis gives bitterness (O.T. 371).
o)fliska/nw with dat., as Eur. Bacch. 854 ge/lwta qhbai/ois o)flei=n, etc.; but in this use it can also take pro/s tina or para/ tini (Plato). Cp. O. T. 511.
These two verses give a moment of stillness before the storm breaks forth. So at O. T. 404 four verses of the chorus divide the angry speech of Oedipus from the retort of Teiresias.

to\ ge/nnhma th=s paido/s (the offspring consisting in the maiden) the maiden his offspring, dhloi= (sc. o)\n) w)mo/n, shows herself fierce, e)c w)mou= patro/s, from a fierce sire (i.e. by the disposition inherited from him). Cp. 20 dhloi=s...kalxai/nousa (n.): the omission of o)/n is somewhat bold, but possible for poetry; cp. 709 w)/fqhsan kenoi/: Plat. Legg. 896B de/deiktai yuxh\ tw=n pa/ntwn presbuta/th. ge/nnhma occurs below, 628, O. T. 1167, and Tr. 315, meaning always ‘that which is begotten,’ the offspring. So in Plato the word always means the thing produced; for in Sophist. 266 D, to\ d' o(moiwma/twn tinw=n ge/nnhma, where Ast takes it as=‘confectio,’ the sense is, ‘the other a product (consisting in) certain images.’ In Aesch. PV 850 e)pw/numon de\ tw=n *dio\s gennhma/twn | te/ceis kelaino\n *)/epafon, the word, if genuine, would certainly mean ‘begetting’; but Wieseler's correction, ge/nnhm' a(fw=n (‘an offspring called after the touch of Zeus’), is highly probable. For to\ ge/nnhma th=s paido/s as=h( gennhqei=sa pai=s, cp. 1164 te/knwn spora=|, El. 1233 gonai\ swma/twn e)moi\ filta/twn (her brother), Eur. Med. 1098 te/knwn...bla/sthma. Here, the thought would have been complete without th=s paido/s (‘the offspring shows the father's fierceness’), which is added, as if by an after-thought, for the further definition of to\ ge/nnhma. I cannot believe that Soph. intended to\ ge/nnhma th=s paido/s to mean, ‘the inborn disposition of the maiden,’—an unexampled sense for ge/nnhma. On the other hand, all the emendations are unsatisfactory and improbable. The language, though somewhat peculiar, appears to be sound.

ei)/kein … kakoi=s, not ‘to succumb’ to them, but to bend before them (as trees before a storm, 713), with a prudent view to self-preservation. Cp. Aesch. PV 320 su\ d' ou)de/pw tapeino/s, ou)d' ei)/keis kakoi=s, | pro\s toi=s parou=si d' a)/lla prosl bei=n qe/leis.
a)ll' i)/sqi toi: so oft. in threat enings: cp. 1064: Tr. 1107 a)ll' eu)=<*> toi to/d' i)/ste: El. 298 a)ll' i)/sqi toi ti/sou<*> g' a)ci/an di/khn.

pi/ptein, instead of the regular pi/ptonta: this inf. after oi)=da (as= ‘I know that...’, not, ‘I know how to...’) is not rare in poetry; cp. O. T. 691, Ph. 1329, Aesch. Pers. 173, 431, 435: so after e)pi/stamai above, 293, and 1092.
o)pto\n … periskelh=, tempered to hardness: for the proleptic adj., cp. Thuc. 2.75 h)/|reto to\ u(/yos...me/ga, Eur. El. 376 (peni/a) dida/skei d' a)/ndra th=| xrei/a| kako/n (to be bad).

periskelh/s, dried or parched all round, from ske/llw, torrere: cp. Il. 23.190 mh\ pri\n me/nos h)eli/oio | skh/lei' a)mfi\ peri\ xro/a i)/nesin: hence, fig., ai/ periskelei=s fre/nes (Ai. 649): cp. retorridus. From the same rt come sklhro/s, skeleto/s (skeleton), and a)skelh/s (dried),—this last having a fig. sense in the Homeric a)skele\s ai)ei/ (‘stubbornly,’ Od. 1.68).
e)k puro/s, by means of fire; cp. 990: Ph. 710e)c w)kubo/lwn to/cwn...a)nu/seie...forba/n.

qrausqe/nta kai\ r(age/nta, ‘broken and shivered.’ r(age/nta is here the stronger word, in so far as it pictures the fragments of the ruptured iron flying asunder, while qrausqe/nta merely says that the iron is broken into pieces. As Heinrich Schmidt observes, the foremost idea in r(hgnu/nai is that of the separation of the parts,—the rent or rift being brought before us; in qrau/ein, that of a whole being broken into small pieces (Synonymik der Gr. Sprache, vol. 111. pp. 304 ff.).
xalinw=| d'. Cp. O. C. 714 i(/ppoisin to\n a)kesth=ra xalino/n, n. For smikrw=| cp. Ai. 1253 me/gas de\ pleura\ bou=s u(po\ smikra=s o(/mws | ma/stigos o)rqo\s ei)s o(do\n poreu/etai.

katartuqe/ntas, brought under discipline, made docile. katartu/w =to equip, or prepare (O. C. 71): then, like a(rmo/zw (O. C. 908), in a fig. sense, to bring into order, regulate, by a course of training: cp. Plat. Legg. 808D (a child is the u(bristo/taton qhri/wn), o(/sw| ma/lista e)/xei phgh
 tou= fronei=n mh/pw kathrtume/nhn (not yet brought under discipline): Plut. Mor. 38C (the sensuous impulses, ai( e)f' h(donh
 o(rmai/, are disastrous) a)
 e)a=| tis a)fe/tous, h(=| pefu/kasi, xwrei=n, kai\ mh\...katartu/h| th
 fu/sin (discipline the character). Plut. Them. 2tou\s traxuta/tous pw/lous a)ri/stous i(/ppous gi/nesqai fa/skwn, o(/tan h(=s prosh(kei tu/xwsi paidei/as kai\ katartu/sews (education and discipline). In Aesch. Eum. 473 the act. perf. part. kathrtukw\s (i(ke/ths) is said to be a term applied to a horse whose mouth was ‘fully furnished’ with teeth (i.e. which had shed its foal's teeth), and hence, ‘broken in,’ ‘tamed’: at any rate, it must be kept distinct from the passive katartuqei/s as used here.

Suspicion has fallen on e)kpe/lei, which occurs only here: Hesych. explains it by e)/cesti, and e)ce/pelen by e)cege/neto. He would hardly have invented the imperf., if he had not met with it in literature: and the metrical convenience of such a synonym for e)/cesti is a further reason for believing that it was current.
o(/stis: for the omission of the anteced. tou/tw|, see on 35: for the gender, on 464.
tw=n pe/las: cp. fr. 83 ('tis better to conquer by any means) h)\ dou=lon au)to\n o)/nta tw=n pe/las klu/ein.

au(/th d'. Creon began by addressing Antigone (473). He now denounces her to the Chorus. Cp. O. T. 1078 au(/th d' i)/sws, k.t.l. (of Iocasta).— u(bri/zein me
 … u(/bris d': epanaphora (O. T. 25 n.). The sense is, ‘Her disobedience was an act of consummate insolence; and her defiance now makes it worse.’ e)chpi/stato, ‘knew thoroughly,’ with bitterness; cp. 686; Eur. fr. 796 o(/stis swfronei=n e)pi/statai. to/t' is explained by u(perbai/nousa.—tou\s prok., which had been set forth: cp. O. T. 865, Eur. I. T. 1189 to
 no/mon...to
 prokei/menon.
tou/tois, neut., these deeds: cp. 468 kei/nois ...toi=sde.
dedrakui=an gela=n=to exult in having done it. For the partic., cp. Aristoph. Vesp. 1007 kou)k e)gxanei=tai/ s' e)capatw=n *(upe/rbolos.
nu=n, ‘now,’ i.e. ‘under these circumstances,’ is better than nun or ta)/r' here.

ei) tau=ta … kra/th, if this victory shall remain on record for her, without bringing her any punishment. For kra/th, deeds of might, and so prevalence, victory, cp. El. 476 *di/ka, di/kaia ferome/na xeroi=n kra/th: ib. 689 ou)k oi)=da toiou=d' a)ndro\s e)/rga kai\ kra/th. For kei/setai, cp. Pind. I. 4. 17ti\n d' e)n *)isqmw=| diplo/a qa/llois' a)reta/, | *fulaki/da, kei=tai, ‘for thee, Phylacidas, a double glory of valour is laid up at the Isthmus.’ So, here, kei/setai means, ‘placed to her credit,’ ‘permanently secured to her’; cp. the colloquialism, ‘to score a success.’ Other interpretations are:—(1) ‘If this royal power of mine shall have been instituted without penalty for her.’ For the word kra/th, this sense is tenable (cp. 60, 166, 173, O. T. 237): it is the whole phrase that appears strained. And tau=t' (said with bitter emphasis) evidently refers to Antigone's acts; cp. 483 tou/tois. Semitelos reads pei/setai: ‘If this sovereignty of mine’ (here Creon lifts his sceptre) ‘shall yield to her without punishing her.’ The verb would, however, be strange, and somewhat weak. (2) ‘If these edicts shall have been set forth without penalty for her.’ This last gives an impossible sense to kra/th. Aristoph. Ran. 1126 ff. illustrates the poetical ambiguity of kra/th, the debate there being whether, by patrw=|a kra/th, Aesch. meant, ‘a victory over a father,’ or ‘power derived from a father.’—For the form of a)nati/, cp. O. C. 1251 n.: for tau=ta without ta/, ib. 471.
a)delfh=s, (child of) a sister, a)delfidh=: for the gen., cp. 380, 825.

ei)/q' o(maimoneste/ra, ‘or nearer in blood to me than any member of my family.’ The gen. o(maimoneste/ras (see cr. n.) would mean, ‘or (child of) one nearer in blood to me,’ etc. She could be the child of no one nearer than a sister, unless it were of a mother or of a daughter; and it is far-fetched to suppose that Creon means, ‘my niece,—aye, my sister, or my granddaughter.’ All that he means is, ‘my niece,—aye, or the nearest relation possible.’ This is more simply and clearly said by the nom. o(maimoneste/ra. If the comparative were here restricted to the regular Sophoclean sense of the positive o(/maimos and o(mai/mwn, as meaning brother or sister (see on O. C. 330), then the gen. could be explained in another way, viz., as a rhetorical hyperbole: ‘sister's child, or child of one who was thrice my sister,’ —like Plato Lysis 210C o( path\r kai\ h( mh/thr kai\ ei)/ ti tou/twn oi)keio/tero/n e)sti.

Hyperbole is congenial to Creon's excitement; cp. 1040. But the addition, tou= panto\s *z. e(rkei/ou, ill suits this, while, on the other hand, it agrees well with the nom. o(maimoneste/ra. On the whole, then, I incline to prefer the nom.; but the point is a nice one, and the gen. is quite tenable.
kurei= (ou)=sa), =e)sti/: cp. O. T. 362 fone/a...kurei=n.

tou= panto\s *zhno\s e(rkei/ou = pa/ntwn tw=n oi)kei/wn (schol.): so Eustath. 1930, 30 e(rkei=on *di/a e)kei=nos (Sophocles) tou\s e)n oi)/kw| pa/ntas dhloi=. The altar of *zeu\s e(rkei=os stood in the court-yard (au)lh/) in front of the Greek house; e(/rkos denoting the buildings which enclose the au)lh/, or, sometimes, the space so enclosed, the au)lh/ itself. In Od. 22.334 Phemius thinks of passing from the me/garon into the au)lh/, *dio\s mega/lou poti\ bwmo
 | *(erkei/ou. (Cp. my Introd. to Homer, p. 58.) This is the altar at which Peleus was sacrificing, au)lh=s e)n xo/rtw| (Il. 11.774 : cp. Athen. 5, p. 189 F): as in Plat. Rep. 328C there is sacrifice in the au)lh/. So in Her. 6.68 Demaratus supplicates his mother especially by tou= *(erkei/ou *dio\s tou=de (whose altar or image he is touching, katapto/menos). Priamisslain pro\s...krhpi/dwn ba/qrois...*zhno\s e(rkei/ou (Eur. Tro. 16),—e)pi\ th=| e)sxa/ra|, tou= *(erkei/ou (Paus. 4.17.4): cp. Ovid Ibis 286, Cui nihil Hercei profuit ara Iovis. In Cratinus jun., *xei/rwn 1 ff. (c. 350 B.C.), a returned exile says, cuggenei=s | kai\ fra/toras kai\ dhmo/tas eu(rw
 mo/lis | ei)s to\ kulikei=on e)negra/fhn (put on the feasting-list—para\ prosdoki/an for ei)s to\ grammatei=on): *zeu\s e)/stimoi | e(rkei=os, e)/sti fra/trios: where e(rkei=os corresponds with cuggenei=s. Dionysius 1. 67 expresses the attributes of the Roman Penates by the words patrw=|oi, gene/qlioi, kth/sioi, mu/xioi, e)rkei=oi (for e(rki/ous in his text should be e(rkei/ous: so L has e(rki/ou here).—In relation to the family, *zeu/s is also gene/qlios ( Pind. O. 8. 16: cp. cu/naimos, Pind. O. 659), o(mo/gnios, and e)fe/stios (as presiding over household life: Ai. 492, Her. 1.44).—For the god's name used to denote that which he protects, cp. Eur. Hec. 345 pe/feugas to
 e)mo
 i(ke/sion *di/a, = my supplication, with its consequences.

a)lu/ceton. The pres. ind. a)lu/skw occurs in Apollon. Rhod., and the pres. part. in Hom. Od.; otherwise we find only the fut. (usu. a)lu/cw, but a)lu/comai, Hes. Op. 363) and aor. h)/luca (once midd., e)calu/cwmai Ai. 656). The gen. mo/rou follows the analogy of a)polu/esqai, a)palla/ttesqai, etc. The regular constr. of the verb is with the acc. (as in the Homeric kh=ras a)lu/cas), and so Eur. always has an acc. with e)ch/luca. In El. 627 qra/sous | tou=d' ou)k a)lu/ceis, the gen. is not like this, but causal (‘for this boldness’). Oppian's e)ch/luce mo/roio ( Hal. 3. 104) was obviously suggested by our verse. So in Ph. 1044 Soph. has ventured on th=s no/sou pefeuge/nai, thinking, doubtless, of the Homeric pefugme/nos h)=en a)e/qlwn.
kai\ ga\r ou)=n, for indeed: cp. 771 eu)= ga\r ou)=n, O. C. 980 ou) ga\r ou)=n, ib. 985 a)ll' e(\n ga\r ou)=n.
