e)paitiw=mai kei/nhn, I accuse her, bouleu=sai i)/son tou=de ta/fou, of having had an equal share in plotting this burial. For the inf. after e)paitia=sqai cp. El. 603 o(\n polla\ dh/ me soi\ tre/fein mia/stora | e)ph|tia/sw. Aristoph. Vesp. 1446 *ai)/swpon oi( *delfoi/ pote...fia/lhn e)ph|tiw=nto kle/yai. Plat. Critias 120C ei)/ ti/s ti parabai/nein au)tw=n ai)tiw=|to/ tina. For the substantival i)/son with gen., cp. Eur. Ion 818 o(moi=os ei)=nai th=s tu/xhs t' i)/son fe/rein: id. Ph. 547dwma/twn e)/xwn i)/son.—Another construction is possible: i)/son e)paitiw=mai kei/nhn tou=de tou= ta/fou, bouleu=sai: ‘I charge her equally with this burial,—i.e. with plotting it.’ The constr. with the gen. is frequent (Aesch. PV 974 h\= ka)me\ ga/r ti cumfora=s e)paitia=|;): the objection here is that the epexegetic infin. bouleu=sai, requiring a case different from that governed by e)paitiw=mai, ought to come last: cp. Plat. Crito 52B ou)d' e\piqumi/a se a)/llhs po/lews ou)d' a)/llwn no/mwn e)/laben ei)de/nai: Eur. Med. 1399 xrh/|zw sto/matos | pai/dwn o( ta/las prosptu/casqai. In O. T. 644 ei)/ se/ ti | de/drak', o)loi/mhn, w(=n e)paitia=| me dra=n, w(=n might represent either (a) tou/twn w(=n, dra=n being epexegetic, or (b) tou/twn a(/ (acc. governed by dra=n); the latter is simplest.
bouleu=sai, of plotting mischief, as Tr. 807 toiau=ta...patri\ bouleu/sas' e)mw=|: Ai. 1055 stratw=|...bouleu/sas fo/non.

kai/ nin kalei=t', ‘And now call her.’ This is the kai/ so frequent in the orators, when the speaker turns to call for witnesses, documents, etc.: Lys. or. 16 § 13 kai/ moi a)na/bhqi, or. 13 § 35 kai/ moi a)na/gnwqi to\ yh/fisma.
lussw=san … ou)d' e)p.: cp. O. T. 58 n.: Her. 9.55 maino/menon kai\ ou) frenh/rea.

e)ph/bolon, ‘in possession of’ (compos), a word used by Aesch. ( Aesch. P. V. 444frenw=n, Aesch. Ag. 542no/sou), but not by Eur. Itbelonged to the diction of Ionian epos, appearing first in Od. 2.319 (ou) ga\r nho\s e)ph/bolos ou)d' e)reta/wn), and is used by Herod. ; Plato, too, admits it (as Euthyd. 289B e)pisth/mhs e)phbo/lous). Düntzer would derive it from e)pi/ and a)/bolos (‘meeting with’), assumed from the late verb a)bole/w as=a)ntibole/w ( Rhod. Ap. 3. 1148); but it is more likely that it was simply an epic metrical license for e)pi/bolos. The sense seems to come from e)piba/llomai as=‘to throw oneself on’ a thing, and so take possession of it.

o( qumo\s tw=n … texnwme/nwn, the mind of those who are planning nothing aright (planning utter mischief) in the dark, filei= klopeu\s h(|rh=sqai, is apt to stand convicted of its treason, pro/sqen, beforehand,—i.e. before the treasonable deed has been done. For the order of words (o( qumo/s being divided from the attributive gen. by the predicate), cp. Thuc. 2.8 h( de\ eu)/noia para\ polu\ e)poi/ei tw=n a)nqrw/pwn ma=llon e)s tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous. Ismene has not yet been caught in a disloyal act; but her guilty conscience has already shown itself. klopeu/s here answers to kle/ptein as=‘to do by stealth or fraud,’ Ai. 1137 po/ll' a)\n kakw=s la/qra| su\ kle/yeias kaka/. It denotes the plotter's treachery towards the State, not the betrayal of the plotter by his own conscience (as some have taken it). h(|rh=sqai klopeu/s (without w)/n), as O. T. 576 foneu\s a(lw/somai: the perf. (expressing that the exposure is already decisive), like hu(rh=sqai ib. 1050.

texnwme/nwn midd., as usual; cp. Ph. 80texna=sqai kaka/. This is better than to make it pass., as a gen. absol., (‘when utter mischief is being contrived,’) a constr. which seems to require the change of o)rqw=s to o)rqw=n, since ta\ mhde
 o)rqw=s could hardly mean, ‘things which (are) in no wise well,’ sc. e)/xonta. oi( mhde
 o)rqw=s texnw/menoi=those who plan nothing in such a way as to be right (the generic mh/): cp. Ph. 407pan<*>s a)
 lo/gou kakou= | glw/ssh| qigo/nta kai\ panourgi/as, a)f' h(=s | mhde
 di/kaion e)s te/los me/lloi poiei=n.
ge me/ntoi: cp. O. T. 442 n. ‘(I hate such plotting in the dark:) however, I certainly hate this also,—when a detected traitor seeks to glorify the treason.’

Ismene's guilty terror is contrasted with Antigone's impudent hardihood,—as Creon deems it. misw= … o(/tan, like me/mnhsai o(/te...e)poi/hsas ( Xen. Oec. 2. 11), oi\=d' h(ni/k' *ai)/as ei(=lke (Eur. Tro. 70) etc.
e)/peita, like ei)=ta, as Ai. 760 o(/stis a)nqrw/pou fu/sin | blastw\n e)/peita mh\ kat' a)/nqrwpon fronh=|.

kallu/nein, to make kalo/s (fr. 786 pro/swpa kallu/nousa, of the waxing moon), here, to make specious: so Plat. Legg. 944B eu)dia/bolon kako\n kallu/nwn (a soldier excusing himself for o(/plwn a)pobolh/).

qe/leis ti mei=zon, sc. poiei=n,— not that qe/lw could not take a simple acc., but a Greek would mentally supply a general inf. to balance kataktei=nai: cp. Thuc. 3.85 a)po/gnoia...tou= a)/llo ti (sc. poiei=n) h)\ kratei=n th=s gh=s.
e(lw/n: cp. O. T. 641 ktei=nai labw/n.
e)gw\ me\n ou)de/n. He desires nothing more,—and will take nothing less.
a(/pant' e)/xw: cp. Eur. Or. 749 tou=to pa/nt' e)/xw maqw/n (‘tell me that, and I am satisfied’).
a)resto\n ou)de/n, not a)resto\s ou)dei/s: cp. O. T. 1195 brotw=n | ou)de/n.

mhd' a)resqei/h. Cp. 686. If sound (as it seems to be), this is a solitary example of the aor. pass. h)re/sqhn as=‘became pleasing,’ and must be defended by the pass. (or midd.) a)re/skomai as used by , Herod. 6. 128h)re/skonto, ‘they were approved’ (or, ‘they pleased’): 9. 79 mh/te *ai)ginh/th|si a(/doimi mh/te toi=si tau=ta a)re/sketai (those who approve this course). Considering the Ionic affinities of Attic Tragedy, this use of a)re/skomai in Ionic prose seems a sufficient warrant for a corresponding use of h)re/sqhn, whether we take it as properly passive (‘was approved’), or as a pass. form used to supplement the middle (‘pleased’). I do not add Eur. fr. 942 qeoi=s a)re/skou, because there I should read qeou\s a)re/skou, ‘propitiate the gods,’ the Attic use of the midd.; cp. Xen. Mem. 4.3.16 no/mos de\ dh/pou pantaxou= e)sti kata\ du/namin i(eroi=s qeou\s a)re/skesqai, ‘to propitiate the gods with sacrifice. The Attic passive meant ‘I am pleased,’ Thuc. 1.129 toi=s lo/gois toi=s a)po\ sou= a)re/skomai, 5. 37 oi( boiwta/rxai h)re/skonto, but occurs only in pres. and impf.: h)re/sqhn, as the corresponding aor., appears only in later Greek, as Paus. 2.13.8 ou)k a)resqei\s tw=| doqe/nti pw/mati. The traditional a)resqei/h, then, is at least not less probable than Hermann's a)resqei/hn, when the whole question is viewed in the light of attested usage. As to Elmsley's neat a)re/st' ei)/h, a fatal objection to it is the change to the impers. plur.; as if one said, ‘not one of your words pleases me; and never may I feel pleasure:’ (without, ‘in them’).
ta)ma/, a general phrase, ‘my views.’ Cp. El. 1050 ou)/te ga\r su\ ta)/m' e)/ph | tolma=|s e)painei=n ou)/t' e)gw\ tou\s sou\s tro/pous.
e)/fu with partic. (‘are naturally ...’), cp. O. T. 9 pre/pwn e)/fus.

kai/toi marks the transition to another and higher point of view than Creon's. ‘Thou wilt never approve my deed. And yet how could I have won a better claim to the approval of all who judge rightly?’ In kai/toi po/qen kle/os g' the absence of caesura gives a slower movement, just as in v. 44: she communes with her own thought. kle/os … eu)klee/steron, like du/spnooi pnoai/ (587), fre/nes du/sfrones (1261), po/noi du/sponoi (1277): Ph. 894cu/nhqes...e)/qos. Distinguish the case of the adj. compounded with a noun merely cognate in sense to the subst.; above, v. 7 n.

e)n ta/fw| tiqei=sa, i.e. symbolically, by sprinkling dust and pouring xoai/: cp. 80, 395, and O. C. 1410 n.— tou/tois pa=si le/goito a)/n, by all these it would be said, tou=to a(nda/nein (au)toi=s), that this seems good to them: for dat. with pres. pass. (a constr. usually restricted to the pf. pass.) cp. Menander Sentent. 511 ta)lhqe\s a)nqrw/poisin ou)x eu(ri/sketai. If the datives were taken with a(nda/nein, le/goito a)/n would be too indefinite. At the same time the proximity of a(nda/nein has influenced the construction. tau)to\ has been suggested, but there is nothing suspicious in tou/tois tou=to, which Nauck groundlessly condemns.—The pres. e)gklh/|oi is required by the sense, since the act is a continuing one; e)gklh/|sai would refer to some given moment or particular occasion. The MSS. favour the aor., but most of the recent edd. rightly give the pres.

a)ll' h( turanni/s. ‘(If these men dared to say what they think, they would applaud me.) But royalty has the advantage of being able to do and say what it pleases, without being opposed in word or deed’:—and so these men are silent. These are two excellent and vigorous lines,—not only free from the slightest internal mark of spuriousness, but admirably suited to their place, both by thought and by expression. It was an extraordinary freak of arbitrary criticism to reject them. The reasons assigned for doing so deserve mention only for their curious weakness; as (a) a)ll' h( ought to be h( ga/r—Dindorf: (b) Antigone should not mention the advantages of the turanni/s— JacobA. : (c) Creon could not be reproached with dra=n le/gein q' a)\ bou/letai—Nauck: of which last objection Bellermann, in his simple and triumphant vindication of these verses, justly says that it is ‘wholly unintelligible.’ (d) Wecklein, too, has effectively defended them. We may add that Creon's reply in v. 508, which refers primarily to vv. 504 f., does not therefore ignore vv. 506 f., since these two vv. cohere closely with the former: vv. 504—507 express a single thought. For similar references in tragedy to the turanni/s, as it was viewed by Greeks in the historical age, cp. Aesch. PV 224 f., Eur. Ion 621—632.
mou/nh: tw=nde refers to the Chorus: for the Ionic form, cp. 308, 705.

tou=to … o(ra=|s, seest this,=‘takest this view’; viz., that thy deed is right, and that only my power prevents its being publicly approved. A very rare use of o(ra=n: indeed, I know no strictly similar instance, for we cannot compare O. T. 284, where see n.: still, it is natural enough. Cp. Phaedr. 276 A a)/llon o(rw=men lo/gon. So we say, ‘I do not see it,’=‘I cannot take that view.’ mou/nh tw=nde: cp. 101 ka/lliston...tw=n prote/rwn, n.

u(pi/llousin (for the spelling cp. n. in Appendix on 340), lit., ‘turn’ (or ‘roll’) ‘under,’ said of an animal putting its tail between its legs; cp. Eur. fr. 544 (from his *oi)di/pous,—referring to the Sphinx) ou)ra\n d' u(pi/las' u(po\ leonto/poun ba/sin | kaqe/zet'. Verg. Aen. 11. 812 (a terrified wolf) caudamque remulcens Subiecit pavitantem utero. Here, ‘keep down’ the utterance of their thoughts; ‘make their lips subservient’ to thee. Cp. sai/nein, adulari.—Euphony commends, though metre does not require, the n e)felkustiko/n, which L gives. Cp. 571.

su\ d' ou)k e)paidei=; And art thou not ashamed of it (cp. e)paisxu/nomai), if thou thinkest otherwise than they do?— thinkest, namely, that thou art free to act on thy own views, regardless of thy king. For the sake of argument, he concedes their possible sympathy with her, but insists on their loyal behaviour. She answers, ‘No, I am not ashamed, for I am doing nothing shameful.’
o(/maimos always of brother and sister in Soph. : O.C. 330 n.

e)k mia=s te. The soundness of the text is thoroughly vindicated by Plat. Legg. 627C (quoted by Schneidewin), polloi\ a)delfoi/ pou ge/noint' a)\n e(no\s a)ndro/s te kai\ mia=s ui(ei=s, which also confirms the MS. te against the conjecture ge.
pw=s dh=t': why, then, dost thou render (to Polyneices) a tribute impious in the sight of Eteocles?—i.e., which places the latter on the same level with the former.

e)kei/nw|, ethic dat., ‘in his judgment’: cp. 904, O. C. 1446 a)na/ciai... pa=sin, and ib. 810 n., O. T. 40. We cannot well render, ‘impious towards him,’ which would be pro\s or ei)s e)kei=non: nor can the dat. be one of ‘interest,’ as though dussebh= were equivalent to blabera/n. The next verse agrees well with e)kei=nw| being ethic dat.: ‘he will not so testify,’ =‘he will not say that he thinks my act impious.’

xa/rin is usu. explained as acc. of the inner object, like tima=|s timh/n. But it would evidently be awkward to have an objective acc. added, as timw= xa/rin au)to/n. Rather tima=|s is here slightly deflected from the sense, ‘to honour by observance,’ ‘to observe duly,’ as Eur. Tro. 1210 ou(\s *fru/ges no/mous | timw=sin, Ion 1045th\n eu)se/beian...tima=n, and means, ‘to render duly,’ as religious observance requires. So I should take it also in the parallel phrase, Eur. Or. 828 patrw/|an | timw=n xa/rin, duly rendering grace to thy sire.— o( katqanw\n ne/kus: cp. 26.
ei)/ toi, siquidem: O. T. 549.— sfe: cp. 44 n.

e)c i)/sou, only on a level with, as O. T. 1019. So i)/son=‘equally little’ (Her. 2.3), or ‘equally vain’ (id. 8. 79): and id. 8. 109 ta/ te i(ra\ kai\ ta\ i)/dia e)n o(moi/w| e)poie/eto, i.e. made sacred things of (only) the same account as things profane. Cp. 393.
ou) ga/r ti dou=los. No, Eteocles

cannot complain, for Polyneices was not his slave—his natural inferior—but his brother, and had the same claim on me that he had. Creon insists on the difference between the loyal man and the disloyal. Antigone dwells on the fact that both men had the same claim on her natural piety, and (519) on her sense of religious duty.
porqw=n de/: for de/ introducing an objection, cp. O. T. 379: for the partic., ib. 1001, 1011.

o( d', but the other (perished) a)ntista\s u(pe\r th=sde gh=s, as this land's champion. u(/per is paroxytone as virtually following its case, since the gen. is supplied from th/nde gh=n. Cp. Ai. 1231 tou= mhde\n a)nte/sths u(/per.

tou/tous, the reading of the MSS., has been rejected by nearly all modern editors in favour of i)/sous, which the Scholiast mentions as a variant. But the simple tou/tous is perfectly suitable, —‘these laws,’ the laws of sepulture (to\ qa/ptein, as a schol. paraphrases); and everything that i)/sous would convey is already expressed by o(/mws. ‘One was the country's foe, the other its champion —granted. Nevertheless Hades desires these laws,’—i.e. even in the case of the foe. A corruption of i)/sous into tou/tous is very improbable. Rather i)/sous was merely one of those conjectures which so often appear in the margin of the MSS., having for their object the supposed improvement of a point. The MS. i)/sos in 520 does not strengthen the case for i)/sous here.

The MS. laxei=n i)/sos is usu. explained, ‘equal in respect to obtaining (rites),’ i.e. with an equal claim to rites. The phrase is not only without any parallel, but seems impossible. i)/sos laxei=n no/mima would be very strange; i)/sos laxei=n, absolutely, is stranger still. The train of thought strongly favours i)/sous, as Nauck suggests and Semitelos reads. ‘Hades may desire these rites; but the good man does not (desire) to receive only the same rites as the wicked’: i.e. Eteocles will not be satisfied with the equality merely because Polyneices was his brother (517): he will think of the contrast between that brother's merits and his own. The dead can be said lagxa/nein no/mous (of burial), in the sense of obtaining that which the no/moi give. Therefore we need not write i)/son or i)/sa.

ka/twqen, simply ‘below’: cp. 1070, Eur. Alc. 424 tw=| ka/twqen a)spo/ndw| qew=|: Dem. or. 23 § 28 o( ka/twqen no/mos, the law below (=the continuation of a law already cited). We need not understand here, ‘if these things are approved from below.’ ka/tw 'sti\n has the MS. authority: but it is most improbable that Soph. would have given such a needlessly unpleasing verse, and the change is sufficiently explained by a later belief that the sense required ka/tw.

eu)agh=, right in respect to a)/gos, i.e. free from it, pure (O. T. 921). She means: ‘who can tell if Eteocles, in the world below, will not think it consonant with piety that Polyneices should be honoured?’ Perhaps earthly feuds are made up there. Creon answers, ‘No,—foe once, foe always,— even in death: Eteocles will resent it.’ Cp. Od. 11.543 where the spirit of Ajax in Hades will not speak to Odysseus— kexolwme/nh ei(/neka ni/khs | th/n min e)gw\ ni/khsa.—There would be far less point in Creon's words if we took them to mean, ‘my dead foe is still my foe’ (cp. Ai. 1348, 1372).

ou)/toi sune/xqein. ‘Even if my brothers hate each other still, my nature prompts me, not to join Eteocles in hating Polyneices, but to love each brother as he loves me’: cp. 73 fi/lh...fi/lou me/ta. Cp. Polybius 1. 14 filo/filon dei= ei\=nai to\n a)gaqo\n a)/ndra kai\ filo/patrin, kai\ summisei=n toi=s fi/lois tou\s e)xqrou\s kai\ sunagapa=n tou\s fi/lous. Eur. imitates our verse, I. A. 407 (Agam. to Menelaus) susswfronei=n ga/r, ou)xi\ sunnosei=n e)/fun, ‘nay, my sympathies are with prudence, not with frenzy.’

nu^n, as Ai. 87, Tr. 92, Ph. 1196, but nu_n O.T. 658, and oft.—kei/nous = tou\s e)kei=, the dead. Nauck proposes nekrou/s, which would be a deplorable change. For the pause after the emphatic word, cp. 46 n.

kai\ mh\n introducing the new person: O. C. 549 n. At Creon's command (491), two pro/spoloi had gone to bring Ismene. The door from which she now enters is that by which she had left the stage (99). It is supposed to lead to the gunaikwni=tis (cp. 578).

ei)bome/nh, the correction of Triclinius for the MS. leibome/nh, enables us to keep da/krua, instead of changing it to da/kru, when fila/delfa must be taken as adv. (cp. O. T. 883 n.). The Schol. so took it (he paraphrases by filade/lfws), and it would seem, therefore, that he read da/kru leibome/nh. But, though this constr. is quite admissible, it would be far more natural that fila/delfa should agree with da/krua. In O. C. 1251 we have lei/bwn da/kruon: neither lei/bw nor ei)/bw occurs elsewhere in Soph. ; and the only other place in Tragedy where ei)/bw has good support is Aesch. PV 400, where Hermann, by reading dakrusi/stakton a)p' o)/sswn p(adinw=n d' ei)bome/na p(e/os, for the MS. dakrusi/stakton d'...leibome/na, restores the metre. But kata\ da/kruon ei)/bein and da/krua lei/bein were equally familiar as Homeric phrases; and if an Attic poet could use the latter, there was certainly no reason why he should not use the former. I may remark, too, that ka/tw points to a reminiscence of the phrase
with ei)/bein, for Homer never says kata\ da/krua lei/bein. Nothing is more natural than that ei)bome/nh should have become leibome/nh in the MSS., the latter word being much the commoner.

ka/tw, adv., ‘downwards’: cp. 716, fr. 620 w=)ta kullai/nwn ka/tw. Nauck's objection, that ka/tw ei)bome/nh could not stand for kateibome/nh, would have force only if ka/tw were necessarily a prep., substituted for kata/. He proposes katai\ (cp. kataiba/ths).

nefe/lh d' o)fru/wn u(/per, a cloud of grief (resting) on her brow,—as dark clouds rest on a mountain-summit: cp. Eur. Hipp. 173 stugno\n d' o)fru/wn ne/fos au)ca/netai: Aesch. Theb. 228 ta\n a)mh/xanon | ka)k xalepa=s du/as u(/perq' o)mma/twn | krhmname/nan nefe/lan: so sunnefh/s = sunwfruwme/nos. Cp. Deme supercilio nubem ( Hor. Ep. 1. 18. 94). The cloud of sorrow is associated with the rain of tears: cp. Shaksp. Ant. 3. 2. 51 Will Caesar weep?—He has a cloud in 's face.

ai(mato/en, here, ‘suffused with blood,’ darkly flushed. This application of ai(mato/eis to the human face seems unparalleled, though in Anthol. P. 6. 154 Leonidas of Tarentum (c. 280 B.C.) has fu/lla te peptame/nwn ai(mato/enta r(o/dwn. Eur. Phoen. 1487 was less daring when he called a dark blush to\n u(po\ blefa/rois | foi/nik' (‘crimson’), e)ru/qhma prosw/pou. It recalls the well-known fragment of Ionin Athen. 603 E, where the schoolmaster objects to Phrynichus's e)pi\ porfure/ais parh=|si, on the principle, ou) ka/rta dei= to\ kalo\n tw=| mh\ kalw=| fainome/nw| ei)ka/zein,—and Sophocles makes a lively defence of it. Shaksp. uses ‘bloody’ for ‘blood-red’: Hen. V. 1. 2. 101 unwind your bloody flag.

r(e/qos = pro/swpon, as H. F. 1203 pa/res a)p' o)mma/twn | pe/plon, a)po/dike, r(e/qos a)eli/w| dei=con. Cp. Eustathius 1090, 27 i)ste/on o(/ti r(e/qea oi( me\n a)/lloi ta\ me/lh fasi/n, *ai)olei=s de\ mo/noi, kata\ tou\s palaiou/s, to\ pro/swpon r(e/qos kalou=sin. This suggests that the Attic dramatists had lyric precedent for this use of r(e/qos: as Lycophron (173) may also have had for using it as =sw=ma. The Homeric use is confined to the phrase e)k r(eqe/wn (thrice in Il., never in Od.).
ai)sxu/nei, i.e. overcasts its sunny beauty: cp. Thomson, Spring 21, Winter ...b<*> his driving sleets Deform the day delightless.

su\ d' with fe/r', ei)pe/ (534).— u(feime/nh, submissa, ‘lurking,’ as a viper lurks under stones: H. A. 8. 15 ai( d' e)/xidnai u(po\ ta\s pe/tras a)pokru/ptousin e(auta/s. H. F. 72 sw/|zw neossou\s o)/rnis w(\s u(feime/nh, like a cowering hen (u(feime/nous Kirchhoff). The word may also suggest a contrast between Antigone's bolder nature and the submissive demeanour of Ismene (cp. El. 335 nu=n d' e)n kakoi=s moi plei=n u(feime/nh| dokei=, ‘with shortened sail’). But we should not render it by ‘submissive’; its primary reference is to the image of the e)/xidna. Others render, ‘having crept in,’ clam immissa. The act. can mean to ‘send in secretly’ (see on u(fei/s, O. T. 387), but the pass. u(fi/esqai does not seem to occur in a corresponding sense.

e)/xidna: cp. Tr. 770 (the poison works) foini/as | e)xqra=s e)xi/dnhs i)o\s w(/s. So of Clytaemnestra (Aesch. Cho. 249): Eur. Andr. 271 e)xi/dnhs kai\ puro\s peraite/rw: cp. Ion 1262.This image for domestic treachery is quaintly illustrated by the popular notions mentioned in Mirab. 165 (p. 846 b 18 Berl. ed.) tou= perknou= e)/xews th=| e)xi/dnh( sugginome/nou,

h( e)/xidna e)n th=| sunousi/a| th
 kefalh
 a)poko/ptei. dia\ tou=to kai\ ta\ te/kna, w(/sper to
 qa/naton tou= patro\s meterxo/mena, th
 gaste/ra th=s mhtro\s diarrh/gnusin. (Cp. Shaksp. Per. 1. 1. 64 I am no viper, yet I feed On mother's flesh.)

lh/qousa/ m' e)ce/pines. It seems unnecessary to suppose a confusion of images. The venom from the echidna's bite is here described as working insidiously, and, at first, almost insensibly. So Heracles says of the poison, which he has already (Tr. 770) compared to the echidna's, e)k de\ xlwro\n ai(=ma/ mou | pe/pwken h)/dh, Tr. 1055. Cp. El. 784 h(/de ga\r mei/zwn bla/bh | cu/noikos h)=n moi, tou)mo\n e)kpi/nous' a)ei\ | yuxh=s a)/kraton ai(=ma.

a)/ta ka)panasta/seis. The dual is commended, as against a)/tas, by a certain scornful vigour; just as at 58 the dual has an emphasis of its own. And the combination with a plural is no harsher than (e.g.) Laches p. 187 A au)toi\ eu(retai\ gegono/te. Cp. O. C. 530 au(=tai de\ du/' e)c e)mou=...pai=de, du/o d' a)/ta.

e)panasta/seis, abstract (like a)/ta) for concrete: so 646 po/nous (bad sons): kei=nos h( pa=sa bla/bh ( Ph. 622), o)/leqros, etc. qro/nwn, object. gen. (e)pani/stasqai qro/nois). Creon suspects the sisters of being in league with malcontent citizens (cp. 289), who wish to overthrow his rule.
to\ mh\: cp. 443. [Dem. ] or. 57 § 59 ou)k a)\n e)como/saito mh\ ou)k ei)de/nai. Plat. Legg. 949A e)carnhqe/nti kai\ e)comosame/nw|.

o(morroqei=, concurs, consents: fr. 446 o(morroqw=, sunqe/lw, | sumparaine/sas e)/xw. Schol. ad Aristoph. Av. 851 o(morroqei=n de\ kuri/ws to\ a(/ma kai\ sumfw/nws e)re/ssein. So Orphic Argonaut. 254 o(morroqe/ontes, ‘rowing all together’ (cp. above on 259). The image thus agrees with cu/mploun in 541. Ismene remembers her sister's words: ‘even if you should change your mind, I could never welcome you now as my fellow-worker’ (69). She says, then, ‘I consider myself as having shared in the deed—if my sister will allow me.’ Nauck sadly defaces the passage by his rash change, ei)/per h(/d': o(morroqw=.

th=s ai)ti/as depends on both verbs. cummeti/sxw having prepared the ear for a partitive gen., no harshness is felt in the reference of that gen. to fe/rw also. We cannot take the gen. with the first verb only, and regard kai\ fe/rw as parenthetic. Some real instances of such a parenthetic construction are given in the n. on 1279 f.; but the supposed examples often break down on scrutiny. Thus in Ai. 274, e)/lhce ka)ne/pneuse th=s no/sou, the gen. goes with both verbs (cp. on O. C. 1113): for O. C. 1330, see n. there: in Aesch. PV 331 pa/ntwn metasxw\n kai\ tetolmhkw\s e)moi/, the pron. might be dat. of interest with the second partic.; but we ought perhaps to read suntetolmhkw/s t' e)moi/.
a)ll' ou)k e)a/sei s': cp. O. C. 407 a)ll' ou)k e)a=| tou)/mfulon ai(=ma/ s', w)= pa/ter.
'koinwsa/mhn: prodelision of the augment, as 457 (n.): cp. O. C. 1602 taxei= 'po/reusan su\n xro/nw|.

cu/mploun: cp. H. F. 1225 kai\ tw=n kalw=n me\n o(/stis a)polau/ein qe/lei, | sumplei=n de\ toi=s fi/loisi dustuxou=sin ou)/. I. T. 599 o( naustolw=n ga/r ei)m) e)gw\ ta\s sumfora/s, | ou(=tos de\ sumplei=.
Cp. Ph. 1293w(s qeoi\ cuni/stores.
lo/gois, and not e)/rgois. Cp. Ph. 307lo/gois | e)leou=si, they show compassion in word (only). Theognis 979 mh/ moi a)nh\r ei)/h glw/ssh| fi/los a)lla\ kai\ e)/rgw|.

mh/ m' a)tima/sh|s, do not reject me (the word used by the suppliant Oed., O. C. 49, 286), to\ mh\ ou) (cp. 443 n.), so as to hinder me from dying with thee, and paying due honour to the dead. a(gni/sai to\n q. is to make him a(gno/s, i.e. to give him the rites which religion requires; as, conversely, a corpse which is a)/moiros and a)kte/ristos is also a)no/sios (1071). Eur. Suppl. 1211 i(/n' au)tw=n sw/maq' h(gni/sqh puri/, where their corpses received the rites of fire, i.e. were burned. Cp. 196 n. If Ismene shares in the penalty of the deed, she will share in the merit.

mh/ moi, not mh/' moi/, since the main emphasis is on the verbal notion (‘share not my death,’ rather than, ‘share not my death’): cp. 83 n. The combination mh/ moi...su\ has a scornful, repellent tone (cp. O. C. 1441 n.). koina/, adv.: cp. Ai. 577: O. T. 883 u(pe/ropta (n.).

mhd' a(\ mh\ 'qiges. If this were an instance of qigga/nw with acc., it would be a solitary instance in Soph. , who has qigga/nw with genitive in nine passages; in Soph. Ph. 667pare/stai tau=ta/ soi kai\ qigga/nein, tau=ta is nom. Nor is there any authentic instance of qigga/nw with acc. in classical Greek. In H. F. 963, path de/ nin | qigw
 krataia=s xeiro\s e)nne/pei ta/de, nin depends on e)nne/pei: cp. Ai. 764 o( me
 ga au)to
 e)nne/pei: te/knon, etc. In Theocr. 1. 59 ou)de/ ti/ pa poti\ xei=los e)mo
 qi/gen, the gen. au)tou= is understood with prose/qigen, and ti is adv., ‘at all.’ Nor does yau/w govern an acc. below in 859, 961 (where see notes). Krüger (11. § 47. 12. 2) treats a(/ here as a sort of adverb (ib. 11. § 46. 6. 9), i.e., in a case where you did not put your hand (to the deed, sc. tou= e)/rgou); but this is very awkward. Rather, I think, there is an unusual kind of attraction, due to the special form of the sentence. We could not say (e.g.) a(\ mh\ e)ra=| tis, ou) qhra=tai, (a(/ for tau=ta w(=n). But here mhd' w(=n mh\ 'qiges poiou= seauth=s would have been intolerable, on account of the second gen. after poiou=. For the sake of compactness, and of clearly marking the object to poiou=, the poet has here allowed a(/ to stand for tau=ta w(=n. I do not compare O. C. 1106, ai)tei=s a(\ teu/cei, holding that a/ there=tau=ta a(/ (not w(=n): see n.

poiou= seauth=s, a somewhat rare phrase. Her. 1.129 e(wutou= poie/etai to\ *ku/rou e)/rgon. [Plat. ] Plat. Hipp. min. 372C e)mautou= poiou/menos to\ ma/qhma ei)=nai w(s eu(/rhma. Dem. or. 19 § 36 ei)s au(to\n poiou/menos (taking on himself) ta\ tou/twn a(marth/mata. In Thuc. 8.9 e(autou=...to\n sto/lon i)/dion poih/sasqai, the gen. goes with the adj.
a)rke/sw in the pers. constr., cp. Ai. 76 e)/ndon a)rkei/tw me/nwn, and O. T. 1061 n.
sou= leleimme/nh|, bereft of thee. lei/pomai/ tinos, to lag behind, then, fig., to be deprived of, as El. 474 gnw/mas leipome/na, Eur. Alc. 406 ne/os e)gw/, pa/ter, lei/pomai fi/las | ...matro/s.
fi/los has been groundlessly suspected, for no other reason, seemingly, than because it is masc.

khdemw/n, alluding esp. to v. 47. Cp. Xen. Anab. 3.1.17 h(ma=s de/, oi(=s khdemw\n...ou)dei\s pa/restin, who would have no one to plead our cause (no ‘friend at court,’ such as the younger Cyrus had in his mother Parysatis). In Il. 23.163 khdemo/nes are the chief mourners for the dead. In Attic, though sometimes poet. for khdesth/s, the word did not necessarily imply kinship.
a)lgou=sa me\n dh=t', yes, indeed, it is to my own pain that I mock thee,— if I do mock. dh=ta assents (O. T. 445 n.) to ou)de\n w)feloume/nh: there is, indeed, no o)/felos in it, but only a)/lgos.
e)n soi/: cp. Ai. 1092 e)n qanou=sin u(bristh/s, ib. 1315 e)n e)moi\ qrasu/s.

Heath's ei) gelw= g', for ei) ge/lwt', is supported by the accent gelw=t' in L, and seems right. It smooths the construction; and ei) gelw= g' better expresses that the taunt sprang from anguish, not from a wish to pain. Then ge/lwta gelw=, without an epithet for the subst., is unusual.—Cp. Ai. 79 ou)/koun ge/lws h(/distos ei)s e)xqrou\s gela=n;
a)lla\ nu=n, now, at least: O. C. 1276 a)ll' u(mei=s ge, n.
ka)mpla/kw, and am I to miss the

fate? i.e. to be dissociated from it: delib. aor. subj., which can be used, not only in asking what one is to do, but also in expressions of despair as to what one must suffer (Tr. 973 ti/ pa/qw;). For a)mplakei=n cp. 910, 1234.
ei(/lou, alluding to v. 78 f.
zh=n: for the emphatic pause, cp. Ph. 907ou)/koun e)n oi(=s ge dra=|s: e)n oi(=s d' au)da=|s, o)knw=.

e)p' a)rrh/tois … toi=s e)m. l. (but you did not choose death) without my words (my arguments against that course) having been spoken,—referring to vv. 49—68. For e)pi/ with the negative verbal (=pri\n tou\s e)mou\s lo/gous r(hqh=nai) cp. Eur. Ion 228 e)pi\ d' a)sfa/ktois | mh/loisi do/mwn mh\ pa/rit' e)s muxo/n (‘before sheep have been slain, pass not,’ etc.).

su\ me\n toi=s: ‘you seemed wise to the one side (Creon); I, to the other’ (to Hades and the dead). Nauck pronounces the text unsound, objecting to the use of toi=s: but that it was good Attic is sufficiently shown by Plat. Legg. 701E (cited by Wolff) ou) sunh/negken ou)/te toi=s ou)/te toi=s (it profited neither party). Cp. O. C. 742, n. on e)k de\ tw=n.—su\ me\n soi/, the schol.'s reading, is very inferior.—For the rhetorical xiasmo/s cp. O. T. 538 n. (and ib. 320).
kai\ mh/n, and yet,—though I did shrink from breaking Creon's law,—I am now, morally, as great an offender as you, since I sympathise with your act.

qa/rsei is not said with bitterness (that could hardly be, after 551): rather it means, ‘Take heart to live,’ as Whitelaw renders it. These two verses quietly express her feeling that their lots are irrevocably sundered, and exhort Ismene to accept the severance.
h( e)mh\ yuxh/, my life, a periphrasis for e)gw/, like O. C. 998 th\n patro\s | yuxh\n...zw=san (n.).
pa/lai, i.e. ever since she resolved to break the edict. (Cp. O. T. 1161.)

w(/ste toi=s q. w)felei=n, so as to (with a view to) serving the dead. The dat., as with e)parkei=n: Ph. 871cunwfelou=nta/ moi: Aesch. Pers. 842 w(s toi=s qanou=si plou=tos ou)de\n w)felei=: Eur. Or. 665 toi=s fi/loisin w)felei=n: Aristoph. Av. 419 fi/loisin w)felei=n e)/xein. So e)pwfelei=n O. C. 441.—Dobree proposed to understand se as subj. to the inf., ‘so that (you) are helping the dead,’ —i.e., your offer of help (552) is made to one who is already as good as dead. But se/ could not be thus understood; and this sense (which it has been sought to obtain by emendations, see cr. n.) would be frigid.

L gives tw\ pai=de fhmi\ as in O. C. 317 kai\ fhmi\, and this may probably be taken as the traditional accentuation, though some modern edd. write tw\ pai=de/ fhmi, kai/ fhmi. The justification of the oxytone fhmi\ is in the emphasis which falls on it. Similarly it has the accent when parenthetic, as Lucian Deor. Conc. 2polloi\ ga/r, fhmi/, ou)k a)gapw=ntes k.t.l.

tw\ pai=de … th
 me
 … th
 de/, partitive apposition: see on 21.
a)rti/ws, because Creon had hitherto regarded Ismene as being of a docile and submissive nature: cp. on 531 u(feime/nh.
The apology is for her sister as well as for herself: even such prudence (cp. 68 nou=n) as may have been inborn forsakes the unfortunate under the stress of their misfortunes.
bla/sth|: cp. El. 238 e)n ti/ni tou=t' e)/blast' a)nqrw/pwn; O. C. 804 fu/sas...fre/nas (n.).
toi=s k. pra/ssousin, dat. of interest: Tr. 132 me/nei ga\r ou)/t' ai)o/la nu\c | brotoi=sin.

e)ci/statai, stands aside, gives place (Ai. 672); and so, leaves its proper place, becomes deranged: cp. Eur. Bacch. 928 a)ll' e)c e(/dras soi plo/kamos e)ce/sthx' o(/de. The converse phrase is commoner, e)ci/stamai tw=n frenw=n: cp. 1105.—Schneidewin cp. Antigone fr. 165 a)/kouson: ou) ga\r oi( kakw=s peprago/tes | su\n tai=s tu/xaisi tou\s lo/gous a)pw/lesan,—which plainly glances at our passage. For similar allusions cp. O. C. 1116 n.
soi\ gou=n (cp. 45 n.) sc. e)ce/sth.
kakoi=s, i.e. Antigone: for the plur., cp. 10.
th=sd' a)/ter explains mo/nh|: cp. on 445.

biw/simon is Ionic and poet.; the Attic word was biwto/s. It is needless to change ti/ (subst.) into pw=s. The more usual phrase was, indeed, impers., as Her. 1.45 ou)de/ oi( ei)/h biw/simon: Plat. Crito 47D a)=ra biwto\n h(mi=n e)sti/; But, just as we can have o( bi/os ou) biwto/s e)sti (cp. O. C. 1691), so also ou)de\n biwto/n e)sti, no form of life is tolerable. Cp. O. T. 1337 ti/ dh=t' e)moi\ blepto/n, h)\ | sterkto/n, h)\ prosh/goron | e)/t' e)/st', etc., where the only difference is that the subst. ti/ corresponds to an object. accus., and not as here to a cognate (bi/on biw=nai).
a)lla\ … me/ntoi, ‘nay, but...’: cp. Ph. 524a)ll' ai)sxra\ me/ntoi sou= ge/ m' e)ndee/steron | ce/nw| fanh=nai.

h(/de mh\ le/ge, say not ‘h(/de,’ speak not of her as still with thee, for she is already numbered with the dead. oi(/de are oi( e)nqa/de, the living (75), as kei=noi (525) are oi( e)kei=, the dead (cp. 76). The peculiarity is that we should have expected either (a) th/nde, acc. to le/ge, or (b) th=sde, as a direct quotation from the last verse: cp. Dem. or. 18 § 88 ti/s h)=n...; u(mei=s, w)= a)/ndres *)aqhnai=oi. to\ d' u(mei=s o(/tan le/gw, le/gw th\n po/lin. If (e.g.) u(mw=n had preceded w a)/ndres, Dem. would doubtless have said to\ d' u(mw=n, or else u(ma=s d'. Here, however, no fair objection would remain if we had a)lla\ to\ h(/de mh\ le/ge, i. e. ‘never use the word h(/de about her,’—which makes the sense more general than if he said, a)lla\ th=sde mh\ le/ge, i. e. ‘do not say (that you cannot live without) h(/de.’ The question, then, seems to resolve itself into this:—Wishing to give the more general sense just indicated, could the poet say h(/de instead of to\ h(/de? To show that the art. was not always required in such quotation, it is enough to cite Aristoph. Eq. 21 le/ge dh\ mo/lwmen, by the side of to\ mo/lwmen ib. 26. While, then, I cannot produce any exact parallel for this h(/de, I think it reasonable to suppose that colloquial idiom would have allowed it. Those who deny this have two resources. (1) To point thus: a)ll' h(/de me/ntoi—mh\ le/g': i.e. instead of adding ou)k e)/stin e)/ti after me/ntoi, he breaks off his sentence—‘do not speak of her.’ So Bellermann. (2) Semitelos reads a)ll' h(/de me/n soi mh\ le/g' w(s a)/r' [for ou) ga\r] e)/st' e)/ti, ‘do not say that you have her any longer.’ As to soi, see cr. n. above. Neither of these readings gives such a forcible sense as the vulgate.

numfei=a, sc. i(era/, ‘nuptials,’ as Tr. 7 (but ib. 920 ‘bridal-chamber,’ as in sing. below, 1205); here=nu/mfhn. Cp. Eur. El. 481 sa\ le/xea, thy spouse: and so eu)nh/, etc.—Having failed to win Creon's pity for herself, Ismene now appeals to his feeling for his son. Haemon's coming part in the play is thus prepared.

a)rw/simoi, a poet. form (only here), analogous to the epic forms of adjectives in which a short vowel is lengthened for metre's sake (cp. on 492). Though the verb was a)ro/w, the adj. with the suffix simo would properly be formed from the subst. a)/rosis (cp. O. C. 27 n.). Suidas gives a)ro/simon kli/ma: to\ a)rotriou/menon. For the metaphor cp. O. T. 1256 mhtrw/|an ...a)/rouran, and ib. 1485, 1497: Lucr. 4. 1107.

ou)x w(/s g' (‘Another marriage is possible for him’). ‘No, not in the sense of the troth plighted between him and her,’—not such a union of hearts as had been prepared there. h(rmosme/na h)=n, impers., lit., ‘as things had been adjusted’; cp. on 447: Her. 1.112 h(mi=n kakw=s bebouleume/na e)/stai: id. 6. 83 te/ws me\n dh/ sfi h)=n a)/rqmia e)s a)llh/lous. The choice of the word has been influenced by the Ionic and poet. use of a(rmo/zein as=to betroth (e(ggua=n): Her. 3.137 a(/rmostai (perf. pass. as midd.) th\n *mi/lwnos qugate/ra...gunai=ka, he has become engaged to her: Pind. P. 9. 127a(rmo/zwn ko/ra| | numfi/on a)/ndra. Cp. 2 Epist. Cor. 11. 2h(rmosa/mhn ga\r u(ma=s e(ni\ a)ndri\ parqe/non a(gnh/n.

ui(e/si, the regular Attic dat. plur. (as Plat. Rep. 362E, Aristoph. Nub. 1001, etc.), from the stem ui(u-, which furnished also the Attic nom. and gen. plur., ui(ei=s, ui(e/wn; and the dual ui(h= (or rather ui(ei=, Meisterhans p. 63), ui(e/oin. The Attic forms of the sing. and the acc. plur. were taken from ui(o-, except that ui(e/os, ui(ei= were alternative forms for the gen. and dat. sing. Here L has the epic ui(a/sin, from a third stem, ui(-, whence the Homeric forms ui(=os, ui(=i,
ui(=a, ui(=e, ui(=es, ui(=as: cp. Monro Hom. Gr. § 107.—The dat. of interest goes with kaka\s gunai=kas, not with stugw=: cp. Aristoph. Nub. 1161 pro/bolos e)mo/s, swth\r do/mois, e)xqroi=s bla/bh.

It is not of much moment that L, like the later MSS., gives this verse to Ismene. Errors as to the persons occur not seldom in L (see, e.g., cr. n. to O. C. 837, and cp. ib. 1737); and here a mistake would have been peculiarly easy, as the dialogue from v. 561 onwards has been between Creon and Ismene. To me it seems certain that the verse is Antigone's, and that one of the finest touches in the play is effaced by giving it to Ismene. The taunt, kaka\s gunai=kas ui(e/si, moves Antigone to break the silence which she has kept since v. 560: in all this scene she has not spoken to Creon, nor does she now address him: she is thinking of Haemon,—of the dishonour to him implied in the charge of having made such a choice, —w(s ai)ei\ to
 o(moi=on a)/gei qeo\s w(s to
 o(moi=on. How little does his father know the heart which was in sympathy with her own. This solitary reference to her love heightens in a wonderful degree our sense of her unselfish devotion to a sacred duty. If Ismene speaks this verse, then to\ so
 le/xos in 573 must be, ‘the marriage of which you talk’ (like El. 1110 ou)k oi)=da th
 sh
 klh/|don'), which certainly is not its natural sense.
*ai(=mon. L has ai(/mwn. Soph. would have written AIMON: hence the tradition is subject to the same ambiguity as in KPEON. The analogy of dai=mon would probably have recommended the form in o.

a)/gan ge lupei=s, ‘Nay, thou art too troublesome,’—the impatient phrase of one who would silence another, as Ai. 589 (Ajax to Tecmessa) a)/gan ge lupei=s: ou) ka/toisq', etc.: so ib. 592 po/ll' a)/gan h)/dh qroei=s.

The MSS. give this verse to Ismene; but Boeckh is clearly right in giving it to the Chorus. Ismene asked this question in 568, and Creon answered: she rejoined to this answer (570), and Creon replied still more bitterly. She could not now ask her former question over again. But there is no unfitness in the question being repeated by a new intercessor, since to ask it thus is a form of mild remonstrance.

e)moi/, L's reading, is right. Creon has been asked,—‘Can you indeed mean to deprive your son of his bride?’ He grimly replies, ‘I look to the Death-god to break off this match.’ The e)/fu in the later MSS. was obviously a mere conjecture,—and a weak one.

This verse clearly belongs to the Chorus, to whom L assigns it. The first words of the next verse show this. Hermann objected that in similar situations the Chorus usually has two verses. It is true that this is usually the case. But O. T. 1312 is enough to show that there was no rigid rule; why, indeed, should there be? And, here, surely, ple/on h(/misu panto/s.
dedogme/na (e)sti/), = de/doktai: cp. on 570 h(rmosme/na, 447 khruxqe/nta. Cp. Menander *)arrhfo/ros 1. 3 dedogme/non to\ pra=gm': a)nerri/fqw ku/bos.

kai\ soi/ ge ka)moi/, sc. dedogme/na. It is settled, for both of us: i.e., I shall not change my mind, and it is vain for thee to plead. The datives are ethic. We might also understand, ‘settled by thee, as by me,’—alluding to the words of the Chorus in v. 211 and in v. 220. But I now feel, with Mr T. Page, that this would be somewhat forced.—We must not point thus: kai\ soi/ ge. kai/ moi mh\ triba/s, etc. (so Semitelos). This would be more defensible if, in 576, soi/ had stood with dedogme/na: but, as it is, the vagueness of the latter confirms kai\ soi/ ge ka)moi/. Bellermann, giving 576 to Ismene, adopts Kern's kai\ soi/ ge koinh=| (‘yes, and she shall die with you’).
mh\ triba/s, sc. poiei=sqe: cp. Aristoph. Ach. 345 a)lla\ mh/ moi pro/fasin, a)lla\ kata/qou to\ be/los: Vesp. 1179 mh/ moi/ ge mu/qous.
nin, plur., as O. T. 868 (masc.), O. C. 43 (fem.), El. 436 (neut.), etc.

e)k de\ tou=de, k.t.l. Compare 484 h)= nu=n e)gw\ me\n ou)k a)nh/r, au(/th d' a)nh/r: 525 e)mou= de\ zw=ntos ou)k a)/rcei gunh/: also 678 ff. This much-vexed passage is sound as it has come down to us. Creon means: ‘henceforth they must be women, and must not roam unrestrained.’ The fact that a woman has successfully defied him rankles in his mind. Hence the bitterness of gunaikas here. The Attic notions of feminine propriety forbade such freedom as a)neime/nas denotes. Cp. El. 516 (Clytaemnestra finding Electra outside the house) a)neime/nh me/n, w(s e)/oikas, au)= stre/fei: Electra should be restrained, mh/ toi qurai/an g' ou)=san ai)sxu/nein fi/lous. So pseudoPhocyl. 216 (keep a maiden in-doors), mhde/ min a)/xri ga/mwn pro\ do/mwn o)fqh=men e)a/sh|s. Aristoph. Lys. 16 xaleph/ toi gunaikw=n e)/codos. The emphasis of gunai=kas here is parallel with the frequent emphasis of a)nh/r (as Eur. El. 693 a)/ndra gi/gnesqai/ se xrh/, a man). Cp. O. C. 1368 ai(/d' a)/ndres, ou) gunai=kes, ei)s to\ sumponei=n.—All the emendations are weak or improbable. See Appendix.

xoi( qrasei=s. Remark how well the use of the masc. here suits the taunt conveyed in the last verse. pe/las (o)/nta)... ei)sorw=si: cp. O. C. 29 pe/las ga\r a)/ndra to/nde nw=|n o(rw=: and see ib. 586 n.

div2.p: Second sta/simon. 1st strophe, 582—592,=1st antistr., 593— 603. 2nd strophe, 604—614,=2nd antistr., 615—625. See Metrical Analysis.

The sentence of death just passed on Antigone leads the Chorus to reflect on the destiny of her house, and on the power of fate generally.—When a divine curse has once fallen upon a family, thenceforth there is no release for it. Wave after wave of trouble vexes it. Generation after generation suffers. These sisters were the last hope of the race; and now an infatuated act has doomed them also. —What mortal can restrain the power of Zeus? Human self-will and ambition may seem to defy him, but he is drawing them on to their ruin.—Anapaests (626— 630) then announce the approach of Haemon.

div3.p: kakw=n a)/geustos, act., cp. O. T. 969 a)/yaustos e)/gxous n. Eur. Alc. 1069 w(s a)/rti pe/nqous tou=de geu/omai pikrou=. Her. 7.46 o(...qeo\s gluku\n geu/sas to\n ai)w=na (having allowed men to taste the sweetness of life).

seisqh=| qeo/qen, i.e. by an a)ra/ (likened to a storm, or earthquake, that shakes a building): when a sin has once been committed, and the shock of divine punishment has once been felt. In the case of the Labdacidae the calamities were traced to the curse called down on Laïus by Pelops, when robbed by him of his son Chrysippus (O. T. p. xix.).

a)/tas ou)de\n e)llei/pei, (for these men, oi(=s = tou/tois oi(=s) no sort of calamity is wanting. Some join e)llei/pei with e(/rpon, on the analogy of pau/esqai with part., ‘never fails to go’; but this constr. is at least very rare. In a probably spurious yh/fisma ap. Dem. or. 18 § 92 we have ou)k e)llei/yei eu)xaristw=n: but Xen. Mem. 2. 6§ 5 (adduced by Wecklein) is not an example, for there mh\ e\llei/pesqai eu)= poiw=n=‘not to be outdone in generosity.’ Then in Phaedr. 272 B o(/ ti a)\n au)tw=n tis e)llei/ph| le/gwn =simply ‘omit in speaking.’

genea=s e)pi\ plh=qos. The phrase is bold, and somewhat strange; but I do not think that it is corrupt. genea=s here is the whole race, not (as in 596) a generation of the race. The words mean literally, ‘over a multitude of the race’; i.e., the a)/th does not cease with the person who first brought it into the family, or with his generation, but continues to afflict succeeding genera tions. The collective noun genea=s justifies the use of plh=qos: as he might have said, a)pogo/nwn plh=qos. It is needless, then, to write genea=n. We cannot understand, ‘to the fulness of the race,’ i.e. till the race has been exhausted.
o(/moion, adv.: Plat. Legg. 628D o(/moion w(s ei)...h(goi=to/ tis.

ponti/ais (see cr. n.) is far the most probable reading. The loss of the second i, leaving ponti/as, would easily have brought in a(lo/s, which the metre shows to be superfluous. In Greek poetry there is no objection to the three epithets with pnoai=s: the whole phrase would be felt as meaning, ‘stormy seawinds from Thrace.’ Construe: o(/tan oi)=dma, when a surge, ponti/ais duspn. *qr. pnoai=s, driven by stormy sea-winds from Thrace (instr. dat., cp. on 335 no/tw|), e)pidra/mh| e)/rebos u(/falon, rushes over the dark depths of the sea (lit., the darkness under the surface of the sea). For duspn. pnoai=s, cp. 502 n.: for *qrh/|ssaisin, Aesch. Ag. 192 pnoai\ d' a)po\ *strumo/nos molou=sai, ib. 654 *qrh/|kiai pnoai/ (and 1418): Il. 9.5 (where the tumult in the breasts of the Greeks is likened to a storm) *bore/hs kai\ *ze/furos, tw/ te *qrh/|khqen a)/hton.

kelaina\n qi=na, the dark-coloured mud or sand that the storm stirs up from the bottom of the sea. qi/s is masc. in Homer, Ar. , and Arist. , and that was prob. its usual gender. Soph. has it fem. again in Soph. Ph. 1124, and so it is in later writers. In the Il.qi/s is always the sea-shore; in Od.that is its regular sense, but once (12. 45) it means ‘heap.’ It is used as here by Aristoph. Vesp. 696 w(/s mou to\n qi=na tara/tteis (my very depths). Verg. G. 3. 240 at ima exaestuat unda Vorticibus, nigramque alte subiectat arenam.

dusa/nemoi should be read. dusa/nemon could not here be adv. with bre/mousin, and must therefore be epithet of qi=na, when it could mean only th\n u(po\ a)ne/mwn taraxqei=san (schol.), i.e. ‘stirred up by the storm,’—a strained sense for it. Cp. Apoll. Rhod. 1. 593 a)kth/n t' ai)gialo/n te dush/nemon.
sto/nw| br.: cp. 427.

a)ntiplh=ges (only here) a)ktai/, headlands which are struck in front, struck full, by the waves; in contrast with paraplh=ges, ‘struck obliquely’: see Od. 5.417 (Odysseus seeking a place to land) h)/n pou e)feu/rw | h)tona/s te paraplh=gas lime/nas te qala/sshs (‘shores where the waves strike aslant’). Soph. was doubtless thinking of the Homeric phrase.—Not (1) ‘beating back the waves,’ a)nti/tupoi: nor (2) ‘beaten again,’—i.e. by the everreturning waves. This last is impossible. —Cp. O. C. 1240 where Oed. is likened to a bo/reios...a)kta\ kumatoplh/c. Oppian Cyn. 2. 142krhmnoi=si kai\ u(datoplh/gesin a)/krais.

a)rxai=a, predicate: I see that, from olden time, the house-troubles (oi)/kwn ph/mata) of the (living) Labdacidae are heaped upon the troubles of the dead. The dead are now Laïus, Oedipus, and his two sons. a)rxai=a carries us back to the starting-point of the troubles, —the curse pronounced on Laïus by Pelops (cp. on 583).

o(rw=mai, midd., as in Homer and Attic Comedy, but not in Attic prose; which, however, used the midd. periora=sqai (Thuc. 6.103) and proora=sqai (Dem. or. 18 § 281, etc.). Soph. has o(rwme/nh, midd., Tr. 306 (dial.); and so, too, ei)do/mhn Ph. 351(dial.), etc. Though oi)/kwn answers metrically to the first two syllables of a)/geustos in 582, it is not suspicious, because the second syllable of the trochee can be irrational (a long for a short): see Conversely Anal., fqi^tw=n is metrically admissible, though its first syllable answers to the first of seisqh=| in 583. This correction of fqime/nwn is strongly confirmed by the similar error of the MSS. in Eur. Alc. 100 (see cr. n.).
a)palla/ssei, releases (by exhausting the malignity of the a)ra/): so'oft. a)palla/ssw tina\ kakw=n, fo/bou, etc.

genea\n ge/nos: cp. 1067 ne/kun nekrw=n: Ai. 475 par' h)=mar h(me/ra.—The subject to e)/xei (a)ll' e)rei/pei qew=n tis being parenthetical) is ‘the Labdacid house,’ i.e. genea/ in the larger sense (585), supplied from genea/n just before. This is simpler than to supply ph/mata as subject.
lu/sin, deliverance from trouble, as O. T. 921, Tr. 1171.

nu=n ga\r e)sxa/tas k.t.l. (1) The first question is,—are we to read o(\ te/tato or e)te/tato? If e)te/tato, then the sentence is complete at do/mois. A new sentence beginning with kat' au)= would be intolerably abrupt: yet neither ka)=|t' nor kai\ tau/tan appears probable. This difficulty would be avoided by changing u(pe/r to o(/per: but then r(i/zas fa/os must mean, ‘the comfort (or hope) afforded by the r(i/za,’—a strange phrase. And te/tato confirms u(pe/r as well as fa/os. I therefore prefer o(\ te/tato. (2) The next point concerns nin. Reading o(\ te/tato, Wecklein still refers nin to r(i/zas, not to fa/os, saying that the constr. is as though a(=s u(pe\r e)sxa/tas r(i/zas had preceded. This is a grammatical impossibility. With o(\ te/tato, nin can refer only to fa/os. Can this be justified? Thus, I think. The e)sxa/th r(i/za of the family is the last remaining means of propagating it. A light of hope (fa/os) was ‘spread above’ this ‘last root,’—as sunshine above a plant,—because it was hoped that the sisters would continue the race. The sisters themselves are, properly speaking, the e)sxa/th r(i/za. But as the word r(i/za can also have an abstract sense, denoting the chance of propagation, the sisters can here be identified with the hope, or fa/os, which shines above the r(i/za. In Greek this is the easier since fa/os was often said of persons, as Il. 18.102 ou)de/ ti *patro/klw| geno/mhn fa/os, Eur. Hec. 841 w)= de/spot', w)= me/giston *(/ellhsin fa/os. To say katama=n fa/os (do/mwn) is like saying, ‘to mow down the hope of the race,’—in this case, the two young lives. A further reason against referring nin to r(i/za is that the verb should then be, not katama=|, but e)cama=|, as Ai. 1178 ge/nous a(/pantos r(i/zan e)chmhme/nos: a root is not ‘mowed down,’ in such a case, but cut out of the ground. The proposed change of fa/os into qa/los, though not difficult in a palaeographical sense, is condemned by te/tato, which does not suit qa/los, but exactly suits fa/os. Cp. Ph. 831ta/nd' ai)/glan a(\ te/tatai tanu=n. Od. 11.19 a)ll' e)pi\ nu\c o)loh\ te/tatai deiloi=si brotoi=si: Hes. Op. 547a)h\r purofo/ros te/tatai maka/rwn e)pi\ e)/rgois (rich men's fields): Theogn. 1077 o)/rfnh ga\r te/tatai. Plat. Rep. 616B dia\ panto\s tou= ou)ranou= kai\ gh=s tetame/non fw=s. As to the proposed substitution of qa/los for u(pe/r, (with fa/os retained,) it would be as violent as needless.—For r(i/zas cp. Pind. O. 2. 46o(/qen spe/rmatos e)/xonta r(i/zan: El. 765 pro/rrizon...e)/fqartai ge/nos: Lucian Tyr. 13panwleqri/a panto\s tou= ge/nous kai\ r(izo/qen to\ deino\n a(/pan e)kkekomme/non.

kat' au)= … a)ma=|, = katama=| au)=, ‘mows down in its turn’ (not, ‘otherwise than we hoped’). In my first edition I adopted the conjecture kopi/s. Prof. Tyrrell's able defence of the MS. ko/nis (Classical Review, vol. 11. p. 139), though it has not removed all my difficulties, has led me to feel that more can be said for that reading than I had recognised. I now prefer, therefore, to leave ko/nis in the text, and to re-state here the arguments for and against it.

(1) If ko/nis be right, ko/nis qew=n tw=n nerte/rwn is the dust, belonging (due) to the gods infernal, which Antigone strewed on her brother's corpse; it is foini/a, because the corpse was gory. The strongest point in favour of ko/nis is that it is in harmony with the following words, lo/gou t' a)/noia kai\ frenw=n e)rinu/s. The whole sense then is: ‘She, too—the last hope of the race—is now to die,—for a handful of blood-stained dust (i.e., for a slight, yet obligatory, act of piety towards her slain brother)—and for those rash words to Creon,—the expression of her frenzied resolve.’ On the other hand, the objection to ko/nis is the verb katama=|, which implies the metaphor of reaping. (See Appendix.) The proposed version, ‘covers,’ is impossible, and, if possible, would be unsuitable. What we want is a verb meaning simply ‘destroys,’ or ‘dooms to death.’ Now it is true that Greek lyric poetry often tolerates some confusion of metaphor (see on v. 117, and cp. O. T. p. lviii): the question is whether this example of it be tolerable. Prof. Tyrrell holds that it is excused by the tumult of feeling in the mind of the Chorus. That is, the metaphor of a young life ‘mowed down’ is not completed by a mention of the agent, the Destroyer: it is swiftly succeeded in the speaker's thought by a dramatic image of the cause, Antigone sprinkling the dust, and defying Creon. This is conceivable; but it is at least extremely bold.

(2) If we read kopi/s, then katama=| is appropriate, and foini/a also has a more evident fitness. The great objection is the want of unison with lo/gou t' a)/noia kai\ frenw=n e)rinu/s. If the t' after lo/gou means ‘both,’ the kopi\s nerte/rwn is the deadly agency as seen in the girl's rash speech and resolve: if the t' means ‘and,’ it is an agency to which these things are superadded. On either view the language is awkward. This must be set against the gain in unity of metaphor.

It has further been urged against kopi/s that the word is too homely. This may be so; but we lack proof. kopi/s seems to have been a large curved knife, known to the Greeks chiefly as (a) a butcher's or cook's implement, (b) an oriental military weapon. It does not follow, however, that the effect here would be like that of ‘chopper,’ or of ‘scimitar,’ in English. The dignity of a word may be protected by its simplicity; and kopi/s is merely ‘that which cuts.’ Pindar was not afraid of homeliness when he described a chorus-master as a krath/r, or an inspiring thought as an a)ko/na (cp. O. C. 1052 n.). Nicander could say, of the scorpion, toi/h oi( ke/ntroio kopi/s (Ther. 780). If kopi/s be right, the change to ko/nis may have been caused, not by a misreading of letters, but by mere inadvertence,—the copyist having the word ko/nis in his thoughts at the moment: it has already occurred frequently (247, 256, 409, 429).—See Appendix.

lo/gou … a)/noia, folly shown in speech (defining gen.),—Antigone's answer to Creon (450 ff.): cp. 562 (a)/noun), 383 (a)frosu/nh|). frenw=n e)rinu/s, an erinys of (or in) the mind: i.e. the infatuated impulse which urged Antigone to the deed is conceived as a Fury that drove her to her doom. Schol. o(/ti oi)strhqei=sa u(po\ tw=n e)rinu/wn...tou=to teto/lmhken.
tea/n, epic and Ion. (Hom. , Hes. , Her., Pind. , etc.); admitted by Aesch. and Eur. in lyrics.
du/na^sin: cp. 951. A poetical form used by Pind. , Eur. (in dial. as well as in lyr.), etc.

kata/sxoi. Epic usage admits the optat. (without a)/n) where an abstract possibility is to be stated, as Il. 19.321 ou) me\n ga/r ti kakw/teron a)/llo pa/qoimi, ‘for I could not (conceivably) suffer anything worse.’ The Homeric instances are chiefly in negative sentences (Od. 3.231 being a rare exception, r(ei=a qeo/s g' e)qe/lwn kai\ thlo/qen a)/ndra saw/sai). Attic verse affords some certain examples,—all in negative sentences, or in questions when (as here) a negative answer is expected. So Aesch. PV 291 ou)k e)/stin o(/tw| | mei/zona moi=ran nei/maim' h)\ soi/. Other instances are Aesch. Ch. 172, Aesch. Ch. 595: Aesch. Ag. 620: Eur. Alc. 52. Our passage is undoubtedly another genuine instance, and the attempts to alter it (see cr. n.) are mistaken. Attic prose, on the other hand, supplies no trustworthy example: in most of those which are alleged a)/n should be supplied. I have discussed this question in O. C., Appendix on v. 170, p. 273.—Men may overstep their due limits: but no such u(perbasi/a can restrict the power of Zeus. He punishes the encroachment.

The MS. pantogh/rws is unquestionably corrupt. Sleep, the renewer of vigour, could not be described as ‘bringing old age to all.’ Nor can the epithet be explained as ‘enfeebling all,’ in the sense of ‘subduing them’; nor, again, as ‘attending on all, even to old age.’ The neighbourhood of a)gh/rws is not in favour of pantogh/rws, but against it; in the case of pantopo/ros—a)/poros (360), and of u(yi/polis—a)/polis (370), there is a direct contrast between the two words. Either pa/nt' a)grw=n or pantagreu\s (see cr. n.) would be good, if ou)/t' could be taken from the next verse, and added to this. But ou)/t' clearly belongs, I think, to the next verse,—as will be seen presently. Bamberger proposed pantoqh/ras, or panto/qhros. The former would be a subst. like i)xquoqh/ras, ‘fisherman,’ o)rniqoqh/ras, ‘fowler’: the latter (which I should prefer), an adj. like polu/qhros, ‘catching much’ (Heliodorus 5. 18), eu)/qhros, ‘having good sport.’ panto/qhros would suit the sense well. But its probability depends on the way in which we conceive the corrupt pantogh/rws to have arisen. It is evident that the genuine a)gh/rws in the next line had something to do with it. It seems most likely that the eye of the transcriber who first wrote pantogh/rws had wandered to a)gh/rws, and that by a mere inadvertence he gave a like ending to the earlier word. Now this might most easily have happened if the sixth letter of the earlier series had been *g, but would obviously have been less likely if that letter had been *q. I therefore think it more probable that pantogh/rws arose from pa/nt' a)greu/wn than from panto/qhros. It is immaterial that the last four letters of the latter are nearer to the MS., since, on the view just stated, the transcriber's error arose from the fact that the consecutive letters a)g were common to a)greu/wn and a)gh/rws, and that, from these letters onwards, he accidentally copied a)gh/rws. It may be added that such an error would have been easier with a separate word like a)greu/wn than with the second part of a compound like panto/qhros.—The verb a)greu/w, ‘to catch’ (common both in verse and in prose) is used by Soph. in fr. 507.— Soph. was thinking of Il. 14.244 ff. (*(/upnos speaking to Hera), a)/llon me/n ken e)/gwge qew=n ai)eigeneta/wn | r(ei=a kateunh/saimi... | *zhno\s d' ou)k a)\n e)/gwge *kroni/onos a)=sson i(koi/mhn, | ou)de\ kateunh/saim', o(/te mh\ au)to/s ge keleu/oi.
The MS. ou)/t' a)ka/matoi qew=n should answer metrically to 618 ei)do/ti d'

ou)de
 e(/rpei. Far the best emendation is ou)/te qew=n a)/kmatoi (Hermann a)/kmhtoi). This supposes merely a transposition of two words, of which L affords undoubted instances (cp. on 107), and the very natural development of a)ka/matoi out of the rarer form a)/kmatoi. For the latter cp. Hom. hymn. Apoll. 520 a)kmh/tois de\ lo/fon prose/ban posi/n. The word qew=n seems to me clearly genuine. Many recent editors have condemned it, because Zeus is the marshaller of the seasons (Il. 2.134 *dio\s mega/lou e)niautoi/, Od. 24.344 *dio\s w(=rai, Plat. Prot. 321A ta\s e)k *dio\s w(/ras). How, then, could the poet say that Zeus is not subdued by ‘the months of the gods’? The simple answer is that the term qew=n is not opposed to Zeus, but includes him. Though Zeus (the Sky Father) was more especially the tami/as w(rw=n, that function can also be ascribed to the gods collectively: see e.g. Plat. Legg. 886A ou)kou=n, w)= ce/ne, dokei= r(a/|dion ei(=nai a)lhqeu/ontas le/gein w(s ei)si\ qeoi/;— pw=s;—prw=ton me
 gh= kai\ h(/lios a)/stra te ta\ cu/mpanta kai\ ta\ tw=n w(rw=n diakekosmhme/na kalw=s ou(/tws, e)niautoi=s te kai\ mhsi\ dieilhmme/na. Cp. ib. 809 D, as illustrating another reason which made the phrase qew=n mh=nes so natural—the fact, namely, that the e(ortai/ were the land-marks of the Calendar: ti/nwn dh\ pe/ri le/gomen; h(merw=n ta/cews ei)s mhnw=n perio/dous kai\ mhnw=n ei)s e(/kaston to
 e)niauto/n, i(/na w(=rai kai\ qusi/ai kai\ e(ortai\ ta\ prosh/konta a)polamba/nousai e(autai=s e(/kastai... qeoi=s me
 ta\s tima\s a)podidw=si k.t.l. And, if qew=n be genuine, then ou)/te belongs to this verse, and we gain a fresh argument against those emendations which would append ou)/t' to v. 606: for ou)/t' | a)ka/matoi qew=n <nin> is certainly not probable. See Appendix.—All the immortals have a life which is not worn out by those months which they themselves control. The distinction of Zeus is that his supremacy over gods and men is unalterable.
a)/kmatoi, untiring in their course: cp. Il. 18.239 h)e/lion d' a)ka/manta: Eur. fr. 597 a)ka/mas te xro/nos.

I doubt whether the dat. xro/nw| could be instrumental or causal here (‘not made old by time’). It rather seems to be an adverbial dat. of circumstance, ‘not growing old with time’ (as time goes on). xro/nw| oft.=‘at length’ (O. C. 437).

marmaro/essan (only here) =marmare/an. marmai/rw and its cognate adj. are applied to any sparkling or flashing light (as of sun or stars, bright eyes, gleaming metal). Cp. Il. 1.532 a)p' ai)glh/entos *)olu/mpou. Blackwall A. compares the language of St Paul in 1 Tim. 6. 15 o( maka/rios kai\ mo/nos duna/sths...fw=s oi)kw=n a)pro/siton.

to/ t' e)/peita (acc. of duration) is what will immediately follow the present moment (cp. Plat. Parm. 152C tou= te nu=n kai\ tou= e)/peita), and is here distinguished from to\ me/llon, the more distant future; Plaut. Pers. 778 (quoted by Schneid.) qui sunt, quique erunt (to\ e)/peita), quique fuerunt, quique futuri sunt posthac (to\ me/llon). It is much as if we said, ‘to-morrow, and for all time.’ Many have compared Eur. I. T. 1263 ta/ te prw=ta | ta/ t' e)/peiq' a(/ t' e)/melle tuxei=n: but even if Seidler's a(/ t', rather than o(/s', be there the true correction of the MS. o(/sa t', the parallelism is not strict, since ta\ e)/peita would then mean ‘what followed ta\ prw=ta,’ not, ‘what is to follow ta\ nu=n.’

kai\ to\ pri/n is usu. explained as a compressed form of w(/sper kai\ to\ pri\n e)ph/rkese: but this is at least much bolder than the examples which are brought to support it, as Dem. or. 18 § 31 kai\ to/te kai\ nu=n kai\ a)ei\ o(mologw=, which would be parallel only if it were kai\ nu=n kai\ a)ei\ kai\ to/te o(mologw=: and nu=n te kai\ pa/lai dokei= (181) is irrelevant, since pa/lai can take the pres. (279). Rather, perh., e)parke/sei, ‘will hold good,’ means, ‘will be found true,’—both in the future, and if we scan the past.—For to_ before pri/n, cp. O. C. 180 e)/ti_; probi/baze. e)parke/sei, will hold out, hold good,=diarke/sei: so only here, perhaps, for in Solon fr. 5. 1 dh/mw| me\n ga\r e)/dwka to/son kra/tos o(/sson e)parkei=, we must surely read a)parkei=, with Coraës.

pa/mpolu/ g' (Heath), for pa/mpolis, is not only the best emendation, but (in my belief) a certain one. I do not know whether it has been noticed that pa/mpolu+n in one of the late MSS. (see cr. n.), —a mere blunder for pa/mpolis,—forcibly illustrates the ease with which the opposite change of pa/mpolu/ g' into pa/mpolis could have occurred. The no/mos, then, is:— ‘Nothing vast comes to (enters into) the life of mortals, e)kto\s a)/tas, free from a curse (cp. e)/cw...ai)ti/as, 445)’—without bringing a)/th. Cp. Plat. Rep. 531D pa/mpolu e)/rgon, Legg. 823 B pa/mpolu/ ti pra=gma, ib. 677 E gh=s d' a)fqo/nou plh=qos pa/mpolu. Too much power, or wealth, or prosperity —anything so great as to be mh\ kat' a)/nqrwpon—excites the divine fqo/nos: the man shows u(/bris, and this brings a)/th. Cp. Her. 7.10 o(ra=|s ta\ u(pere/xonta zw=|a w(s keraunoi= o( qeo\s ou)de\ e)a=| fanta/zesqai, ta\ de\ smikra\ ou)de/n min kni/zei; o(ra=|s de\ w(s e)s oi)kh/mata ta\ me/gista ai)ei\ kai\ de/ndrea ta\ toiau=ta a)poskh/ptei ta\ be/lea; file/ei ga o( qeo\s ta\ u(pere/xonta pa/nta kolou/ein. L. Diog. 1. 3. 2(Zeus) ta\ me
 u(yhla\ tapeinw=n, ta\ de\ tapeina\ u(yw=n. Soph. fr. 320 kalo
 fronei=n to
 qnhto
 a)nqrw/pois i)/sa.

e(/rpei: cp. Ai. 1087 e(/rpei paralla\c tau=ta (come to men): for the dat., cp. above, 186. The inf. e(/rpein would be admissible after ou)de/n, since this is not a precept (like mh\ ploutei=n a)di/kws), but a statement of fact. In 706 L has e)/xei by mistake for e)/xein, and such errors are frequent. And dokei=n in 622 might seem to recommend e(/rpein here. Yet e(/rpei seems right. For this is not what the no/mos says,—as dokei=n in 622 depends on e)/pos pe/fantai, and dra/santi paqei=n in Aesch. Cho. 313 on mu=qos...fwnei=. The constant fact, ou)de\n e(/rpei, is the no/mos. Cp. Ph. 435lo/gw| de/ s' e)n braxei= | tou=t' e)kdida/cw: po/lemos ou)de/n' a)/ndr' e(kw\n | ai(rei= ponhro/n.
pa/mpolis is impossible. For the attempts to explain it, and for other conjectures, see Appendix.

a( ga\r dh/ k.t.l. The ga/r introduces an explanation of the law just stated. ‘No inordinate desire comes to men without bringing a)/th. For hope, which can be a blessing, can also be a curse, by luring a man to pursue forbidden things; and then he sins blindly, till the gods strike him. The gods cause him to mistake evil for good; and his impunity is of short duration.’ Creon is destined to exemplify this. polu/plagktos, roaming widely—as a mariner over unknown seas—in dreams of the future. Soph. was perh. thinking of Pind. O. 12. 6ai(/ ge me\n a)ndrw=n | po/ll' a)/nw, ta\ d' au)= ka/tw yeu/dh metamw/nia ta/mnoisai kuli/ndont' e)lpi/des, ‘at least, the hopes of men are
oft tossed up and down, ploughing a sea of vain deceits.’—polu/plagktos might also be act., ‘causing men to err greatly’; but this is less fitting here.

polloi=s me\n o)/nasis, by cheering them, and inciting to worthy effort. This clause is inserted merely for the sake of contrast with the next. When Greek idiom thus co-ordinates two clauses, the clause which we should subordinate to the other is that which has me/n; as here, ‘though a blessing to many.’ So O. C. 1536 (n.), eu)= me\n o)ye/ d', ‘late, though surely.’

a)pa/ta … e)rw/twn. The gen. is best taken as subjective, a cheating (of men) by desires; i.e., e)/rwtes a)patw=si. The e)lpi/s is such an a)pa/th, because it ends in that. If the gen. were objective, the sense would be e)lpi\s a)pata=| e)/rwtas. This is equally possible, but hardly so natural. In 630, a)pa/tas lexe/wn, the gen. is neither of these, but one of relation (a deceiving of him about his marriage). Cp. Hes. Op. 460newme/nh ou)/ s' a)path/sei, when ploughed again, the soil will not disappoint thee.
koufono/wn: see on 343.

The a)pa/th, or final frustration of his desires, e(/rpei, creeps on him, ou)de
 ei)do/ti, knowing nothing. Others construe, ou)de
 e(/rpei ei)do/ti, nothing comes to him aware of it; i.e. he understands the true meaning of nothing that happens to him. This is somewhat forced; and that ou)de/n is object to ei)do/ti is confirmed by Antiphon or. 1 § 29 oi( d' e)pibouleuo/menoi ou)de
 i)/sasi pri
 e)n au)tw=| w)=si tw=| kakw=| g' h)/dh. Cp. Ai. 964 ta)gaqo
 xeroi=n | e)/xontes ou)k i)/sasi, pri/n tis e)kba/lh|.
pri\n … prosau/sh|. Attic, like epic, poetry can use simple pri/n, instead of pri\n a)/n (308), with subjunct.: so Ai. 965 (see last n.), Ph. 917, Tr. 608, 946, etc.

prosau/sh| (only here), ‘burn against.’ The simple verb occurs Od. 5.490 i(/na mh/ poqen a)/lloqen au)/oi (sc. pu=r), ‘kindle.’ Attic had e)nau/w, ‘kindle,’ and a)fau/w, ‘parch.’ The image here seems to be that of a man who walks, in fancied security, over ashes under which fire still smoulders (cp. Lucr. 4. 927 cinere ut multo latet obrutus ignis, Hor. c. 2. 1. 7 incedis per ignes Suppositos cineri doloso). There was a prov., e)n puri\ be/bhkas (Suidas, etc.).

po/da: cp. Aesch. Ch. 697e)/cw komi/zwn o)leqri/ou phlou= po/da: Aesch. P. V. 263phma/twn e)/cw po/da | e)/xei (and so Soph. Ph. 1260e)kto\s klauma/twn, Eur. Her. 109 e)/cw pragma/twn).—Some render prosau/sh| ‘bring to,’ assuming an au)/w equiv. in sense to ai)/rw: but the evidence for this is doubtful: see Appendix.
sofi/a|, modal dat.,=sofw=s: cp. El. 233 eu)noi/a| g' au)dw=: so o)rgh=| (O. T. 405), qumw=| (O. C. 659), etc.

e)/k tou, i.e. by some wise man of olden time:—not like the ou)k e)/fa tis in Aesch. Ag. 369 (alluding to Diagoras). Cp. frag. adesp. 383 (schol. on Tr. 296) kai\ tou=to tou)/pos e)sti\n a)ndro\s e)/mfronos, | o(/tan kalw=s pra/ssh| tis, e)lpi/zein kaka/. For similar gnw=mai in tragic lyrics, cp. Aesch. Ag. 750, Ch. 313.
pefa/ntai: Tr. 1 lo/gos me\n e)/st' a)rxai=os a)nqrw/pwn fanei/s: O. T. 525, 848.

to\ kako\n dokei=n pot' k.t.l. The sense of pote/ here is not ‘sometimes,’ but ‘at one time or another,’ ‘at length,’ as Ph. 1041a)lla\ tw=| xro/nw| pote/. A moment arrives when he makes the fatal error. a)/th (a)a/w), as the heaven-sent influence that leads men to sin, is properly ‘hurt done to the mind.’ Milton, Samson

1676 Among them he a spirit of phrenzy sent, Who hurt their minds. Cp. blayi/frwn, frenoblabh/s. Il. 19.137 a)ll' e)pei\ a)asa/mhn, kai/ meu fre/nas e)ce/leto *zeu/s. Theognis 403 speu/dei a)nh/r, ke/rdos dizh/menos, o(/n tina dai/mwn | pro/frwn ei)s mega/lhn a)mplaki/hn para/gei, | kai/ oi( e)/qhkh dokei=n, a(\ me
 h)=| kaka/, tau=t' a)ga/q' ei)=nai, | eu)mare/ws, a(\ d' a)
 h)=| xrh/sima, tau=ta kaka/. Lycurgus in Leocr. § 92 oi( ga qeoi\ ou)de
 pro/teron poiou=sin h)\ tw=n ponhrw=n a)nqrw/pwn th
 dia/noian para/gousi: kai/ moi dokou=si tw=n a)rxai/wn tine\s poihtw=n w(/sper xrhsmou\s gra/yantes toi=s e)pigignome/nois tau=ta ta\ i)ambei=a katalipei=n: o(/tan ga o)rgh\ daimo/nwn bla/pth| tina/, | tou=t' au)to\ prw=ton, e)cafairei=tai frenw=n | to
 nou=n to
 e)sqlo/n, ei)s de\ th
 xei/rw tre/pei | gnw/mhn, i(/n' ei)dh=| mhde)n w(=n a(marta/nei. The schol. on our verse quotes an unknown poet's lines, o(/tan d' o( dai/mwn a)ndri\ porsu/nh| kaka/, | to
 nou=n e)/blaye prw=ton, w(=| bouleuetai. (‘Quem Iuppiter vult perdere, dementat prius.’ See n. in Appendix.)— The epic e)/mmen (used also by Pind. and Sappho) occurs nowhere else in tragedy.

o)li/giston, a superl. used not only in epic poetry but also by Attic writers (as Ar. and Plat. ), is right here. The MS. o)ligosto/n cannot be defended by Aristoph. Pax 559 pollostw=| xro/nw|, which is merely another form of pollostw=| e)/tei (Cratinus jun. *xei/r. 1); i.e. pollosto/s has its proper sense, ‘one of many’ (multesimus), and the xro/nos, like the e)/tos, is conceived as the last of a series. So o)ligosto\s xro/nos would mean, not, ‘a fraction of time,’ but, ‘one in a small number of xro/noi’ or periods. In Arist. Metaph. 9. 1. 14 most MSS., and the best, have o)li/giston...xro/non: while Ab (cod. Laur. 87. 12) is the only MS. cited in the Berlin ed. (p. 1053 a 9) for o)ligosto/n. And otherwise o)ligosto/s occurs only in later Greek, as Anton. 51 kataba\s o)ligosto/s, ‘having gone to the coast with a small retinue’; Caes. 49 o)ligostw=| tosau/thn a)munome/nw| po/lin ‘fighting so great a State with a small force.’— pra/ssei … e)kto\s a)/tas, like pra/ssei kalw=s: so pra/ssein kata\ nou=n (Plat. Rep. 366B, Aristoph. Eq. 549). a)/tas is here ‘calamity’ (as in 584, 614), while in the last verse a)/tan is rather ‘infatuation.’—Donaldson changed a)/tas here to a)/lgous, because the strophe (614) also ends with e)kto\s a)/tas. On the other hand Dindorf ejects e)kto\s a)/tas from 614 (leaving a lacuna). But I believe e)kto\s a)/tas to be genuine in both places, as ou)de\n e(/rpei also is both in 613 and in 618. We have to remember, first, that Soph. (like other ancient poets) easily tolerated repetition of words (see on O. C. 554); secondly, that tragic lyrics could admit refrains, and might, by a kindred instinct, permit such verbal echoes as these.
mh/n instead of the usu. kai\ mh/n (526).
ne/aton, ‘youngest and last,’ Megareus being dead (1303): cp. 807 ta\n nea/tan o(do/n; so 808, Ai. 1185. As applied
to a person, ne/atos could not be said of a sole survivor unless he was also the latest-born. ge/nnhm': cp. 471 n.
a)xnu/menos with mo/ron as internal acc.: cp. Il. 5.361 a)/xqomai e)/lkos.

In the MS. reading (see cr. n.) nu/mfhs is a gloss on ta/lidos: but th=s melloga/mou should be retained. Except in the lexicons, ta=lis occurs only here and in a verse of Callimachus, au)ti/ka th
 ta=lin paidi\ su
 a)mfiqalei=, quoted by the Schol., who says, ta=lis le/getai par' *ai)oleu=sin h( o)nomasqei=sa/ tini nu/mfh. Hesychius has, ta=lis: h( mello/gamos parqe/nos kai\ katwnomasme/nh tini/: oi( de\ gunai=ka gameth/n: oi( de\ nu/mfhn. This shows that ta=lis could mean, not only an affianced bride, but also a bride after marriage: just as nu/mfh can mean either. The epithet th=s melloga/mou is not, then, superfluous; and th=s mellonu/mfou in 633 is no argument against it. On the other hand ta/lidos, without the epithet, would have a crude effect. A passage in Pollux (3. 45) has been taken to prove that he had th=s melloga/mou in his text. It does not prove this,—nor the reverse. th=s melloga/mou in Pollux should be (as Semitelos saw) th
 mello/gamon, and we should refer his words solely to v. 633. His point is simply that h( mello/numfos is more correct than h( mellonu/mfh.—Curtius connects ta=lis with te/r-hn, tender; qro/na, flowers: Sanskrit ta/r-una-s, youthful, tender, ta/l-unI, girl, young woman. He supposes the first idea to be that of a plant sprouting or blossoming (cp. qa/los). This at least agrees well with what we know as to the usage of ta=lis.

a)pa/tas (gen. sing.) lexe/wn, a deceit practised on <*> disappointment, in regard to his <*>. The gen. lexe/wn is one of relation <*>ed, perhaps, by the idea of privation <*> a)pa/th were a)poste/rhsis).

div2.p: Third e)peiso/dion. Haemon vainly intercedes with his father. They quarrel, and the son abruptly leaves the scene (765). Creon then commands that Antigone shall at once be immured in a rocky vault.

div3.p: ma/ntewn u(pe/rteron = be/ltion h)\ ma/nteis i)/sasin (better, therefore, than they could tell <*> Schol. o( lo/gos paroimiakw=s, o(po/te mh\ <*>smw=| xrw/meqa, a)ll' au)to/ptai tw=n pr<*> gino/meqa. H. F. 911 *a*g. <*> do/moisi.—*x*o. ma/ntin ou)x e(/teron <*>. ‘I will not bring a seer, other than <*>self’ (cp. O. T. 6), i.e. ‘I need no <*> tell me that’:— imitated by the <*> of the Rhesus 949 sofisth\n d' a)/llon <*>ta/comai, who also has 952 h)/|dh <*>de\n ma/ntews e)/dei fra/sai. Cp. O. <*> <*>.
telei/an He announces that he will not yield.
a)=ra mh/, like mw=n, ‘can it be <*>’ El. 446.
th=s mellonu/mfou: for <*> gen., cp. Thuc. 1.140 to\ *megare/wn <*>isua, and n. on 11.

lussai/nwn, the <*>ing of the MSS., is a word not extant e<*>where, but as correctly formed as <*> xalepai/nw, etc. At first sight it <*> strong: lu/ssa is ‘raving.’ But <*>ain vehemence of language characte<*> Creon (cp. 280 ff.). Instead of saying <*>, ‘have you come here in displeas<*> he says, ‘have you come here to sto<*> me?’ As soi\ me/n shows, there is a <*> contrast with the sisters: he had des<*> Ismene as lussw=san (492). I therefore think lussai/nwn genuine, and a finer reading than the variant noted in L, qumai/nwn. The latter word is used by Hesiod, and in Attic comedy. Some recent edd. place it in the text.
soi\ me/n: cp. 498.

pantaxh=| drw=ntes, ‘however I may act.’ Ai. 1369 w(s a)\n poih/sh|s, pantaxh=| xrhsto/s g' e)/sei. Her. 9.27 pa/nth| ga\r tetagme/noi (wherever we may be posted) peirhso/meqa ei)=nai xrhstoi/: id. 8. 110 pa/ntws e(/toimoi h)=san le/gonti pei/qesqai (‘ready in every case’).
so/s: cp. O. C. 1323.

gnw/mas e)/xwn xrhsta/s, having good counsels, a)porqoi=s (au)ta/s) moi, thou settest them before me as rules. a)porqo/w (a rare word) means, like a)peuqu/nw, (1) ‘to straighten out.’ and then (2) ‘to guide in a straight course.’ Plat. Legg. 757E (praying the gods) a)porqou=n to\n klh=ron pro\s to\ dikaio/taton, ‘to direct the lot (for magistracies) in the best interests of justice.’ Here the gnw=mai are the kano/nes, regulae, which are to guide the youth's course: cp. fr. 430 w(/ste te/ktonos | para\ sta/qmhn i)o/ntos o)rqou=tai kanw/n. Eur. El. 52 gnw/mhs ponhroi=s kano/sin a)nametrou/menos | to\ sw=fron.—Others understand: (1) a)por<*> gnw/mas moi, thou guidest my views, <*>sta\s e)/xwn, having good views (of thine own). Or (2) ‘Having good views, thou guidest me,’ supplying me with a)porqoi=s (like O. T. 104 a)peuqu/nein po/lin). But moi would then be awkward. Cp. Plaut. Trin. 304 (a son to his father) sarta tecta tua praecepta usque habui mea modestia.

a)ciw/setai, pass.; cp. 210, O. C. 581 dhlw/setai, O. T. 672 stugh/setai (n.). a)c. mei/zwn fe/resqai, will be esteemed more important to win (cp. 439 h(/ssw labei=n): so Plat. Theaet. 161D w(/ste kai\ a)/llwn dida/skalos a)ciou=sqai dikai/ws, ‘to be justly ranked as a teacher.’ The same use is implied in Legg. 917 D o(po/shs a)\n timh=s a)ciw/sh| to\ pwlou/menon (at whatever price he may value...).—L's reading, a)ci/ws e)/stai, though tenable, seems slightly less probable, when we observe that this adv. is regularly used either (a) with gen., a)ci/ws e(autw=n, etc., or (b) absol., in such phrases as Thuc. 3.40 kola/sate...a)ci/ws tou/tous, ‘according to their deserts.’ (So O. T. 133 a)ci/ws=‘as the case required.’) Thus we could say, ou(=tos o( ga/mos a)ci/ws e)/stai mei/zwn f., ‘will deservedly (=on its merits) be a greater prize.’ But it is less natural to say, ou)dei\s ga/mos a)ci/ws e)/stai m. f., ‘no marriage will rightly be preferred,’ etc., where a)ci/ws becomes a mere equiv. for dikai/ws or proshko/ntws. The change of a)ciw/setai into a)ci/ws e)/stai would have been the easier, since the ordinary fut. was a)ciwqh/somai.

sou= kalw=s h(goum., (with mei/zwn), than thy good guiding: cp. Her. 1.34 meta\ de\ *so/lwna oi)xo/menon. —It is a mistake (I think) to detect a mental reserve in the participle (‘than thy guiding, if, or when, it is good’). Haemon knows that his one chance of saving Antigone is first to mollify his father, and then to urge the argument from public opinion (688 ff.). His deference is unqualified.
ga/r in assent (O. T. 1117).

dia\ ste/rnwn e)/xein, lit., ‘to be disposed in one's breast,’=fronei=n, or diakei=sqai. The phrase differs in two points from others which seem like it. (1) The gen. with dia/ in such phrases regularly denotes a state or act of the mind, whereas ste/rnwn represents the mind itself. (2) e)/xein in such phrases is always trans., the intrans. verb being ei)=nai. Thus e)/xw tina/ (or ti) di' ai)sxu/nhs, ai)ti/as, o)rgh=s, fulakh=s, etc. But ei)mi\ di' h(suxi/hs (Her. 1.206), dia\ fo/bou (Thuc. 6.59), di' o)/xlou (Aristoph. Eccl. 888). Here ou(/tw, going with e)/xein, shows that the verb is intrans.,—not trans., with tau=ta understood.

(One ought to think thus),—that is, o)/pisqen e(sta/nai patr. gnw/mhs, one ought to place oneself under the guidance of a father's counsel, pa/nta, in all things (adv. neut. pl., O. T. 1197 etc.). Thus e(sta/nai depends on xrh/,—the indefinite subject of e)/xein (tina/) being continued with it; and the whole clause explains ou(/tw. The image from a soldier posted behind his leader suits the military tone in which Creon presently enforces the value of discipline (670). Cp. Plat. Rep. 471D ei)/te kai\ e)n th=| au)th=| ta/cei ei)/te kai\ o)/pisqen e)pitetagme/non. The phrase o)/pisqen e(sta/nai gnw/mhs is a poetical equiv. for a)kolouqei=n th=| gnw/mh| (Thuc. 3.38).—We could also render,—‘that all things rank second to a father's will’: when e(sta/nai would depend on dia\ ste/rnwn e)/xein as=nomi/zein. But e(sta/nai applies to the ta/cis of persons more naturally than to the estimation of things: cp.
