Her. 9.27 i(/na doke/ei e)pithdeo/taton h(me/as ei)=nai e(sta/nai (in battle): and the constr. is also less simple. i(sta/nai (which Musgrave proposed) would suit that view better.
w(s without a)/n, as 760, O. T. 359, and oft.

a)ntamu/nwntai, a neutral word: thus Thuc. 2.67 toi=s au)toi=s a)mu/nesqai, to retaliate; but 1. 42 toi=s o(moi/ois h(ma=s a)mu/nesqai, to reward: here kakoi=s defines it.—e)c i)/sou patri/ = w(/sper o( path/r (cp. 516): O. C. 171 a)stoi=s i)/sa xrh\ meleta=n.—The son's part is tou\s au)tou\s e)xqrou\s kai\ fi/lous nomi/zein,—the definition of a cummaxi/a as dist. from a merely defensive e)pimaxi/a, Thuc. 1.44. Cp. 523 n.: Pind. P. 2. 83fi/lon ei)/h filei=n: | poti\ d' e)xqro\n a(/t' e)xqro\s e)w\n lu/koio di/kan u(poqeu/somai.

a)/llo is most simply taken as governed by fu=sai, though, if we had h)/ instead of plh/n, Greek idiom would rather lead us to supply poih=sai: see on 497, and cp. Ai. 125 ou)de\n o)/ntas a)/llo plh\n | ei(/dwl'. This is better than to make a)/llo object to ei)/pois (‘what could one say of him,’ etc.).
po/nous: cp. 533.—
ge/lwn: cp. El. 1153 gelw=si d' e)/xqroi: Ai. 79 ou)/koun ge/lws h(/distos ei)s e)xqrou\s gela=n; 961 oi( d' ou)=n gelw/ntwn ka)pixairo/ntwn kakoi=s.

ta\s fre/nas g'. Recent edd. have usually scorned the simple insertion of ge, by which Triclinius healed the metre. But it should be noticed that ge may emphasise ta\s fre/nas e)kba/lhs, and not merely ta\s fre/nas: cp. 747: O.C. 1278 tou= qeou= ge prosta/thn, where ge emphasises the whole phrase, not merely the word qeou=. The deprecatory force of ge, as seen in mh\ su/ ge (O. C. 1441 n.), also recommends it, even when we have not su/. Cp. Eur. Hipp. 503 kai\ mh/ ge pro\s qew=n, eu)= le/geis ga/r, ai)sxra\ de/, | pe/ra probh=|s tw=nd'. Without, then, thinking fre/nas g' certain, I think it far more probable than the next best remedy, fre/nas su/ g' h(donh=|. As to a third conjecture, su/ g' h(donh=s, the phrase ou(/neka h(donh=s gunaiko/s (pleasure in her) would be very awkward. Some strange emendations have been proposed: see Appendix.

fre/nas … e)kba/lh|s, cast off the restraint of reason, as O. T. 611 fi/lon... e)sqlo\n e)kbalei=n, O. C. 631 eu)me/neian e)kba/loi (reject friendship). The first idea is that of casting out of house or land, banishing. Somewhat similar is Plat. Crito 46B tou\s de\ lo/gous, ou(\s e)n tw=| e)/mprosqen e)/legon, ou) du/namai nu=n e)kbalei=n (reject). Cp. 683.
u(f' h(donh=s: Ai. 382 h)= pou polu\n ge/lwq' u(f' h(donh=s a)/geis. Here the word denotes sensuous impulse: cp. Eur. Phoen. 21 h(donh=| dou/s: Thuc. 3.38 a)koh=s h(donh=| h(ssw/menoi.
yuxro/n, frigid, joyless: Eur. Alc. 353 yuxra\n me/n, oi)=mai, te/ryin.

paragka/lisma: so Tr. 540 u(pagka/lisma (of a wife); and so a)gka/lisma, e)nagka/lisma. The neuter gives a contemptuous tone. Cp. 320 la/lhma, 756 dou/leuma. Eur. Or. 928 ta)/ndon oi)kourh/mata (of women), Aesch. Ag. 1439 *xrushi/+dwn mei/ligma (Agamemnon).
do/mois. For the full stop after the 5th foot cp. O. T. 800.

e(/lkos, esp. an ulcer; said in Il. 2.723 of a serpent's venomous bite; hence fitting here in ref. to the false friend, the e)/xidna in the house (531). So civil strife (sta/sis e)/mfulos) is described by Solon as pa/sh| po/lei...e(/lkos a)/fukton (4. 17).

fi/los is any one near and dear to us; the masc. is used, though the reference is to a wife, because the thought of domestic treason is put in the most general way: so (though with ref. to a woman) 464 katqanw/n, 496 a(lou/s. Cp. Eur. Alc. 355 h(du\ ga\r fi/lous | ka)n nukti\ leu/ssein, o(/ntin' a)\n parh=| xro/non (Admetus speaking of his wife: we might read fi/los).
ptu/sas, with loathing: Aesch. PV 1069 (speaking of treason) kou)k e)/sti vo/sos | th=sd' h(/ntin' a)pe/ptusa ma=llon.

w)sei/ te dusmenh= (ou)=san), and as if she were a foe. For ptu/sas connected by te with an adj. in a different case, see n. on 381 se/ g' a)pistou=san...a)/gousi...kai\...kaqelo/ntes. In El. 234 we have ma/thr w(sei/ tis pista/: but nowhere in Attic poetry do we find the epic and lyric use of w(sei/ te as merely=w(sei/ (Il. 2.780, Pind. 1. 44, etc.). And, as we have seen, it is needless to assume it here. Yet supposed difficulties about fi/los and w(sei/ te have led Nauck to propose that vv. 652—654 should be made into two, thus: ge/noit' a)\n e(/lkos mei=zon; a)ll' a)poptu/sas | th\n pai=d' e)n *(/aidou th/nde numfeu/ein me/qes.
numfeu/ein here=gamei=sqai, nubere, as 816. But it also=gamei=n, uxorem ducere: Eur. I.A. 461*(/aidhs nin, w(s e)/oike, numfeu/sei ta/xa.
a)pisth/sasan: cp. 219.— yeudh=: referring to his solemn and public declaration, 184—210.
ktenw=. For the emphatic pause, cp. 72 qa/yw, and n. on 46.

pro\s tau=t', after an announcement of resolve, and before a defiant imperative, as O. T. 426, O. C. 455, El. 820, Aesch. PV 992, Aristoph. Ach. 959 etc. Similarly pro\s ou)=n ta/de, Aristoph. Nub. 1030.
e)fumnei/tw, repeatedly invoke (a scornful word): cp. 1305, O. T. 1275 n.
*di/a cu/naimon: see on 487.

ta/ g' e)gg. fu/sei, those who, by birth, are relatives: for the place of the adverbial fu/sei, cp. El. 792 tou= qano/ntos a)rti/ws, Aesch. PV 216 tw=n parestw/twn to/te. For the neut., instead of tou\s e)ggenei=s, cp. Ph. 448ta\ me\n panou=rga kai\ palintribh=...ta\ de\ | di/kaia kai\ ta\ xrh/st'.
a)/kosma, unruly: so of Thersites, Il. 2.213 o(/s r(' e)/pea fresi\n h(=|sin a)/kosma/ te polla/ te h)/|dh, | ma/y, a)ta\r ou) kata\ ko/smon, e)rize/menai basileu=sin. Cp. 730.
qre/yw with predicative adj., as 1080, O. T. 98, etc.

ka/rta tou\s e)/cw g., sc. a)ko/smous qre/yw. It is needless to supply a more general verb, like poih/sw: the ruler's relation to his people justifies qre/yw: cp. O. T. 1 w)= te/kna. ‘If I allow my own kindred to be unruly, I shall be obliged to tolerate unruliness in the citizens at large. For my authority as a ruler will be gone.’

Seidler transposes vv. 663—667, placing them after 671. The object is to bring vv. 668—671 into immediate connection with 662. In this there is one slight grammatical gain; since, as the vv. stand in the MSS., tou=ton ...to\n a)/ndra (668) means, ‘the man who acts thus’ (viz., as described in vv. 666 f.). But the order given in the MSS. is right. The transposition obliterates one of the finest touches in the speech. Creon demands that the obedience of the citizens to the ruler shall be absolute (666 f.). And then he supplements this demand with a remark on the dignity of such obedience. The man who so obeys gives the best proof that he could also rule (668 ff.). Seidler destroys the point of vv. 668 ff. by placing them after 662.

The connection of thought in the whole passage—which is slightly obscured by compression—may be most clearly shown by taking the verses in small consecutive groups. (1) 659 f. If I tolerate disloyalty

in my own relatives, I shall encourage it in other citizens. (2) 661 f. For (ga/r) only a man who is firm (xrhsto/s) where his own relatives are concerned will be found to uphold justice in the State (i.e. will have the authority necessary for doing so). (3) 663 f. Now, I recognise disloyalty in any one who breaks the law and defies the government, as Antigone has done. (4) 666 f. Instead of so doing, the citizen is bound to obey the government in everything. (5) 668—671. There is nothing slavish in that; on the contrary, it shows that the citizen is not only a good subject, but would, if required, be a good ruler;—as he would also be a good soldier.—Then comes the general censure on unruliness (672—676). And then the conclusion:—I must vindicate my authority, and punish Antigone (677 —680).
u(perba/s, absol., having transgressed: Il. 9.501 o(/te ke/n tis u(perbh/h| kai\ a(ma/rth|: so Plat. Rep. 366A u(perbai/nontes kai\ a(marta/nontes.
tou)pita/ssein, prop. said of a master giving orders to slaves (O. C. 839): so e)pita/gmata are a despot's commands (Arist. Pol. 4.4. 28). For the art., cp. 78.
noei=, as 44.—Antigone ‘did violence to the laws’ by her deed: she seemed ‘to dictate to her rulers’ when she proclaimed a law superior to theirs (450 ff.). Cp. 482 ff.

sth/seie: the optat. (instead of o(\n a)\n sth/sh|) puts the case in the most general way: any one whom she might conceivably appoint. Hence this optat. suits gnw=mai: cp. 1032: Tr. 92 to/ g' eu)= | pra/ssein, e)pei\pu/qo/ito, ke/rdose)mpola=|: O.T. 315 (n.), ib. 979.

kai\ ta)nanti/a, i.e. kai\ mega/la kai\ a)/dika. So oft. in euphemisms, Thuc. 4.62 a)gaqo\n h)\...ta\ e)nanti/a: Plat. Rep. 472C eu)daimoni/as te pe/ri kai\ tou= e)nanti/ou. Cp. Leutsch Paroem. App. 1. 100kreisso/nwn ga\r kai\ di/kaia ka)/dik' e)/st' a)kou/ein: and the verse cited by schol. on Aesch. PV 75 dou=le, despotw=n a)/koue kai\ di/kaia ka)/dika.

tou=ton … to\n a)/ndra refers to the indefinite subject of klu/ein in 666:—the man who thus obeys. The looseness of grammatical connection would hardly be felt when the sense was so clear. Cp. 1035 (tw=n d'). So in O. C. 942 au)tou/s refers to th\n po/lin in 939.
kalw=s...eu)=: for the change of word in the epanaphora cp. O. C. 1501 safh\s me\n a)stw=n e)mfanh\s de\ tou= ce/nou (n.).
a)/n with a)/rxein (=o(/ti a)/rxoi a)/n) as well as qe/lein.
doro\s … xeimw=ni. Eur. Suppl. 474 polu\s klu/dwn | h(mi=n te kai\ soi\ cumma/xois t' e)/stai doro/s.
prostetagme/non, the regular term for placing soldiers at their posts: Thuc. 2.87 e(/pesqe, xw/ran mh\ prolei/pontes h(=| a)/n tis prostaxqh=|.

parasta/thn, one who stands beside one in the ranks (as prosta/ths in front and e)pista/ths behind): Xen. Cyr. 3.3.21 (the gods are invoked as) parasta/tas a)gaqou\s kai\ summa/xous. The Attic e)/fhbos, on beginning, at eighteen, his term of service as a peri/polos, took an oath, ou) kataisxunw= o(/pla ta\ i(era\ [the arms given to him by the State], ou)d' e)gkatalei/yw to\n parasta/thn o(/tw| a)\n stoixh/sw (by whose side he should be placed): Serm. 43. 48. Thus for an Athenian audience this verse would be effective, and would seem peculiarly appropriate when addressed to the youthful Haemon.

po/leis o)/llusin, h(/d' is far better and more spirited than po/leis t' o)/llusin h)d': it is also strongly confirmed by the similar passage, 296 ff., where we have tou=to—to/d'—to/d', just as here au(/th...h(/d'... h(/d'. When po/leis had become, as in L, po/lis,—a corruption found also in Aesch. Pers. 489,—t' may have been added for metre's sake. To h)de/ itself there is no objection: it was certainly used in iambics by Soph. (fr. 253, fr. 503), no less than by Aesch. ( Aesch. Cho. 1025, Aesch. Eum. 414), and by Eur. ( Eur. Hec. 323, H. F. 30).— Campb. reads po/leis t' … h(/d', and regards the anacoluthon as making the lines ‘more expressive.’

summa/xou is a certain correction of L's summa/xhi. The meaning is, ‘Disobedience causes allied forces (su/mmaxon do/ru) to break up in flight.’ It turns union into disunion,—the hope of victory into defeat. With su\n ma/xh| the sense would be, ‘Disobedience, aiding the spear (of the foe), causes rout.’ But this would represent disobedience as merely one cause of defeat,—an incident that turns the scale. It is evidently more forcible to represent it as breaking up an army which might otherwise have stood united and firm.

tropa\s katarrh/gnusi, lit., causes rout to break forth, i.e. breaks up the army in rout. Cp. Athen. 130 C o( gelwtopoio\s ei)sh=lqe...kai\ pollou\s kate/rrhcen h(mw=n ge/lwtas, ‘and caused shouts of laughter to break forth among us’: (not, ‘wreaked many witticisms upon us,’—as Casaubon took it.) The only peculiarity in the use of the verb is that it is here equiv. to poiei= katarrh/gnusqai. We cannot compare Theocr. 22. 172 nei=kos a)narrh/cantas, ‘having broken into strife’ (said of the parties to it), which is merely like r(h=cai fwnh/n, etc.

tw=n d' o)rqoume/nwn (masc.), of those who have a prosperous course: Thuc. 2.60 po/lin...o)rqoume/nhn, opp. to sfallome/nhn: 8. 64 cune/bh...th\n po/lin a)kindu/nws o)rqou=sqai. Cp. 163, 167.— ta\ polla\ sw/mata, ‘the greater number of lives,’ differing from tou\s pollou/s only by bringing out the notion of personal safety more vividly. Cp. Ai. 758 where the masc. o(/stis follows ta\...sw/mata.
h( peiqarxi/a: called th=s eu)praci/as | mh/thr by Aesch. Th. 225.The schol. quotes Il. 5.531 ai)dome/nwn d' a)ndrw=n ple/ones so/oi h)e\ pe/fantai.

a)munte/', the impers. neut. plur., as Her. 9.58 e)kei/noisi tau=ta poieu=si ou)k e)pitrepte/a e)sti/, a)lla\ diwkte/oi ei)si/: I. Thuc. 86timwrhte/a, Thuc. 88polemhte/a, Thuc. 118e)pixeirhte/a, etc.: so O. C. 495 o(dwta/. Cp. 447, 576. Eur. Or. 523 a)munw= d', o(/sonper dunato/s ei)mi, tw=| no/mw|. Thuc. 1.140 toi=s koinh=| do/casi bohqei=n.

toi=s kosmoume/nois (neut.), the regulations made by oi( kosmou=ntes, the rulers: meaning here, his own edicts. For the act. kosmei=n, cp. Her. 1.59 (Peisistratus) e)/neme th
 po/lin kosme/wn kalw=s te kai\ eu)=. And for the pass. thus used, ib. 100 tau=ta me
 kata\ ta\s di/kas e)poi/ee (Deïoces), ta/de de\ a)/lla e)kekosme/ato/ oi(: ‘and the following regulations had also been made by him.’— Another view (also noticed by the Schol.) makes toi=s k. dat. of oi( kosmou/menoi, ‘the rulers.’ But (a) the only place which might seem to favour this use of the midd. is Thuc. 8.24 (the Chians, the more they prospered) to/sw| kai\ e)kosmou=nto e)xurw/teron: but there the verb may well be pass., ‘the more securely was their government organised.’ (b) As Creon is himself at once o( a)mu/nwn and o( kosmw=n, it is more natural that he should speak of his own edicts than of ‘the rulers.’—ko/smos was said of a constitution, esp. oligarchical (Thuc. 4.76 metasth=sai to
 ko/smon kai\ e)s dhmokrati/an...tre/yai: 8. 72 me/nein e)n tw=| o)ligarxikw=| ko/smw|). The Cretan ko/smoi were oligarchical magistrates, with military as well as civil powers (Arist. Pol. 2.10).

kou)/toi … h(sshte/a: Aristoph. Lys. 450 a)ta\r ou) gunaikw=n ou)de/pot' e)/sq' h(tthte/a | h(mi=n. (Cp. Milton, Samson 562 ‘Effeminately vanquished.’) Since h(ssa=sqai is only pass., its verbal in te/os can be only pass.: as a(lwte/on could mean only, ‘one must be taken.’ But even in other cases the verbal in te/os sometimes answers to the pass., not to the act., sense of the verb: as Xen. Oec. 7§ 38 o(/tan e)kei/nh (the queen-bee) e)kli/ph|, ou)demi/a oi)/etai tw=n melittw=n a)poleipte/on ei)=nai, a)ll' e(/pontai pa=sai: i.e. o(/ti dei= a)polei/pesqai (pass.), ‘to be left behind’: (for the stationary bees could not be said a)polei/pein the emigrant.)
dei=: for the pause, cp. 555.— e)kpesei=n: here absol., to be displaced,
thrust out: oft. of dethronement (e)kp. turanni/dos, a)rxh=s, kra/tous, Aesch. ), or of exile (xqono/s, O. C. 766).

kou)k a)\n...kaloi/meq' a)/n: the doubled a)/n, as oft. in emphatic or excited utterances (O. T. 339 n.). —These two verses (like so many others) have been suspected merely because they are not indispensable. A defence is perhaps hardly needed. It is enough to remark that Creon's irritation under a woman's defiance (484, 525, 579) naturally prompts this further comment on the word gunaiko/s in 678. And the phrase gunaikw=n h(/ssones (680) has a peculiar force as spoken to Haemon,— whom Creon afterwards taunts as gunaiko\s u(/steron (746).
tw=| xro/nw|, by our age: cp. 729 to\n xro/non, ‘my years’: O. T. 963.
kekle/mmeqa, are deceived: so 1218: Tr. 243 ei) mh\ cumforai\ kle/ptousi/ me.

dokei=s le/gein fronou/ntws peri\ (tou/twn peri\) w(=n le/geis. At first sight it is natural to wish, with Herm. , for dokei=s... w(=n le/geis le/gein pe/ri. Cp. 1057 a(\n le/gh|s le/gwn. But here it is fitting that le/gein should have the prominence of the first place. And the undoubted harshness of the order may be partly excused by observing that w(=n le/geis is practically equiv. to tou/twn.

qeoi/. Creon had urged that filial piety demands the submission of the son's judgment to the gnw/mh patrw/|a (640); and had warned Haemon against disregarding the voice of reason (648). Haemon replies: ‘Reason is the gift of the gods. I dare not suggest that your reasonings are wrong; but other men, too, may sometimes reason soundly. Now, I know what the Thebans are saying of your action; and, as a son devoted to your welfare, I ought to tell you.’—The tact and deference which mark this speech place Creon's au)qa/deia in a stronger light.
kthma/twn: cp. 1050: O. T. 549: Her. 5.24 kthma/twn pa/ntwn e)sti\ timiw/taton a)nh\r fi/los cuneto/s te kai\ eu)/noos.

e)gw\ d' o(/pws: lit., ‘I should not be able to say (and may I never be capable of saying!) in what respect (o(/pws) thou dost not say these things rightly.’ He could not, if he would—and would not, if he could—impugn his father's reasonings. He only suggests that the case may have also another aspect, which Creon has not considered.

mh\ after o(/pws is generic, as after o(/s, o(/stis (691, 696): I could not say what point in thy argument is such as not to be true:—just as we could have, ou)k oi)=da o(\ (or o(/ ti) mh\ a)lhqeu/eis. The mh/ might be taken with o)rqw=s (‘how thou sayest otherwise than rightly’), but the order of words is against this. [It cannot be explained as substituted for ou) through the influence of the optatives.]

mh/t' e)pistai/mhn. For this verb as=‘to be capable of,’ cp. 472, Tr. 543 e)gw\ de\ qumou=sqai me\n ou)k e)pi/stamai | nosou=nti kei/nw|. For the wish co-ordinated with the statement of fact, cp. 500: Tr. 582 kaka\s de\ to/lmas mh/t' e)pistai/mhn e)gw\ | mh/t' e)kma/qoimi, ta/s te tolmw/sas stugw=: and ib. 143.

kalw=s e)/xon (sc. ti: cp. O. T. 517 ei)s bla/bhn fe/ron), something good, some true thought, ge/noito a)
 kai\ e(te/rw|, might come to (accrue to) another also. For ge/noito cp. Plat. Symp. 211D ei)/ tw| ge/noito au)to\ to\ kalo
 i)dei=n. (The phrase ge/noito me/nta)
 occurs also Ai. 86.)—Not: ‘Yet it might be found well for another’ (to say that you were wrong). Haemon seeks to propitiate his father; but that purpose would scarcely be served by such a speech as this—‘Being your son, I do not contradict you myself, though I think that other people might very reasonably do so.’

sou= d' ou)=n: ‘but in any case (i.e., whatever may be the worth of opinions different from yours) it is my natural part to watch on your behalf,’ etc. For d' ou)=n cp. 722, 769: O. C. 1205 e)/stw d' ou)=n o(/pws u(mi=n fi/lon.—The gen. sou= is supported by the use of the gen. with prokh/domai (741), protarbw= (83), pronow=, etc., and expresses the idea, ‘in thy defence,’ better than soi/ would do. Cp. Eur. Med. 459 to\ so\n...proskopou/menos.— Herm. adopted the v.l. of the schol. in L, su\ d' ou) pe/fukas, which Ellendt approves: but (a) pe/fukas is then less fitting, and (b) d' ou)=n commends the vulgate as genuine.—For the repeated tis, cp. Aesch. Eum. 889mh=ni/n tin' h)\ ko/ton tin'. Thuc. 4.62 ei)/ tw/| ti e)/stin a)gaqo\n h)\ ei)/ tw| ta\ e)nanti/a. (Distinguish Eur. Or. 1218 h)/n tis,... | h)\ su/mmaxo/s tis h)\ kasi/gnhtos,— anyone,—be he ally or brother: and Andr. 733e)/sti ga/r tis ou) pro/sw | *spa/rths po/lis tis, which, if sound, is a mere pleonasm.)

to\ ga so/n, not to\ so
 ga/r: so O. T. 671 to\ ga so/n, ou) to\ tou=d': ib. 1024 h( ga pri
...a)paidi/a. In the case of so/n, at least, this order seems to strengthen, rather than diminish, the emphasis. o)/mma: cp. O. T. 447 ou) to\ so
 | dei/sas pro/swpon. Jeremiah i. 8 ‘Be not afraid of their faces.’
dhmo/th|, the ordinary Theban citizen: cp. O. C. 78 n.

lo/gois toiou/tois, causal dat.: thy face is terrible to the citizen on account of such words as shall displease thee: i.e. the citizen imagines the stern king's face growing darker at the sound of frank speech, and restrains his lips. (Cp. 509.) Doubts as to the dat. lo/gois t. led Dindorf to suppose the loss of one verse (or more) after 690. Herwerden has suggested something like kou)dei/s pot' a)stw=n e)mfanw=s xrh=tai, pa/ter, | lo/gois toiou/tois k.t.l. Nauck thinks that either v. 691 is wholly spurious, or that the words lo/gois toiou/tois are corrupt. But, while the dat. is certainly bold—esp. with a)ndri\ d. preceding it—it is (I think) quite within the possibilities of classical idiom. We should remember that Athenians were accustomed to use a simple dat. (of ‘time’ or ‘occasion’) in speaking of festivals,—as tragw|doi=s kainoi=s: cp. (e.g.) Plat. Symp. 174A xqe\s ga\r au)to\n die/fugon toi=s e)piniki/ois, ‘I eluded him yesterday when he was holding his sacrifice for victory.’ So, here, the dat. lo/gois toiou/tois, though properly causal, might sound to a Greek ear like, ‘at such words,’ i.e. ‘when such words are spoken.’ The causal dat. in 391, tai=s sai=s a)peilai=s, is similar. Cp. also Thuc. I. 84 eu)pragi/ais...ou)k e)cubri/zomen, where the notion, ‘by reason of successes,’ is similarly blended with the notion, ‘in seasons of success.’

oi(=s with te/ryei (cp. O. C. 1140, Ph. 460), klu/wn epexegetic. If, however, the order had been klu/wn te/ryei, then oi(=s might have been for ou(/s, by attraction. The mh/ is generic (‘such that not...’), cp. 696. For the fut. midd. te/ryomai (with pass. sense) cp. fr. 612 o(/pou ge mh\ di/kaia te/ryetai, and [Eur.] Rhes. 194. For the fut. ind. after a relative with mh/, cp. O. T. 1412 n. —Nauck reads te/ryh| (aor. midd.). This rare aor. e)tery)a/mhn is epic, as Od. 12.188 terya/menos (‘having had delight’). It is not Attic, the Attic aor. in that sense being e)te/rfqhn (O. C. 1140).

u(po\ sko/ton goes with a)kou/ein more naturally than, with o)du/retai, and the sense is the same: i.e., he is in the sko/tos where the things are said: for the gen., cp. 65 n., and Tr. 539 mi/mnomen mia=s u(po\ | xlai/nhs, which shows that we need not here conceive the sounds as ‘coming from under’ the darkness. Cp. Xen. Cyr. 4.6.4 kate/sxen u(po\ sko/tou to\n fqo/non. Eur. Or. 1457 u(po\ sko/tou | ci/fh spa/santes. But u(po\ sko/tw| also occurs (Aesch. Ag. 1030, Eur. Phoen. 1214).
ka/kist' … eu)kleesta/twn: cp. O. T. 1433 a)/ristos e)lqw\n pro\s ka/kiston. Plat. Apol. 30A ta\ plei/stou a)/cia peri\ e)laxi/stou poiei=tai.
a)p' e)/rgwn, as their result: Ai. 1078 pesei=n a)\n ka)\n a)po\ smikrou= kakou=.

h(/tis with causal force (O. C. 962); hence, too, the generic mh/q' … mh/q' which belong to ei)/ase (understood with the second mh/q'), not to o)le/sqai: ‘being one who did not allow’ (quae non permiserit).
au)ta/delfon: cp. 1.

e)nfonai=s: cp. 1314. The phrases e)n fonh=|sin and a)mfi\ fonh=|sin are Homeric, and Her.uses the former (with art., Her. 9. 76e)n th=|si fonh=|si e)o/ntas). The phrase e)n fonai=s is used by Pindar, Aesch. , Eur. , and (in parody) by But Ar. v. 1003 of this play— the only play of Soph. which contains the word—seems a solitary Attic instance of fonai=s without e)n.

xrush=s, a general epithet for what is brilliant or precious: thus Pind. P. 3. 73u(gi/eian...xruse/an, and even ( Pind. O. 10. 13) stefa/nw| xruse/as e)lai/as (the wreath of natural olive), as Olympia is ma/thr xrusostefa/nwn a)e/qlwn ( Pind. O. 8. 1) in a like sense. Cp. O. T. 157 (‘golden’ hope), O. C. 1052 (the ‘golden’ bliss of initiation).—There is no allusion to a xrusou=s ste/fanos.
laxei=n can take either gen. or acc., the latter being more freq. (O. C. 450 n.). But here the inf. is rather epexegetic (cp. 1098 labei=n), the gen. depending on a)ci/a.
e)pe/rxetai, spreads over (the town). Cp. Od. 1.299 oi(=on kle/os e)/llabe... | pa/ntas e)p' a)nqrw/pous. Cp. u(fe/rpein, of secret rumour, O. T. 786 n.
qa/llontos, prospering, as Ph. 419me/ga | qa/llonte/s ei)si nu=n e)n *)argei/wn stratw=|.
mei=zon eu)klei/as = mei=zon h)\ eu)/kleia.

pro\s pai/dwn, on their part, from their side: cp. Tr. 738 ti/ d' e)/stin, w)= pai=, pro/s g' e)mou= stugou/menon; We understand mei=zon a)/galma/ e)sti th=s e)kei/nwn eu)klei/as. —The conjecture eu)klei/a is attractive, (a) because qa/llw so oft. takes a dat. of respect, as Hes. Op. 234(a)gaqoi=si), Pind. O. 9. 16(a)retai=sin), etc.: (b) because the strong sigmatism of the verse is thus modified. But the words pro\s pai/dwn confirm eu)klei/as, since with eu)klei/a| we should have expected pai/dwn alone. It is true that path\r qa/llwn eu)klei/a| could mean ‘a father's fame’ (cp. 638); but one could not havé, pro\s pai/dwn ti/ mei=zon a)/galma pai/dwn eu)klei/a| qallo/ntwn;— Triclinius wrongly joined eu)klei/as a)/galma, thinking of eu)klei/as ge/ras ( Ph. 478) and ste/fanon eu)klei/as me/gan (Ai. 465).
nun: cp. 524.

fo/rei: Aristoph. Eq. 757 lh=ma qou/rion forei=n: Eur. Hipp. 118 spla/gxnon e)/ntonon fe/rwn. So Shaksp. Cymb. 3. 4. 146 ‘if you could wear a mind | Dark as your fortune is’: Caes. 5. 1. 113 ‘He bears too great a mind.’
h)=qos=a way of thinking: the inf. depends on it, as on ‘do not think.’ w(s fh\s su/, your way of speaking,=o(\ su\ fh/s: cp. O. C. 1124 (n.) kai/ soi qeoi\ po/roien w(s e)gw\ qe/lw.

kou)de/n, not kai\ mhde/n: it is merely oratio obliqua for o(/ti tou=to kai\ ou)de
 a)/llo o)rqw=s e)/xei. The imperative mh\...fo/rei does not affect this: cp. Ai. 1085 kai\ mh\ dokw=men drw=ntes a(
 h(dw/meqa | ou)k a)ntiti/sein au)=qis a(
 lupw/meqa. But kai\ mhde/n could also have stood here, since v. 705 could be regarded as equiv. to, ‘do not feel confident that...’: see n. on O. T. 1455.
tou=to, antecedent to w(s fhs, emphatically placed: cp. O. T. 385.
mo/nos with fronei=n only.— yuxh/n: cp. 176. Theognis 221 o(/stis toi doke/ei to\n plhsi/on i)/dmenai ou)de/n, | a)ll'

au)to\s mou=nos poiki/la dh/ne' (devices) e)/xein, | kei=no/s g' a)/frwn e)sti/, no/ou beblamme/nos e)sqlou=, | i)/sws ga\r pa/ntes poiki/l' e)pista/meqa. Isocr. or. 3 § 43 joins Theognis, Hesiod and Phocylides as a)ri/stous...sumbou/lous tw=| bi/w| tw=| tw=n a)nqrw/pwn. They were read in schools.
ou(=toi after the collective o(/stis: Xen. Oec. 7. 37o(\s a)\n ka/mnh| tw=n oi)ketw=n, tou/twn soi e)pimelhte/on pa/ntwn.

diaptuxqe/ntes, when laid open. Cp. Eur. Hipp. 984 to\ me/ntoi pra=gm', e)/xon kalou\s lo/gous, | ei)/ tis diaptu/ceien, ou) kalo\n to/de. Andr. 330e)/cwqe/n ei)sin oi( dokou=ntes eu)= fronei=n | lamproi/, ta\ d' e)/ndon pa=sin a)nqrw/pois i)/soi. Also sko/lion no. 7 in Bergk Poet. Lyr. (from Athen. 694 C, etc.) ei)/q' e)ch=n o(poi=o/s tis h)=n e(/kastos | to\ sth=qos dielo/nt', e)/peita to\n nou=n | e)sido/nta, klh/|santa pa/lin, | a)/ndra fi/lon nomi/zein a)do/lw| freni/. The image might be suggested by various objects,— a casket, tables, fruit, or the like.—Cp. Shaks. Rom. 3. 2. 83(of Romeo) ‘Was ever book containing such vile matter So fairly bound?’
kenoi/, sc. o)/ntes: cp. 471.
a)/ndra, subject to manqa/nein, as O. T. 314 a)/ndra d' w)felei=n k.t.l.: for the place of to/, cp. 723, Tr. 65 se\... | to\ mh\ puqe/sqai instead of to\ se\ mh\ puqe/sqai.
kei) … h)=|: see O. T. 198 n.

tei/nein, absol., here, like tei/nein to/con or tei/nein po/da, ‘to strain the cord too tight,’—to be overrigid in maintaining one's own views. This poet. use should be distinguished from the ordinary intrans. use of tei/nw, like tendere, ‘to have a direction,’ or ‘take one's way’ (Xen. Anab. 4.3.21 e)/teinon a)/nw pro\s to\ o)/ros).
para\ r(ei/qr.: for ā before initial r(, cp. O. T. 847 (e)me\ r(e/pon), O. C. 900 a)po\ r(uth=ros.

xeima/rrois, here a neut. adj., as Eur. Tro. 449 u(/dati xeima/rrw|: usu. o( xeima/rrous (sc. potamo/s). Tozer, Geo. Gr. p. 84: ‘The numerous torrents (xeima/r)r(oi) are the natural result of the configuration of the country, for the steep limestone mountains have but little of a spongy surface to act as a reservoir for the rain... It is especially at the time of the autumn rains that the greatest floods take place, and the sudden swelling and violent rush of the stream has furnished Homer with some of his finest similes.’ (Il. 4.452 ff., 16, 384 ff.: imitated by 2. 305 ff., 12. 523.)—Antiphanes (c. 380 B.C.) parodies these verses (fr. incert. 10: Athen. 22 F).

u(pei/kei. Cp. Babrius fab. 36: an oak, torn up by the roots, is being swept down by a boiling torrent, and asks the reeds how they have managed to escape; when a reed (ka/lamos) answers;—su\ me
 maxome/nh tai=s pnoai=s e)nikh/qhs, | h(mei=s de\ kampto/mesqa malqakh=| gnw/mh|, | ka)
 baio
 h(mw=n a)/nemos a)/kra kinh/sh|.
au)to/premna = au)to/rriza, pro/rriza; Il. 9.541 xamai\ ba/le de/ndrea makra\ | au)th=|sin r(i/zh|si.
au)/tws, adv. from au)to/s (with ‘Aeolic’ acc.); see on O. T. 931.

nao/s, Doric for new/s, allowed by tragedy even in iambics, as Ai. 872, Aesch. Th. 62, Eur. Med. 523: though na=es (953) and nai/+ occur only in lyrics. So nao/s, temple (286), *)aqa/na, kunago/s, o(dago/s, podago/s (1196): and even in Att.prose loxago/s, ou)rago/s, cenago/s.
e)gkrath=, proleptic: cp. 475 periskelh=.

po/da, the sheet: the po/des were ropes attached to the two lower corners of the sail, whence their name. Eur. Or. 706 kai\ nau=s ga/r, e)ntaqei=sa pro\s bi/an podi/, | e)/bayen, e)/sth d' au)=qis, h)\n xala=| po/da: a ship dips when strained too hard by the sheet (i.e. when the sheet is hauled too taut), but rights again, if one slackens.
mhde/n, generic (such an one as does not...).

ka/tw stre/yas, sc. nau=n, easily supplied from nao/s: for ka/tw, cp. 527: for stre/fw = a)nastre/fw, O. C. 1453. Hermann's to\ ploi=on for to\ loipo/n is not only needless, but spoils the force of the phrase: ‘thenceforth voyages,’ is an ironical way of saying that the voyage comes to an abrupt end: cp. 311.
se/lmasin, the rowers' benches: thus u(pti/ois vividly suggests the moment of capsizing.

ei)=ke qumou=, ‘cease from wrath,’ lit., recede from it. The qumo/s is conceived as ground from which he retires; so qumou= pera=n=‘to go far in wrath,’ and is contrasted with ei)/kein: O. T. 673 stugno\s me\n ei)/kwn dh=los ei)=, baru\s d', o(/tan | qumou= pera/sh|s. For the gen., cp. Il. 4.509 mhd' ei)/kete xa/rmhs | *)argei/ois: ib. 5. 348 ei)=ke, *dio\s qu/gater, pole/mou kai\ dhi+oth=tos: Her. 2.80 ei)/kousi th=s o(dou=: id. 7. 160 u(pei/comen tou= a)rxai/ou lo/gou: Aristoph. Ran. 790 u(pexw/rhsen au)tw=| tou= qro/nou. Eur. has a somewhat similar phrase, Eur. Hipp. 900o)rgh=s d' e)canei\s kakh=s, a)/nac | *qhseu=, to\ lw=|ston soi=si bou/leusai do/mois, where the sense is, ‘having remitted thy wrath,’ e)canei\s [seauto\n] o)rgh=s.

kai\ meta/stasin di/dou, ‘and concede a change’: allow our pleading to change your mood. A change in Creon's mood implies a change in the whole situation. For the notions thus blended in meta/stasin here, cp. Alexis fr. incert. 46 tw=n metri/wn ai( mei/zones | lu=pai poiou=si tw=n frenw=n meta/stasin: Andoc. or. 2 § 18 oi)/sein e)/mellen...tou= to/te paro/ntos kakou= meta/stasin.

di/dou: a verb oft. used of concession to the remonstrance of friends: Ai. 483 pau=sai/ ge me/ntoi kai\ do\s a)ndra/sin fi/lois | gnw/mhs krath=sai: Tr. 1117 do/s moi seauto/n, mh\ tosou=ton w(s da/knei | qumw=| du/sorgos.—Others place a comma or point at ei)=ke, taking kai/ as= ‘also’; ‘yield, also permitting thy wrath to change’ (with didou/s); or ‘yield: also permit,’ etc. (an asyndeton, with di/dou). On this view, either qumw=| or qumou= is possible. But the fatal objection to it is the weakness of kai/, whether the ‘also’ is explained (a) as by Campbell (with di/dou) —‘if you are angry, be also placable’; or (b) as by Wecklein (with didou/s)—‘it is possible not only to moderate one's passion, but also to desist from it,’ which implies that he might yield while still angry.—See Appendix.

ei)/ tis gnw/mh pro/sesti kai\ a)p' e)mou= n. (o)/ntos), i.e., if I also, younger though I am, can contribute a sound opinion. Cp. O. C. 292 ta)nqumh/mata | ...ta)po\ sou=, the thoughts urged on thy part. El. 1464 telei=tai ta)p' e)mou=. For the modest kai/, cp. O. T. 1100 ei) xrh/ ti ka)me\...staqma=sqai: Ph. 192ei)/per ka)gw/ ti fronw=.—If ka)p' were taken as kai\ e)pi/, it must mean, ‘in my case also.’ Plat. Rep. 475A e)p' e)mou= le/gein (to take me as an instance). In El. 1469 I formerly thus took ka)p' e)mou= qrh/nwn tu/xh|, but now think that there, too, it is kai\ a)po/.
presbeu/ein = presbu/taton ei)=nai, to be the best thing: Eur. Her. 45 oi)=si presbeu/ei ge/nos, whose birth has precedence (=the eldest): cp. O. T. 1365 (presbu/teron) n.
fu=nai, should be by nature: Pind. O. 9. 107to\ de\ fua=| kra/tiston a(/pan (opposed to didaktai\ a)retai/).

pa/nt', adv.: Tr. 338 tou/twn e)/xw ga\r pa/nt' e)pisth/mhn e)gw/: O. T. 475 n.—The merit of listening to good advice is often thus extolled: Hes. Op. 291ou(=tos me\n pana/ristos, o(\s au)to\s pa/nta noh/sh|: | e)sqlo\s d' au)= ka)kei=nos, o(\s eu)= ei)po/nti pi/qhtai. Her. 7.16 i)/son e)kei=no, w)= basileu=, par' e)moi\ ke/kritai, frone/ein te eu)= kai\ tw=| le/gonti xrhsta\ e)qe/lein pei/qesqai. Cp. pro Cluentio 31: Livy 22. 29.

ei) d' ou)=n, sc. mh\ e)/fu toiou=tos. This is better than to suppose that filei= ga/r has changed the form of the sentence (ei) d' ou)=n tou=to mh\ tau/th| r(e/pei), since this elliptical ei) d' ou)=n was a familiar Attic idiom: see Plat. Apol. 34D ei) dh/ tis u(mw=n ou(/tws e)/xei—ou)k a)ciw= me
 ga e)/gwge, ei) d' ou)=n [sc. ou(/tws e)/xei]—e)pieikh= a)/n moi dokw= pro\s tou=ton le/gein: ‘If any one of you is so disposed—I do not think that he ought to be so, but suppose that he is—I think that I might fairly say to him,’ etc. Eur. Hipp. 507 ei)/ toi dokei= soi, xrh=n me
 ou)/ s' a(marta/nein: | ei) d' ou)=n [sc. h(/martes], piqou= moi (‘you ought not to have erred,—but if you have’). So, without ellipse, Aesch. Ag. 1042 ei) d' ou)=n a)na/gkh th=sd' e)pirre/poi tu/xhs, ‘but if one should be doomed to slavery’ (then worthy masters are best). Eur. fr. 463 lu/ph me
 a)/th| peripesei=n...| ei) d' ou)=n ge/noito, k.t.l. Cp. d' ou)=n in 688 (n.).
tou=to … tau/th|: cp. Ai. 950 ta/d' e)/sth th=|de: Aesch. PV 511 ou) tau=ta tau/th|. mh/ is generic, going with tau/th|: in a way other than this.
r(e/pein to incline (as the scale of a balance does): so Plat. Legg. 862D th=|de r(e/pein, Tim. 79 E e)kei/nh| r(e/pon (to incline, or tend, in that direction).
kai\ to\ tw=n eu)= lego/ntwn manqa/nein kalo/n (e)sti): for the place of eu)=, cp. 659: for that of to/, 710. The simple gen., as O. T. 545, etc.

se/ t' doubled: cp. 1340, O. T. 637.—L's dipla=i really favours dipla= rather than Hermann's diplh=|: for i subscript is oft. wrongly added or omitted (cp. 726 cr. n.); whereas h=i was not likely to become a=i here. Either word is admissible; but I slightly prefer dipla=, for this reason. It is true that the plur. of diplou=s in poetry usu.=simply ‘two’ (51, 1232, 1320, O. T. 20, 1135). But Soph. has at least one instance of the distributive sense (‘two sets’), viz., O. T. 1249, where diplou=s=a twofold brood, i.e. Oed., and his children. (I do not add O. T. 288 diplou=s | pompou/s, taking it to mean merely ‘two,’ not ‘two sets.’) And in Attic prose the distributive use is not rare: thus in Plat. Legg. 722E diploi=... no/moi are not ‘two laws,’ but ‘two sets of laws.’ We have, then, good warrant for dipla= here as=‘two sets of arguments.’

On the other hand, diplh=| is strange (though possible) as=‘in two ways,’ i.e. ‘on both sides.’ It usu. means, ‘doubly’ (Eur. Ion 760 kei) qanei=n me/llw diplh=|); or ‘twice as much’ (Plat. Rep. 330C diplh=| h)\ oi( a)/lloi). So, here, it would more naturally mean, ‘twice over.’
kai\ with didac., shall we indeed be taught: El. 385 h)= tau=ta dh/ me kai\ bebou/leuntai poiei=n; O. T. 772 n. For didac. as pass., cp. 637.
dh/, an indignant ‘then’: the word ends a verse also in 923, Tr. 460, Ph. 1065, Eur. Suppl. 521, Hipp. 1093.
th\n fu/sin, birth, and so age; O. C. 1295 w)\n fu/sei new/teros.
mhde/n, sc. dida/skou: to\ mh\ di/k. = o(\ mh\ di/kaio/n e)sti: see on 360 ou)de\n...to\ me/llon.

to\n xro/non, my years: cp. 681.— The change of ta)/rga into tou)/rgon (adopted by Nauck) is no gain. The sing. is taken as ‘the cause’ (which he defends). But he means, ‘you should consider, not my age, but my conduct,—my merits’: and this is expressed by ta)/rga, just as in O. C. 265 o)/noma mo/non dei/santes: ou) ga\r dh\ to/ ge | sw=m' ou)de\ ta)/rga ta)ma/. Cp. Menander fr. incert. 91 mh\ tou=to ble/yh|s, ei) new/teros le/gw, | a)ll' ei) fronou/ntwn tou\s lo/gous a)ndrw=n le/gw (v.l. fronou=ntos...a)ndro/s: Bentley, fe/rw).

e)/rgon. Haemon has asked that his e)/rga may be considered. Creon asks scornfully, ‘Do you consider it an e)/rgon— something which you can urge in your favour—to be the champion of a rebel?’ e)/rgon would not have been thus used alone, but for the desire to give ta)/rga a derisive echo. The Attic associations of the word help, however, to explain this use. Thus e)/rgon meant (a) a thing worth doing, as Aristoph. Lys. 424 ou)de
 e)/rgon e(sta/nai, it is no use...(cp. Ai. 852); so ou)de
 prou)/rgou e)sti/, non operae pretium est: or (b), one's allotted task, as Aristoph. Av. 862, i(ereu=, so
 e)/rgon, qu=e. So here, without meaning so much as ‘achievement’ (El. 689), it could mean, ‘useful act,’ ‘worthy task.’
tou\s a)kosmou=ntas: so Ph. 387: cp. above 660, Ph. 677.
se/bein, as 511.

ou)d', not even: O. C. 1429 (n.) ou)d' a)ggelou=men flau=ra. So far am I from showing honour to evil-doers, that I would not even wish others to do so. Without directly denying that Antigone can be described as a)kosmou=sa, he denies that she is kakh/. This involves the whole question between the divine and the human law.

toia=|de … nosw|, that of being kakh/. Others understand, tw=| ei)s tou\s kakou\s eu)sebei=n. But the sense of the dialogue runs thus:—‘C. Do you approve of honouring law-breakers?—H. I should not dream of honouring wrong-doers.—C. Is not she<*> then, a wrong-doer?’ Doubtless, Creon could also say,—‘Does not she, then, honour wrong-doers (Polyneices)?’ Here, however, his point is that she is a rebel,— not, that her brother was a traitor.—For the fig. use of no/sos, cp. 1052, and n. on 653.
e)pei/lhptai, attacked, as by a disease: so the act., Thuc. 2.51 (h( no/sos) di\s...to\n au)to\n...ou)k e)pela/mbane. (Distinguish the sense of e)pi/lhptos in 406.)

*qh/bhs, possessive gen., not gen. with o(mo/ptolis, which=‘of the same city’: the sense is, ‘the united folk of Thebes,’=the whole city, pa/ndhmos po/lis (7). Cp. 693. The epic pto/lis is used both in lyr. and in dial. by Aesch. and Eur. , but in neither by

h(mi=n, plur. (instead of e)moi/), combined with the sing. e)me/: cp. 1194: Ai. 1400 ei) de\ mh/ 'sti soi\ fi/lon | pra/ssein ta/d' h(ma=s, ei)=m', e)paine/sas to\ so/n: Ph. 1394ei) se/ g' e)n lo/gois | pei/sein dunhso/mesqa mhde\n w)=n le/gw (and ib. 1219 ff.): H. F. 858 h(/lion marturo/mesqa drw=s' a(\ dra)=n ou) bou/lomai: Ion 391kwluo/mesqa mh\ maqei=n a(\ bou/lomai.
w(s a)/gan ne/os—despite the difference between your age and mine (726).

Dobree's me for ge is clearly right; ge would throw a false emphasis on xrh/ (‘Now, ought I to rule...?’): the sense requires the stress to fall on a)/llw| h)\ 'moi/. This dat. ‘of interest’ does not mean, ‘for my own advantage’ (or gain), but, ‘to my own satisfaction,’ i.e. ‘according to my own views.’ Haemon has made light of Creon's protest against dictation from Thebes. Creon rejoins, ‘What, am I to rule Thebes in dependence on any other judgment than my own?’ In Eur. Suppl. 410 Creon's herald says, po/lis ga\r h(=s e)gw\ pa/reim' a)/po | e(no\s pro\s a)ndro/s, ou)k o)/xlw|, kratu/netai.—For e)moi/ instead of e)mautw=|, cp. Plat. Gorg. 474B e)gw\ ga\r dh\ oi)=mai kai\ e)me\ kai\ se\...h(gei=sqai.—Though xrh/ ge is untenable, the dat. is no argument against it: xrh/ could be absolute, the dat. being still a dat. of interest. There is no certain Attic instance of xrh/ with dat. In Ión 1317 toi=si d' e)ndi/kois | i(era\ kaqi/zein, o(/stis h)dikei=t', e)xrh=n, Dobree's tou\s de/ g' e)ndi/kous is needless: the sense is, ‘in the interest of the just, it was right,’ etc. In Lys. or. 28 § 10 toi=s a)/rxousi toi=s u(mete/rois e)pidei/cete po/teron xrh\ dikai/ois ei)=nai, we should read dikai/ous, and just afterwards u(felome/nous. Xenophon has dei= with dat. and infin., if the text is sound in Xen. An. 3. 4. 35.

po/lis ga\r ou)k e)/sq'. Cp. Arist. Pol. 3.16 peri\ de\ th=s pambasilei/as kaloume/nhs,—au)/th d' e)sti\ kaq' h(\n a)/rxei pa/ntwn kata\ thn e(autou= bou/lhsin o( basileu/s,— dokei= de/ tisin ou)de\ kata\ fu/sin ei)=nai to\ ku/rion e(/na pa/ntwn ei)=nai tw=n politw=n, o(/pou sune/sthken e)c o(moi/wn h( po/lis. For Plato, the
turanni/s is e)/sxaton po/lews no/shma, Rep. 544C. de Rep. 3. 31 ubi tyrannus est, ibi...dicendum est nullam esse rempublicam.

nomi/zetai with gen., as O. C. 38 (n.).—In a different sense (and rather with an allusion to demagogues) it is said in Ph. 386po/lis ga\r e)/sti pa=sa tw=n h(goume/nwn (like e)/sti tou= le/gontos, O. T. 917).

kalw=s e)rh/mhs g' (L) is much better than kalw=s g' e)rh/mhs (Blaydes and Nauck): Soph. often thus adds ge to the emphatic adj., as El. 365 ou)d' a)\n su/, sw/frwn g' ou)=sa: ib. 518 qurai/an g' ou)=san: Ph. 811ou) mh/n s' e)/norko/n g' a)ciw= qe/sqai.
Though at least one late MS. (Paris E) has summaxei=n, it is needless to assume here the same mixed constr. as Tr. 1238 a(nh\r d' o(/d', w(s e)/oiken, ou) nemei=n e)moi\ | fqi/nonti moi=ran.
ou)=n, indeed, in fact: cp. 489.— prokh/domai: cp. on proskopei=n, 688.
w)= pagka/kiste: so Heracles to his son Hyllus, Tr. 1124. Cp. O. C. 743 plei=ston...ka/kistos.

dia\ di/khs i)w\n patri/, engaging in controversy with him, bandying arguments with him. Thuc. 6.60 a)rnhqe/nti dia\ di/khs e)lqei=n, to deny the charge, and stand a trial. Xen. Anab. 3.2.8 pa/lin au)toi=s dia\ fili/as i)e/nai...dia\ panto\s pole/mou au)toi=s i)e/nai. So dia\ ma/xhs (Her. 6.9), di' e)/xqras (Eur. Phoen. 479).— Cp. Plut. Mor. 483C (a brother, in a brother's defence, ought to brave the displeasure of parents): ai( de\ u(pe\r a)delfou= par' a)ci/an kakw=s a)kou/ontos h)\ pa/sxontos a)ntidiki/ai kai\ dikaiologi/ai pro\s au)tou\s (the parents) a)/memptoi kai\ kalai/: kai\ ou) fobhte/on a)kou=sai (to have said to one) to\ *sofo/kleion: w)= pai= ka/kiste (quoting this v.)...kai\ ga\r au)toi=s h( toiau/th di/kh (controversy) toi=s e)legxome/nois poiei= th\n h(=ttan h(di/w th=s ni/khs.

a)rxa/s, the king's powers or prerogatives, like kra/th (60, 166, 173): cp. 177, 797. Cp. Aesch. Ch. 864a)rxa/s te polissono/mous | pate/rwn q' e(/cei me/gan o)/lbon (Orestes). Eur. I. A. 343 e)pei\ kate/sxes a)rxa/s (Agamemnon).

ou) ga\r se/beis: ‘(that plea is void), for,’ etc.: i.e. ‘nay, but thou dost not...’ Creon has asked, ‘Do I wrong, when I reverence my royal office?’ Haemon answers, ‘Nay, there can be no such reverence, when you dishonour the gods.’ A king rules by the divine grace. He sins against his own office when he uses his power to infringe the majesty of the gods.
tima/s, esp. sacrifices (as in this case the offerings to the ne/rteroi): cp. O. T. 909 n.

w)= miaro/n. In Haemon's last words Creon hears an echo of Antigone's doctrine—that the qew=n no/mima rank above the human king's edict (453). Hence gunaiko\s u(/steron, ‘inferior to her,’ ranking after her; so Ai. 1366, Ph. 181.Not, ‘unable to resist her influence’ (through love), as though it were gunaiko\s h(=sson: a meaning which u(/steros could not have. The general sense is, however, the same, —viz., that he ranks behind a woman, who leads him.

‘I may be inferior to a woman, but at least you will never find me yielding to base temptations.’ It would have been ai)sxro/n if he had allowed fear or self-interest to deter him from pleading this cause. (Cp. 509.) Cp. Tr. 489 e)/rwtos...h(/sswn: fr. 844 h(/sswn...o)rgh=s.

ou)/ ta)/n is a certain correction of ou)k a)/n (cp. O. T. 1445, 1469: O. C. 1351: Tr. 279: Ai. 456, 534, etc.). Against the weak conjecture ou)k a)/n g' is the repetition of ge: cp. on O. C. 387. Where ta)/n has been corrupted in our MSS., it has most often become t' a)/n, sometimes g' a)/n or d' a)/n. But a change of ou)/ ta)/n into ou)k a)/n would also be easy in writing where, as in that of L, the k of ou)k was often attached to the next word (see cr. n.).
ge emphasises the whole phrase, h(/ssw tw=n ai)sxrw=n, not h(/ssw alone: cp. 648 n.
gou=n: cp. O. C. 24 n. To plead her cause is to be h(/sswn tw=n ai)sxrw=n.
kai\ sou= ge. Creon is concerned, not merely as a king whose city will be punished by the gods, but as a man who is to be saved from incurring guilt.

Objections have been made to the traditional order of these verses, chiefly in two respects. (1) 755 ei) mh\ path\r h)=sq' is—it is argued—the strongest thing said by Haemon, and ought therefore to come immediately before Creon's final outburst, a)/lhqes; (758). How could it be followed by merely so mild a phrase as mh\ kw/tille/ me?—We may reply:— Haemon says that, if Creon were not his father, he would have thought him mad. It is to this that mh\ kw/tille/ me refers, meaning, ‘Do not seek to deceive me by an affectation of filial deference.’ (2) 757 bou/lei le/gein ti is too mild a remark—it is said—to form the climax of provocation to Creon's anger. We may reply:—It is in substance, if not in form, such a climax, —for a father who holds that unquestioning obedience (640) is a son's first duty. It asserts Haemon's right to maintain his own views against his father's,—dia\ di/khs i)e/nai, as Creon put it (742). The traditional order seems, therefore, to be right.

Three modes of transposition have been proposed. (1) Enger puts 756 and 757 after 749. Then kw/tille (756) refers to Haemon's plea that he has his father's cause, and that of religion, at heart. We lose nothing by such a transposition; but neither do we gain.

(2) Donner (in his transl., ed. 1863) simply transposed verses 755 and 757, leaving the rest as they stand. For this it may fairly be said that 757 comes very fitly after 754. On the other hand it seems to me that 756 does not aptly follow 757.

(3) Pallis arranges thus:—749, 756, 755, 754, 757, 750—753. Thus kena\s gnw/mas (753) becomes the last sting.— The fact is that, in a stormy altercation, we do not look for a closely logical texture and a delicately graduated crescendo. The MS. order is (to my mind) the best; but other arrangements are possible, and would be nearly as good.

Creon, instead of replying to v. 749, abruptly repeats his resolve. ou)k e)/stin w(s tau/thn e)/ti zw=san gamei=s (fut.) pote/, it cannot be that you shall ever wed her while she yet lives; i.e. she is to die at once, and can become your bride, if ever, only e)n *(/aidou (654). Cp. 1240.— w(s for the more usual o(/pws: so Ph. 196ou)k e)/sq' w(s ou).—The strange place of pote/ is explained by the strong emphasis on tau/thn (‘her, at any time, it is impossible that thou shouldest wed’). Soph. often admits bold arrangements of words (cp. O. T. 1245, 1251: O. C. 1428).

h(/d' referring to tau/thn (cp. 296 f.). At first sight h( d' is attractive; but that phrase is properly used with the imperat., and has a defiant or scornful tone (O. T. 669 o( d' ou)=n i)/tw: Ai. 961 oi( d' ou)=n gelw/ntwn: Aristoph. Ach. 186 oi( d' ou)=n bow/ntwn). The quiet h(/d' is more impressive here.— o)lei= tina/, i.e. e)me/: Creon understands him to mean se/. As vv. 763 f. show, Haemon is resolved not to survive Antigone. But he has no thought of threatening his father's life: his frantic action at v. 1231 was a sudden impulse, instantly followed by remorse (1245). For the sinister tis, cp. Ai. 1138 tou=t' ei)s a)ni/an tou)/pos e)/rxetai/ tini. Aristoph. Ran. 552 ff. kako\n h(/kei tini/...dw/sei tis di/khn. Thuc. 4.68 ei)...mh\ pei/setai/ tis, au)tou= th\n ma/xhn e)/sesqai.

h)= e)pece/rxei kai e)papeilw=n w(=de qrasu/s; Dost thou go the length of e'en threatening so boldly? The participial clause defines the manner of e)pece/rxei, and so is practically equiv. to w(/ste kai\ e)papeilei=n etc. The kai/ here belongs to the partic. (distinguish the composite h)= kai/ in question, O. T. 368). Eur. Bacch. 1346 a)ll' e)pece/rxei li/an, (we have erred,) but thou goest too far (in vengeance). Cp. O. C. 438 to\n qumo\n e)kdramo/nta moi | mei/zw kolasth/n.
klai/wn, as O. T. 401, 1152.
frenw/seis, a poet. word, used by Xen. Mem. 4.1.5 tou\s e)pi\ plou/tw| me/ga fronou=ntas...e)fre/nou le/gwn.
ou)k eu)= fronei=n, as angrily refusing (754) to hear reason.
dou/leuma: cp. on 650.

mh\ kwtille/ me, ‘do not seek to cajole me,’— referring to ei) mh\ path\r h)=sq', as expressive of filial respect. Creon means, ‘do not pretend that you have any of the feelings with which a son ought to regard a father.’

Cp. Theognis 363 eu)= kw/tille to\n e)xqro/n (cajole)' o(/tan d' u(poxei/rios e)/lqh|, | ti=sai/ nin, pro/fasin mhdemi/an qe/menos: id. 851 *zeu\s a)/ndr' e)cole/seien *)olu/mpios, o(\s to\n e(tai=ron | malqaka\ kwti/llwn e)capata=n e)qe/lei.

le/gein … klu/ein; do you wish to speak, and yet not to hear? le/gein ti has a euphemistic tone (‘to say something strong, or harsh’), like dra=n ti (El. 336), but the ti could hardly be represented in translation without exaggerating it. le/gein kai\ a)kou/ein was a familiar phrase for fair discussion (Thuc. 4.22 le/gontes kai\ a)kou/ontes peri\ e(ka/stou cumbh/sontai: cp. O. C. 189). El. 628 pro\s o)rgh\n e)kfe/rei, meqei=sa/ moi | le/gein a(\ xrh/|zoim', ou)d' e)pi/stasai klu/ein: ib. 990 h( promhqi/a | kai\ tw=| le/gonti kai\ klu/onti su/mmaxos. The words imply a claim of equality, and are also full of scorn: hence Creon's outburst. —Not: ‘do you wish to taunt and not to be taunted in return?’—as if klu/ein=‘to have things said to one’ (Ai. 1322 klu/onti flau=ra sumbalei=n e)/ph kaka/: El. 523 kakw=s de/ se | le/gw kakw=s klu/ousa pro\s se/qen qama/).
a)/lhqes; the word which marks that Teiresias can no longer restrain his wrath against Oedipus (O. T. 350).
ou) to/nd' *)/ol., without ma/: O. T. 660, 1088. Cp. Ai. 1389 *)olu/mpou tou=d' o( presbeu/wn path/r: O. C. 1655.
i)/sq' o(/ti, adverbial: cp. 276 n.
xai/rwn, impune, as O. T. 363, Ph. 1299.

e)pi\ yo/goisi denna/seis, lit., revile me with (continual) censures: yo/gos is merely censure, fault-finding, not necessarily implying offensive speech (cp. 689). denna/zw, to reproach or revile: Ai. 243 kaka\ denna/zwn r(h/maq': [Eur.] Rhes. 925 (the Muse speaking of Thamyris) o(\s h(mw=n po/ll' e)de/nnasen te/xnhn. So Theogn. 1211 (if the verse be his, and not Anacreon's) mh/ m' a)felw=s [a)fi/lws?] pai/zousa fi/lous de/nnaze tokh=as, alluding to her saying that they had been slaves. Her. 9.107 para\ de\ toi=si *pe/rsh|si gunaiko\s kaki/w a)kou=sai de/nnos me/gisto/s e)sti. This e)pi/ with dat. is not merely ‘with,’ but implies a continuing strain of utterance: El. 108 e)pi\ kwkutw=| tw=nde patrw/|wn | pro\ qurw=n h)xw\ pa=si profwnei=n: Eur. Tro. 315 e)pi\ da/krusi kai\ | go/oisi to\n qano/nta pate/ra... kataste/nous' e)/xeis (thou art ever lamenting).—Others explain e)pi/ as (a) ‘in addition to,’ which implies too sharp a contrast with denna/seis, esp. without kai/: (b) ‘with a view to,’ i.e. ‘in order to blame me.’ Cp. Eur. Phoen. 1555 ou)k e)p' o)nei/desin ou)d' e)pi\ xa/rmasin | a)ll' o)du/naisi le/gw (‘not for insult or spiteful joy, but in pain’). Here, however, that sense would be weak. —For Dobree's e)/ti, cp. Plut. 64 ou)/toi ma\ th\n *dh/mhtra xairh/seis e)/ti. It is plausible, and may be right. But I prefer e)pi\ yo/goisi, because (in the sense explained above) it is so fitting when an impatient man breaks off a dialogue which has irritated him throughout.

a)/gete. The plur. is addressed to the two pro/spoloi who had ushered the sisters into the house (578, komi/zet' ei)/sw, dmw=es). So at 491 the plur. is used, kalei=t'. And, in general, such orders are usu. given in the plur., or by tis with 3rd pers. (as O. T. 1069). Cp. 931 toi=sin a)/gousin. This is against Wecklein's a)/g' a)/ge. The objection to L's a)/gage is not only the sing. number, but also the fact that the 2nd aor. imperat. act. (and midd.) of a)/gw does not seem to have been used in
to\ mi=sos: Ph. 991w)= mi=sos (Odysseus): so mi/shma, stu/gos, stu/ghma.
kat' o)/mmat': Xen. Hier. 1. 14ou)dei\s... e)qe/lei tura/nnou kat' o)fqalmou\s kathgorei=n (‘to his face’).
paro/nti … plhsi/a. The accumulation of words for ‘presence’ marks his vehement anger: cp. Haemon's pleonasm in 764, and O. T. 430.

e)/moige is placed as if it were to be common to both the clauses (ou)/te... te), but the constr. changes: cp. El. 913 a)ll' ou)de\ me\n dh\ mhtro\s ou)/q' o( nou=s filei= | toiau=ta pra/ssein ou)/te drw=s' e)la/nqanen.— For ou)/te followed by te cp. O. C. 1397 (n.).
ou)dama/, neut. plur. adv.: this form is required by metre in 830, as ou)dama=| (Doric) in 874: L always gives ou)dama=i: see on O. C. 1104.
e)n o)fqalmoi=s, with them (the instrumental e)n, 962, 1003, 1201): an epic phrase, Il. 1.587 e)n o)fqalmoi=sin i)/dwmai, etc.: so oft. e)n o)/mmasin (Tr. 241).

toi=s qe/lousi, i.e. any who can endure it. Cp. the words of Teiresias, 1087.—Haemon now finally quits the scene. The deuteragonist is thus set free for the parts of the *)/aggelos and the *)eca/ggelos.
e)c o)rgh=s taxu/s, in haste caused by wrath: cp. Il. 7.111 mhd' e)/qel' e)c e)/ridos seu= a)mei/moni fwti\/ ma/xesqai, out of mere rivalry.
baru/s, resentful: cp. O. T. 673 baru\s d', o(/tan | qumou= pera/sh|s; so as epith. of mh=nis (O. C. 1328) and o)rgh/ ( Ph. 368). The sense of baru/ in 1251 is different.

mei=zon h)\ kat' a)/ndra is said in answer to their hint of fear:—let his passion touch the human limit, aye, or overpass it. O. C. 598 ti/ ga\r to\ mei=zon h)\ kat' a)/nqrwpon nosei=s; For a)nh/r = a)/nqrwpos, ib. 567.
i)w/n: Ph. 351ei) ta)pi\ *troi/a| pe/rgam'
ai(rh/soim' i)w/n: Ai. 304 o(/shn kat' au)tw=n u(/brin e)kti/sait' i)w/n. So here it scornfully suggests some daring enterprise.
For d' ou)=n cp. 688, 722.

tw\ … tw/de: cp. 561 (tw/), O. T. 1472 (toi=n), O. C. 1600 (tw/), El. 977 (tw/de tw/)—all fem.—Attic inscriptions of c. 450— 320 B.C. present numerous instances of fem. dual tw/, toi=n, tou/toin, oi)=n, but no instance of fem. dual ta/, tai=n, tau/tain, or ai(=n. (Meisterhans p. 50.) Hitherto the gen. and dat. tai=n, tai=nde, tau/tain have been retained even by those edd. who give tw/, tw/de, etc. (cp. O. T. 1462, 1504: O. C. 445, 859, 1149, 1290, etc.). But, so far as epigraphic evidence goes, the distinction is arbitrary.
kai/ with the whole phrase katakt. noei=s rather than with katakt. alone (for no minor penalty is in view): cp. 726.
qigou=san: cp. 546.

kai/ with bouleu/ei; (her doom having been fixed,) by what fate do you purpose to slay her? For kai/ thus following the interrog., cp. 1314. Aesch. Ag. 278 poi/ou xro/nou de\ kai\ pepo/rqhtai po/lis; Eur. Hec. 515 pw=s kai/ nin e)cepra/cat';
sfe = au)th/n, Antigone: cp. 44 n.
e)/nqa = e)kei=se e)/nqa, as O. T. 796: so O. C. 188 a)/ge...me... | i(/n' a)/n etc. Cp. Ph. 486mh/ m' a)fh=|s | e)/rhmon ou(/tw xwri\s a)nqrw/pwn sti/bou.

petrw/dei … e)n katw/ruxi, ‘in a rocky cavern’; schol., e)n u(pogei/w| sphlai/w|. Verse 773 shows that Creon is not yet thinking of any particular spot. And katw=ruc shows that he is not thinking of some merely natural grotto or cavern. This word, usu. an adj., here a subst., means a cavern, or chamber, excavated by man's hand: cp. Eur. Hec. 1002 xrusou= palaiai\ *priamidw=n katw/ruxes. So the place is described by kataskafh/s (891). The katw=ruc actually used was near the furthest and highest part of the plain, where Polyneices lay (1197). What, then, was the poet's conception? He seems to suppose the existence of tombs artificially constructed in the rocky pa/goi (411) which bordered on the Theban plain. In one of these tombs— chosen for the remoteness of its situation (773)—Antigone is to be immured. The general type of sepulchral chamber supposed here can be illustrated from actual remains which have been discovered in Greece: see below on vv. 1216 ff.

w(s a)/gos mo/non, sc. ei)=nai, so much as to be barely an expiation; only just enough to avoid the mi/asma. The conjectural change of w(s into o(/son (adopted by several edd.) would be necessary if the indic. e)sti/ had to be supplied, since we could not say tosou=ton w(s (instead of o(/son) a)/gos e)sti/. That change is unnecessary, because it is the inf. ei)=nai that is understood. Cp. Xen. An. 7. 3§ 22 o(/son mo/non geu/sasqai, and see n. on O. C. 790 for other instances where the inf. is expressed. The inf. is understood, as here, in Xen. An. 7. 8§ 19 e)/xontes pro/bata o(/son qu/mata (sc. ei)=nai): so ib. 7. 3 § 20 e)/xwn...o(/son e)fo/dion.

a)/gos was used by Soph. in his lost Phaedra to denote a(/gnisma qusi/as (Hesych. 1. 63), i.e. ‘an expiatory sacrifice’ (cp. Aesch. Eum. 325 a(/gnisma fo/nou). In Aesch. Cho. 154 also a)/gos has been taken as=‘expiation,’ but there it seems rather to be ‘pollution.’ Cp. the schol. here: e)/qos palaio/n, w(/ste to\n boulo/menon kaqeirgnu/nai tina\ a)fosiou=sqai braxu\ tiqe/nta trofh=s, kai\ u(peno/oun ka/qarsin to\ toiou=to, i(/na mh\ dokw=si limw=| a)nairei=n: tou=to ga\r a)sebe/s.—Curtius, Etym. 5th ed., § 118, would write a(/gos here. He distinguishes two roots. (1) a)g-, a)/gos, ‘guilt,’ e)nagh/s, ‘accursed’; Sanskr. Aa/g-as, ‘vexation,’ etc. (2) a(g-, a(/gos, ‘consecration, sacrifice,’ a(/gios, etc.: Sanskr. jag-. On the other hand the analogy of piaculum suggests that a)/gos might combine the sense of ‘expiation’ with that of ‘pollution.’

Creon's edict had announced that the transgressor would be publicly stoned to death (36). It is to this that the anxious question of the Chorus alludes (772). Creon had already said that Antigone's doom was to be ka/kistos (489). But now, at least, he feels that he cannot inflict such a death on the maiden, his kinswoman. She shall die, not by stoning, but by starvation. The choice is not prompted by cruelty, but simply by the desire to avoid physical violence.

The danger of a mi/asma—to be avoided by a dole of food—has no relation to the special circumstances,—Antigone's royal birth, and the nature of her offence. In the ancient belief, that danger existed whenever a person was put to death by starvation. Two notions were probably blended; (a) that, if a little food was given, the death was nature's work, not man's; (b) that the ne/rteroi claimed an indemnity for the usual e)nagi/smata. So the Greeks put Philoctetes ashore on desolate Lemnos, —r(a/kh proqe/ntes baia\ kai/ ti kai\ bora=s | e)pwfe/lhma smikro/n ( Ph. 274). So, too, when a Vestal was to be buried alive, the small vault in the Campus Sceleratus was furnished with a couch, a burning lamp, and a small table, on which the dole was placed,—bread, olives, milk, and a jug of water ( Plut. Num. 10).
pa=s': cp. on 178. The sense is, ‘in order that the whole city may not be defiled’ (as it otherwise would be): mi/asm' u(pekfu/gh| = mh\ mianqh=|.
o(\n mo/non se/bei. Polyneices had come to destroy the shrines of the qeoi\
e)ggenei=s (199). By honouring him, and Hades (519), she has dishonoured those other gods.

to\ mh\ qanei=n in acc. with teu/cetai: cp. Aesch. Ch. 711tugxa/nein ta\ pro/sfora: O. C. 1106 (n.): fr. 824 kai\ ta\ kai\ ta\ tugxa/nwn. This comparatively rare constr. has here been influenced by ai)toume/nh: though it is unnecessary to refer the acc. to the partic. only, or to understand, ‘will successfully ask.’ See, however, Her. 5.23 th\n para\ *darei/ou ai)th/sas e)/tuxe...dwreh/n: 9. 109 pa/nta ga\r teu/cesqai ai)th/sasan: where, in both instances, the acc. depends on the partic. only.—We could not well take to\ mh\ qanei=n here as=w(/ste mh\ qanei=n (like kwlu/w to\ mh\ poiei=n ti).
a)lla\ thnikau=ta: cp. 552.— ta)n, instead of tou\s e)n, *(/aidou: 659.

div2.p: Third stasimon. Strophe 781—790=antistr. 791—800.

After Creon's and Haemon's speeches, the comment of the Chorus was in a neutral tone (724). When Haemon departed in anger, they spoke words implying that allowance must be made for the heat of youth (767). This beautiful ode is in a kindred strain. If Haemon has sinned against great qesmoi/—loyalty to country and to father—at least he is under the influence of a god whom none can withstand.

The pathos of the maiden's fate is heightened by this plea for her lover. When she is led in by the guards, on her way to death, the Chorus avow that pity works with them even as love with Haemon (801—805). A perfect preparation is thus made for the lyric dialogue between the Chorus and Antigone (806—882).

div3.p: a)ni/kate ma/xan: Tr. 441 *)/erwti me/n nun o(/stis a)ntani/statai, | pu/kths o(/pws e)s xei=ras, ou) kalw=s fronei=. Eur. fr. 433 *)/erwta, pa/ntwn dusmaxw/taton qeo/n. Plat. Symp. 196D kai\ mh\n ei)/s ge a)ndri/an *)/erwti ou)de\ *)/arhs a)nqi/statai: ou) ga\r e)/xei *)/erwta *)/arhs, a)ll' *)/erws *)/arh.

e)n kth/masi pi/pteis, who fallest upon men's possessions; who makest havoc of their wealth and fortunes. Cp. Od. 24.526 e)n d' e)/peson proma/xois, ‘they fell on the fore-fighters’: so e)mpi/ptein is oft. said of the attacks of disease or passion. Love makes men reckless of possessions: it can bring ruin on great houses and proud cities. Sophocles himself has given us the best commentary: see Tr. 431, referring to the capture of Oechalia by Heracles, who loved Iolè, the daughter of its king, Eurytus: w(s tau/ths po/qw| | po/lis damei/h pa=sa, kou)x h( *ludi/a | pe/rseien au)th/n, a)ll' o( th=sd' e)/rws fanei/s. The same thought is finely expressed by Eur. , in a choral ode to *)/erws, which this passage has certainly helped to inspire ( Eur. Hipp. 525 ff.): *)/erwta de/, to\n tu/rannon a)ndrw=n, | ...ou) sebi/zomen, | pe/rqonta kai\ dia\ pa/sas | i)o/nta sumfora=s | qnatoi=s, o(/tan e)/lqh|. Troy was sacked for the sake of Helen,—e(le/naus, e(/landros, e(le/ptolis. Medea betrayed her father's treasure to Jason (cp. Eur. Med. 480). The resistless power of Love is the central thought of this ode. All that men prize most becomes his prey.—See Appendix.

e)n malakai=s pareiai=s. Ionof Chios (ap. Athen. 603 E) describes Soph. as saying, w(s kalw=s *fru/nixos (the tragic poet, flor. c. 490) e)poi/hsen ei)/pas: la/mpei d' e)pi\ porfure/ais parh=|si fw=s e)/rwtos. Plut. Mor. 760D sko/pei toi/nun...toi=s a)rhi/+ois e)/rgois o(/son *)/erws peri/estin, ou)k a)rgo\s w)/n, w(s *eu)ripi/dhs e)/legen, ou)de\ a)stra/teutos, ou)d' e)n malakai=sin [e)nnuxeu/]wn pareiai=s neani/dwn.

e)nnuxeu/eis, keepest thy vigil: perh. here an image suggested by a soldier's night-watch (like Horace's pulcris excubat in genis, sc. Cupido, C. 4. 13. 8); cp. Xen. Anab. 6.4.27 e)n de\ toi=s o(/plois e)nukte/reuon, and so nuktofulakei=n. Shaksp. Rom. 5. 3. 94 ‘beauty's ensign yet Is crimson in thy lips and in thy cheeks.’ Gray, Progress of Poesy 1. 3. 16 ‘O'er her warm cheek and rising bosom move The bloom of young desire and purple light of love.’

u(perpo/ntios: cp. 1301: so e)kto/pios (O.T. 1340), qala/ssios (ib. 1411), qurai=os (El. 313), para/ktios (Eur. I. T. 1424), etc. So Eur. fr. 434 (*)/erws) ka)pi\ po/nton e)/rxetai. Plut. Mor. 760D quotes an unknown poet, on *)/erws:—pu=r kai\ qa/lassan kai\ pnoa\s ta\s ai)qe/ros | pera=n e(/toimos. Lucr. 1. 18(Venus moves) per maria ac montes fluviosque rapaces Frondiferasque domos avium camposque virentes.

e)/n t' a)gr. au)lai=s. a)gro/nomoi au)lai/ =dwellings in a)gro\s nemo/menos, pastoral wilds: cp. 349 a)grau/lou: O. T. 1103 pla/kes a)gro/nomoi, upland pastures. El. 181 a)kth\ bou/nomos, a shore on which oxen are pastured (cp. O. T. 26).—Some take the sense to be, ‘Love conquers not man only, but fishes and wild beasts’; cp. fr. 856.9 (*ku/pris) ei)se/rxetai me\n i)xqu/wn plwtw=| ge/nei, | e)/nesti d' e)n xe/rsou tetraskelei= gonh=|. (How could u(perpo/ntios imply a visit to the fish?) Others find a reference to Paris carrying Helen over the Aegean, Aphrodite visiting Anchises in the pastures of Ida, etc. Rather the poet is merely saying, quite generally, how boundless is the range of Love.

ou)/t' a)qana/twn: Tr. 443 (of Love) ou(=tos ga\r a)/rxei kai\ qew=n o(/pws qe/lei: fr. 856. 13 (*ku/pris) ti/n' ou) palai/ous' e)s tri\s e)kba/llei qew=n; Eur. fr. 434 *)/erws ga\r a)/ndras ou) mo/nous e)pe/rxetai, | ou)d' au)= gunai=kas, a)lla\ kai\ qew=n a)/nw | yuxa\s xara/ssei.

se\ … fu/cimo/s e)sti, = se\ du/natai feu/gein. Cp. Aesch. PV 904 o( po/lemos a)/pora po/rimos: Ag. 1090(ste/ghn) polla\ cuni/stora | ...kaka/: Xen. Cyr. 3.3.9 e)pisth/mones d' h)=san ta\ prosh/konta: Isae. or. 5 § 26 e)/carnoi/ ei)si ta\ w(mologhme/na: [Plat. ] Alcib. II. 141 D oi)=mai de/ se ou)k a)nh/koon ei)=nai e)/nia/ ge...gegenhme/na. Similarly with a subst., Plat. Apol. 18B ta\ mete/wra frontisth/s.

se/ g': for ge with the repeated se, cp. O. T. 1101, Ph. 1116.—The MS. e)p' could mean only, ‘in the case of’ (and so, ‘among’): a use which is not adequately supported by Aristeid. Pan. 1. 96 mo/nh| th=| po/lei e)pi\ tw=n *(ellhnikw=n, where he means, ‘in the case of’ (i.e., ‘so far as they are concerned’). Nor could e)p' be an adverb (‘moreover,’ O. T. 181), as some take it.
o( d' e)/xwn: Phaear. 239 C a)nh\r e)/xwn e)/rwta.

a)di/kous proleptic: cp. on 475: Tr. 106 eu)na/zein a)dakru/twn blefa/rwn po/qon (so that they shall not weep).— paraspa=|s (cp. 298), a metaphor from a driver jerking his horses aside out of their course: El. 732 (the charioteer) e)/cw paraspa=| (sc. tou\s i(/ppous), pulls them aside, out of the crowd of chariots. The word is fig. again in O. C. 1185 ou) ga/r se... paraspa/sei | gnw/mhs, pluck thee from thy resolve.
cu/naimon, not cunai/mwn, since nei=kos-a)ndrw=n forms one notion: cp. 862: El. 1390 tou)mo\n frenw=n o)/neiron: Ph. 952sxh=ma pe/tras di/pulon: Aesch. Eum. 325 matrw=|on a(/gnisma...fo/nou.
e)/xeis with aor. part.: cp. 22.
tara/cas, excitasti. Dem. or. 18 § 153 i(/n' ei)dh=te h(li/ka pra/gmata h( miara\ kefalh\ tara/casa au(/th di/khn ou)k e)/dwken. In this sense later prose has also suntara/ttw.

e)nargh/s, ‘clearly seen,’ ‘present to the lover's sight,’ marks the vivid appeal to the senses, in contrast with the invisible and spiritual majesty of the qesmoi/ which Love overrides. For e)nargh/s as =‘before our eyes,’ ‘in bodily presence,’ cp. O. C. 910; Tr. 11, 224.

blefa/rwni(/meros, love-influence from the eyes, eu)le/ktrou nu/mfas, of the fair bride. Both genitives are possessive, but blefa/rwn goes more closely with i(/meros, denoting the latter's source. Cp. 929: O. C. 729 o)mma/twn... | fo/bon...th=s e)mh=s e)peiso/dou, fear, shown in your eyes (possess. gen.), of my entrance (objective gen.). In Phaedr. 251 B Plato describes i(/meros as the desire infused into the soul by an emanation of beauty (ka/llous a)porroh/) proceeding from the beloved, and received through the eyes of the lover (dia\ tw=n o)mma/twn). So the soul is spoken of (ib. E) as e)poxeteusame/nh i(/meron, ‘having refreshed herself with the love-shower’ or ‘effluence of beauty.’ And i(/meros itself receives fanciful derivations, as ib. 251 C, e)kei=qen me/rh e)pio/nta kai\ r(e/onta, a(\ dh\ dia\ tau=ta i(/meros kalei=tai (i.e. from i)e/nai me/rh and r(ei=n): while in Crat. 419E it is explained by i(e/menos r(ei=. The real origin of the word is prob. from rt. i)s, ‘wish,’ whence i)o/thti, and *)is-mh/nh, Desiderata. Curt. § 617. So Soph. fr. 161 o)mma/twn a)/po | lo/gxas i(/hsin: 733 o)mma/teios po/qos: 430 (Hippodameia speaking of Pelops), toia/nd' e)n o)/yei li/gga qhrathri/an | e)/rwtos, a)straph/n tin' o)mma/twn, e)/xei (‘such a subduing arrow of love, a lightning from the eyes’): Aesch. Ag. 742 malqako\n o)mma/twn be/los, | dhci/qumon e)/rwtos a)/nqos: Suppl. 1004 o)/mmatos qelkth/rion | to/ceum' e)/pemyen, i(me/rou nikw/menos: Eur. Hipp. 525 *)/erws, *)/erws o(\ kat' o)mma/twn | sta/zeis po/qon, ei)sa/gwn glukei=an | yuxai=s xa/rin ou(\s e)pistrateu/sh| [i.e. ‘on the eyes’ of mortals: better o(...sta/zwn, or else o(\s a)p'—.]
eu)le/ktrou, epithet of *ku/pris in Tr. 515. Cp. Anthol. P. 7. 649 eu)legxe/os qala/mou (happy nuptials).

pa/redros e)n a)rxai=s. I leave these words in the text, without marking them as corrupt, because the case against them is not decisive, while no emendation is certain. But I strongly suspect them. If sound, they mean that the love inspired by the maiden's eyes is a power ‘enthroned in sway by the side of the great laws.’ The great laws are those ‘unwritten’ moral laws which most men feel and acknowledge (cp. on 454 f.); here, especially, the law of loyalty to country, the law of obedience to parents. In Haemon's case, love has shown that it is at least of equal force with these qesmoi/. For pa/redros, cp. O. C. 1267 *zhni\ su/nqakos qro/nwn | *ai)dw/s: ib. 1382 *di/kh cu/nedros *zhno\s a)rxai/ois no/mois. Pind. O. 8. 21*dio\s ceni/ou pa/redros | ...*qe/mis. For e)n a)rxai=s, Eur. Andr. 699 semnoi\ d' e)n a)rxai=s h(/menoi kata\ pto/lin: Or. 897o(\s a)\n du/nhtai po/leos e)/n t' a)rxai=sin h)=|. Cp. also on 744.

The words answer metrically to fu/cimos ou)dei/s (788). The first two syllables of pa/redros therefore represent a resolved long syllable. Pindar affords some instances of such resolution (see Appendix), and there is a probable example below (970 a)gxi/polis *)/arhs, where see n.). But it is rare, and certainly unpleasing. As

a whole, too, the phrase pa/redros e)n a)rxai=s is suspicious. A yet stronger objection is the strangeness of describing the power which is in conflict with the qesmoi/ as their assessor, or peer, in sway; an expression which would seem appropriate only if that power was working in harmony with them; as when Eur. ( Eur. Med. 843) speaks of sofi/a| pare/drous...e)/rwtas, | pantoi/as a)reta=s cunergou/s,—‘the loves that sit with wisdom, co-workers of all excellence,’—those aspirations of the soul which assist intellectual effort.

The best line of emendation yet suggested is that of Semitelos, who writes w(/ste pe/ra dra=n. He supposes that pe/ra dra=n became, first, pa/redron (*p*e*r*a*d*r*a*n— *p*a*r*e*d*r*o*n). Then, pa/redron qesmw=n seeming obscure, a marginal gloss e)n a)rxai=s was added. This gloss came into the text, dislodging w(/ste: and pa/redron became pa/redros, to agree with i(/meros. The original sense, then, was: ‘the i(/meros prevails, so that one transgresses the great qesmoi/.’ Cp. El. 1506 o(/stis pe/ra pra/ssein ge tw=n no/mwn qe/lei. This suits, too, the following lines, where the Chorus says, kau)to\s (i.e., like Haemon) qesmw=n | e)/cw fe/romai.—See Appendix.

e)mpai/zei, ‘wreaks her will’ in that contest which nika=| implies. We find e)mpai/zw with a dat. (1) of the object, as Her. 4.134 e)mpai/zontas h(mi=n, ‘mocking us’: (2) of the sphere, as Ar. Th. 975 xoroi=sin e)mpai/zei, ‘sports in dances.’ The e)n of e)mpai/zei here might also be explained as (a) in the i)/meros, or the ble/fara, i.e. by their agency: or (b) ‘on her victim.’ But the interpretation first given appears simpler. (Cp. Vergil's absol. use of illudere, G. 1. 181, Tum variae illudant pestes.)
kau)to\s qesmw=n e)/cw: i.e. like Haemon, I also am moved to rebel against Creon's sentence, and to take Antigone's part.

fe/romai, a proverbial image from the race-course: Aristoph. Ran. 993 mo/non o(/pws | mh/ s' o( qumo\s a(rpa/sas | e)kto\s oi)/sei tw=n e)law=n, because some olives marked the limits of the course at the end of the race-course (schol. ad loc.), where the chariots turned, and where the horses were most likely to swerve or bolt. Plat. Crat. 414B ou) ga\r e)piskopei=s me w(/sper e)kto\s dro/mou fero/menon, e)peida\n lei/ou e)pila/bwmai (when I get on smooth ground). Aesch. PV 883 e)/cw de\ dro/mou fe/romai lu/sshs | pneu/mati ma/rgw|. Eur. Bacch. 853 e)/cw d' e)lau/nwn tou= fronei=n.
i)/sxein d': cp. 817 e)/xous': 820 laxou=s', by the rule of continuity (suna/feia) in anapaestic systems. In lyrics such elision is rarer (see on 350).

phga/s, not, the sources or springs, but the streams, of tears: so Tr. 852 e)/rrwgen paga\ dakru/wn, and oft.: cp. O. C. 479, where phga/s=the water gushing from the bowl. On the other hand in fr. 658 nukto/s...phga/s=‘the sources of night’ (the west).

pagkoi/thn. The question between Doric and Attic forms in tragic anapaests cannot be decided by a rigid rule. It depends on the presence or absence of a lyric character. Thus in 110 f. the Doricisms are justified by the purely lyric stamp of the anapaests. Here, Attic forms are preferable. The lyric strains

of Antigone are brought into finer relief by the different tone of the choral anapaests. Cp. 822, and see Appendix on 110.—Cp. O. C. 1578 (Death) to
 ai)e/nupnon. The word qa/lamon here has ref. to its special sense, ‘bridal-chamber’: cp. 891 numfei=on, 1207 pasta/da. So oft. in epitaphs on the unmarried; Anthol. P. 7. 489 (by Sappho) *tima/dos a(/de ko/nis, ta
 dh\ pro\ ga/moio qanou=san | de/cato *persefo/nas kua/neos qa/lamos. Kaibel Epigrammata 241 (on two young brothers) oi( dissoi\ suno/maimoi, i)w\ ce/ne, tw=|d' u(po\ tu/mbw| | a)/yaustoi te/knwn kei/meqa kouridi/wn: | *(ike/sios ka)gw\ neara
 plhrou/menos h(/ban | *(/ermippos kruero
 to/nd' e)/xomen qa/lamon.
a)nu/tousan with acc. of place, as Ai. 607 (a)nu/sein), O. C. 1562 (e)canu/sai): cp. 231.

div2.p: Fourth e)peiso/dion. Antigone has now been brought out of the house by two of Creon's servants (oi( a)/gontes, 931) who are about to conduct her to her doom. She speaks of her fate to the Chorus, and they seek to comfort her,—while they intimate that she alone is to blame (853, 875). Creon enters (883); and, in obedience to his peremptory command, Antigone is presently led forth to death (943).

The structure of the kommo/s (806—882) is as follows. 1st strophe (806—816)=1st ant. (823—833). A system of choral anapaests (817—822) comes after the strophe, and a similar system (834—838) after the antistrophe.—2nd strophe (839—852) = 2nd ant. (857—871).—3rd str. (853—856) =3rd ant. (872—875).—An epode forms the close (876—882). See Metrical Analysis.

div3.p: nea/tan … ne/aton de/. In such an epanaphora me/n regularly precedes de/ (as O. T. 25, 259; O. C. 5, 610, etc.); but there are numerous exceptions in Soph. , as O. C. 1342 sth/sw s' a)/gwn, | sth/sw d' e)mauto/n: Ph. 633pa/nta lekta/, pa/nta de\ | tolmhta/: Tr. 517 to/t' h)=n xero/s, h)=n de\ to/cwn pa/tagos: ib. 1147 ka/lei to\ pa=n moi spe/rma sw=n o(maimo/nwn, | ka/lei de\ th\n ta/lainan *)alkmh/nhn.
ne/aton, in contrast with au)=qis, is best taken as adv.: Eur. Tro. 201 ne/aton teke/wn sw/mata leu/ssw: cp. the adv. teleutai=on (O. T. 1183), e)/sxaton (O. C. 1550), panu/staton, etc.

kou)/pot' au)=qis, sc. o)yome/nhn: Ai. 857 *(/hlion prosenne/pw | panu/staton dh\ kou)/pot' au)=qis u(/steron.—Cp. the passage in Swinburne's Erechtheus where the maiden Chthonia, being about to die, speaks with the Chorus of Athenian Elders:—‘People, old men of my city, lordly wise and hoar of head, | I, a spouseless bride and crownless, but with garlands of the dead, | From the fruitful light turn silent to my dark unchilded bed.’

pagkoi/tas = o( pa/ntas koimi/zwn. Ai. 831 kalw= q' a(/ma | pompai=on *(ermh=n xqo/nion eu)= me koimi/sai. Blaydes conjectures pa/gkoinos, very plausibly. Cp. El. 138 to/n g' e)c *)ai/+da | pagkoi/nou li/mnas. But these points may be noted. (1) Though we have had pagkoi/thn so lately as in v. 804, such a repetition is no safe argument for spuriousness: see on 76. (2) The 2nd and 3rd syllables of pagkoi/tas = kai/ nin in 828, and pa/gkoinos therefore gives a more exact correspondence; but this proves nothing, since a spondee and a trochee are equally admissible. (See Analysis. Metr.) (3) pagkoi/tas is here a more expressive epithet than pa/gkoinos (‘receiving all’): eyes still bright with life and youth are to suffer the a)te/rmona nh/greton u(/pnon.

a)/gei … a)kta/n, a rare poet. constr. with a)/gw, as Ph. 1175*trw|a/da ga=n m' h)/lpisas a)/cein: Aesch. Pers. 861 no/stoi... | eu)= pra/ssontas a)=gon oi)/kous (so Porson for e)s oi)/kous). Cp. O. T. 178 a)kta\n pro\s e(spe/rou qeou=.

ou)/q' u(menai/wn … ou)/t' e)pinu/mfeios … u(/mnos. The u(me/naios has not been sung by friends escorting bride and bridegroom to their home; nor has the e)piqala/mion been sung in the evening at the door of the bridal chamber. (1) For the procession-song, cp. Il. 18.492 nu/mfas d' e)k qala/mwn, dai/+dwn u(/po lampomena/wn, | h)gi/neon a)na\ a)/stu: polu\s d' u(me/naios o)rw/rei. Aristoph. Pax 1332 ff. gives a specimen, with the refrain *(umh/n, *(ume/nai' w)=. Cp. also Av. 1736.This was specially called the a(rma/teion me/los (from the carriage conveying the newly-married couple), Etym. M. p. 145. (2) As to the e)piqala/mios (u(/mnos), or e)piqala/mion (me/los), sung in the evening, see Phot. Bibl.p. 321 kai\ ta\ e)piqala/mia de\ toi=s a)/rti qalameuome/nois a(/ma oi( h)i/+qeoi kai\ ai( parqe/noi e)pi\ tw=n qala/mwn h)=|don. Extant specimens are Theocritus Idyll. 18 (for Helen and Menelaus), Catullus 61 and 62: for a burlesque, see Lucian Symp. 41.The word u(me/naios, though more specially denoting the procession-song, was a general term for a gamh/lion a)=|sma, and could denote the e)piqala/mios, in which *(umh\n w)= *(ume/naie was the usual refrain (Theocr. 18. 58, Catull. 61. 4 etc.): so Pindar P. 3. 17
ou)de\ pamfw/nwn i)axa\n u(menai/wn, a(/likes
oi(=a parqe/noi file/oisin e(tai=rai
e(speri/ais u(pokouri/zesq' a)oidai=s: Apollon. Rhod. 4. 1160 numfidi/ais u(me/naion e)pi\ promolh=|sin (threshold) a)/eidon.

ou)/te … e)/gklhron, … ou)/te … u(/mnhsen: we expected ou)/te u(mnhqei=san: a finite verb is substituted for the second participial clause: cp. 255 f.: O.C. 348 polla\ me\n...a)lwme/nh, | polloi=si d' h(gei=tai, with n. there on 351.

e)pinu/mfeios, Dindorf's correction of e)pinumfi/dios, is strongly supported by these facts. (1) In O. C. 1088 Soph. certainly used e)pinikei/w| instead of the usual e)piniki/w|. Cp. above, Soph. 358, e)nai/qreia. (2) In Aesch. Cho. 334 e)pitu/mbios (restored with certainty by Herm. ) had been corrupted into e)pitumbi/dios. Bergk's e)pi\ numfei/ois (‘for crown of nuptials’) is quite possible (cp. n. on 568); but an epithet for u(/mnos is decidedly preferable here. Bergk relies on the schol., lei/pei qu/rais h)\ koi/tais, which suggests that the Schol. read e)pi\ numfidi/ois (or numfei/ois); but, if this were so, the fact would have little weight. The corruption would have been easy.— SchHerm. ütz defends e)pinumfi/dios as metrically possible. But, though it is possible that a logaoedic dactyl might replace a spondee here, the latter is at least better suited to the grave and mournful rhythm. The antistrophic verse (831) ends with pagklau/tois. So v. 816 ends with numfeu/sw, and 833 with kateuna/zei.
*)axe/ronti numfeu/sw: cp. on 654.

cife/wn (possessive gen.) e)pi/xeira, ‘the wages of swords,’ i.e. the reward of strife with the sword,—viz. a violent death. The gen. after e)pi/xeira always denotes that for which the reward is given, as Aesch. PV 318 u(yhgo/rou | glw/sshs, Aristoph. Vesp. 581 tau/ths (sc. th=s di/khs), Plat. Rep. 608C a)reth=s, [Dem. ] Epist. p. 1484. 4 tw=n...peponhme/nwn. Here, cife/wn can hardly be a subjective gen., ‘the reward which the sword gives’; though the meaning is the same. The ironical sense of e)pi/xeira occurs in Attic prose as well as verse; Antiphon or. 1 § 20 h( me\n diakonh/sasa (in the murder) e)/xei ta\ e)pi/xeira w)=n a)ci/a h)=n (torture and death). Cp. El. 1382 ta)piti/mia | th=s dussebei/as. cife/wn might be poet. plur. for sing., as in Eur. Andr. 812 e)/k te decia=s | ci/fh kaqarpa/zousin, and Or. 1398(cp. skh=ptra, etc.); but it is rather an ordinary plural.

au)to/nomos, i.e. of your own free will. No one constrained her to do the act for which she suffers. She knew that death would be the consequence, and she chose it. The word is fitting, since she has set her laws (the qew=n no/mima) above Creon's. The implied contrast is with the helpless victims of disease or of war.—The word could not mean, ‘by an ordinance peculiar to your case,’ i.e. ‘by the unique doom of a living death.’
dh/ strengthens mo/nh, as Tr. 1063.— *)ai/+dhn seems preferable to *(/aidhn in the paroemiac. Cp. on 804.— Acc. of motion, like do/mous stei/xein (O. C. 643).

h)/kousa dh/.
