The Chorus has said, ‘No mortal's fate was ever like thine.’ She continues: ‘I have heard before now (dh/) how Niobe perished,—by a doom like mine.’ To which the Chorus reply that Niobe was not a mere mortal (834).—The Theban princess remembers the fate of the Theban queen. Niobe, daughter of Tantalus, married Amphion, king of Thebes. She vaunted that she had borne many children, while Leto had borne only two. Wherefore those two, Apollo and Artemis, slew all her sons and daughters,—at Thebes, as said the Theban story; but Niobe returned to her old home at Mount Sipylus, and was there turned to stone. (Ovid, Met. 6. 310, represents her as carried to Sipylus after the change.) *nio/bh was the title of lost plays by Aesch. and
lugrota/tan, adverbial: cp. 305 (o(/rkios): Ai. 966 e)moi\ pikro\s te/qnhken.

ce/nan, in relation to Thebes; the foreign wife of the Theban king. Pindar wrote a paia/n on Niobe's marriage, and said that the Lydian a(rmoni/a was first used at Thebes on that occasion. ( de Mus. 15.)

*tanta/lou, gen. of parentage: cp. 486, Ai. 172 *dio\s *)/artemis: 952 *zhno\s h( deinh\ qeo/s. Tantalus, son of Zeus, had his royal seat on Mount Sipylus, which belonged to Phrygia in the older and larger sense of that term. In Aesch. *nio/bh (fr. 153) he describes his realm as extending ‘twelve days journey’ from Sipylus westward to Ida.

*sipu/lw|. Mount Sipylus is in the country once called Maeonia, and afterwards Lydia. It is a branch of the Tmolus range (N. of which stood Sardis), and extends in a N.W. direction to the Hermus. Magnesia ‘ad Sipylum’ was on that river's left bank. From a remote age volcanic forces were active in this region, known to the Greeks as the katakekaume/nh. Cp. Arist. Meteor. 2.8 genome/nou seismou= ta\ peri\ *si/pulon a)netra/ph. A city called Tantalis, once situated at Sipylus, was said to have perished by an earthquake, which made a lake. Tantalus, like Niobe, is a type of prosperity plunged by u(/bris into misery. Here, as in the case of Sodom and Gomorrah, some physical catastrophe was at the root of the tradition.—See on 831.
a)tenh/s, prop. ‘strained,’ ‘intent’ (e.g. a)tenh\s o)/yis), or ‘intense’ (as a)tenei=s o)rgai/): here it denotes the close embrace of the ivy. Cp. hederae sequaces (Persius prol.).

petrai/a bla/sta da/masen, the ‘growth of stone’ (the process of petrifaction) ‘subdued her,’ i.e. passed gradually over her whole form: cp. Ovid, Met. 6. 301: Orba resedit | Exanimes inter natos, natasque, virumque, | Diriguitque malis. Nullos movet aura capillos. | In vultu color est sine sanguine: lumina maestis | Stant immota genis: nihil est in imagine vivi. | Ipsa quoque interius cum duro lingua palato | Congelat, et venae desistunt posse moveri. | Nec flecti cervix, nec bracchia reddere gestus, | Nec pes ire potest: intra quoque viscera saxumst. For ai^ in petrai/a, cp. 1310 n.

kai/ nin o)/mrroi, k.t.l. The poet is thinking of Niobe's petrified form among the lonely mountain-crags (Il. 24.614 nu=n de/ pou e)n pe/trh|sin, e)n ou)/resin oi)opo/loisin, | e)n *sipu/lw|). ‘The rain and the snow never leave her, as she pines with grief’: i.e. she is amid the storms that visit snow-crowned Sipylus throughout the year. By these words the poet wishes to call up a general image of bleak and stormbeaten solitude. Niobe's own weeping is then described by te/ggei d', etc. Now, if we kept the MS. o)/mbrw|, that dat. would go closely with takome/nan: ‘as she melts, flows down, with rain’ (or ‘with water’), ‘the snow never leaves her.’ Thus te/ggei … deira/das would be anticipated, and in a prosaic manner; viz., by words suggesting that the appearance of weeping is due to water trickling down the rock. This is the true reason for preferring o)/mbroi to o)/mbrw|. It is no argument against o)/mbrw| that xiw/n t' would answer to te/ggei q' (for te irregularly placed, cp. O.T. 258 n.). With o)/mbroi, q' could still follow te/ggei, but d' is better.—For the constr. o)/mbroi...xiw/n t' ou) lei/pei (verb agreeing in number with nearest subject) cp. 1132 f.: O.C. 7 ste/rgein ga\r ai( pa/qai me xw( xro/nos cunw\n | makro\s dida/skei (n.).

xiw/n is taken by Wecklein as=‘snowwater’ (Eiswasser). The only passage which seems to favour that sense is Eur. Tro. 1066 *)idai=a...na/ph | xio/ni kata/ruta potami/a|, but there the adj. makes the difference: ‘snow carried down streams’ can be only ‘snow-water.’ In Andr. 215*qrh/|khn xio/ni th\n kata/rruton means merely, ‘on which snow falls thickly.’ Cp. Quintus Smyrnaeus 1. 293 u(pai\ *sipu/lw| nifo/enti.
ou)dama/: cp. 763.

te/ggei d' u(p' o)fru/si … deira/das. Though o)fru/s and deira/s could be said of a mountain, Soph. is here thinking simply of the human form. pagklau/tous (L) might be proleptic (cp. n. on a)di/kous, Soph. 791), but pagklau/tois is better, since o)fru/si seems to need an epithet.

The Niobe of Sipylus has usually been identified with a colossal rock-image on the N. side of the range. It is rudely carved in relief, within a rectangular niche on the face of a limestone cliff, and represents a woman seated on a throne. (See Stark, Niobe, pl. 1, Leips. 1863: cp. Baumeister, Denkm. p. 1029). Prof. W. M. Ramsay, however, holds that this image is the ‘very ancient’ a)/galma of Cybele mentioned by Paus. 3.22.4. In two respects it differs from the ancient accounts of the Niobe (quoted below): (a) it does not ‘weep,’—for the rainwater drops from the front of the niche, clear of the figure; and (b) the likeness to a human form grows, instead of vanishing, as one approaches. (Journ. Hellen. Studies III. 61 ff., 1882.) This has been confirmed by another traveller, Herr Schweisthal (as reported in the Berl. Phil. Wochenschr., May 28, 1887, p. 704). He finds the true Niobe at no great distance from the Cybele, but nearer Magnesia, and in the vicinity of a stream (the Jarikkaia) which Humann, in his ‘Excursion into Sipylus’ (1881), had already identified with the Achelous of Il. 24.616. It is a natural phenomenon,—the semblance—as seen from a distance—of a draped woman, seated high on the rocks; she looks towards the right, and lifts her right arm, as if in lament.

The best ancient description is by a poet whose native place was in that neighbourhood,—Quintus Smyrnaeus (1. 293— 306):—‘Her streaming tears still fall from the heights of the rugged cliff; and in sympathy with her the sounding waters of the Hermus make lament, and the lofty peaks of Sipylus, over which the mist that shepherds dread floats evermore. A great marvel is she to passers by, because she is like a sorrowful woman, who mourns some cruel grief, and weeps without stint. Such verily seems the figure, when thou gazest at it from afar; but when thou drawest near, lo, 'tis but a sheer rock, a cliff of Sipylus’ (fai/netai ai)ph/essa pe/trh, *sipu/loio/ t' a)porrw/c).

Nonnus was thinking of the effect from the road, when he wrote (2. 160), e(/ssomai w(s *nio/bh kai\ e)gw\ li/qos, o)/fra kai\ au)th\n | lai+ne/hn stena/xousan e)poiktei/rwsin o(di=tai. Pausanias, too, says that, at a certain distance from the cliff, dedakrume/nhn do/ceis o(ra=n kai\ kathfh= gunai=ka, but that the illusion vanishes on a nearer approach (1. 21 § 3).

o(moiota/tan, because the stone into which Niobe was changed may be likened to Antigone's rocky tomb: cp. El. 150 i)w\ pantla/mwn *nio/ba, se\ d' e)/gwge ne/mw qeo/n, | a(/t' e)n ta/fw| petrai/w| | ai)ai= dakru/eis.—The Niobe in the Uffizi Gallery at Florence will occur to many as offering an ideal type of majestic sorrow and beauty not unworthy to be associated with Antigone, and yet suggesting a contrast no less than a resemblance; the contrast between the desolate mother, and the maiden who is going to join those whom she loves (897); between pride steadfast under divine anger, and the piety that has dared to offend man.

a)lla\ … qanou=san. The Chorus desire to console Antigone. There is no element of reproof in their words here. She has likened herself to Niobe. ‘And yet Niobe’—the Chorus say—‘was a goddess, while thou art a mortal. But (kai/toi) it will be a great glory for thy memory that thy fate was as the fate of a goddess, in life and in death.’ ‘In life’ (zw=san), and not only in death (qanou=san), because Niobe, like Antigone, was in the fulness of her vitality when she met her doom. The moments of life through which Antigone is now passing are like the moments through which Niobe passed as she felt the beginning of the change into stone.—Why does Antigone rejoin, oi)/moi gelw=mai? Because her thought had been, ‘my doom is terrible and miserable as Niobe's’; but the Chorus had answered, ‘It is indeed glorious for thee to be as Niobe.’ She had looked for present pity. They had comforted her with the hope of posthumous fame. —See Appendix.

qeo/s, sc. e)kei/nh me/n e)sti (cp. 948). The absence of a pron., to balance h(mei=s, is unusual, but it is easy to carry on the subject of te/ggei in 831. Niobe is of divine race, since her father was the son of Zeus, and her mother the Pleiad Taygetè (or Dionè, one of the Hyades). So in Aesch. *nio/bh (fr. 157) her family is described as oi( qew=n a)gxi/sporoi (near kin), ...kou)/pw nin e)ci/thlon ai(=ma daimo/nwn.

qeogennh/s, god-begotten. The peculiarity is that the word is formed directly from ge/nna, and not from the stem of the pass. aor. in use: i.e., we should expect qeoge/nnhtos. But Pindar could coin qeo/timos (I. 5. 13) as=qeoti/mhtos. Why, then, should not a poet coin qeogennh/s as=qeoge/nnhtos? It is of little moment that the extant classical literature happens to present no strictly parallel compound with ge/nna (pontogennh/s and prwtogennh/s being late Byzantine). qeiogenh/s occurs in Orac. Sibyll. (5. 261), but is not classical. The Schol.'s paraphrase, qeiote/rou ge/nous tugxa/nousa, is no token (as some fancy) that he read a gen., such as qei/ou te ge/nous.

kai/toi has an illative force, introducing the next step in the reasoning: cp. 949, O. T. 855.—L's fqime/na should prob. be fqime/nh| (see on pagkoi/thn 804). The variant fqime/nw| (noted in L) is warrantable as the masc. of general statement (cp. 463): but it would be extremely harsh, when zw=san...qanou=san refers to the same person.

ka)kou=sai, ‘e'en to have it said of her’ (kai/ meaning, ‘even if there is no other comfort’). This seems a little more expressive than ta)kou=sai (Wecklein), and also slightly more probable palaeographically (cp. O. C. 172 cr. n.). The MS. me/g' a)kou=sai is certainly wrong, since a paroemiac could not begin a new sentence. For a)kou/w (=le/gomai, audio) with inf., cp. Her. 3.131 *)argei=oi h)/kouon mousikh\n ei)=nai *(ellh/nwn prw=toi.

toi=s i)soqe/ois su/gklhra, a lot shared by demigods. Plut. Mor. 103F xrh\ ga ou) mo/non e(auto
 ei)de/nai qnhto
 o)/nta th
 fu/sin, a)lla\ kai\ o(/ti qnhtw=| su/gklhro/s e)sti bi/w| kai\ pra/gmasi r(a|di/ws meqistame/nois pro\s tou)nanti/on: i.e. that one shares the lot of humanity at large.—The decisive objection to the MS. reading e)/gklhra is the sense of the adj.; for e)/gklhros always means either (1) act., having a share in, as Eur. I. T. 682 e)/gklhron... kasignh/thn, ‘heiress,’=e)pi/klhron, and so

Hipp. 1011: or (2) pass., included in one's klh=ros, as H. F. 468 e)/gklhra pedi/a ...kekthme/nos (‘by inheritance’). Here, e)/gklhra was perh. partly due to a reminiscence of e)/gklhron in 814.—The change of toi=s i)soqe/ois into toi=si qeoi=sin, though easy, is needless. The epic i_ of i)so/qeos might well be allowed in tragic lyrics or anapaests, like the a_ of a)qa/natos (cp. 339 n.): and Aesch. once uses it, Aesch. Pers. 80i)so/qeos fw/s. [But i)so/qeos has i^ in Eur. Tro. 1169, I. A. 626 (dial.), as i)so/neiron has in Aesch. PV 547.] Note that the MS. toi=s i)soqe/ois e)/gklhra would have arisen more easily from *t*o*i*s*i*s*o*q*e*o*i*s*s*u*g*k*l*h*r*a than from *t*o*i*s*i*q*e*o*i*s*i*n*s*u*g*k*l*h*r*a.

zw=san … qanou=san. The constr., fqime/nh| me/ga e)sti/n, a)kou=sai zw=san su/gklhra laxei=n (instead of zw/sh|), is not rare: cp. Xen. An. 1. 2§ 1 *ceni/a| tw=| *)arka/di h(/kein paragge/llei labo/nta tou\s a)/ndras [though shortly before, paragge/llei tw=| *klea/rxw| labo/nti h(/kein]: ib. 3. 1. 5 sumbouleu/ei tw=| *cenofw=nti e)lqo/nta ei)s *delfou\s a)nakoinw=sai: ib. 3. 2. 1 e)/docen au)toi=s profulaka\s katasth/santas sugkalei=n tou\s stratiw/tas. The dat. with the inf. is, in such cases, equally right, but the acc. sometimes excludes an ambiguity. (Cp. on O. T. 913.) El. 479 u(/pesti/ moi...klu/ousan is not similar.—I can see no reason to suppose the loss of a verse. The fact that six anapaestic verses (817—822) follow the strophe proves nothing. Cp. on 110 f., and Append. on 155 ff.
gelw=mai: see on 834 ff. Cp. Job xvii. 2: ‘Are there not mockers with me?’

polukth/mones, an epith. which also implies eu)genei=s: cp. O. T. 1070 plousi/w| xai/rein ge/nei. So these Theban elders are called koirani/dai (940), and in O. T. 1223 w)= gh=s me/gista th=sd' a)ei\ timw/menoi: as Thebes itself, a)glaai/ (O. T. 153) and mega/lai (ib. 1203).
krh=nai: so Polyneices appeals to Oed., pro/s nu/n se krhnw=n kai\ qew=n o(mogni/wn (O. C. 1333, where see n.): and the dying Ajax invokes the krh=nai of Troy (Ai. 862).
eu)arma/tou: see n. on 148 f.

a)/lsos: cp. El. 5 (Argos) th=s oi)stroplh=gos a)/lsos *)ina/xou ko/rhs, as the scene of Io's visitation by Hera. So Thebes is the ‘sacred precinct’ of Dionysus (cp. 154, 1137) and the other qeoi\ e)gxw/rioi.
e)/mpas, even if human sympathy fails me. Soph. has e)/mpas (=o(/mws) also in Ai. 122, 1338, and e)/mpa^ ib. 563 (dial.).
u)/mm' (Aeolic and epic), as Aesch. Eum. 620: so dat. u)/mmi O. C. 247 (n.).

e)piktw=mai, acquire, win: Aesch. Eum. 671 (o(/pws) kai\ to/nd' e)pikth/saio su/mmaxon, qea/. In this general sense the e)pi/ is not inconsistent with what e)/mpas implies, viz. that she fails to win human sympathy.
oi(/a: cp. on 823 (lugrota/tan).—
fi/lwn a)/klautos: cp. 1034: Ai. 910 a)/farktos fi/lwn, and O. C. 1722 n.

e(/rgma tumbo/xwston, an enclosure (prison) with a sepulchral xw=ma. The e(/rgma is the chamber in the rock, petrw/dhs katw=ruc (774), in which she is to be immured: the xw=ma consists of the stones heaped up at the entrance, so as to close it: cp. 1216 a(rmo\n xw/matos liqospadh=. For e(/rgma (ei(/rgw, to shut in) cp. Part. Anim. 2. 15. 1, where it is said that the eyelashes (blefari/des) protect the eyes, oi(=on ta\ xarakw/mata poiou=si/ tines pro\ tw=n e(rgma/twn, like the palings sometimes placed in front of fences (or hedges). The Berlin ed. (p. 958 b 18) there gives e)rgma/twn from the MSS. just as here L has e)/rgma, and as, conversely, MSS. of Pindar (I. 1. 27 etc.) give e(/rgma for e)/rgma = e)/rgon. The old edd. of Arist. give e)ruma/twn.—The reading e(/rma (from e)rei/dw)=‘mound’: C. I. 4599 e)risqene\s e(/rma qanou=sin: Kaibel Epigr. 1063. 4ka)gh/raon e(/rma. But this seems less fitting here than the notion of ‘prison’: cp. 886 periptu/cantes, 892 a)ei/frouros.
potaini/ou, usu., ‘recent,’ ‘fresh’: here, ‘of a new kind’: cp. fr. 154. 5 h(dona\s potaini/ous. A tomb destined for the dead is to receive the living (cp. 821).

Though every treatment of this verse must remain subject to doubt, far the most probable (to my mind) is Seyffert's modification of Boeckh's brotoi=s ou)/t' e)n nekroi=s kurou=sa. This gives an exact correspondence with 870, kasi/gnhte ga/mwn kurh/sas, and there is every reason to think that 870 is sound. Further, the origin of L's reading is elucidated. The first ou)/te is omitted (Aesch. Ag. 532 *pa/ris ga\r ou)/te suntelh\s po/lis, cp. O. T. 239); and this poetical license might easily have led a corrector to suppose that the first ou)/te had been lost. Again, the loss of kurou=sa would have been easy after nekroi=s.

me/toikos: cp. 868, 890: see on O. C. 934. It is her doom, zw=sa tumbeu/ein (888). She is not a dweller with the living, because her abode is the grave; nor with the dead, because she lives.— The similar phrase—perhaps imitated from this—in Eur. Suppl. 968 f., ou)/t' e)n toi=s fqime/nois | ou)/t' e)n zw=sin a)riqmoume/na (Musgrave krinome/na) has no such special point: the Argive widows merely mean that their life is a living death.

proba=s' … polu/: having advanced to the furthest limit of rashness, thou hast struck heavily (polu/) against the lofty pedestal of Justice. We are to imagine the daring offender as going forward to a boundary where Justice sits enthroned, forbidding all further advance. Instead of pausing there, the rebel still rushes on, to cross the boundary—and, in doing so, dashes herself against the throne of the goddess. For ba/qron cp. Her. 1.183 (a sitting statue of Zeus) kai\ to\ ba/qron (pedestal) oi( kai\ o( qro/nos xru/seo/s e)sti. For prose/peses, Polyb. 1. 39 prospeso/ntes ei)/s tina braxe/a (having struck on some shallows—in sailing). Cp. Aesch. Theb. 409 ma/l' eu)genh= te kai\ to
 *ai)sxu/nhs qro/non | timw=nta kai\ stugou=nq' u(pe/rfronas lo/gous. Ag. 383lakti/santi me/gan *di/kas bwmo/n. Eum. 539bwmo
 ai)/desai *di/kas, | mhde/ nin ke/rdos i)dw
 a)qe/w| podi\ la\c a)ti/sh|s. Solon fr. 4. 14 ou)de\ fula/ssontai semna\ qe/meqla *di/khs.

polu/ (adv.) =sfo/dra, violently.—Bellermann, adopting Kvíčala's general view, and also Kern's e)sxa/tou, renders: ‘having advanced, with extreme rashness (Dem. or. 18 § 17 ou)/te dikai/ws ou)/t' e)p' a)lhqei/as ou)demia=s ei)rhme/na), to the lofty threshold (ba/qron) of Justice, thou hast fallen heavily down’ : i.e., ‘ while, with the utmost boldness, thou wast obeying the command of Justice, thou hast been hurled to destruction.’ But (1) prose/peses could not mean this: we must at least have kate/peses. (2) The Chorus feel pity, indeed, for Ant. , and recognise the praise of piety, which she has won (817, Ant. 872). But they also regard her collision with the city's law as an act of frantic folly (lo/gou t' a)/noia kai\ frenw=n e)rinu/s, Ant. 603); and they presently tell her that she has left Creon no choice but to punish her (874). By *di/kh they understand the law of the State,—not those qew=n no/mima which Ant. preferred to obey.

patrw=|o/n tina … a)=qlon, ‘some ordeal inherited from thy sire’ (v. 2); tina/ softens a statement into a conjecture; it is perhaps the work of the fate which he bequeathed. This is better than to take tina/ closely with patrw=|on as=‘of the paternal kind.’
e)kti/neis, art paying (to the fates which exact it), like e)kti/nw di/khn, ti/sin, a)/poina.

meri/mnas, gen. sing.: oi)=kton, acc. depending on e)/yausas...meri/mnas as =e)poi/hsa/s me merimna=n: cp. El. 122 ti/na | ta/keis w(=d' a)ko/reston oi)mwga
 | to
 pa/lai e)k dolera=s a)qew/tata | matro\s a(lo/nt' a)pa/tais *)agame/mnona, where to
...*)agame/mnona is governed by ti/na ta/keis...oi)mwga/n as =ti/ oi)mw/zeis; see other examples in n. on 211 f. patro/s and po/tmou are objective genitives with oi)=kton.—The objection

to taking oi)=kton as acc. in apposition with e)/yausas...meri/mnas is that this would imply to/ (se) yau=sai a)lg. e)moi\ meri/mnhs oi)=kto/s e)stin: as Eur. Or. 1105 *(ele/nhn kta/nwmen, *mene/lew| lu/phn pikra/n, implies, to\ *(ele/nhn ktanei=n *mene/lew| lu/ph pikra\ e)/stai: Aesch. Ag. 224 e)/tla d' ou)=n | quth\r gene/sqai qugatro/s, gunaikopoi/nwn pole/mwn a)rwga/n, implies, to\ quth=ra gene/sqai a)rwgh\ h)=n. Now, if we had, for instance, a)nemnh/sqhn meri/mnhs, it is conceivable that oi)=kton, as acc. in appos., should mean oi)/ktou a)formh/n or e)/gersin. But when, as here, the subject of e)/yausas is distinct from the person who makes the lament, it seems impossible that oi)=kton should have this pregnant sense.

a)lg. meri/mnas is certainly not acc. plur. See on 546 and 961. No Greek hearer of these lyrics could take meri/mnas for anything but the usual gen. after yau/w. If Soph. had intended the acc., he would at least have written a)lgeinota/tan...me/rimnan.—The interpretation given above would admit the reading oi)=ton, ‘doom,’ which has, however, less authority (cr. n.). El. 166 to\n a)nh/nuton | oi)=ton e)/xousa kakw=n. But, as oi)=ton po/tmou is an impossible pleonasm, it would then be necessary to take tou= te ...po/tmou as depending on e)/yausas: for tripo/liston oi)=ton could not be a parenthetic acc. in apposition with e)/yausas... meri/mnas patro/s. This would be very awkward. Further, oi)=kton is clearly the right word to introduce the lament i)w/, etc., which actually follows.

tripo/liston (oi)=kton), a lament which has often been renewed; a thrice-told tale of sorrow. pole/w=to turn up the soil with the plough: a)napole/w, to plough anew: then fig., to ‘go over the same ground’ again. Pind. N. 7. 104tau)ta\...tri\s tetra/ki t' a)mpolei=n: Soph. Ph. 1238di\s tau)ta\ bou/lei kai\ tri\s a)napolei=n m' e)/ph; No poli/zw as =pole/w occurs, but Pind. once has a)napoli/zw as=a)napole/w ( Pind. P. 6. 3). Similarly a poet might well use tripo/listos as if poli/zw existed. It is needless to write tripo/lhton. The epic adj. is tri/polos.

kleinoi=s *labdaki/daisin, dat. of interest after po/tmou, all the fate for (i.e. appointed for) us, the Labdacidae, instead of the possessive gen., kleinw=n *labdakida=n. Cp. Eur. Phoen. 17 w)= *qh/baisin eu)i/ppois a)/nac. It is needless to explain the dat. by pressing the deriv. of po/tmos from pi/ptw (‘what falls to one’). Cp. on 571, and on 865 (e)mw=| patri/).
a(mete/rou (=h(mi=n) is here joined with the dat. of interest, as the possessive pron. is oft. joined with the gen. of the pers. pron. (ta)ma\ dusth/nou kaka/, O. C. 344).

matrw=|ai le/ktrwn a)=tai = matrw/|wn l. a)=tai (see n. on 793), calamities of the mother's bed, i.e. springing from marriage with a mother. (So O. C. 526 ga/mwn . . a)/ta|.) For the plur. a)=tai in this sense, cp. O. C. 1244, El. 215.—L's patrw=|ai (‘calamities of my father's marriage’) is possible, but less good, since (a) the epithet mhtrw=|a denotes the bed to which he came: cp. O. T. 976 kai\ pw=s to\ mhtro\s
le/ktron ou)k o)knei=n me dei=; and (b) with patrw=|ai the explanation by e)mw=| patri/, etc., would have been less needed.

koimh/mata . . au)toge/nnhta . . matro/s, the mother's union with her own offspring; the adj.=meta\ tou= au(th=s gennh/matos: cp. O. C. 1463 ktu/pos . . dio/bolos (=ktu/pos tou= e)k *dio\s be/lous): Aesch. Eum. 212 o(/maimos (=suggenou=s) au)qe/nths fo/nos.

e)mw=| patri/, dat. of interest, ‘for my sire’ (i.e. to his misery); the whole phrase being equiv. to, ‘a mother's incestuous union with our father.’ The dat. goes with the whole preceding phrase, not with au)toge/nnhta only (‘incestuous in relation to him’), nor with koimh/mata only (‘sleep with him’). The latter, which Wecklein assumes, implies koima=sqai/ tini as=sugk. tini/, an unproved constr.; for Hes. Th. 213ou)/tini koimh:qei=sa qea\ te/ke *nu\c e)rebennh/ is of doubtful genuineness, and even there ou)/tini could go with te/ke.
dusmo/rou is far better than dusmo/rw|: without it, the words could imply that only the father's sin merited pity.

oi(/wn (masc.) pote/ is exclamatory: ‘from what manner of parents’ (for the gen., cp. 38). The exclamatory oi(=os is freq. in Soph. (cp. 1228, Tr. 997, etc.), and pote/ strengthens it just as it strengthens the interrogative ti/s or poi=os (O. T. 754, Ph. 222, etc.). So the exclamatory oi)=os is strengthened by a)/ra (Ai. 367, 910).—Most commentators make oi(/wn neut. relative to koimh/mata: ‘such (wedlock) as that from which I sprang.’ But pote/ is fatal to this; for (a) it cannot here mean, ‘in former days’; that would be too weak: (b) nor can oi(/wn pote/ mean, ‘of whatever kind they may have been’— like o(/stis pote/. Besides, the masc. ou(/s most naturally refers to persons denoted by oi(/wn. I have therefore pointed at matro/s.—a)rai=os, fem.: elsewhere this adj. is always of three terminations. So Attic tragedy uses koino/s, poqeino/s, ptwxo/s, fanero/s, etc., as fem.: see O. C. 751 n.
me/toikos: see on 852.

kasi/gnhte. Polyneices. His marriage with Argeia, daughter of the Argive king Adrastus, was the seal of the armed alliance against Thebes, and thus the prime cause of Antigone's death (O. C. 378).—Not Oedipus. Such an allusion would be too repulsive here. In O. C. 535 a)delfeai/ marks the climax of horror, and the word is wrung from unwilling lips. Further, as the doom of the whole race is in question (859), the brother is fitly mentioned.
qanw\n e)/t' ou)=san: so Electra says of her brother Orestes, w(/s m' a)pw/lesas qanw/n. Cp. on O. T. 1453.

kath/nares. This act. aor. occurs in later poetry. The epic form of the compound is katenai/romai, aor. katenhra/mhn. Eur. uses the epic e)nai/rw, h)/naron, but only in lyrics. Soph. has kathnarisme/nas (katenari/zw) in dial., Ai. 26.
se/bein. ‘Reverent action’ (meaning her loyalty to Polyneices) ‘is, in a

sense, eu)se/beia’: i.e. though it is not complete eu)se/beia—which the Chorus regard as including loyalty to the State's laws— yet, so far as it goes, it deserves praise of the same kind. Cp. 924 th\n dusse/beian eu)sebou=s' e)kthsa/mhn: by practising eu)se/beia towards the dead, she had come to be thought, on the whole, dussebh/s—as a law-breaker. The Chorus is here the apologist of Creon, and this concession is meant to emphasise the next sentence. Hence the purposed vagueness of se/bein. The speaker avoids a direct reference to the peculiarly sacred and tender duty which Ant. had fulfilled. The proposed emendations (see cr. n.) would obliterate this touch.

kra/tos de\ ou)dama=| parabato\n pe/lei ( tou/tw| ), o(/tw| kra/tos me/lei: but an offence against authority cannot be permitted by him who has authority in his keeping. The antecedent to o(/tw|, viz. tou/tw|, is an ethic dat., ‘in his sight’; he must not look on and see the law broken. For this dat., cp. 904.
ou)dama=| (Dor.): cp. 763.—For me/lei cp. 1335: Il. 2.25 w(=| laoi/ t' e)pitetra/fatai kai\ to/ssa me/mhlen. The Chorus echoes Creon's saying (677).

au)to/gnwtos, act., deciding for oneself, au)th\ gignw/skousa, like mempto/s, ‘blaming,’ u(/poptos, ‘suspecting,’ etc. (O. C. 1031 n.). Not pass., ‘resolved upon’ (i.e. here, ‘adopted’) ‘by one's own choice,’ as Ellendt takes it (‘ultro susceptus’), and as the Schol. perh. did, who gives, au)qai/retos kai\ i)diognw/mwn tro/pos.
o)rga/, disposition: see n. on 354 ff. (o)rga/s).

e(toi/man, imminent, i.e. for which everything is prepared; Il. 18.96 au)ti/ka ga/r toi e)/peita meq' *(/ektora po/tmos e(toi=mos: Plut. Mor. 706C e(/toimon to\ diafqarh=nai toi=s mh\ bohqou=nta:. . .to\n logismo\n e)/xousi (corruption is imminent for those who have not reason to aid them). Cp. 936.
to/de l. i(ro\n o)/mma = th=sde i(era=s lampa/dos o)/mma (793 n.). Cp. Eur. I. T. 194 a)lla/cas... | i(ero\n...o)/mm' au)ga=s | a(/lios. Ion 1467a)eli/ou d' a)nable/pei lampa/sin.
a)da/kruton, predicate, with proleptic force: no friend mourns my fate,

(and so it remains) unwept. Soph. has several instances of the predicative adj. thus added to a subst. which has the art. and possessive pron.; as O. T. 671 to\ ga\r so/n, ou) to\ tou=d', e)poikti/rw sto/ma | e)leino/n (n.): El. 1143 th=s e)mh=s pa/lai trofh=s | a)nwfelh/tou. Cp. 791.

a)=r' i)/ste, w(s, ei) xrei/h le/gein a)oida\s kai\ go/ous pro\ tou= qanei=n, ou)d' ei)=s a)
 pau/saito (le/gwn); The constr. would have been clearer with le/gwn instead of le/gein, but the latter has naturally been conformed to xrei/h. The conject. pau/seien is admissible (cp. O. C. 1751 pau/ete qrh=non, pai=des), but unnecessary, and scarcely probable. Prof. Postgate's suggestion, that a)oida\s kai\ go/ous are objects to i)/ste, is tenable; but against it is the fact that in such cases the object of the principal verb is almost invariably the anticipated subject of the dependent clause (as O. C. 1197 gnw/sei kakou= | qumou= teleuth
 w(s kakh\ prosgi/gnetai); as if here we had, a)=r' i)/st' a)oida\s w(s makrai/ ei)si; An object is very rarely so anticipated, as in Isae. or. 10 § 18, i)/sws ou)=n a)/n tis...to
 xro/non u(mw=n qauma/seie, pw=s pote polu
 ou(/tws ei)a/samen.
ou)d' a)\n ei(=s, more emphatic than ou)dei\s a)/n: O. T. 281 n.

ou)k a)/ceq'. When the first of two or more commands is given by ou) with fut. indic., that constr. is usually continued, either (a) with kai/, as Eur. Andr. 1066 ou)x o(/son ta/xos | xwrh/setai/ tis...kai\... le/cei...; or (b) with repeated ou), as Aristoph. Lys. 459 ou)x e(/lcet', ou) paih/set', ou)k a)ra/cete; Here a direct imperat. follows (887), and a note of interrogation must therefore be placed after ta/xista.—kathrefei=, prop. ‘roofed over,’ oft. an epithet of a natural cave (Od. 13.349 spe/os, Soph. Ph. 272e)n k. pe/tra|), and in El. 381 of a chamber (ste/gh) like this katw=ruc. The fact that Nauck wishes to change it into katw/ruxi (or katwruxei=) is a strong instance of metabolh\ pa/ntwn gluku/.
periptu/cantes: see on 848 (e(/rgma). Cp. Eur. Phoen. 1357 teixe/wn periptuxai/. Kaibel Epigr. 468lai/+neos sth/lh me pe/ric e)/xei.

xrh=|, wishes: 3rd pers. pres. ind. of xra/w, with contraction into h= instead of a=, as in diyh=n, zh=n, knh=n, peinh=n, smh=n, xrh=n (to give an oracle), xrh=sqai, yh=n. Schol., ei) xrh/|zei kai\ qe/lei. If the nom. zw=sa is sound, as it seems to be, in the next v., then xrh=| is certain: for ei) xrh/|zei has no probability. Only one other passage, however, gives unambiguous support to the forms xrh=|s, xrh=|,—viz. Aristoph. Ach. 778, (the Megarian) ou) xrh=sqa; sigh=|s, w)= ka/kist' a)poloume/na; ‘will you not make a sound?' (ou) qe/leis, sc. fwnei=n;). There, indeed, Blaydes writes ou) xrh/ tu

sigh=n; but the MSS. are supported by the testimony of Suidas and Hesychius to xrh=|s as=xrh/|zeis. In the other four places where these forms are usu. read, they are not indispensable, xrh/ being possible; but in two, at least, they are much better than xrh/, viz. El. 606 kh/russe/ m' ei)s a(/pantas, ei)/te xrh=|s kakh/n, | ei)/te sto/margon, k.t.l.: and Ai. 1373 soi\ de\ dra=n e)/cesq' a(\ xrh=|s. In the other two, xrh/ might well stand: Eur. fr. 910 pro\s tau=q' o(/ ti xrh=| kai\ palama/sqw | kai\ pa=n e)p' e)moi\ tektaine/sqw: Cratinus *no/moi fr. 2 nu=n ga\r dh/ soi pa/ra me\n qesmoi\ | tw=n h(mete/rwn, pa/ra d' a)/ll' o(/ ti xrh=|s. Except in Ach. 778, the MSS. everywhere give xrh/: and the variants in the next v. (see cr. n.) show that xrh=| was strange to the copyists, though known to the Scholiast.

zw=sa tumbeu/ein, to live entombed. Elsewhere tumbeu/w=to entomb (Ai. 1063 sw=ma tumbeu=sai ta/fw|); or to bring as a funeral offering, El. 406 patri\ tumbeu=sai xoa/s. Here it is intrans.,=e)n tu/mbw| ei)=nai. Cp. saleu/w, which means either (1) to put others on a sa/los,—to toss them: or (2) intrans., to be on a sa/los. So the intrans. qalasseu/w=to be on the sea. parqeneu/w, which is trans. in classical Gk. (‘to bring up a maiden’), is intrans. in Heliod. 7. 8to\...parqeneu=on tou= a)/steos. —The conject. numfeu/ein is not right. That taunt would be quite out of place here. Creon says simply, ‘I immure her,—I do not kill her; she can either die, or live,—but in the tomb.’
ste/gh|, iron.: cp. El. 381 zw=sa d' e)n kathrefei= | ste/gh| xqono\s th=sd' e)kto\s u(mnh/seis kaka/, i.e. in a cave, or subterranean cell.
a(gnoi/: see on 775. His thought is: (1) she had warning: (2) no blood has been shed.

tou)pi\ th/nde, in what concerns her. In this phrase with the acc., e)pi/ more often means, ‘so far as depends on one’: Eur. Hec. 514 h(mei=s d' a)/teknoi tou)pi\ s': Or. 1345sw/qhq' o(/son ge tou)p' e)/m': Thuc. 4.28 (he told Cleon to try) to\ e)pi\ sfa=s ei)=nai (so far as the generals were concerned): Xen. Cyr. 1.4.12 a)/llou tino\s to\ e)pi\ se\ a)na/gkh e)/stai dei=sqai h(ma=s. In all these places e)pi/ with dat. would equally suit the sense; but not so in this verse. Cp. 1348 ta/ g' ei)s qeou/s.
metoiki/as, cp. 852.
sterh/setai, 637.
w)= tu/mbos, nom for voc.: cp. 379.
numfei=on: cp. 1205.
kataskafh/s: see on 774....a)ei/frouros = h(\ a)ei\ frourh/sei me, not, h(\n e)gw\ a)ei\ frourh/sw (like Aesch. PV 31 th/nde frourh/seis pe/tran): cp. 886.
a)riqmo\n … plei+ston: she thinks of Laïus, her father and mother, and her two brothers.
e)n nekroi=s with de/dektai: the queen of the nether world has greeted them as they passed through the polu/cenoi
pu/lai to Hades (O. C. 1569 f.). So Oedipus is led by *(ermh=s o( pompo\s h(/ te nerte/ra qeo/s (ib. 1548). As h( a)fanh\s qeo/s she is associated with Hades (ib. 1556).

*ferse/fassa has L's support here. That form occurs also in Eur. Helen 175, but *perse/fassa in Aesch. Cho. 490. The Il.and Od.have only *persefo/neia. *fersefo/neia occurs in Hom. Hymn. 13.2. Pindar uses *fersefo/na. Plato attests that, in his day, the popular form was *ferre/fatta, which he explains as the goddess of wisdom, who enables men ferome/nwn e)fa/ptesqai, to grasp changing phenomena. People were afraid to utter the name *fersefo/nh ( Crat. 404C). Attic inscrr. of the 4th cent. B.C. give *persefo/nh, *fersefo/nh, *ferre/fatta (Meisterhans pp. 36 ff.). MSS. have *ferse/fatta (which should perh. be *ferre/fatta) in Aristoph. Ran. 671, Th. 287.A vase ascribed to c. 435 B.C. gives *p*e*r*s*w*f*a*t*a (sic, Baumeister Denkm. p. 424). Welcker cites *f*e*r*e*f*a*s*a from an Agrigentine vase (Götterl. 1. 393). We may infer that Soph. , c. 440 B.C., might have used either *perse/fassa or *ferse/fassa. The testimony of our oldest and best MS., L, may therefore be allowed to turn the scale.— In *persefo/nh, the fon is certainly fan, as in *)argeifo/nths, and this comes out more clearly in *perse/fassa: cp. *thlefa=ssa = *thlefa/essa, Apollod. 3. 1. 1.The first part of the word is prob. fer, fe/rw; and the name meant originally, ‘she who brings (vegetation) to the light.’ The initial II would then have been due to the following f (cp. pe/-fuka for fe/-fuka). The replacement of the initial *f may have been prompted by a wish to mitigate the dusfhmi/a of the name by avoiding an association with pe/rqw.
ka/kista, as a law-breaker (cp. 59): dh/ with superl., see 58 n.
moi=ran … bi/ou: cp. 461. e)ch/kein of time, as Ph. 199.
e)n e)lpi/sin tre/fw = e)lpi/zw. e)n e)lpi/di (or e)lpi/sin) ei)mi/ was a common phrase. Cp. e)n po/qw| labei=n ti (O. C. 1678).—fi/lh me\n … prosfilh\s de/: cp. 669 kalw=s me\n...eu)= de/, n.

kasi/gnhton ka/ra. Eteocles. Whatever view may be taken of vv. 904—920, few would question the genuineness of 900—903: and if the latter are genuine, nu=n de/ shows that Polyneices is not meant here. She speaks first of those kinsfolk to whom she had rendered pious offices in the usual manner. Then she comes to him who is uppermost in her thoughts,—the brother whose case was different from that of the others. In v. 23 she spoke of the rumour that Eteocles had been duly buried. But nothing here implies her presence at his e)kfora/. e)/lousa ka)ko/smhsa were acts preparatory to the pro/qesis. The xoai/ could be rendered afterwards. She loved both brothers (cp. on 523). If father and mother were named here, without any mention of Eteocles, the omission would suggest that from him she could expect no welcome,—a contradiction of her real feeling (515). Further, the brevity of this reference to Eteocles heightens the effect of what follows.
u(ma=s. This play supposes Oedipus to have died at Thebes: see on 50.
e)/lousa ka)ko/smhsa: see nn. on O. C. 1602 f. loutroi=s te/ nin | e)sqh=ti/ t' e)ch/skhsan h(=| nomi/zetai. Cp. below, 1201.
xoa/s: cp. 431.

periste/llousa: here, of sprinkling the dust and pouring the xoai/: cp. the general sense of the word in Ai. 1170 ta/fon peristelou=nte. More oft. of laying out the dead (like kosmei=n here, and sugkaqarmo/zein in Ai. 922): Od. 24.292 ou)de/ e( mh/thr | klau=se peristei/lasa. Verg. Aen. 9. 485 canibus date praeda Latinis | Alitibusque iaces: nec te tua funera mater | Produxi, pressive oculos, aut vulnera lavi, | Veste tegens.
de/mas: 205.

Few problems of Greek Tragedy have been more discussed than the question whether these vv., or some of them, are spurious. Arist. ( Arist. Rhet. 3. 16§ 9) quotes vv. 911, 912, and certainly had the whole passage in his text of The Soph. interpolation, then, if such it be, must have been made soon after the poet's death; and has been imputed to his son Iophon (o( yuxro/s), or some other sorry poet; or to the actors. I confess that, after long thought, I cannot bring myself to believe that Soph. wrote 905—912: with which 904 and 913—920 are in organic unity, and must now stand or fall. Some remarks will be found in the Appendix.

The main points (to my mind) are briefly these. (1) The general validity of the divine law, as asserted in 450— 460, cannot be intelligibly reconciled with the limitation in vv. 905—907. (2) A still further limitation is involved in 911 f. She has buried her brother, not simply as such, but because, while he lived, he was an irreplaceable relative. Could she have hoped for the birth of another brother, she would not, then, have felt the duty to be so binding. (3) The composition of vv. 909—912 is unworthy of Sophocles.
'ti/mhsa (cp. 'fa/nh, 457 n.), with eu)= (last word of v., as O. C. 642), I honoured thee rightly, toi=s fronou=sin, in the judgment of the wise; ethic dat. (25 n.): cp. 514.
e)th/keto, lay mouldering: Plat. Tim. 82E o(/tan...thkome/nh sa\rc a)na/palin ei)s ta\s fle/bas th\n thkedo/na e)cih=|. So tabum of corpses, Verg. Aen. 8. 487.

bi/a| politw=n. This was Ismene's phrase (79). Antigone had believed hat the city was on her side (509). This has been noted as a mark of spuriousness in the verse. But it cannot (I think) be fairly claimed as such; for, since the Chorus had seemed to fail in sympathy (838), she had regarded herself as a)/filos (876) in Thebes.
pro\s xa/rin: see on 30.

Cp. Her. 3.119, which clearly supplied, not merely the thought, but the form, of these verses:—a)nh me/n moi a)
 a)/llos ge/noito, ei) dai/mwn e)qe/loi, kai\ te/kna a)/lla, ei) tau=ta a)poba/loimi: patro\s de\ kai\ mhtro\s ou)ke/ti moi zwo/ntwn, a)delfeo\s a)
 a)/llos ou)deni\ tro/pw| ge/noito (3.119.6). Arist. Rhet. 3.16 § 9 (if you introduce a trait of character which will seem improbable, the reason ofit should be added): a)
 d' a)/piston h)=|, to/te th
 ai)ti/an e)pile/gein, w(/sper *sofoklh=s poiei= para/deigma to\ e)k th=s *)antigo/nhs, o(/ti ma=llon tou= a)delfou= e)kh/deto h)\ a)ndro\s h)\ te/knwn: ta\ me
 ga a)
 gene/sqai a)polo/mena [this=vv. 909, 910]: mhtro\s d' e)n a(/|dou k.t.l. (he then quotes 911 f., with bebhko/twn,—a mere slip of memory: see on 223).

Three points in these vv. are strange. (1) The gen. abs. katqano/ntos, for which a gen. has to be evolved from po/sis. The gen. of that word was not in Attic use (‘mihi non succurrit exemplum ubi po/seos aut po/sews legatur,’ Pors. Med. 906). Why was not a)ndro/s used? Itlooks as if the composer who made up these verses from Her. 3.119 (see above) had sought to impart a touch of tragic dignity by substituting po/sis for the historian's word, a)nh/r. The gen. katqano/ntos cannot be taken (as some wish) with a)/llos, ‘different from the dead’ (!). (2) a)p' a)/llou fwto/s. Why is it assumed that the first husband died before, or with, his child? The two hypotheses of loss should have been kept separate. We wanted something like kai\ pai=s a)\n a)/llos, paido\s e)sterhme/nh|. (3) tou=d' means the first husband's child, but is most awkward.—As to ou)k e)/st' a)delfo/s k.t.l., it may be somewhat inelegant; but it is not (as some urge) incorrect, since ou)k e)/stin o(/stis = ou)dei/s.

e)kprotimh/sas', ‘having singled thee out for honour,’ with ref. to the supposed cases in which she would not have paid the burial rites. The double compound occurs only here,—as e)cafora/w only in O. C. 1648.
dia\ xerw=n … labw/n, i.e., by forcible arrest, as though I were a criminal. Cp. O. C. 470 di' o(si/wn xeirw=n qigw/n (=‘with’), Aesch. Suppl. 193 (i(kthri/as) e)/xousai dia\ xerw=n.
a)nume/naion: see on 813.
a)ll': cp. on 810.

pro\s fi/lwn with e)/rhmos (not with e)/rxomai), forsaken on the part of my friends. The sense of pro/s in Ph. 1070 is similar, though there it goes with the verb; h)= kai\ pro\s u(mw=n w(=d' e)/rhmos, w)= ce/noi, | leifqh/somai dh/...;
daimo/nwn di/khn, that which the gods recognise (451), as distinguished from the human di/kh (854) which she has offended.
If the gods allow her to suffer for obeying them, is it not vain for her to invoke them?
ble/pein ei)/s tina (for help), as Ai. 398, 514, El. 959.
ti/na … cumma/xwn, what ally (of all conceivable allies)?
e)pei/ ge dh/: cp. Tr. 484 e)pei/ ge me\n dh/. For the place of dh/, cp. 726.

th\n dusse/beian, the repute of it; El. 968 eu)se/beian e)k patro\s | qano/ntos oi)/sei: Eur. I. T. 676 kai\ deili/an ga\r kai\ ka/khn kekth/somai: Med. 218du/skleian e)kth/santo kai\ r(a|qumi/an: Ion 600ge/lwt' e)n au)toi=s mwri/an te lh/yomai.
The gods are allowing her to perish. But it does not follow that they approve of her doom: for they are sometimes slow in punishing wrong (O. C. 1536). Hence the dilemma, introduced

by a)ll' ou)=n (‘well then’). (1) If the gods approve of my doom, then, after suffering it, I shall become conscious (in the other world) that I have sinned. (2) But if they disapprove of it, and regard Creon as the sinner, then they will punish him at last. And I could wish him no sorer doom than mine.
e)n qeoi=s: cp. 459.

cuggnoi=men = suneidei/hmen. Lys. or. 9 § 11 sune/gnwsan de\ kai\ au)toi\ sfi/sin w(s h)dikhko/tes, ‘became conscious that they had done wrong.’ The word could also mean, o(mologh/saimen, ‘confess’: but in that sense it regularly takes either an inf., as Her. 1.91 sune/gnw e(wutou= ei)=nai th\n a(marta/da: or a dependent clause, as Plat. Legg. 717D cuggignw/skonta w(s ei)ko/tws...qumoi=t' a)/n.

h(marthko/tes belongs more closely to the verb than does paqo/ntes: cp. Plat. Phaedo 70A (h( yuxh\) diaskedasqei=sa oi)/xhtai diaptome/nh. For the tragic masc. plur., when a woman speaks of herself, cp. El. 399.
oi(/de, Creon: cp. 10.
mh\ plei/w, i.e. she will be content if they suffer i)/sa. She can imagine no worse fate. The tame conjecture mei/w would not express this bitter feeling.—kai\ drw=sin, do on their part: O. C. 53 n.

a)ne/mwn-r(ipai\ yuxh=s, stormgusts of the soul: both genitives are possessive: cp. 795 blefa/rwn-i(/meros...nu/mfas —Dindorf's expulsion of au(tai\ | yuxh=s (cr. n.) is unwarranted. yuxh=s interprets the figurative sense; for au(tai/ after tw=n au)tw=n cp. n. on 155 ff. (ne/oxmos nearai=si).
tou/twn, neut., causal gen. (O. T. 48). After th/nde g', this is better than tau/thn would be: toiga/rtoi (whether with kai/ or with nin) would be unpleasing.
klau/maq': cp. 754: so Ph. 1260e)kto\s klauma/twn.
u(/per = e(/neka (O. T. 165 n.). oi)/moi follows, but the change of person excuses the breach of synapheia: so O. C. 139 to\ fatizo/menon is followed by i)w/, and ib. 143 pre/sbus by ou).
This threat (to the guards) ‘has come very near to death,’ i.e., ‘portends imminent death for me.’ The phrase is not fig., ‘is bitter as death to hear’ (being a prelude to death).
Said by Creon, clearly—not by the Chorus. ‘I can give thee no encouragement (ou)de/n adv.) to hope that
the doom is not to be ratified on this wise’ (i.e., by death). mh\ ou), not mh/, on account of ou)de/n (443 n.).

katakurou=sqai, pres. denoting what is to be; Ph. 113ai(rei= ta\ to/ca tau=ta th\n *troi/an mo/na. Attic prose used kurou=n or e)pikurou=n (gnw/mhn, no/mon, yh/fisma, etc.). Cp. Creon's peremptory word telei/an in 632.
tau/th| (722) combined with ta/de: cp. 39.

qeoi\ progenei=s, ancestral, not merely as protectors of the race, but also as progenitors. She thinks esp. of Ares and Aphrodite, the parents of Harmonia, wife of Cadmus: Aesch. Theb. 135 su/ t', *arhs, po/lin *ka/dmou e)pw/numon | fu/lacai kh/desai/ t' e)nargw=s. | kai\ *ku/pris, a(/t' ei)= ge/nous proma/twr, | a)/leuson. Dionysus, the son of ‘Cadmean’ Semele (1115), is another of the deities meant. progenh/s, born before one, a poet. word, unfamiliar to good Attic prose, but used by Aristotle and later writers, usu. in comparat. (as oi( progene/steroi, ‘those who have gone before us’): so oi( metagene/steroi.
dh/ = h)/dh (O. T. 968), as in kai\ dh/.

kou)ke/ti me/llw, and am no longer (merely) about to be led away: cp. O. C. 1074 e)/rdous' h)\ me/llousin; Ph. 1255ka)me/ toi | tau)to\n to/d' o)/yei drw=nta kou) me/llont' e)/ti. Meineke's conjecture mellw/ (=me/llhsis, Aesch. Ag. 1356) was needless.— Seyffert understands, ‘I make no more delay,’—said firmly and proudly: she scorns to bring punishment on her guards by detaining them longer. But this does not suit a)/gomai dh/.

oi( koirani/dai, the Theban eu)patri/dai of the Chorus: see on 843. The nom. with art., instead of voc.,=‘ye who are princes of Thebes,’ and so brings out the implied reproach to their apathy. This constr. usu. has a somewhat peremptory tone, as Plat. Symp. 218B oi( de\ oi)ke/tai...pu/las...toi=s w)si\n e)pi/qesqe. It is different when a voc. precedes the art. and partic., as Aristoph. Av. 30 w)=ndres oi( paro/ntes e)n lo/gw|: cp. on 100 f.

basileida=n, i.e., of the race of the Labdacidae. This correction of basili/da is certain. In Plat. Critias 116C, to\ tw=n de/ka basileidw=n ge/nos, the same corruption, basili/dwn, occurs in the MSS. Suidas has basilei/dhs: o( tou= basile/ws (where Küster wrongly proposed o( tou= *basilei/ou). In adding the patronymic suffix ida_ to a stem in eu (basileu), the u is dropped, as in the gen. plur. (basile/-wn): hence basile-i/dhs, basilei/dhs: cp. *phlei/dhs.

mou/nhn, ignoring Ismene; not in bitterness (cp. on 559), but because she feels that, in spirit at least, she herself is indeed the last of the race. It is otherwise when Oed. speaks of his daughters as his only children (O. C. 895); and when Electra says that she is a)/neu toke/wn (187),— since Clytaemnestra is a mh/thr a)mh/twr (1154).
eu)sebi/an. Epic and lyric poetry could substitute -ia for -eia in fem. nouns from adjectives in -hs: so O. C. 1043 promhqi/as: Pind. P. 12. 4eu)meni/a|: Aesch. Eum. 534 dussebi/as: H. F. 696

eu)geni/as. The motive was metrical convenience. Such forms are not Ionic, as Triclinius called them (cr. n.): thus Herod. used a)lhqei/h, not a)lhqi/h: though there are other cases in which Ionic substitutes e for ei (as baqe/a, e)pith/deos, etc.).— sebi/sasa, of respecting a law or custom: so O. C. 636, Ai. 713 (qe/smia...se/bwn).

div2.p: Fourth stasimon. 1st strophe 944—954=1st antistrophe 955— 965. 2nd str. 966—976=2nd antistr. 977—987. See Metrical Analysis.

As Antigone spoke the verses ending at 943, the guards were in the act of leading her forth. The choral ode may have begun before she had vanished; but she is not to be conceived as still present when she is apostrophised (949, 987).

A princess is about to be immured in a rocky cell. The Chorus remember three other royal persons who have suffered a like fate—Danaë, Lycurgus and Cleopatra. The only points which these cases have in common with Antigone's are the facts of noble birth and cruel imprisonment.

All four cases illustrate the same general truth—no mortal can resist fate. Danaë and Cleopatra were innocent; Lycurgus was guilty. But the Chorus do not mean to suggest Antigone's guilt or innocence; still less, to foreshadow the punishment of Creon. On this side, the ode is neutral, purely a free lyric treatment of the examples. Such neutrality suits the moment before the beginning of the peripe/teia. Teiresias is soon to come.

div3.p: Acrisius, the father of Danaë, was king of Argos. The oracle at Delphi told him that he was to be slain by his daughter's son. He therefore immured the maiden in a chamber built for that purpose within the precincts of his house at Argos. Here Zeus visited her in the golden rain; she bore Perseus; and Acrisius sent mother and child adrift on the Aegean in a chest; but Zeus heard her prayer, and brought them safely to the island of Seriphus. Both Soph. and Eur. wrote a *dana/h: Soph. wrote also an *)akri/sios.

kai\ *dana/as de/mas e)/tla a)lla/cai ou)ra/nion fw=s: note the bold order of words, and cp. Ph. 598 f. (ti/nos...pra/gmatos). e)/tla kai/ is a Homeric echo, from Il. 5.382 ff. Aphrodite has been wounded by Diomede: her mother Dionè comforts her by saying that Ares, Hera, and Hades have also suffered wounds: te/tlaqi, te/knon e)mo/n... | tlh= me\n *)/arhs... | tlh= d' *(/hrh... | tlh= d' *)ai/+dhs. So here we have three examples—Danaë, Lycurgus, Cleopatra.

de/mas in periphrasis (Tr. 908) here suggests her youthful beauty.—a)lla/cai ou)r. fw=s e)n xalkod. au)lai=s, ‘to give up light, (so as to be) in a prison,’ i.e. to exchange the light for the darkness of a prison. a)lla/ssw ti/ tinos can mean either to give, or to take, one thing in exchange for another. When a)lla/ssw is used absolutely, with ref. to place, it more naturally means ‘to go to’ (Eur. Hec. 483 a)lla/cas' *(/aida qala/mous), not, as here, ‘to leave’: but a)mei/bw is freq. in both senses. Cp. Ph. 1262a)mei/yas...ste/gas (having quitted them).

xalkode/tois au)lai=s, ‘a brass-bound dwelling’: poet. pl. for sing., like dw/mata, etc.: cp. 785. Pherecydes (ap. schol. Apoll. Rhod. 4. 1091) describes it as ‘a brazen chamber (qa/lamon...xalkou=n) made under ground, in the court-yard (au)lh/) of his house.’ Paus. (2. 23. 7) says that he saw at Argos kata/gewn oi)kodo/mhma, e)p' au)tw=| de\ h)=n o( xalkou=s qa/lamos (made by Acrisius): i.e. the qa/lamos itself was above ground;—as Horace calls it turris aenea (C. 3. 16. 1). By the epithet xalkou=s the legend evidently meant to denote the strength and security of the prison,—as though the doors were of bronze. But it is very probable that this epithet originally came into the story through a reminiscence of a tomb (like the ‘treasury of Atreus’ at Mycenae), to the walls of which bronze plates had been nailed. (Cp. Introd. to Homer, ch. 11. § 25.) In Simonides fr. 37. 7 xalkeogo/mfw| is said of the chest in which Danaë was sent adrift,—not of the qa/lamos.
tumbh/rei: cp. on 255.

katezeu/xqh: was brought under the yoke, i.e., was strictly confined. Her. 8.22 ei)... u(p' a)nagkai/hs me/zonos kate/zeuxqe h)\ w(/ste a)pi/stasqai, if ye are in the bondage of a control too severe, etc. Cp. zeu/xqh, 955.

ti/mios, sc. h)=n: cp. 834. Hermann's kai/toi kai/ is preferable to Wieseler's kai/toi g' h)=n, because the doubled kai/ is forcible, while kai\ *zhno/s (without a previous kai/) would be somewhat weak.

tamieu/eske, as a precious charge. Cp. Aesch. Eum. 660 ti/ktei d' o( qrw/skwn: h( d' (the mother) a(/per ce/nw| ce/nh | e)/swsen e)/rnos. The iterative form occurs in only three other places of trag.: 963: Aesch. Pers. 656 e)/sken, Aesch. fr. 305 klai/eskon.

xrusoru/tous, for metre's sake, like Ai. 134 a)mfiru/tou: rr regularly follows a simple vowel, but r a diphthong (O. C. 469).—A bowl (krath/r) from Caere, of the 5th cent. C.B. , shows the golden rain descending on Danaë; she is sitting on the bed in her chamber, and preparing to retire to rest. A second scene, on the same bowl, represents the moment when she is about to be placed, where Simonides imagines her, larnaki e)n daidale/a|. Both paintings are reproduced by Baumeister (Denkm. p. 407).

a( moiridi/a tis k.t.l. The peculiar place of tis makes it really equiv. to a parenthetic thought: ‘the power of fate (whatever it may be) is a dread power.’ So, while the general sense is what would be ordinarily given by a( moiridi/a du/nasis deina/ tis (du/nasi/s) e)stin, the actual order of the words is more expressive. This is not merely an instance of tis preceding the adj. (as though tis deina/ stood for deina/ tis, cp. Ph. 519). Nor, again, is it strictly parallel with o(/tan d' o( ku/rios | parh=| tis (O.C. 288), where art. and subst. precede; though it is similar.
ou)/t' … o)/lbos: wealth cannot buy off fate; arms cannot vanquish it; walls cannot keep it out; flight beyond sea cannot elude it.—Bacchylides fr. 36

p.quote: qnatoi=si d' ou)k au)qai/retoi | ou)/t' o)/lbos ou)/t' a)/kamptos *)/arhs ou)/te pamfqe/rshs sta/sis, | a)ll' e)pixri/mptei ne/fos a)/llot' e)p' a)/llan | gai=an a( pa/ndwros ai)=sa.

div3.p: pu/rgos, ˙ citywalls, with their towers (O. T. 56).
ou)/t' … ou)/t', followed by ou) … ou)x: so even when only one ou)/te has been used, 249 n.
zeu/xqh, was brought under the yoke. As katezeu/xqh in 946 better suited the sense, ‘was strictly confined,’ so here the simple zeu/xqh better suggests the idea, ‘was tamed by imprisonment.’
o)cu/xolos k.t.l. = o( *dru/antos o)cu/xolos pai=s: the adj. is epithet, not predicate. Verg. Aen. 3. 13 Terra procul vastis colitur Mavortia campis, | Thraces arant, acri quondam regnata Lycurgo.

The *)hdwnoi/, or *)hdw=nes (Thuc. 2.99), occupied in historical times the part of Thrace E. of the Strymon and W. of the Nestus. In earlier times they had dwelt further west, but had been driven eastward by the Macedonian conquest of Mygdonia.

Dionysus, when he came from Asia with his new rites, was opposed by Lycurgus in Thrace, as by Pentheus at Thebes. The *lukou/rgeia of Aeschylus is known from the schol. on Ar. Th. 135.This trilogy consisted of *)hdwnoi/, *bassari/des, *neani/skoi, with *lukou=rgos as satyric drama. In Il. 6.130 ff. Dionysus, pursued by Lycurgus, dives beneath the sea; Thetis receives him; and Zeus blinds Lycurgus.

kertomi/ois o)rgai=s, causal dat. with zeu/xqh: was subjugated by reason of the bursts of fury in which he reviled Dionysus. For the dat., cp. 391, 691: El. 838 xrusode/tois e(/rkesi krufqe/nta gunaikw=n, (Amphiaraus) buried alive, by reason of a woman's golden snares. o)rgai=s might be general, ‘moods’ (355), but here has its special sense, though plur.: cp. Aesch. Eum. 848 o)rga\s cunoi/sw soi. The dat. could be taken as a modal dat. with o)cu/xolos (‘in,’ or ‘with,’ his o)rgai/), but this is less good.—We could not take zeu/xqh...o)rgai=s as=‘was enslaved to (his own) fierce moods.’—The recurrence of kertomi/ois in 961 is noteworthy, but not a ground for suspicion (76 n.): cp. 613 ou)de\n e(/rpei with 618: and 614 e)kto\s a)/tas with 625. The idea of kerto/mios is mockery, or bitter jest: cp. Ph. 1235kertomw=n le/geis ta/de; with the answer, ei) kerto/mhsi/s e)sti ta)lhqh= le/gein. The word is illustrated by the whole scene in which Pentheus mocks and taunts Dionysus (Eur. Bacch. 451—514). So Aesch. fr. 59 made Lycurgus ask, podapo\s o( gu/nnis; (‘whence comes this womanish youth?’).

e)k *dionu/sou, by his command (O. C. 67 n.). Lycurgus, having been driven mad by Dionysus, did many violent deeds, until at last the Edonians were commanded by an oracle to imprison him in a cave on Mount Pangaeus ( Apollod. 3. 5. 1). He was afterwards torn asunder by wild horses (ib.), or devoured by panthers (Hyginus Fab. 132).
petrw/dei … desmw=|, the cave. Cp. Plat. Legg. 864E e)n dhmosi/w| desmw=| deqei/s.
kata/farktos: for the spelling, cp. on 241.
ou(/tw, i.e., under the discipline of the rocky prison.

a)nqhro/n, bursting into flower, hence, fig., exuberant, or at its height: cp. Plat. Polit. 310D pe/fuken a)ndri/a...kata\ me\n arxa\s a)kma/zein r(w/mh|, teleutw=sa de\ e)canqei=n panta/pasi mani/ais: Aesch. Pers. 821 u(/bris...e)canqou=s'. So oft. a)/nqos = a)kmh/, as Tr. 998 to/d' a)kh/lhton | mani/as a)/nqos.

a)posta/zei = a)porrei=, ‘trickles away,’ so ‘gradually passes off.’ The fig. use of a)nqei=n being so familiar, the change of metaphor in a)posta/zei would hardly be felt. Wecklein, indeed, conceives that the poet is thinking of a tumour, which bursts when it has attained its full size. Unity of metaphor can be bought too dearly.—Others understand: ‘so dread and exuberant is the rage that flows from madness’: i.e., ‘so dreadful was the excess of impiety into which L. had been led by his madness.’ But here we look rather for some direct comment on his punishment. His abasement (zeu/xqh) is the theme of these verses. The reference to his crime comes later (962).

e)pe/gnw to
 qeo/n, mani/ais yau/wn (au)tou=) e)n k. glw/ssais: he came to know the god, when in madness he assailed him with taunts. He had mistaken Dionysus for an effeminate mortal (see on 955 f.). Cp. Od. 24.216 patro\s peirh/somai... | ai)/ ke/ m' e)pignw/h| (recognise). yau/w nowhere else takes an acc. in class. Greek (see on 546, 859), and it is unnecessary to regard this passage as a solitary example. Poetry, esp. lyric, allowed occasional boldness, and even harshness, in the arrangement of words (cp. 944: O. T. 1251 n.: O. C. 1428). Even in prose we could have (e.g.) e)ni/khsan a)/fnw e)pipeso/ntes tou\s polemi/ous, though the partic. could not govern an acc. Here the order is only so far bolder, that to
 qeo/n divides yau/wn from e)n k. glw/ssais: as if, in our example, a second qualification of e)pipeso/ntes (such as nu/ktwr) followed tou\s polemi/ous. But, since the meaning of yau/wn is already indicated by mani/ais, we are not mentally straining forward for a clue to be given by e)n kert. glw/ssais. That is, we are not forced to bind the words, yau/wn to
 qeo/n, closely together in our thought, but can easily take the sentence as though it were pointed thus:— e)pe/gnw, mani/ais | yau/wn, to
 qeo/n, e/n kert. glw/ssais.
mani/ais, modal (rather than causal) dat.
yau/wn like kaqapto/menos (a)ntibi/ois e)pe/essi, Od. 18.415), but also suggesting profanation,—a)qi/ktou qigga/nwn.
glw/ssais, a bold use of the plur., due to the fact that the sing., with an adj., could so easily be fig., e.g. kakh\ glw=ssa=‘slander’: so kerto/mioi glw=ssai=‘taunts.’
pau/eske: see on 950.
e)nqe/ous gunai=kas: the Maenads attendant on Dionysus, cp. 1128, 1150, O. T. 212, O. C. 680.

eu)/ion … pu=r, the torches which the Bacchanals swing while they raise the cry eu)oi=. In O. T. 211 the god himself is eu)/ios. Cp. Eur. Bacch. 307 (Dionysus by night on Parnassus) phdw=nta su\n peu/kaisi diko/rufon pla/ka.

*mou/sas. An interesting illustration is afforded by a sarcophagus in Baumeister's Denkmaeler, p.837. In the centre of the group is the raging Lycurgus, with uplifted axe, about to slay the Dionysiac nymph Ambrosia, who cowers at his feet. A Fury is on each side of him, urging him on. To the right is Dionysus.—about to

save the nymph by changing her into a vine; and behind him stand his followers. At the extreme left are three Muses—Urania, with globe; Clio, with roll; Euterpè, prob. with flutes. (Zoega seems clearly right in thus explaining the three women: others have made them Moirae.)—The close relation of Dionysus with the Muses is marked by one of his Attic titles, *melpo/menos (Paus. 1.2.5), as conversely Apollo had the title *dionuso/dotos (id. 1. 31.4). Muses were sometimes said to have nursed him. (Cp. Welcker, Götterl. 2. 611.)

The monuments relating to the myth of Lycurgus have been critically treated by Michaelis (Annal. Inst. 1872, pp. 248— 270). The Italian vase-paintings follow a version different from that of Soph. , viz. that the frenzy of Lycurgus was wreaked on his own son and wife. A large Neapolitan vase gives two pictures: in one, we see his murderous rage; in the other, Dionysus sits on his throne in calm majesty, stroking his panther.

Cleopatra is the third example. Her father was the wind-god, Boreas: her mother, the Athenian Oreithyia, whom he carried off to his wild home in Thrace. Cleopatra married Phineus, king of the Thracian Salmydessus, on the W. coast of the Euxine, not far from the entrance to the Bosporus. She bore him two sons. He afterwards put her away, and imprisoned her. Her imprisonment is not directly mentioned here: but cp. Diod. 4. 44, who says of Heracles, when serving with the Argonauts, th\n *kleopa/tran e)k th=s fulakh=s proagagei=n. Phineus then married Eidothea, sister of Cadmus. Eidothea put out the eyes of Cleopatra's two sons, and caused them also to be imprisoned.

It is the fate of Cleopatra herself which Soph. means to compare with Antigone's: this is plain from 986. The fate of the sons is made so prominent only because nothing else could give us so strong a sense of the savage hatred which pursued the mother.

Soph. supposes the outline of the story to be familiar. Cleopatra has already been divorced and imprisoned. The poet chooses the moment at which Cleopatra's sons are being blinded by Eidothea, with the sharp shuttle in her blood-stained hands. Ares, the god of cruel bloodshed, beholds with joy a deed so worthy of his Thracian realm.

The name of Cleopatra (like that of Capaneus, 133) is not mentioned. Two strophes are given to this theme, partly, perh., as having an Attic interest (982). Soph. wrote two plays called *fineu/s. We know only that Cleopatra's sons were there called *)/oarqos (?*parqe/nios H. Weil) and *kra/mbos: and that the subsequent blindness of Phineus was represented as a punishment of his cruelty (schol. Apoll. Rhod. 2. 178). Eidothea was mentioned by Soph. in his *tumpanistai/ (schol. on 980),—a play which perh. concerned the Dionysiac worship, since the tu/mpanon (kettle-drum) was used in his o)/rgia as well as in those of Cybelè. Another version called her Idaea, daughter of Dardanus.

para\ de\ *kuanea=n pela/gei d. a(lo/s. For the double possessive gen., cp.795,929. pela/gei...a(lo/s, as Eur. Tro. 88 pe/lagos *ai)gai/as a(lo/s, the Homeric a(lo\s e)n pela/gessin, etc. The rocky islets on the N. side of the entrance from the Euxine to the Bosporus were regularly called *kua/neai simply (without nh=soi or pe/trai, Her. 4.85). L's petrw=n has long been recognised as a gloss. But Wieseler's change
of pelage/wn into spila/dwn is also erroneous.

L's accent, pela/gewn, points to the truth,—as similar small hints in that MS. have been found to do elsewhere also (cp. O. C. 1113 n.). The correction, pela/gei, is so easy that it may well have occurred to others; but I have not met with it. It removes the difficulty (insuperable, to my mind) of para/ with the genitive here. Those who read kuanea=n spila/dwn, or kuane/wn pelage/wn, are forced to take para/ as=‘extending from the dark rocks (etc.) are the coasts.’ But such a use is wholly unparalleled. As to 1123, see n. there. In Pind. P. 1. 75a)re/omai | pa\r me\n *salami=nos *)aqanai/wn xa/rin=‘from Salamis’ (i.e., by celebrating it). In Aristoph. Ach. 68 the Ravenna has e)truxo/mesqa para\ *kau/+stri/wn | pedi/wn o(doiplanou=ntes, while other MSS. have dia\ (also with gen. plur.); but there para\ *kau/+strion | pedi/on (Dindorf) is certain. In Pind. P. 3. 60gno/nta to\ pa\r podo/s, ‘having learned one's nearest business’ (cp. Pind. P. 10. 63), para/ has its normal sense,—‘that which begins from one's foot,’=which is directly before one in one's path. The corruption of pela/gei into pelage/wn naturally followed that of *kuanea=n into kuane/wn.

a)ktai\ *bospo/riai, sc. ei)si/ (cp. 948 n.). The *kua/neai are at the point where the coast of the Bosporus joins the western coast of the Euxine. The city Salmydessus stood just S. of the promontory of Thynias, about 60 miles N.W. of the entrance of the Bosporus, near the modern Midjeh. The name Salmydessus was given also to the tract of coast extending S. of the town.—After *qrh|kw=n a cretic has been lost (=-ton gona/n in 980). Boeckh supplies it with a)/cenos, which is at least simple and fitting. Cp. Aesch. PV 726 traxei=a po/ntou *salmudhssi/a gna/qos | e)xqro/cenos nau/taisi, mhtruia\ new=n. Schütz, referring to the schol. on 969, pe/lagos de/ e)sti dusxei/meron peri\ *qra/|khn, proposes du/sximos (‘dangerous’), a word used by Aesch. and Eur. , though not by Soph. But the want of a verb is somewhat awkward. Can the missing word be klh/|zetai? (Cp. O. T. 1451 n.: and for the sing., below, 1133.) Ships often grounded on the shallows (te/nagos) which stretched from Salmydessus into the Euxine. The Thracians had set up slabs (sth=lai), marking off the coast into allotments for wrecking purposes. Before this was done, there had been much bloodshed between rival wreckers (Xen. Anab. 7.5.13).—The MS. †h)d' cannot be right. A short syll. is required (=the last syll. of e)/xontes in 980). In my first ed. I adopted i)d', the conjecture of Triclinius. Prof. Tyrrell remarks (Class. Review vol. 11. p. 141) that i)de/ is not elsewhere elided in classical poetry. As h)de/ could be elided, that may be accidental. Still, it should be noted along with the other facts,—that i)de/ occurs nowhere else in tragedy, and that the hiatus after *bospo/riai must be excused, as in epic verse, by the ictus before caesura (Introd. to Homer p. 194): cp. Il. 14.175 a)leiyame/nh, i)de\ xai/tas | pecame/nh. On the whole, I now prefer to leave h)d', with an obelus. Either *bospo/riai kai\ o( or *bospo/riai/ q' o(/ te would be possible.

a)gxi/polis *)/arhs. This reading (L's) agrees metrically with the antistrophe (981 a)rxaiogo/nwn), if we suppose the 2nd and 3rd syllables of a)gxi/polis to represent a resolved long syllable. Such a resolution is rare, but not unexampled: see on 797 f.. We could avoid it by reading, with Gleditsch, a)ktai\ *bospo/riai, i(/n' o( *qrh|kw=n a)/cenos | *salmudhsso\s *)/arhs t' a)gxi/polis. But (a) this does not explain how h)d' came into the MSS.: and (b) it is evidently better to say, ‘where Ares saw,’ than, ‘where Salmydessus and Ares saw.’ The reference to the god's cruel joy would thus lose much of its force. If, on the other hand, a)gxi/ptolis is read, then *)/arhs has a_, and in 981 we must suppose the loss of a syllable after a)rxaiogo/nwn. But such a loss is very improbable: that verse appears sound. Neither a)/gxouros nor a)rxe/polis has any likelihood.—Ares is ‘neighbour to the city’ of Salmydessus because his home is in Thrace (Il. 13.301, etc.). There may also be a special reference to some local shrine. ‘He saw the wound dealt’: i.e., it was a deed such as he loves to see.
*finei/+dais, dat. of interest, with tuflwqe/n.

a)rato/n, accursed, bringing a curse on the authors of the wound. In his dramatic treatment of the story, Soph. had connected this blinding of the sons with the punishment of blindness which the gods afterwards inflicted on Phineus himself (schol. Apoll. Rhod. 2. 178).

e(/lkos tuflwqe/n. tuflou=n e(/lkos=to inflict a blinding wound. Cp. Ai. 55 e)/keire... fo/non, he dealt death by hewing down. Eur. Suppl. 1205 trw/sh|s fo/non, (wherever) thou dealest the death-wound. Verg. Aen. 11. 82 caeso sparsuros sanguine flammam (caedere sanguinem = to shed blood by cutting). In such pregnant idioms the special verb=a general verb plus the partic. of the special verb used instrumentally: e.g., tuflw= e(/lkos = poiw= e(/lkos tuflw=n.
e)c here=u(po/ of the direct agent: for, as kerki/dwn indicates, she did it with her own hand. Distinguish e)k *dionu/sou in 957 (by his order).
a)lao\n … ku/klois, sightless for the orbs, i.e., making them sightless. Cp. Pind. O. 1. 26kaqarou= le/bhtos, the purifying cauldron.

a)lasto/roisin. The form a)la/storos was used by Aesch. as =a)la/stwr (fr. 87 preumenh\sa)., fr. 286 me/gan a).). The form may have been generally current, since Pherecydes used *zeu\s *)ala/storos instead of *z. *)ala/stwr (Cramer Anecd. 1. 62). The blind orbs are a)la/storoi, ‘avenging spirits,’ in the sense that they mutely appeal to the gods for vengeance.—For the parh/xhsis (O. T. 371) Wolff cp. Il. 6.201 ka\p pedi/on to\ *)alh/i+on oi)=os a)la=to.
a)raxqe/ntwn. So a)ra/ssw is used of Oed. striking his eyes with the pero/nai (O. T. 1276).
u(po/ with dat. of the instrument, as in the epic u(po\ xersi\ damh=nai, O. T. 202 u(po\ sw=| fqi/son keraunw=|.

kerki/dwn, poet. plur. for sing., like bwmoi/, skh=ptra, etc.—The kerki/s (kre/kw, to strike the web in weaving) was ‘like a large netting needle’ (Rich s.v. radius), ‘rather longer than the breadth of the web.’ It was used for two purposes. (1) As a rod with which to strike the threads of the woof, in order to condense them. The flat blade called spa/qh was a later substitute. In the modern loom this is done by the moveable bar called the ‘batten.’ (2) As a shuttle, i.e., an instrument for shooting the threads of the woof (kro/kh) from one side of the loom to the other, between the threads of the warp (sth/mwn). In the East weavers sometimes use a long reed for both these purposes. Eur. Tro. 198 ou)k *)idai/ois i(stoi=s kerki/da | dineu/ous' e)calla/cw (‘no more,
at the loom, will I send the shuttle flying across the warp’).—Cp. Eur. Hec. 1170, where the women blind Polymestor with their brooches (po/rpai = pero/nai); and O. T. 1269 n.
kata/ in tmesis, as O. T. 1198, O. C. 1689, etc.—katatako/menoi alludes to their imprisonment; cp. schol. on 980 tuflw/sasa tou\s *kleopa/tras pai=das e)n ta/fw| kaqei=rcen.
me/leoi mele/an: cp. 156: O. T. 479.

matro\s e)/xontes a)n. gona/n, having their origin from an unhappily-married mother. The epithet is made to agree with gona/n, not with matro/s, as in 793, nei=kos-a)ndrw=n cu/naimon: i.e., mhtro\sgonh/, mother-source, forms one notion. For gona\s e)/xein cp. O. C. 972 o(\s ou)/te bla/stas pw geneqli/ous patro/s, | ou) mhtro\s ei)=xon. For a)nu/mf., cp. Tr. 144 a)/loxoi me/leai...kai\ du/snumfoi: Hipp. 757kakonumfota/tan o)/nasin (‘to bless her with a marriage most unblest’). O. T. 1214 a)/gamon ga/mon.—The comma should not be placed after matro/s, which is inseparable from the following phrase. Without matro/s, the words e)/xontes a)nu/mfeuton gona/n could still mean, ‘born from one who was unhappily married,’ but would be harsh and obscure. The word pa/qan refers to their own fate. Then matro\s … gona/n supplements this by indicating that they mourn for their mother's fate also.
spe/rma, acc. of respect; Od. 15.267 e)c *)iqa/khs ge/nos ei)mi/.
a)rxaiog.: Ai. 202 genea=s xqoni/wn a)p' *)erexqeidw=n.

a)/ntas' *)er., attained unto them, could trace her lineage to them,—her mother Oreithyia being the daughter of Erechtheus. Remark that the acc. spe/rma mitigates the boldness of a)/ntase, and also suggests its primary meaning—viz., that the genealogy is carried back to a point at which it meets the Erechtheid line. Cp. Her. 2.143 (Hecataeus) genehlogn/santi/ te e(wuto
 kai\ a)nadh/santi th
 patrih
 e)s e(kkaide/katon qeo/n.

thlepo/rois, merely poet. for ‘distant’; lit., to which it is a far journey. Not (I think), ‘spacious’ (i.e. ‘in which one can go far’): nor, ‘extending far into the mountains.’ So in Ai. 564, thlwpo\s oi)xnei=, the adj. is merely ‘distant’; it has not its full sense, ‘seen afar.’ Boreas carried Oreithyia to a region of Thrace which the poets called ‘Sarpêdon’ (we see the association with a(rpa/zw)—not, seemingly, the promontory called ‘Sarpedonion,’ on the S. coast, but in the wilds of Haemus. It is of this that Soph. is thinking here: cp. fr. 575 h(mei=s d' e)n a)/ntrois, e)/nqa *sarphdw\n pe/tra. That verse is from the *tumpanistai/, in which the story of Cleopatra was noticed (cp. on 966); and she was probably the speaker. Oreithyia bore two sons to Boreas, Calais and Zetes; and, besides Cleopatra, another daughter, Chionè.

a(/mippos, swift as horses. Cp. O. T. 466 a)ella/dwn | i(/ppwn, ‘storm-swift steeds.’ In prose a(/mippoi=foot-soldiers who, in the Boeotian army, were sometimes told off to run alongside the cavalry (Thuc. 5.57, Xen. Hellen. 7.5.23). Cp. Theogn. 715 w)ku/teros d' ei)/hsqa po/das taxew=n *(arpuiw=n | kai\ pai/dwn *bore/w.

o)rqo/podos, steep. o)rqo/pous, ‘erect upon one's feet,’ seems to be here merely a poet. equiv. (suggested by metrical convenience) for o)/rqios. This was the more natural, since pou/s, knh/mh, etc., were so oft. said of mountains. In O. T. 866 u(yi/podes, said of the eternal no/moi, differs from o)rqo/pous here by implying movement (‘of sublime range’). We need not, then, explain o)rqo/pous as=o)/rqios toi=s tou= a)nabai/nontos posi/.

ka)p' e)kei/na| … e)/sxon = kai\ e)kei/nh| e)/pesxon, from the intrans. e)pe/xw as=‘to direct (one's course) against a person,’ ‘to attack him’: cp. Od. 19.71 ti/ moi w)=d' e)pe/xeis kekotho/ti qumw=|; (‘assail me’): ib. 22. 75 e)p' au)tw=| pa/ntes e)/xwmen (‘let us all have at him’).—Others understand, ‘extended even to her,’ ‘reached her,’ which mars the personification.—makrai/wnes: Aesch. Eum. 172 palaigenei=s... *moi/ras.

div2.p: Fifth e)peiso/dion. Teiresias denounces the divine wrath. Creon, terror-stricken, hastens to bury Polyneices and to release Antigone.

div3.p: a)/naktes: cp. 843, 940.—du/' e)c e(no\s bl., two seeing by the agency of one (e)k as in 973): cp. O. C. 33 th=s u(pe/r t' e)mou= | au(th=s q' o(rw/shs. The words would usu. mean, ‘two seeing, where only one saw formerly.’ Cp. O. C. 1764, where the regular sense of pra/ssein kalw=s, ‘to fare well,’ has not hindered the poet from using it as=‘to do rightly.’

au(/th k., the blind have this kind of walking appointed for them,— viz., walking with the help of a guide. au(/th k. = au(/th h( k. (O. C. 471): ke/leuqos is not predicate (like pau=lan in O. C. 88), as if the sense were, ‘this (au(/th for tou=to) is walking for the blind,—viz. to walk with a guide.’ We do not need the art. h( with e)k, because pe/lei=not simply ‘is,’ but, ‘is possible.’ Cp. O. C. 848 ou)/koun pot' e)k (by means of) tou/toin ge mh\ skh/ptroin e)/ti | o(doiporh/sh|s (the blind Oed.'s daughters).
ti/ d' e)/stin: cp. 20 n.
ou)/koun … ge: cp. 321 n.

di' o)rqh=s, sc. o(dou=. A rare instance of the fem. adj. in such a phrase with dia/, which regularly takes a subst. (742 n.); but it follows the analogy of the freq. phrases with e)k, as e)c eu)qei/as: Tr. 395 e)k taxei/as, 727 e)c e(kousi/as: Thuc. 3.92 e)k kainh=s: Her. 5.116 e)k ne/hs, 6. 85 e)c u(ste/rhs, 8. 6 e)k th=s a)nti/hs, etc.

e)nauklh/reis is right. The seer hopes, indeed, that the mischief can still be repaired (1025 ff.), but he thinks that Creon has made a disastrous mistake (1015). He could hardly say, then, di' o)rqh=s...nauklhrei=s. Creon has only just become king; but he had formerly been regent for some years (cp. O. T. 1418). Aesch. has the verb in this fig. sense ( Aesch. Th. 652). Cp. 167 w)/rqou: O. T. 104 a)peuqu/nein: ib. 923 kubernh/thn.

peponqw\s o)nh/sima, e)/xw marturei=n (peponqe/nai). We could say, marturw= soi eu)ergeth/santi (like su/noida): but less well, marturw= eu)= peponqw/s. Cp. O. C. 1128 ei)dw\s d' a)mu/nw toi=sde toi=s lo/gois ta/de, with like emphasis on the partic., ‘I have felt these benefits which I thus requite.’

fro/nei bebw/s, bethink thee that thou art placed. O. C. 1358 e)n po/nw| | ... bebhkw/s, n. Il. 10.173 nu=n ga\r dh\ pa/ntessin e)pi\ curou= i(/statai a)kmh=s, | h)\ ma/la lugro\s o)/leqros *)axaioi=s, h)e\ biw=nai. H.F. 630 w)=d' e)/bht' e)pi\ curou=; Helen. 897 e)p' a)kmh=s ei)mi\ katqano/nt' i)dei=n.
tu/xhs, interpreting curou=, adds dignity and solemnity to the phrase.
w(s, exclamatory. El. 1112 ti/ d' e)/stin, w)= ce/n'; w(/s m' u(pe/rxetai fo/bos.
qa=kon. Paus. (9. 16. 1) saw at Thebes, near the temple of Zeus Ammon, oi)wnoskopei=on...*teiresi/ou kalou/menon. Near it was a shrine of *tu/xh.

limh/n, a place to which the birds came: schol. o(/rmos kai\ e(/dra, o(/pou pa/nta ta\ o)/rnea prose/rxontai. Cp. Eur. Or. 1077 kai\ dw=ma patro\s kai\ me/gas plou/tou limh/n (‘receptacle’): Aesch. applied the same phrase to Persia ( Aesch. Pers. 250). Omens were taken, not only from the flight of birds, but also from the positions in which they settled,—from their sounds, —and from their mode of feeding. The limh/n means a place to which they were lured by food, so that their sunedri/ai (Aesch. PV 492), and the other signs, could be noted. Cp. H. A. 9. 1 o(/qen kai\ ta\s diedri/as kai\ ta\s sunedri/as oi( ma/nteis lamba/nousi, di/edra me\n ta\ pole/mia tiqe/ntes, su/nedra de\ ta\ ei)rhnou=nta pro\s a)/llhla.—Herwerden conjectures ou)ranou= limh/n, understanding a space of sky chosen as a field of augural observation (templum).
kakw=|, ill-omened (O.C. 1433).
oi)/strw|, ‘gad-fly,’ then fig., ‘rage,’ a word which often suggests divine stimulation: as Heracles asks, pou= d' oi)=stros h(ma=s e)/labe; ( H. F. 1144).

kla/zontas, since fqo/ggon o)rni/qwn = o)/rniqas fqeggome/nous: Il. 17.755 tw=n d' w(/ste yarw=n ne/fos e)/rxetai h)e\ koloiw=n | ou)=lon keklh/gontes: Od. 12.181 a)ll' o(/te to/sson a)ph=n (sc. h( nhu=s) o(/sson te ge/gwne boh/sas, | r(i/mfa diw/kontes.

bebarbarwme/nw|. To the seer, the voices of birds were usually eu)/shmoi (1021). Conversely the sound of a strange language is likened to the twittering of birds: Her. 2.57 e(/ws de\ e)barba/rize (h( gunh/), o)/rniqos tro/pon e)do/kee/ sfi fqe/ggesqai. Aesch. used xelidoni/zein as=barbari/zein (fr. 440, cp. Aesch. Ag. 1050).

e)n xhlai=sin, ‘with’ them: 764 n. —fonai=s, an adverbial dat. of manner, murderously.’ Cp. O. C. 1318 eu)/xetai kataskafh=| | *kapaneu\s to\ *qh/bhs a)/stu dh|w/sein puri/, where the first dat. is one of manner, like fonai=s here, and the second (instrumental) answers to e)n xhlai=sin. Elsewhere the Attic use of the subst. is limited to the phrase e)n fonai=s (696 n.). The Schol. has fonai=s: tai=s ai(maktikai=s: as though it were from an adj. fono/s. So some recent edd. take it. Such an adj. could have come from the rt. fen, but there is no trace of it.

The feuds and friendships of birds (e)/xqrai te kai\ ste/rghqra Aesch. PV 492) were among the signs noted by augurs. In this case there was a vague omen of bloodshed (fonai=s), but no clear sign. The seer now sought further light by another mode of divination.

e)mpu/rwn, sc. i(erw=n, burnt-sacrifice; where the omen was given by the manner in which the fire dealt with the offering. Eur. Suppl. 155 ma/nteis d' e)ph=lqes, e)mpu/rwn t' ei)=des flo/ga; Phoen. 954e)mpu/rw| xrh=tai te/xnh|. I. T. 16 ei)s e)/mpur' h)=lqe (had recourse to). This was h( di' e)mpu/rwn mantei/a, ignispicium, while i(eroskopi/a=haruspicina, divination by inspecting entrails. In , Aesch. P. V. 488—499, vv. 488—492 concern o)rniqomantei/a: vv. 493—5, i(eroskopi/a: and vv. 496—9, e)/mpura.
e)geuo/mhn, proceeded to make trial of: Tr. 1101 mo/xqwn muri/wn e)geusa/mhn: Plat. Rep. 475C panto\s maqh/matos geu/esqai.

pamfle/ktoisi, fully kindled. Fuel was placed around the offerings on the altar, and ignited at several points. The epithet marks that the failure of the rite was not due to any negligence.— quma/twn. The offering consisted of thighbones cut from a sheep (or ox), with some of the flesh adhering to them, and wrapped round with a double covering of fat. On the top of these thigh-bones were laid parts of the victim's intestines (spla/gxna), including the gall-bladder (xolh/).

*(/hfaistos = pu=r (n. on 120 ff.). It was a good sign if the fire at once seized on the offering, and blazed up in clear flames (Apoll. Rhod. 1. 436 se/las... | pa/ntose lampo/menon que/wn a)/po). It was

a bad sign, if the fire was smothered in smoke, or played feebly around the flesh without consuming it. See Eur. Phoen. 1255 ma/nteis de\ mh=l' e)/sfazon, e)mpu/rous t' a)kma\s | r(h/ceis t' e)nw/mwn, u(gro/tht' e)nanti/an, | a)/kran te lampa/d', h(\ duoi=n o(/rous e)/xei, | vi/khs te sh=ma kai\ to\ tw=n h(sswme/nwn: the seers ‘were watching for points of flame, or for breaks in it,—such flickering as portends evil’; i.e., they were watching to see whether it would blaze up or die down. The a)/kra lampa/s is prob. the highest point of the fire, which, if towards the right side, meant victory; if towards the left, defeat. So Statius, Theb. 10. 599, where Teiresias offers e)/mpura, and his daughter reports the signs to him (as the pai=s does here): Sanguineos flammarum apices (=e)mpu/rous a)kma/s) geminumque per aras | Ignem, et clara tamen mediae fastigia lucis (=a)/kran lampa/da) | Orta docet: tunc in speciem serpentis inanem | Ancipiti gyro volvi (‘as if creeping on its way without an aim, the fire played timidly around the offering’). In Seneca Oed. 307 Teiresias asks, Quid flamma? Larga iamne comprendit dapes? | Utrumne clarus ignis et nitidus stetit, | Rectusque purum verticem caelo tulit, | An latera circum serpit incertus viae, | Et fluctuante turbidus fumo labat?
