The fat wrapped about the thigh-bones ought to have caught fire, when the flesh on the bones would have been burned, and the bones themselves calcined. But here there was no flame; the kindled fuel lay in smouldering embers (spodo/s). The heat caused a fatty moisture to exude from the covering of the thigh-bones. Trickling forth on the embers, this moisture emitted smoke, and sputtered as it threw particles of the fat upwards. The gall-bladder, too, which lay on the top of the thighbones, instead of catching fire, was gradually inflated by the heat, till it burst, scattering the gall into the air. And now the melting of the fat which covered the thigh-bones had gone so far that it was no longer a covering, but merely a liquid that was streaming off them, while they themselves were left naked and intact. So utterly had the gods refused the offering.
mudw=sa: cp. 410: O. T. 1278 fo/nou mudw/sas stago/nas.

khki\s mhri/wn, a moisture exuding from them. For mhri/a see on 1011. Cp. Aesch. Cho. 268 e)n khki=di pissh/rei flogo/s, pitchy ooze of flame, i.e., the funeral-fire of pine-wood from which pitch oozes. We might perh. join mhri/wn e)th/keto, ‘was distilled from them’: but the other constr. is simpler, and th/kesqai/ tinos is not found elsewhere.
e)th/keto here=exuded: it goes with e)pi\ spodw=| (the embers of the fuel placed around the offering).
a)ne/ptue, as particles of the fat crackled and were tossed upward on contact with the smouldering fire.

xolai/. Arist. always uses the sing. xolh/ for the gall-bladder. In Plat. Tim. 82E xola/s=‘kinds of bile,’ the xolh=s ei)/dh of 83 C. Here there was a metrical motive (diespei/ronto) for the plur., which denotes not merely the gallbladder, but also the gall dispersed from it. The gall-bladder, and the lobe of the liver, afforded omens, by colour and form, in i(eroskopi/a (1005 n.): Aesch. PV 495 xolh=s lobou= te poiki/lhn eu)morfi/an: cp. Eur. El. 827 ff. But here, in e)/mpura, the xolh/ was simply a part of the burnt-offering,—added to the mhri/a, because otherwise associated with divination. Cp. the unknown poet in Clemens Strom.p. 851 (it is vain to think that the gods rejoice) o)stw=n a)sa/rkwn kai\ xolh=s puroume/nhs. So, too, Menander ap. Athen. 146 E oi( de\ th
 o)sfu
 a)/kran | kai\ th
 xolh
 o)sta= t' a)/brwta toi=s qeoi=s | e)piqe/ntes au)toi\ ta)/lla katapi/nous' a)ei/.

katarruei=s, running down, dripping, with the fat which was melting off them: Schol. katarreo/menoi, kaqugraino/menoi. This use of the adj. is parallel with a frequent use of the verb, as Eur. Tro. 15 qew=n a)na/ktora | fo/nw| katarrei=: Il. 8.65 r(e/e d' ai)/mati gai=a: Eur. Bacch. 142 r(ei= de\ ga/lakti pe/don, etc.—katarruei=s could also mean, ‘slipping down’; but it does not appear that the mhroi/ were displaced; they were merely bared.

mhroi/ … mhri/wn in 1008,—thighbones, with some flesh on them. mhro/s is the ordinary word for ‘thigh.’ mhri/a was the sacrificial word, denoting thighbones, with so much flesh as the sacrificer chose to leave upon them. The tendency to give the gods more bone than meat is noticed by the poets quoted on v. 1010 (o)stw=n a)sa/rkwn—o)sta= a)/brwta), and by Hes. Th. 556(where men offer o)ste/a leuka/ to the gods),— as it is implied in the story there told, of Prometheus giving the worst parts of the ox to Zeus, and keeping the best for men. Since the bone was an essential part of the offering, mhri/a cannot be merely, ‘slices cut from the thighs.’ In the Homeric phrase, kata\ pi/ona mhri/a kai/ein, the word means, like mhroi/ here, thigh-bones wrapped in fat, the kni/sh|... kw=la sugkalupta/ of Aesch. PV 496. In Od. 3.456 e)k mhri/a ta/mnon | pa/nta kata\ moi=ran, the phrase is equiv. to the mhrou\s e)ce/tamon of the Il.(1. 460 etc.); i.e., mhri/a includes the bones. Only one ox is there in question, but pa/nta=‘completely.’ The Hom. mh=ra = mhri/a (Il. 1.464).

kalupth=s=‘which had been wrapped round them’; cp. Il. 21.321 to/sshn oi( a)/sin kaqu/perqe kalu/yw, ‘so thick a covering of silt will I lay on him.’ This is better than to make the adj. active, ‘covering,’ like mempto/s, ‘blaming’ (Tr. 446: cp. O. T. 969 n.).

pimelh=s (pi/wn), prop., soft fat (adeps), as dist. from ste/ar, stiff fat, tallow (sebum). The fat was laid in a double layer round the mhri/a: Il. 1.460 mhrou/s t' e)ce/tamon kata/ te kni/sh| e)ka/luyan, | di/ptuxa poih/santes. So human bones are wrapped di/plaki dhmw=|, Il. 23.243.— e)ce/keinto, lay outside of, i.e., had been bared of, the fat.
toiau=ta, adverbially with fqi/nonta: cp. 848 oi(/a n.

o)rgi/wn manteu/mata, ‘oracles derived from rites,’ —the predictions which he could have made if the rites had given him a sign. They gave none; and so his hopes of reading the future came to nought (fqi/nonta: cp. O. T. 906 fqi/nonta... | qe/sfata). Cp. Tr. 765 (where Heracles offers burnt sacrifice) o(/pws de\ semnw=n o)rgi/wn e)dai/eto | flo\c ai(mathra/.

a)sh/mwn, not giving the flogwpa\ sh/mata (Aesch. PV 498) which burnt offerings can yield. Such signs might be good or evil, according to the aspects of the fire (cp. 1007 n.). But here the fire had refused to burn at all. Like the birds, these rites also had left him without any definite sign—though with a strengthened presentiment of evil.
h(gemw/n. Cp. Statius Theb. 10. 603: the daughter of Teiresias describes the omens to him, patriasque illuminat umbras.
e)k, of cause, as O. C. 620 e)k smikrou= lo/gou. Cp. 957, 973.
freno/s, counsel, as 993.
nosei=, i.e., has incurred a mi/asma: cp. 1141.
bwmoi/, the public altars of the gods, usu. raised on a base (krhpi/s) with steps (cp. 854, O. T. 182).

e)sxa/rai, portable braziers, used in private houses either for sacrifice to household deities (esp. *(esti/a), or for purposes of cooking. Harpocration s.v. quotes Ammonius of Lamprae (an Attic writer of the 1st cent. A.D. , who left a treatise *peri\ bwmw=n kai\ qusiw=n):—e)sxa/ran fhsi\ kalei=sqai th\n mh\ e)/xousan u(/yos,...a)ll' e)pi\ gh=s i/drume/nhn. It stood on four legs, instead of having a pedestal like the bwmo/s (Ross Inscrr. 3. 52 e)sxa/ran tetra/podon). It was used in sacrifice to the h(/rwes, who, not being qeoi/, had no claim to bwmoi/: Pollux 1. 8 e)sxa/ra d' i)dikw=s dokei= w)noma/sqai, e)f' h(=s toi=s h(/rwsin a)poqu/omen.

pantelei=s, in their full tale, ‘one and all.’ So o(lo/klhroi or o(losxerei=s could be used, where the notion was that of a total to which no unit was lacking.—Not, ‘receiving i(era\ te/leia’; nor, ‘serving for all rites’ (te/lh).

plh/reis (ei)si/n) are defiled, u(p' oi)wn. k. kunw=n, by birds and dogs, bora=s tou=...*oi)d. go/nou, with their food, (torn) from the son of Oed. This sense of plh/rhs belongs also to ple/ws and mesto/s, but esp. to a)na/plews, as to a)napi/mplhmi. The fig. sense of plh/reis might here allow us to take u(po/ with bora=s, but it goes more naturally with the agents. For the gen. go/nou, describing the source or material of the bora/, cp. Aesch. Ag. 1220 krew=n...oi)kei/as bora=s, food supplied by their own flesh (oi)kei/as instead of oi)kei/wn: cp. above, 793). dusmo/rou, adverbially with peptw=tos, instead of dusmo/rws: cp. 823 lugrota/tan o)le/sqai, n. —Two other constructions are possible. (1) tou= … go/nou in appos. with bora=s: ‘their food,—viz., the son’: cp. 1040 bora\n | fe/rein nin. But this seems forced, when the reference is to dispersed morsels of his flesh. (2) tou= … go/nou as gen. absol., ‘as,’ or ‘since,’ he has fallen. Such a gen, absol., however, ought here to express, not, ‘as he has fallen,’ but, ‘as he has been left unburied.’
ka)=|t', ‘and then,’ here=‘and so.’ It usually means, ‘and after that,’ i.e., ‘and nevertheless’ (O. C. 418).

qusta/das, accompanying sacrifice: Aesch. Theb. 269 *(ellhniko\n no/misma qusta/dos boh=s. Cp. Il. 9.499 kai\ me\n tou\s (the gods) que/essi kai\ eu)xwlh=|s a)ganh=|sin | loibh=| te kni/sh| te paratrwpw=s' a)/nqrwpoi | lisso/menoi.

o(/rni^s, as Il. 24.219; El. 149; H. F. 72, fr. 637: Ar. Av. 168 (v.l. ti/s o)/rnis ou(=tos, a quotation from tragedy: v.l. ti/s ou(=tos o)/rnis;). But o)/rni_s (Eur. Bacch. 1364, Aristoph. Av. 833, etc.) is said to have been normal in Attic. —The ruggedness of the rhythm gives a certain impressive slowness, perhaps purposed. When an iambic verse has no caesura in the 3rd or in the 4th foot, it almost always has the ‘quasi-caesura’ (elision) after the 3rd foot (as if eu)sh/mous were eu)fhmou=s'). For other exceptions, cp. Ai. 1091 *mene/lae, mh\ gnw/mas u(posth/sas sofa/s: Ph. 101, Ph. 1064, Ph. 1369: Aesch. Pers. 509 *qrh/|khn pera/santes mo/gis pollw=| po/nw|.
eu)sh/mous: cp. on 1002.
bebrw=tes, as if pa/ntes o)/rniqes sigw=si had preceded. Cp. Her. 1.87 w(s w(/ra pa/nta me\n a)/ndra sbennu/nta to\ pu=r, duname/nous de\ ou)ke/ti katalabei=n.
a)ndrofqo/rou. a)ndro/fqoron ai(=ma = a)ndro\s e)fqarme/nou ai(=ma: cp. Ph. 208au)da\ trusa/nwr: O. C. 711, n. on au)/xhma eu)/ippon.
e)pei/, instead of e)pa/n, with subjunct.: O. C. 1225. The subject to a(ma/rth| (a)nh/r, or tis) is quickly supplied by the next clause.
a)/nolbos, of folly, as Ai. 1156: so du/spotmos, O. T. 888.
a)kei=tai. Il. 13.115 a)ll' a)kew/meqa qa=sson: a)kestai/ toi fre/nes e)sqlw=n.

a)ki/nhtos: cp. O. T. 336 a)/tegktos. Plat. Tim. 51E to\ me\n a)ei\ meta\ a)lhqou=s lo/gou, to\ de\ a)/logon: kai\ to\ me\n a)ki/nhton peiqoi=, to\ de\ metapeisto/n. Il. 15.203 h)/ ti metastre/yeis; streptai\ me/n te fre/nes e)sqlw=n.

au)qadi/a (poet. for au)qa/deia), self-will, incurs the reproach of skaio/ths (for o)fliska/nei cp. 470). As decio/s is a quick-witted man, of flexible and receptive mind, so skaio/s is one whose mental clumsiness makes him unapt to learn. skaio/ths, ‘ineptitude,’ is often associated with ignorance and with inaccessibility to new ideas. Cp. Plat. Rep. 411E; one who omits to cultivate his mind acts bi/a|...kai\ a)grio/thti, w(/sper qhri/on..., kai\ e)n a)maqi/a| kai\ skaio/thti meta\ a)rruqmi/as te kai\ a)xaristi/as zh=|. Lys. or. 10 § 15 h(gou=mai...tou=ton...ou(/tw skaio\n ei(=nai w(/ste ou) du/nasqai maqei=n ta\ lego/mena. Aristoph. Vesp. 1183 w)= skaie\ ka)pai/deute. So here skaio/ths expresses a stupidity that is deaf to remonstrance.

ei)=ke tw=| qano/nti, ‘make a concession to the dead,’ i.e., give him the burial rites which are his due. It is not as if he were a living foe, and prowess (a)lkh/) could be shown by resisting his claim. The words tw=| qano/nti have been groundlessly suspected (see cr. n.).

ke/ntei, stab. Cp. the scene in the Iliad where the Greeks prick Hector's corpse with their swords; Il. 22.371 ou)d' a)/ra oi(/ tis a)nouthti/ ge pare/sth: and ib. 24. 421. For kentei=n of cowardly or treacherous wounding, cp. Ai. 1244 h(ma=s h)\ kakoi=s balei=te/ pou | h)\ su\n do/lw| kenth/seq' oi( leleimme/noi.

e)piktanei=n, ‘slay anew.’ In comp. with verbs of killing, e)pi/ usu.= either ‘in addition’ (O. C. 1733 e)pena/<*>oicon, n.), or ‘over’ a grave, etc., as usu. <*>pisfa/ttein: but cp. 1288: Laert. Diog. 2. 17§ 135 (Menedemus) *bi/wnos...e)pimelw=s katatre/xontos tw=n ma/ntewn nekrou\s au)to\s e)pisfa/ttein e)/lege. Cp. Soph. Ph. 946e)nai/rwn nekro/n.

eu)= fronh/sas, having conceived kindly thoughts; a very rare use of the aor. part. in this sense, instead of eu)= fronw=n. The aor. part. of frone/w usu. means, (1) ‘having come to a sound mind,’ O. T. 649, and so Isocr. or. 8. § 141, eu)= fronh/santas: (2) ‘having formed a project,’ as Her. 7.145: (3) in the phrase tw)uto\ (or ta\ au)ta\) fronh/santes, ‘having come to an agreement,’ Her. 1.60, 5. 72.
manqa/nein d': for the elision (e)pisunaloifh/) see O. T. 29 n.: and cp. above, 350.
ei) … le/goi: for the optative in the gnw/mh, see 666 n. With h(/diston we supply e)sti/, as in O. T. 315.
w(/ste = w(s: O.C. 343.—skopou=, sc. toceu/ousi: the gen. as with stoxa/zomai: so Il. 4.100 o)i/+steuson *menela/ou: 14. 402 *ai)/antos de\ prw=tos a)ko/ntise. Cp. 241.

kou)de\ mantikh=s k.t.l.: not even by seer-craft do ye leave me unattempted: in your plots against me ye resort even to seer-craft. Two points in this phrase are notable. (1) a)/praktos =‘not worked,’ in the sense of, ‘not plotted against.’ pra/ssein oft.=‘to intrigue’; and ‘to intrigue against one’ might be expressed by pra/sseipperi/ tinos, or e)pi/ tini, though e)pibouleu/o tini/ is the usu. phrase. But, while e)pibouleu/omai had a personal pass. use (to be plotted against’), we could not say pra/ssontai, ‘they are the objects of an intrigue.’ a)/praktos is therefore bolder than its prose equivalent, a)nepibou/leutos. Still, for poetry, it seems possible. (2) mantikh=s. Such a gen., joined to a verbal adj. with a privative, more often denotes the agent, answering to a gen. with u(po/ after a pass. verb, or to the subject of an act. verb: cp. 847: Tr. 685 a)kti=nos...a)/qikton (untouched by the ray). Here, the instrument, mantikh/, is, in fact, personified as the agent: i.e., mantikh=s does not correspond to the instrum. dat. in kai\ mantikh=| pra/ssete peri\ e)mou=, but to the nom. in kai\ mantikh\ pra/ssei peri\ e)mou= u(mi=n (ye have even seer-craft practising on me). An easier reading would be mantikh=|. The instrumental dat. is often retained with the negative verbal; as Plat. Symp. 219E xrh/masi...ma=llon a)/trwtos h)\ sidh/rw|: fr. com. anon. 52 a)nepibouleu/tou fqo/nw|. But poetical usage seems to warrant mantikh=s.—The conjecture a)/pratos (see Appendix) would forestall the taunt which now forms the climax, e)chmpo/lhmai.

tw=n d' u(pai\ ge/nous, ‘by the tribe of those men.’—the ma/nteis implied in mantikh=s. Creon, though he addresses Teiresias, is speaking as much to the Chorus as to him. If we read tw=n (without d'), as relative, it would naturally

refer to u(mi=n: it could hardly refer to mantikh=s. The conjecture of Semitelos, mantikoi=s, would then be attractive. But such a substitute for ma/ntesi would be very strange. And, if we keep L's tw=n d', the scornful demonstrative sufficiently interprets the reference to ma/nteis.
u(pai/ in trimeters, as El. 711: Aesch. Ag. 892, 944, Eum. 417.
ge/nous: cp. 1055.—For other views of the passage, see Appendix.

e)chmpo/lhmai. Creon means: ‘The Thebans have bribed Teiresias to frighten me. He has taken their money. In return, he is to deliver me into their hands. I am like a piece of merchandise which has been sold for export, and put on board the buyer's ship.’ Cp. 1063. Her. 1.1 e)cempolhme/nwn (Ion.) sfi sxedo\n pa/ntwn, when they had sold off almost everything.—Neither e)mforti/zomai nor e)kforti/zomai occurs elsewhere, except that an old glossary (cited by Dind.) gives e)ceforti/sato, exoneravit (‘unladed’). In later Greek we find e)mfortou=sqai nau=n, e)/mfortos, and e)kfortou=n (both act. and midd.). Here, e)mpefo/rtismai, the reading of the first hand in L, marks the completion of the sale by the delivery of the goods. The Schol. quotes Callimachus (fr. 529), e)poih/santo/ me fo/rton.—The correction in L, e)kpefo/rtismai, is far inferior. It would mean, ‘unladed (as a cargo) from a ship’: not, ‘made into a cargo,’ nor, ‘exported as a cargo.’—In Tr. 537 there is a like association of e)mpo/lhma and fo/rtos (though the passage is not otherwise similar). Cp. Shaks. Com. Err. 3. 1. 72 ‘It would make a man mad as a buck, to be so bought and sold.’

ta)po\ *sa/rdewn h)/lektron: electron, or silver-gold, from the goldmines of Tmolus in Lydia, the range s. of Sardis. Croesus dedicated at Delphi a lion of refined gold (xruso\s a)/pefqos), standing on a pedestal formed by 117 half-plinths, or ingots, of gold,—four being of refined gold, and the rest of this electron, or ‘white gold’ (leuko\s xruso/s); Her. 1.50. The celebrity of this a)na/qhma in Greece helps to explain the poet's phrase. Stein on Her.l.c. shows that the ratio of silver to gold in electron was about 3 to 7. Pliny, who makes the ratio only 1 to 4, describes electron both as a natural blend of metals, and as an artificial product (fit et cura, … addito argento, Her. 33.80).— Paus. 5. 12§ 7 distinguishes the two senses of h)/lektron, (1) silver-gold, (2) amber. The latter is the h)/lektron of Herodotus (3. 115), and of Od. 15.460, where a Phoenician brings a golden o(/rmos, —meta\ d' h)le/ktroisin e)/erto (‘strung with amber beads’).
ta)po\ is a certain correction of L's ta\ pro (cr. n.): in class. Greek h)/lektron is always neut., as it is in Paus. also.
*)indiko\n xruso/n: Her. 3.94 speaks of the *)indoi/ as sending Dareius an annual tribute of 360 talents in gold dust (yh=gma).

oi( *zhno\s ai)etoi/: Il. 24.310 o(/s te soi\ au)tw=| | fi/ltatos oi)wnw=n, kai/ eu( kra/tos e)sti\ me/giston. Pind. P. 4. 4(the Delphian priestess) xruse/wn *dio\s ai)htw=n pa/redros (the golden eagles on the o)mfalo/s). Hor. Carm. 4. 4. 1ministrum fulminis alitem.

ou)d' w(/s, not even (I say) in that case,—repeating the supposition, ou)d' ei) qe/lous'. Cp. Il. 9.379 ff. ou)d' ei)/ moi deka/kis te kai\ ei)kosa/kis to/sa doi/h, | ... ou)de/ ken w(\s e)/ti qumo\n e)mo\n pei/sei' *)agame/mnwn. Od. 22.61 ff. ou)d' ei)/ moi patrw/i+a pa/nt' a)podoi=te | ...ou)de/ ken w(\s e)/ti xei=ras e)ma\s lh/caimi fo/noio.—Attic prose, too, used kai\ w(/s, ‘even in that case’ (Thuc. 1.44), ou)d' w(/s (id. 1. 132), etc.—parh/sw. ou) mh/, with the 2nd pers. fut. ind., prohibits; but with the 1st or 3rd pers. it can be used in emphatic denial, though the aor. subjunct. is more usual: El. 1052 ou)/ soi mh\ meqe/yomai/ pote: see n. on O. C. 177. There is no reason, then, for suspecting the text (see cr. n.).

qeou\s miai/nein. Teiresias had said that the altars were defiled (1016). Creon replies that he will not yield, even if birds fly with the carrion up to the very throne of Zeus;—‘for no mortal can pollute the gods.’ Campbell takes this to be an utterance of scepticism, like ou)k e)/fa tis | qeou\s brotw=n a)ciou=sqai me/lein (Aesch. Ag. 369),—anticipating the Epicurean conception of gods who are neither pleased nor angered by men.

This view seems to do some injustice to the poet's dramatic psychology. I read the words quite differently. The most orthodox Greek piety held that ‘no mortal could pollute the gods.’ See, for example, H. F. 1232. Heracles, having recovered sanity after slaying his children, has covered his face, to hide it from the holy light of the sun. Theseus —who is a type of normal eu)se/beia— makes him uncover, saying,—ti/ d'; ou) miai/neis qnhto\s w)\n ta\ tw=n qew=n. The sungod cannot be polluted by a mortal. The idea of religious mi/asma was that a mortal had contracted some impurity which disqualified him for communion with the gods. The tainting of an altar cut off such communion by bringing uncleanness to the very place where men sought to be cleansed. Creon excitedly imagines a seemingly worse profanation, and then excuses his apparent impiety by a general maxim which all would admit:—‘no man can pollute the gods.’

‘The sky-throne of Zeus is still more sacred than his altar on earth: if defilement cannot reach him there, much less here.’ The sophism is of the kind with which an honest but stubborn and wrongheaded man might seek to quiet his conscience. Creon reveres Zeus (304): he feels for the majesty of the gods, and refuses to believe that they can honour the wicked (284 ff.). But his religious sense is temporarily confused by his anger.
polla/, adv.,=‘very,’ with adj.: O. C. 1514 n.
kalw=s, = eu)prepw=s, in a bad sense: Eur. Hipp. 505 ta)|sxra\ d' h)\n le/gh|s kalw=s: Thuc. 5.89 met' o)noma/twn kalw=n. So Eur. Hec. 1191 ta)/dik' eu)= le/gein: cp. O. C. 807.

a)=r' oi)=den k.t.l. Instead of being angered by Creon's bitter words, Teiresias is communing with the mournful thought which they suggest—the thought of human folly. His sorrowful exclamation here is like his pa/ntes ga\r ou) fronei=t' in the scene with Oedipus (O. T. 328).
ti/ xrh=ma; Cp. Eur. Hec. 754 (Hecuba having said, i(keteu/w,) *a*g. ti/ xrh=ma masteu/ousa; So oft. in questions, as Ai. 228, Ph. 1231.
pa/gkoinon, a sneer at the generality of the seer's exordium. What aphorism is this to be? But the seer's thought has a terribly definite point, as Creon is soon to feel (1066).
kthma/twn: cp. 684.
o(/sw|per with superl., as O. C. 743 n. By mh\ fronei=n Creon hints that the seer's cleverness has outrun his prudence (1046).
no/sou: cp. 732: plh/rhs, 1017.
In a)nteipei=n kakw=s, a)nti/ qualifies the whole phrase: i.e., it means, ‘to revile in return,’ a)ntiloidorei=n, as a)ntidra=n kakw=s (O. C. 1191)= a)ntadikei=n.

kai\ mh/n, ‘and verily,’ meaning here, ‘and yet,’—the adversative force arising from the contrast between Creon's profession and his practice. Cp. 221.— le/geis, sc. kakw=s to\n ma/ntin.—For the metre, cp. 44, 502.

ge/nos: 1035. Cp. Eur. I. A. 520 to\ mantiko\n pa=n spe/rma filo/timon kako/n. Helen. 755 (of mantikh/), bi/ou ga\r a)/llws de/lear hu(re/qh to/de, | kou)dei\s e)plou/ths' e)mpu/roisin a)rgo\s w)/n,—i.e., the seer's client is never enriched (though the seer himself is).

to\ d' e)k tura/nnwn. The text is sound. Instead of saying, ‘the race of tyrants’ (i.e., all the tyrants who exist), he says, with more rhetorical force, ‘the race bred of tyrants,’ i.e., the tyrants whose progenitors have also been tyrants. Thus e)k expresses that the love of ‘base gain’ is hereditary. For tu/rannos in the bad sense, see O. T. 873 n.

ai)sxroke/rdeian: not in the literal sense in which Creon imputed it to his servants (313), but in this, that Creon secures an unworthy personal triumph by trampling on religion and silencing just remonstrance (505 ff.). Cp. Ai. 1349 mh\ xai=r', *)atrei/dh, ke/rdesin toi=s mh\ kaloi=s.

a)=r' oi)=sqa le/gwn tagou\s o)/ntas a(\ a)\n le/gh|s; knowest thou that whatever it pleases thee to say is said of men who are rulers? le/gw tina/ ti=to say something of him. a(\ a)\n le/gh|s is a scornful euphemism, implying that he indulges in random abuse. tagou/s: only here in Soph. : oft. in Aesch. (in Aesch. P. V. 96Zeus is o( ne/os tago\s maka/rwn); once in Eur. , I. A. 269 (Adrastus). Here the word is not specially=strathgo/s (8), but simply =basileu/s.
e)c e)mou=: cp. O. T. 1221 a)ne/pneusa ...e)k se/qen.

e)/xeis sw/sas, merely=se/swkas (cp. 22). The rare position of e)/xeis might suggest the prose sense (‘thou hast saved, and keepest’); but that position occurs where e)/xw is merely the auxiliary (794; Ai. 22 e)/xei pera/nas).

ta)ki/nhta dia\ frenw=n, = ta\ dia\ frenw=n a)ki/nhta, those secrets in my soul which ought to be let alone. Cp. O. C. 1526 a(\ d' e)ca/gista mhde\ kinei=tai lo/gw|, n. For the place of the adv. dia\ frenw=n, cp. 659 n.: for dia/, 639 n.: Aesch. Th. 593baqei=an a)/loka dia\ freno\s karpou/menos.
ki/nei: a word used esp. of sacrilege: Her. 6.134 kinh/sonta/ ti tw=n a)kinh/twn (in a temple): Thuc. 4.98 u(/dwr...kinh=sai (to profane, by secular use, water reserved for sacrifices).
mo/non de/, sc. ki/nei.

e)pi\ ke/rdesin, i.e., with a view to receiving money from the Thebans for persuading me to bury Polyneices. So Oed. (O. T. 388) calls the seer, do/lion a)gu/rthn, o(/stis e)n toi=s ke/rdesin | mo/non de/dorke.

ou(/tw ga h)/dh: ‘indeed, as matters stand (h)/dh), kai\ dokw= (le/cein), I think that I shall speak thus—i.e., not for gain—so far as thou art concerned.’ The seer, with grave irony, gives a new turn to Creon's phrase, mh\ e)pi\ ke/rdesin, and says that the admonition is superfluous. The message which he has to utter is fraught with no ke/rdh—for Creon. For the plur. ke/rdh in this general sense, cp. 1326. to\ so
 me/ros here=quantum ad te attinet: a sense quite as correct for it as the more usual quantum in te est (O. T. 1509, O. C. 1366, Tr. 1215). For kai/ emphasising dokw= (le/cein), cp. 726. Creon's reply (1063) refers to the covert threat: ‘say what thou wilt, thou shalt not shake my purpose.’— The choice lies between this view and that of the Scholiast, who makes the verse interrogative:—ou(/tw nomi/zeis, o(/ti e)pi\ ke/rdesi le/gw; i.e., ‘what, do I seem now— on thy part—to be speaking for money?’ The points in favour of the Scholiast's interpretation are:—(a) The combination ga/r...kai/ (before the verb) suits an indignant question: cp. 770, Tr. 1124. (b) The tone of rising anger—which began at 1060—fitly preludes the outburst at 1064: cp. O. T. 343—350. But on the other hand:—(a) The indignation comes late, seeing that Creon has already used the same taunt four times (1036, 1047, 1055, 1059); not, indeed, in so directly personal a form, yet still openly enough. (b) Though the seer is angered (1085), it is dramatically better to conceive him as speaking here with a stern calmness. (c) It would be correct to say (e.g.) pe/fasmai le/gwn, to\ so
 me/ros (‘I have been represented as speaking..., so far as you could create such a belief’): but hardly, dokw= to\ so
 me/ros, as merely=dokw= soi/.— On the whole, then, the first view is best. —Others, which may be rejected, are:— (1) ‘I think that I shall speak for your good.’ But, if we are thus to supply e)pi\ ke/rdesin, and not ou)k e)pi\ ke/rdesin, the verse must be interrogative. (2) ‘So far as you are concerned, I do not expect to speak for my own profit’; i.e., I shall receive no thanks from you. (3) ‘Do you really think that I shall find any satisfaction in speaking?’—i.e., it will be only pain for you, without advantage for me.

i)/sqi w(s mh\ e)mp., rest assured that thou art not to trade (1037) on my resolve; i.e., to make profit out of it (from the Thebans) by persuading me to surrender it. w(s (which might have been absent) adds emphasis by marking the point of view at which he is to place himself. In such phrases it is more often added to a partic. in the accus., the object of the imperat. verb: Ph. 253w(s mhde\n ei)do/t' i)/sqi m' w(=n a)nistorei=s: O. T. 848 n. But cp. Her. 1.91 e)pista/sqw *kroi=sos w(s u(/steron...a(lou\s th=s peprwme/nhs.
fre/na: cp. 993.
a)ll' eu\= ge/ toi: 473 n.

mh … telw=n, that thou art not to accomplish, i.e., live through: mh/ is due to the imperat. ka/tisqi (O. C. 78 n.). The easy correction, h(/lion telei=n, has been received by some recent edd. (ka/tisqi then has the constr. with inf., as 473 i)/sqi ...pi/ptein). It may be right. But telw=n, if not a usual phrase, is a natural one; and it is more impressive here to say, ‘thou shalt not live through many days,’ than, ‘the sun shall not fulfil many days.’

tro/xous = dro/mous, ‘courses.’ The MS. troxous=‘runners,’ i.e., ku/klous, wheels. The authority for this Attic distinction goes back at least to the Augustan age: see Chandler § 332 n. 1 (2nd ed.), who cites Ammonius p. 137 troxoi\ o)cuto/nws kai\ tro/xoi baruto/nws diafe/rousi para\ toi=s *)attikoi=s. fhsi\ *tru/fwn (in the Augustan age) e)n deute/ra| peri\ *)attikh=s prosw|di/as. tou\s me\n ga\r periferei=s troxou\s o(moi/ws h(mi=n profe/rontai o)cutonou=ntes: tro/xous de\ baruto/nws le/gousi tou\s dro/mous. This passage helps to explain why our MSS. all give troxou/s here. When Ammonius wrote (towards the end of the 4th cent. A.D. ) tro/xos, ‘course,’ was known only as an Atticism, while troxo/s, ‘wheel,’ was a common word.

a(millhth=ras, racing, rapid: Eur. Or. 456 ge/ronti deu=r' a(milla=tai podi/. Xen. Anab. 3.4.44 w(/rmhsan a(milla=sqai e)pi\ to\ a)/kron.—The Schol. explains, tou\s a)llh/lous diadexome/nous, ‘successive’; perh. taking the word to mean, ‘competitors,’ i.e., ‘vying in swiftness.’ But that does not warrant his version.
e)n oi(=si = e)nto\s w(=n, i.e., before they have elapsed: cp. O. C. 619 n.

tw=n sw=n … e)k spla/gxnwn e(/na, a strong fig. phrase, one whose life is nourished by thine own heart's blood,—the son begotten of thee. If the ref. were to the mother, spla/gxna could mean ‘womb’: cp. Kaibel Epigr. 691zwh\ de\ plei/wn mhtro\s e)n spla/gxnois e)mh/ (of a babe who died just after birth). So brothers and sisters are o(mo/splagxnoi (511).
ne/kun nekrw=n: 596 n. The nekroi/ are Polyneices and Antigone.— a)ntidou\s e)/sei, fut. perf.: cp. O. C. 816 n.
a)nq' w(=n here=a)nti\ tou/twn o(/ti, ‘because’: so Plut. 434. The phrase more often means ‘wherefore’ (O. C. 1295): cp. O. T. 264 n.
e)/xeis balw\n ka/tw tw=n a)/nw (tina/), thou hast thrust to the grave (one) of the living. For the omission of tis after the partitive gen., cp. El. 1322 klu/w | tw=n e)/ndoqen xwrou=ntos.

Bothe, omitting te after yuxh/n, takes the latter with tw=n a)/nw, ‘a life belonging to the upper world.’ We could then read either (a) a)ti/mws...katoiki/sas, or (b) with Bergk, a)ti/mws t'...katoiki/sas or katw/|kisas. But I prefer the MS. reading, because (a) tw=n a)/nw as=tw=n a)/nw tina/ has a certain tone of solemnity and mystery which befits the utterance: (b) tw=n a)/nw … yuxh/n is somewhat weak: (c) the words yuxh/n t' … katw/|kisas, both by rhythm and by diction, naturally form one clause, —paraphrasing and interpreting the darker utterance in v. 1068.—Schütz takes a)nq' w(=n as=a)nti\ tou/twn ou(/s, and tw=n a)/nw as by attraction for tou\s a)/nw: i.e., ‘on account of those persons whom, being alive, thou hast entombed.’ Kern, too, so takes a)nq' w(=n, but makes tw=n a)/nw partitive (‘on account of those among the living whom’); and so, I think, it must be on any view. But the parallelism of e)/xeis me/n...e)/xeis de/ plainly requires that a)nq' w(=n should apply in the same sense to both clauses. Schütz, however, has to supply it with e)/xeis de/ in the changed sense of a)nti\ tou/twn (neut.) o(/ti.—For oi( a)/nw = oi( e)n fa/ei, cp. 890: Ph. 1348w)= stugno\s ai)w/n, ti/ m' e)/ti dh=t' e)/xeis a)/nw | ble/ponta, kou)k a)fh=kas ei)s *(/aidou molei=n;—Some take tw=n a)/nw as=tw=n a)/nw qew=n: ‘one belonging to the gods above.’ This is too forced.
a)ti/mws, ruthlessly: cp. O. C. 428, El. 1181.

e)/xeis de/ = kate/xeis de/. Since in e)/xeis me/n...e)/xeis de/ the rhetorical effect depends simply on the repetition (e)panafora/), the change of sense is immaterial. —tw=n ka/twqen qew=n, possess. gen. with ne/kun, a corpse belonging to them. For ka/twqen = ka/tw, 521 n.
a)/moiron, without its due moi=ra of burial rites: Ai. 13-7 nekro\n tafh=s | a)/moiron. Others take tw=n

k. qew=n with a)/moiron: ‘without a portion in the gods below,’ i.e., not admitted to communion with them. But the phrase is a strange one; and the leading thought here is that the ne/rteroi are robbed of one who belongs to them.
a)kte/riston (1207), without offerings at the grave, kteri/smata (O. C. 1410): cp. 204.

a)no/sion, ‘unhallowed,’ sums up the state of the dead who has received no rites: cp. 545 n. Cp. Shaksp. Haml. 1. 5. 77 ‘Unhousel'd, disappointed, unanel'd’ [without sacrament—unprepared for death—without extreme unction].
w(=n, sc. tw=n nekrw=n, suggested by ne/kun. Others make it neut., ‘such acts as these.’ It cannot refer to oi( ka/twqen qeoi/.

bia/zontai, sc. oi( a)/nw qeoi/: because it was an offence against the pure ou)ra/nioi qeoi/ to keep a mi/asma in their presence. Cp. O. T. 1425 th\n gou=n pa/nta bo/skousan flo/ga | ai)dei=sq' a)/naktos *(hli/ou, and see n. there on 1427. The subject to bia/zontai might, indeed, be oi( ka/twqen qeoi/, for Greek idiom is often bold in such transitions: but the verb suits a positive better than a negative wrong.
tou/twn, neut., causal gen.: cp. 931 n.
lwbhth=res, though the subject is fem.: so El. 850 i)/stwr: Aesch. Ag. 111 xeri\ pra/ktori: ib. 664 tu/xh...swth/r: Suppl. 1040 qe/lktori *peiqoi=.
u(sterofqo/roi, destroying after (though not, here, long after) the crime. Aesch. Ag. 58 (Zeus) u(stero/poinon | pe/mpei paraba=sin *)erinu/n. Anthol. 12. 229 u(stero/poun a(zo/menoi *ne/mesin.
loxw=sin: El. 490 a( deinoi=s kruptome/na lo/xois xalko/pous *)erinu/s.
*(/aidou kai\ qew=n, possess. gen.; the Erinyes are their ministers, avenging their wrongs: so oft. patro/s, mhtro/s, *)erinu/es. In El. 112 the Erinyes are semnai\...qew=n pai=des.

lhfqh=nai, inf. of result: cp. 64 a)kou/ein. The omission of w(/ste is somewhat bold, since the subject of the inf. is not that of loxw=sin. Cp. O. C. 385 e)mou= qeou\s | w)/ran tin' e(/cein w(/ste swqh=nai/ pote.

kathrg., prop., overlaid with silver (Her. 1.98); hence, fig., bribed. Cp. Pind. P. 11. 41misqoi=o sune/qeu pare/xein | fwna\n u(pa/rguron (a word prop. said of a gilded surface, with silver below). —ou) makr. xro/n. tribh/ =a time for which thou wilt not have long to wait. Some, less naturally, make these words a parenthesis with e)/stai understood, and supply tau=ta as subject to fanei=. Cp. Aristoph. Ran. 156 qia/sous eu)dai/monas | a)ndrw=n gunaikw=n.

The po/leis are the cities which had furnished contingents to the Argive expedition against Thebes. These cities are stirred with passionate hatred against Creon by the tidings that burial has been refused to their fallen warriors. There is no direct allusion to the war of the Epigoni,—the expedition which the sons of the fallen chiefs led against Thebes, and in which they destroyed it. Bergk's suntara/contai might suggest such an allusion; but the pres. suntara/ssontai is right. The reference is to the feelings which now agitate the cities. Those feelings are one day to produce the new war. Here the prophet notes them only as signs of a still distant storm. Having foretold a domestic sorrow for the father, he now foreshadows a public danger for the king.

It has been objected that the play contains no hint of burial having been denied to any one except Polyneices. This is not exactly the case: the phrase tw=n e)xqrw=n kaka/ in v. 10 is such a hint. But it was unnecessary for the poet to state a fact which all his hearers would assume. Every one knew how Creon had refused burial to the Argives, and how Theseus had recovered their corpses by force of arms. In the Supplices of Eur. the Chorus consists of widows and mothers of the unburied warriors. No Athenian exploit was more famous (Her. 9.27; Isocr. Paneg. § 52, Encom. Helen. § 31, Panath. § 168; Plat. Menex. 244; [Lys. ] or. 2 §§ 4 ff.: [Dem. ] or. 60 §§ 7 ff.). The war of the Epigoni, which was included in the epic Thebais ( Paus. 9. 9§ 5), was dramatised both by Aesch. and by Soph. (*)epi/gonoi).

Just as, in the O. C. (1410 n.), Soph. glances at the theme of his Antigone, so here he might naturally glance—however indirectly—at a later chapter of the Theban story,—whether his Epigoni already existed, or was still in the future. Dramatically, the reference is the more fitting, since the legend represented Teiresias as still living, and still zealous for Theban welfare, when the Epigoni came.—For other views of the passage, see Appendix.

o(/swn (fem.) spara/gmata, mangled bodies belonging to them, as being the corpses of their citizens. The possessive gen. in this sense is quite justifiable, since spara/gmata = sw/mata e)sparagme/na, just as ptw/mata = sw/mata peptwko/ta. (It would be possible, but harsh, to make o(/swn masc., as=e)pei\ tosou/twn: cp. O. C. 263 n.)

L's kaqh/gnisan=‘hallowed’ them, in the sense of, ‘gave burial rites to them’: cp. Eur. Or. 40 mh/thr puri\ kaqh/gnistai de/mas (has had the funeral rite of fire): Suppl. 1211 i(/n' au)tw=n sw/maq' h(gni/sqh puri/. The v.l. kaqh/gisan reaches the same meaning (‘buried’) by a different channel. kaqagi/zw was properly ‘to devote’ or ‘dedicate’: Her. 1.86 a)kroqi/nia ...katagiei=n qew=n o(/tew| dh/. Then, fig., to devote to the gods below by the funeral fire; Anton. 14 to\...sw=ma tou= *kai/saros e)n a)gora=| kaqagi/sai (‘solemnly burn’). Either kaqh/gnisan or kaqh/gisan, then, is admissible. But (apart from L's support) kaqh/gnisan seems preferable on two grounds: (a) its primary sense lends force to the grim irony: (b) the funereal sense of kaqagi/zw has only post-classical evidence.—Hesychius (kaqagi/sw) says that Soph. used kaqagi/zw, not in the sense of kaqiero/w, but in that of miai/nw:—a statement perh. founded on a misunderstanding

of kaqh/gisan here. The Schol. read the latter (meta\ a)/gous e)ko/misan). But the fact that L has kaqh/gnisan must be set against these doubtful testimonies.—For the irony, cp. El. 1487 pro/qes | tafeu=sin, w(=n to/nd' ei)ko/s e)sti tugxa/nein (as Gorgias called vultures e)/myuxoi ta/foi, Longin. p. u(/yous 3 § 2): Aesch. Th. 1020u(p' oi)wnw=n ... | tafe/nt' a)ti/mws: Ennius Ann. 142volturu' crudeli condebat membra sepulcro: Lucr. 5. 993viva videns vivo sepeliri viscera busto.

e(stiou=xon … po/lin, the city containing the e(sti/ai of those on whose flesh the bird has fed. The sing. is used, although several po/leis are concerned, since the case of one city is the case of all. For the adj., cp. Aesch. Pers. 510 h(/kousin e)kfugo/ntes, ou) polloi/ tines, | e)f' e(stiou=xon gai=an, ‘the land of their homes.’ Eur. Andr. 283 e(stiou=xon au)la/n, the abode that contains his hearth. Here, the word serves to suggest a pollution of hearth and altar (1016). Pollution, in a ceremonial sense, could be brought by the o)smh/, even without an actual transport of carrion. And it is only the birds that are said to carry the taint.—See Appendix on 1080 ff.
sou, ‘at thee,’ with a)fh=ka: 1033 n.

qumw=|, modal dat.: 620 n.— kardi/as toceu/mata, heart-arrows, i.e., arrows for thy heart. Cp. Eur. Hec. 235 kardi/as dhkth/ria: Med. 1360th=s sh=s ga/r, w(s xrh=n, kardi/as a)nqhya/mhn.—Not, arrows from my (angry) heart, like o)/mmatos... to/ceuma (Aesch. Suppl. 1004).—tw=n = w(=n: cp. O. C. 747 n.
w)= pai=. Cp. O. T. 444 a)/peimi toi/nun: kai\ su/, pai=, ko/mize/ me.
tre/fein: cp. 660 n.

h(suxwte/ran, the MS. reading, has been prudently retained by most of the recent edd. In Plat. Charm. 160A the MSS. give o( h(suxw/tatos, though two lines before they give w(s h(suxai/tata. A grammarian in Bekker Anecd. 98. 19 quotes h(suxw/teron. In Aesch. Eum. 223 the MSS. give h(suxaite/ran, and in Plat. Phileb. 24C h(suxaite/rou. It is true that our MSS. have no great weight on such a point, and that, if the w form had been the current one in later Greek, it would have been likely to oust an older form in ai. But we see that sometimes, at least, the MSS. could preserve the ai and the w forms side by side. It seems safer, then, to suppose that the normal w form and the irregular ai form were both in Attic use, than to assume that the ai form alone was tolerated. The dictum of Thomas Magister, (quoted by Dindorf,) p. 426 h(suxai/teron: ou)x h(suxw/teron, is indecisive without more evidence than we possess.

to
 nou=n … tw=n frenw=n a)mei/nw (tre/fein) h)\ nu=n fe/rei (au)to/n). Cp. Il. 18.419 th=|s e)n me
 no/os e)sti\ meta\ fresi/n, there is understanding in their breasts: 22. 475 e)s fre/na qumo\s a)ge/rqh, the soul returned to her breast. The word frh/n being thus associated with the physical seat of thought and feeling, o( nou=s tw=n frenw=n was a possible phrase. So trag. adesp. fr. 240 (when divine anger visits a man) e)cafairei=tai frenw=n | to
 nou=n to
 e)sqlo/n. (Cp. 176 n. ad fin.)

fe/rei: 705 n.—If we took tw=n frenw=n with a)mei/nw, then h)\ must be changed to w(=n, with Brunck. In so compact a clause, h)/ could not be an irregular substitute for w(=n. Nor could h)\ nu=n fe/rei be an epexegesis: ‘better than his (present) mind,—(that is, better) than he now bears it.’
e)c o(/tou: cp. 12 n.

leukh\n … e)k melai/nhs. The words could mean either: (1) ‘since this hair which clothes my head, once dark, has been white’: or (2) ‘since this hair,—once dark, now white,—has clothed my head,’ i.e., from infancy. The first is the sense intended here. There is a certain looseness of expression, since the thought is, ‘though I am old, I can recall no such case’; whereas the period actually described might be a comparatively short one. So we can say, ‘he has grown grey in the service of his country,’ meaning, ‘he has served it all his life.’

a)mfiba/llomai: cp. Rhianus (the elegiac poet of Crete, c. 225 B.C.) Anthol. P. 12. 93 xai/rete, kaloi\ pai=des, e)s a)kmai/hn de\ mo/loite | h(/bhn, kai\ leukh\n a)mfie/saisqe ko/mhn. For the 1st pers. sing. following e)pista/mesqa, see 734 n.

mh\. We might have had the ou) of oratio obliqua with lakei=n, = o(/ti ou)k e)/lake. But here we have mh/, as after pisteu/w and like verbs. So O. T. 1455 oi)=da, mh/te m' a)\n no/son | mh/t' a)/llo pe/rsai mhde/n (n.). Cp. O. C. 656 n., 797 n. In such cases mh/ seems to add a certain emphasis to the statement of fact (like saying, ‘I protest that I know no instance’).

lakei=n, infin. (instead of the more usual partic.) after e)pista/mesqa: 293 n. This verb is esp. used of prophecy: cp. Tr. 822 (where tou)/pos to\ qeopro/pon is subject to e)/laken): Aesch. Ag. 1426 (of Clytaemnestra) peri/frona d' e)/lakes. The ref. is esp. to the seer's denunciation of Oedipus, and his command regarding Megareus (1303 n.).
e)/gnwka, I have noted it=I know it well; more emphatic than oi)=da: cp. O. C. 553 n.

For te … de/, instead of te...te, cp. Tr. 285 tau=ta ga\r po/sis te so\s e)fei=t', e)gw\ de\ pisto\s w)\n kei/nw| telw=: ib. 333 w(s su/ q' oi(= qe/leis | speu/dh|s, e)gw\ de\ ta)/ndon e)carkh= tiqw=. See also O. C. 367 n., 442 n.: Ph. 1312 f. Here, de/ is accentless in L, and the first hand has written t above; but, if the genuine reading had been te … te, the change to te … de/ was not likely to occur; and the antithesis makes de/ very natural. Cp. Aesch. Ag. 206 barei=a me\n kh\r to\ mh\ piqe/sqai, | barei=a d', ei) te/knon datcw.

a)/th| pata/cai (170 n.) qumo\n, to smite my proud spirit with a curse. a)ntista/nta implies that he is stationary: the image is not, then, like that in 854 (e)s *di/kas ba/qron | prose/peses). Rather the a)/th is to be conceived as sweeping down on him, like the torrent which destroys trees that resist it (712).

e)n deinw=| pa/ra (= pa/restin), it is open to me, as the dreadful alternative; lit., as a thing in the region of to\ deino/n. For e)n deinw=| cp. El. 384 nu=n ga e)n kalw=| fronei=n ('tis opportune). Eur. Her. 971 ou)kou=n e)/t' e)sti
 e)n kalw=| dou=nai di/khn: I.A. 969e)n eu)marei= te (sc. e)sti/) dra=n: Helen. 1277 e)n eu)sebei= gou=n no/mima mh\ kle/ptein nekrw=n ('tis a matter of piety). Here, the only peculiarity arises from the fusion of two propositions, viz. (1) pa/restin, and (2) e)n deinw=| e)stin. The phrase would have been clearer if o)/n had been added to e)n deinw=|: cp. 471 n. It may be noticed that elsewhere also Soph. uses pa/resti and paro/n of an evil lot: Ai. 432 nu=n ga pa/resti kai\ di\s ai)a/zein e)moi/: El. 959 h(=| pa/resti me
 ste/nein... | pa/resti d' a)lgei=n: Ph. 283hu(/riskon ou)de
 plh
 a)nia=sqai paro/n. This is a point in favour of the traditional pa/ra.—Seyffert's e(
 deinou= pe/ra would be excellent, were it not for e(/n, which cannot be justified by the use of ei(=s with superlatives (O. C. 563 n.). Cp. [Dem. ] or. 45 § 73 deino/n, w)= gh= kai\ qeoi/, kai\ pe/ra deinou=. Wecklein conjectures e)pi\ (for e)n) deinw=|: ‘by resisting, it is possible that, in addition to the difficulty (of resistance), I may incur calamity.’ But, apart from the risk of calamity, there was nothing in resistance that he could call deino/n. There is no likelihood in conjectures which displace qumo/n, such as Nauck's (see cr. n.).

The question between L's labei=n, and the *kre/on of later MSS., is not an easy one to decide. If labei=n is an error, then it must be explained by the scribe's eye having wandered to v. 1094. But it has not been noticed (I think) that the argument from v. 1094 is two-edged. There, the scribe of L wrote labei=n, which was afterwards corrected to lakei=n, either by his own hand or by another. It might be held, then, that he wrote labei=n, by an error of the eye, in 1094, because his archetype had labei=n in 1098. The epexegetic construction of the inf. (= w(/ste labei=n au)th/n, see examples on 489 f.) may have been a stumblingblock, leading transcribers to think it a redundant gloss; when *kre/on would have been the obvious resource. Everything considered, I prefer to retain labei=n.
katw/ruxos: 774 n.—kti/son is here more than poi/hson, as it implies observance of solemn rites: cp. 1201 ff.: Aesch. Cho. 483 ou(/tw ga\r a)/n soi dai=tes e)/nnomoi brotw=n | ktizoi/at'.

I read the impers. dokei=: ‘and does it seem good (to you) that I should yield?’ The dat. can be understood, as in Ph. 526a)ll', ei) dokei=, ple/wmen, and ib. 645. This correction is confirmed by Aesch. Th. 650su\ d' au)to\s h)/dh gnw=qi, ti/na pe/mpein dokei=, where L has dokei= with an accent erased over the o,—showing that the use of the impers. verb without a dat., seeming strange, had suggested do/kei (imperat.). There, some of the later MSS. have dokei=s. Here, L shares the error of the rest, and has dokei=s—generated, doubtless, from dokei= by the same misapprehension as in Aesch. l. c. The decisive objection to dokei=s here is that it could mean only, ‘art thou minded to yield?’ (Aesch. Ag. 16 o(/tan d' a)ei/dein h)\ minu/resqai dokw=); not, ‘dost thou think it right that I should yield?’
pareikaqei=n: for the form, see on O. T. 651.
sunte/mnousi … tou\s k., cut them (i.e., their careers) short, ‘cut them off.’ The compressed phrase, though not strictly correct, is natural.
podw/keis: cp. Il. 9.505 h( d' *)/ath sqenarh/ te kai\ a)rti/pos: Ai. 837 *)erinu=s tanu/podas (who are taxei=ai, ib. 843): O. T. 418 deino/pous a)ra/.

bla/bai, ‘harms,’ ‘mischiefs,’ with ref. to the primary sense of bla/ptw, to disable, or stop: Il. 6.39 (horses) o)/zw| e)ni/ blafqe/nte muriki/nw|, ‘caught in’ a tamarisk branch: Aesch. Ag. 120 (a hare) blabe/nta loisqi/wn dro/mwn, ‘stopped’ from running further. The bla/bai qew=n cannot, however, be properly regarded as personified beings; and therefore we should not write *bla/bai. In Aesch. Eum. 491 ei) krath/sei di/ka te kai\ bla/ba | tou=de mhtrokto/nou, where some write *di/ka—*bla/ba, the sense is, ‘if the cause and the wrong (=the wrongful cause) of Orestes shall prevail.’
kako/fronas: for the o_ before fr, cp. 336 n.
mo/lis me/n (e)ci/st.), e)ci/st. de/: cp. Eur. Phoen. 1421 mo/lis me/n, e)ce/teine d' ei)s h(=par ci/fos: Aristoph. Nub. 1363 ka)gw\ mo/lis me/n, a)ll' o(/mws h)nesxo/mhn.

e)ci/stamai kardi/as, resign my cherished resolve: Phaedr. 249 D e)cista/menos...tw=n a)nqrwpi/nwn spoudasma/twn, kai\ pro\s tw=| qei/w| gigno/menos. This use of kardi/a was suggested by the similar use of qumo/s, with which Homer associates it as the seat of desire or passion (Il. 13.784 nu=n d' a)/rx', o(/pph se kradi/h qumo/s te keleu/ei): thus plhrou=sa qumo/n (Eur. Hipp. 1328)= plhrou=sa e)piqumi/an.
to\ dra=n, acc. of inner object, defining the concession: Ph. 1252a)ll' ou)de/ toi sh=| xeiri\ pei/qomai to\ dra=n.
dusmaxhte/on: Tr. 492 qeoi=si dusmaxou=ntes.

e)p' a)/ll'. tre/pe = a)/llois e)pi/trepe: Aesch. Eum. 434 h)= ka)p' e)moi\ tre/poit' a)\n ai)ti/as te/los; (‘would ye commit the decision of the charge to me’?) This is ‘tmesis’ in the proper sense,—where the prep. determines the special sense of the verb: cp. Il. 8.108 ou(/s pot' a)p' *ai)nei/an e(lo/mhn = a)feilo/mhn.
w(s e)/xw, i.e., forthwith: 1235: Ph. 819de/cai qana/simo/n m' o(/pws e)/xw.
stei/xoim' a)/n, optat. with a)/n expressing a fixed resolve: O. T. 343 ou)k a)\n pe/ra fra/saimi: O. C. 45 ou)x...a)\n e)ce/lqoim' e)/ti.
i)/t' i)/t'. The rhythm given by the tribrach suits this agitated utterance. ei)=' would be no improvement (see cr. n.).

oi(/ t' o)/ntes oi(/ t' a)po/ntes, one and all. This was doubtless a familiar phrase: cp. 40 n. El. 305 ta\s ou)/sas te/ moi | kai\ ta\s a)pou/sas e)lpi/das die/fqoren. Plaut. Trin. 360 comedit quod fuit quod non fuit.

a)ci/nas. In Xen. Anab. 1.5.12 the a)ci/nh is used by one who is cu/la sxi/zwn. Here it has usually been supposed that the a)ci=nai were to cut wood for the burning of the corpse. But no regular pura/ was made; the remains of the corpse were burned with neospa/des qalloi/, branches freshly plucked from the trees in the plain (1201). On the other hand, some implement was needed to raise the tu/mbos o)rqo/kranos of earth (1203). It seems, then, as if Soph. referred to some kind of axe which could serve like the genh/|s of v. 249 (n.). No tool was used to break open Antigone's tomb; the stones were dragged away (1216).

e)po/yion, pass., looked-upon, beheld, from here: hence= fanero/n (schol.), ‘in view.’ Cp. O. C. 1600 ei)s proso/yion | pa/gon, the hill which was in view. —As Creon speaks, he points with his hand in a direction to the left of the spectators. The region meant is the furthest and highest part of the Theban plain (1197), where the body of Polyneices still lay. In the pa/goi adjacent to it was the rocky tomb of Antigone (774 n.).—Hermann assumed the loss of some vv. after 1110, in which Creon described the e)po/yios to/pos,—explaining that he would first bury Polyneices, and then free Antigone. But what need was there for this, when he was himself to accompany his servants? Besides, his men, like all the other Thebans, might be supposed to know the place meant; and the Chorus had already said what was to be done there. Equally baseless is Bergk's theory that vv. 1111 —1114 are an interpolation, designed to fill a gap in the original text. See the notes on them. Dindorf agrees with Bergk only so far as to suspect vv. 1111, 1112.

e)gw\ d'. The sense is not: ‘do you go and bury Polyneices, while I release Antigone.’ Creon takes part in both acts (1196 ff.). But at this moment his foremost thought is of saving Antigone. If she dies, his son must die (1066). Therefore, while he glances at the burial-rites by telling his men to bring axes, he describes his own part by his most urgent task,—the release.— e)pistra/fh, prop., ‘turned round’; as a person faces about, Eur. Alc. 187 kai\ polla\ qa/lamon e)ciou=s' e)pestra/fh. th=|d', this way, in this direction (O. C. 1547).

au)to/s t' e)/dhsa k.t.l. = w(/sper au)to\s e)/dhsa, ou(/tw kai\ au)to\s parw
 e)klu/somai. The co-ordination (parataxis) of clauses by te...kai/, as elsewhere by me/n... de/, is peculiarly Greek. Cp. O. T. 419 ble/ponta nu=n me
 o)/rq', e)/peita de\ sko/ton (=dark then, though now thou hast sight): O. C. 853 ou)/te nu=n kala\ | dra=|s, ou)/te pro/sqen ei)rga/sw (=thou art not doing well now, as neither didst thou formerly): ib. 1202 (ou) kalo
) au)to
 me
 eu)= | pa/sxein, paqo/nta d' ou)k e)pi/stasqai ti/nein (while receiving benefits, to be incapable of requiting them). Here, the rhetorical effect of the idiom is to place the two acts in bolder contrast. The middle e)klu/omai and the active e)klu/w (Aesch. PV 326) are equivalent in poetry. They do not differ as lu/w (said of the captor) from lu/omai (of the ransomer).—Nauck and others take the words figuratively; ‘As I have made the tangle, I will unravel it’ (cp. 40 n.). This is surely wrong. See on v. 1111.

de/doika mh\ … h)=|: cp. O. T. 747 deinw=s a)qumw= mh\ ble/pwn o( ma/ntis h)=|. In both these places, ‘I fear lest...’ means ‘I shrewdly suspect that...,’ and de/doika mh/ might therefore have been followed by pres. indic., which expresses a fear that something is now going on (cp. 278 n. Aristoph. Nub. 493 de/doika...mh\ plhgw=n de/ei).
tou\s kaqest. no/mous, the laws established by the gods,—the qew=n no/mima of 454 f.
sw/|zonta … to\n bi/on telei=n = sw/|zein e(/ws a)\n teleuth/|shs: but the turn of phrase chosen unconsciously foreshadows Antigone's fate.

div2.p: This u(po/rxhma, or ‘dance-song,’ takes the place of a fifth stasimon. The Chorus hopes that Creon may be in time to save Antigone, and that his sin against the dead may be expiated without disaster. Hence this strain, full of gladness, invoking the healing presence (1144) of the bright and joyous god who protects Thebes. The substitution of a u(po/rxhma for a stasimon is used with a like dramatic purpose in other plays. (1) O. T. 1086—1109: the Chorus hopes that Oedipus may prove to be of Theban birth. (2) Ai. 693—717, a joyous invocation of Pan, the Chorus believing that Ajax has indeed repented. (3) Tr. 633—662: the Chorus joyously anticipates the return of Heracles. In each of these cases the beginning of the end is near.
1st strophe 1115—1125=1st antistr. 1126—1136: 2nd str. 1137—1145=2nd antistr. 1146—1154. See Metrical Analysis.

div3.p: poluw/nume, i.e., worshipped by various special titles in different places. The reference of the epithet to local rituals is well brought out by Theocr. 15. 109 (Aphrodite) poluw/nume kai\ polu/nae. Most of the greater deities are called poluw/numoi by the poets; but the word is peculiarly suitable to Dionysus, owing to the manner in which his cult was interwoven with other cults; thus in relation to Demeter he was *)/iakxos; to the Muses, *melpo/menos; to Hades, *zagreu/s. Dionysus was distinctively polueidh\s kai\ polu/morfos ( Plut. Mor. 389 c). Upwards of sixty titles given to him can be enumerated (see Preller, Griech. Mythol.).
*kadmei/as. We should not write *kadmei/+as, and dilo/foio in 1126, with Dindorf. Nor is it necessary to place nu/mfas after a)/galma, with Nauck. See Metrical Analysis.
a)/galma, glory: Aesch. Ag. 207 te/knon...do/mwn a)/galma.

nu/mfas, bride, young wife. Semele, daughter of Cadmus and Harmonia, was beloved by Zeus, and was ensnared by Hera into praying him that he would come to her in the same guise as to Hera. He came to her. therefore, armed with his thunderbolts, and amid lightning, which destroyed her. She was great with child, and Zeus saved her son, Dionysus. barubreme/ta (for the u_, cp. 336 n.) alludes to this story. Ov. Met. 3. 298(Jupiter, bound by his own oath, grants Semele's prayer): ergo maestissimus altum | Aethera conscendit, nutuque sequentia traxit | Nubila; quis nimbos immixtaque fulgura ventis | Addidit, et tonitrus, et inevitabile fulmen.

The traditional reading, *)itali/an, may be supported by these considerations. (1) Southern Italy, the seat of so many Greek colonies, was preeminently associated with the cultivation of the vine; and Sophocles has himself used the name which expresses that fact: Triptolemus fr. 538 *oi)nwtri/a te pa=sa kai\ *turshniko\s | ko/lpos *aigustikh/ te gh= se de/cetai. (2) The opening words of the ode, *kadmei/as nu/mfas a)/galma, claim Thebes as the birth-place of Dionysus. Though Italy, then, is mentioned before Eleusis, Parnassus and Euboea, that precedence has not the effect of representing Italy as the head-quarters of the Dionysiac worship. Rather the mention of Italy just after Thebes serves to exalt the Theban god by marking the wide range of his power. And this reference to a distant country well suits the immediately following pagkoi/nois, expressing that Eleusis receives votaries from every part of the Greek world. (3) Athenian colonists founded Thurii, on the site of Sybaris, in 444—3 B.C.,—only two or three years before the probable date of this play. Thus, just at this time, the Athenian mind had been turned towards Southern Italy, and the allusion would strike a chord of sympathy in the audience. It may be worth remembering that the poet himself would naturally have felt a more than common interest in the new home of his friend Herodotus.

The only worthy rival of *)itali/an is the conjecture *)ikari/an. This was the name of a deme in the N. E. of Attica, picturesquely situated in an upland valley bounded on the N. by the mountainchain (‘Aphorismo’) which shuts in the plain of Marathon, and on the s. by Pentelicus. The site—at a place called ‘Dionyso’—is proved by local inscriptions, found by members of the American School in 1888. The story was that, when Dionysus first entered Attica, he was received at Icaria by Icarius, whom he taught to make wine. Icaria was associated with the earliest celebrations of the rural Dionysia (thus the a)skwliasmo/s, or dancing on greased wine-skins, was said to have been introduced by Icarius himself), and with the infancy of Attic drama in both kinds,—as it was also the birth-place of Thespis , and, at a later time, of the comic poet Magnes. Inscriptions and other remains show that, in the 5th century B.C., it was the seat of an active Dionysiac worship, with dramatic performances. These discoveries remind us that Sophocles might well have called Icaria kluta/n. Prof. C. Merriam A. further points out that, in literature, the legend of Icaria is often associated with that of Eleusis (American School at Athens: Seventh Annual Report, 1887—88, p. 96). To Statius, Theb. 12. 619(Icarii Celeique domus), may be added Apollod. 3. 14. 7, Lucian De Salt. 39 f., Nonnus 27. 283 ff., etc. But these facts remain: (1) *)itali/an is also suitable, and is in all the MSS.: (2) it widens the range ascribed to the god's power: (3) a corruption of *)ikari/an into *)itali/an is not one to which the letters would readily lend themselves, and would have been the less likely to occur because Icaria was familiarly associated with Dionysus.
pagkoi/nois, welcoming guests from every quarter to the Eleusinian Mysteries: schol. e)n oi)=s pa/ntes suna/gontai dia\ ta\s panhgu/reis. Cp. El. 138 e)c *)ai/+da pagkoi/nou li/mnas. Pind. O. 6. 63
pa/gkoinon e)s xw/ran (Olympia).

ko/lpois, recesses, i.e., the sheltered Thriasian plain, enclosed by hills,—Aegaleos on the E. , Cithaeron on the N., and the Kerāta range on N. W. and W. Cp. Aristoph. Ran. 373 e)s tou\s eu)anqei=s ko/lpous leimw/nwn (where, though the scene is in Hades, the allusion is to the Initiated visiting Eleusis). So Pind. O. 9. 87 *neme/as... kata\ ko/lpon: ib. 14. 23 ko/lpois par' eu)do/cou *pi/sas. This is better than to refer ko/lpois to the Bay of Eleusis, whose shores are the lampa/des a)ktai/ of O. C. 1049 (where see nn.).

*)eleusi^ni/as: on the i^, see n. on this v. in Analysis. Metr.*dhou=s = *dh/mhtros: Hom. h. Dem. 47 po/tnia *dhw/. In this connection the proper name of the god was *)/iakxos (1152), a young deity who was represented as the son of Cora (or of Demeter); cp. O. C. 682 n. Indeed, Arrian expressly distinguishes the Eleusinian Iacchus from the Theban Dionysus, An. 2. 16 § 3: *)aqhnai=oi *dio/nuson to\n *dio\s kai\ *ko/rhs se/bousin...kai\ o( *)/iakxos o( mustiko\s (the chant of the initiated) tou/tw| tw=| *dionu/sw|, ou)xi\ tw=| *qhbai/w|, e)pa/|detai. But, as Welcker remarks (Götterl. 2, p. 543), Dionysus was the general name, often substituted for the special title.

*bakxeu=. The omission of w)= before this word, and the addition of o( before matro/polin, are conjectural (cr. n.). But they are certainly right; for the antistrophic words (1133) answering to *bakxeu=—*qh/ban, are xlwra/ t' a)kta\ | polusta/fulos pe/mpei, which are unquestionably sound.

matro/polin: cp. O. C. 707 n. Thebes is the ‘mother-city’ of the Bacchants, as being the city of Semele and the native place of Dionysus. It was the place at which the Dionysiac cult, coming from Asia Minor by way of Thrace, first established itself in Greece Proper. From Thebes the cult was propagated to Delphi, and associated with the worship of Apollo. See Eur. Bacch. 306. Cp. O. T. 210 n., Tr. 510.

L has u(gro
 … r(e/eqron, not u(grw=n … r(ee/qrwn, which was merely a conjecture of Triclinius. And the use of para/ with the genit. is not only unexampled (see n. on 966), but here, at least, wholly unintelligible. Metre requires, however, that a long syllable (answering to the first syll. of *qhbai/+as in 1135) should precede a)gri/ou. I obtain this by adding t' after r(ei=qron. The second syll. of u(gro/n, as the last of a verse, is common. para/ with acc. is correct in ref. to a river, the notion being that his abode extends along its banks: cp. El. 184 o( para\ to
 *)axe/ronta qeo\s a)na/sswn: Xen. An. 4. 3§ 1 tou= pedi/ou tou= para\ to
 *kentri/thn potamo/n: ib. § 6 e)stratopedeu/santo para\ to
 potamo/n. For the position of t', cp. O. T. 258 n., O. C. 33 n. The sing. r(ei=qron is not less suitable than the plur.: cp. Aesch. Pers. 497, P. V. 790.For the epithet u(gro/n, cp. Od. 4.458 (Proteus) gi/gneto d' u(gro
 u(/dwr, ‘running water.’
*)ismhnou=: see n. on 103 f.

e)pi\ spora=| dr., ‘over the seed of the dragon,’ i.e., on the ground where Cadmus sowed the dragon's teeth, from which the ancestors of the Cadmeans sprang. Hence the Thebans are called spartoi\ a)/ndres (O.C. 1534 n.). The place where Cadmus sowed the teeth was shown on the s. side of Thebes, near the *)/hlektrai pu/lai (Paus. 9.10.1).—Not, ‘(ruling) over the dragon's seed,’ as if spora=| meant the Thebans.
The general sense is: ‘and on the heights of Parnassus thou holdest thy revels by night amid the Corycian Nymphs, who brandish torches.’

dilo/fou pe/tras: i.e., two pe/trai, each with a lo/fos (cp. 146 dikratei=s lo/gxas, n.): two peaks, one of which stands on each side of a great recess in the steep cliffs above Delphi,—the cliffs called *faidria/des, ‘gleaming,’ from their splendour in the morning sunshine (cp. Eur. Ion 86 ff.). These cliffs are about 2000 ft. above sealevel. The easternmost of the two peaks was called *(ua/mpeia: the westernmost, perh. *naupli/a, but this is doubtful. Neither of them is the summit of Parnassus. That summit, called *aukw/reia, rises high above them (about 8000 ft. above the sea). Misunderstanding diko/rufos, the Roman poets gave a wrong impression by their ‘biceps Parnassus,’ which Lucan brings out when he says (5. 72) ‘Parnassus gemino petit aethera colle.’

By u(pe\r dilo/fou pe/tras Soph. means the high ground above these two lower péaks, but below the summit of Parnassus. This high ground is what Eur. calls the diko/rufos pla/c (Eur. Bacch. 307). It consists of uplands stretching about 16 miles westward from the summit, and affording pasturage, interspersed with firs, and with pieces of arable land: wheat, oats, and barley are now grown there. These uplands were the scene of a Dionysiac triethri/s, a torch-festival, held every second year, at the end of winter, by women from the surrounding districts; even Attic women went to it (Paus. 10.4.3). Cp. Lucan 5. 73 Mons Phoebo Bromioque sacer, cui numine misto | Delphica Thebanae referunt trieteria Bacchae: and Macrobius Sat. 1. 18. 3. Here, however, the poet alludes, not to the human festival, but to supernatural revels.
lignu/s is a smoky flame, such as a resinous pine-torch gives; ste/roy finely expresses the lurid and fitful glare flashing through the smoke.

o)/pwpe, gnomic perf., ‘hath (oft) seen thee’: i.e., when the Nymphs brandish their torches, Dionysus is in the midst of them. It was the popular belief that dancing fires could be seen by night on Parnassus, when the god was holding his revels. Eur. Ion 716 (Parnassus) i(/na *ba/kxios a)mfipu/rous a)ne/xwn peu/kas | laiyhra\ phda=| nuktipo/lois a(/ma su\n *ba/kxais: cp. ib. 1125: Bacch. 306: Phoen. 226: I. T. 1243.

*kwru/kiai … *nu/mfai: Nymphs who haunt the *kwru/kion a)/ntron and its neighbourhood. The name is from kw/rukos, ‘a wallet’ (and so, a hollow thing), and was given also to a cave on the Cilician coast. The Parnassian cave is near the top of a hill on the high table-land which lies at the base of the central cone,— about 7 miles N. E. of Delphi, and as many N.W. of Aráchova. E. Itis a large stalactite cavern, consisting of an outer chamber of some 200 ft. in length, and an inner one of about 100 ft.; the greatest breadth is about 200 ft., and the greatest height, E. It 40.In 480 B.C., when the Persians were coming, many of the Delphians took refuge in it (Her. 8.36). An old place of sacrifice can still be seen in it; and an inscription found there shows that it was sacred *pani\ kai\ nu/mfais (C. I. G. 1728). Aesch. Eum. 22 se/bw de\ nu/mfas, e)/nqa *kwruki\s pe/tra | koi/lh, fi/lornis, daimo/nwn a)nastrofh/.

The simple transposition, stei/xousi nu/mfai for nu/mfai stei/xousi, satisfies the metre, and is far more probable than the change of stei/xousi into sti/xousi,—a form which, though noticed by Hesychius, is not known to have been used by any Attic writer of the classical age.

*kastali/as te na=ma, sc. o)/pwpe/ se. The *kastali/a is a stream which flows from a fissure in the high cliffs above Delphi. It issues near the easternmost of the two peaks (1126 ff., n.),—that which was called *(ua/mpeia: and bounds in cataracts, down a precipitous channel, to Delphi, where its water was used for all sacred purposes. Below Delphi it joins the Pleistus (Aesch. Eum. 27). It is now called *(/agios *)iwa/nnhs. It is fitly mentioned here, since it rises on the edge of the highlands which form the scene of the revels.

kai/ se *nusai/wn. And from Nysa in Euboea thou comest to visit Thebes, with thy followers who cry eu)oi=. The Euboean Nysa was imagined near Aegae (famous for its temple of Poseidon), on the W. coast of the island, opposite Anthedon. Cp. Stephanus Byz. and Hesych. s.v. *nu=sa. That word prob. denoted a moist and fertile place: Welcker would refer it to a lost nu/w from rt. nu (ne/w): Götterl. 1. 439. ‘Dionysos’ was ‘the Zeus of Nysa’ (Preller Myth. 1. 549). Legend placed a Nysa in Thrace (Il. 6.133), Macedonia, Thessaly, Boeotia, Naxos, Caria, Lydia, Cilicia, Arabia, Aethiopia, Libya, India, and even at Parnassus. In a fragment of the Thyestes Sophocles beautifully describes a wondrous vine of Euboea, which puts forth leaves and bears fruit in the same day: fr. 235 e)/sti ga/r tis e)nali/a | *eu)boii\s ai(=a: th=|de ba/kxeios bo/trus | e)p' h)=mar e(/rpei, k.t.l.

kissh/reis o)/xqai, ivy-clad hills. Usually o)/xqh =a river-bank, o)/xqos =a hill: so Ph. 726*sperxeiou=...par' o)/xqas, and just afterwards (729) *oi)/tas u(pe\r o)/xqwn. But the distinction is not always observed; nor need we suspect our MSS.,

for the fact was noticed in antiquity (schol. on Aratus Phaenom. 33). Thus Pind. P. 1. 64o)/xqais u(/po *tau+ge/tou: Eur. Suppl. 655 *)ismh/nion pro\s o)/xqon.—The kisso/s was to Dionysus what the da/fnh was to Apollo. The crowning with ivy (ki/sswsis) was a regular incident of his festivals: he was called kisseu/s, kissoko/mhs, kissoxai/ths. Cp. Alciphron Epist. 2. 3 § 10 ma\ to\n *dio/nuson kai\ tou\s *bakxikou\s au)tou= kissou/s. F. 3. 767 hedera est gratissima Baccho.

polusta/fulos: cp. Il. 2.537 *xalki/da t' *ei)re/tria/n te polusta/fulo/n q' *(isti/aian. As Histiaea, afterwards Oreus, was on the N. coast, we may suppose that the Homeric epithet—here borrowed by Soph. —would have been at least equally applicable to other parts of the island.
pe/mpei, agreeing with nearest subject: 830 n.

The words a)mbro/twn e)pe/wn answer metrically to naietw=n par' u(gro/n (1123). There is no metrical reason, then, for altering the MS. a)mbro/twn, with Turnebus, to a)bro/twn. Cp. O. T. 158 a)/mbrote *fa/ma. There is no certain instance of a)/brotos in Tragedy. Cp. Pind. P. 4. 299a)mbrosi/wn e)pe/wn, ‘divine strains.’ Here the epithet suggests the mystic power of the invocation.

eu)azo/ntwn: see on eu)/ion, 964: ‘while divine chants resound with the cry evoe’; i.e., while the bacchants escort thee on thy way to Thebes with chants of praise. The conjecture e(peta=n is neat, but needless.

ta\n e)k pasa=n. There is no reason, metrical or other, for suspecting the MS. reading here. See on 1146. ta/n, *qh/ban, implied in *qhbai/+as: cp. 668, 1072.—For e)k (‘chosen out of’) cp. 164: u(perta/tan, proleptic; cp. Eur. I. A. 573 mei/zw po/lin au)/cei: Plat. Rep. 565C tou=ton tre/fein te kai\ au)/cein me/gan.

kerauni/a|, destroyed by the lightning of Zeus: see on 1115 f. Works of art frequently associate Dionysus with his mother. Thus a fragmentary vase-painting shows him introducing her to Olympus (Welcker, Alte Denkm. III. pl. 13). On coins she is sometimes enthroned beside him. See Baumeister, Denkm. p. 443.

e)/xetai e)pi\ biai/as no/sou, is captive to a violent (=a most grievous) plague. The no/sos is the divine anger which Thebes has incurred (1015). e)pi\ no/sou seems to be like e)p' ei)rh/nhs (‘in time of peace’Il. 2.797), e)pi\ sxolh=s ( Aeschin. or. 3 § 191): i.e., the prep. expresses the continuing presence of the no/sos, and the whole phrase strictly means, ‘the city is in distress, under the prevalence of a malady.’ (We could scarcely compare e)pi\ cu/lou, and suppose a metaphor from a rack or cross; cp. n. on 308 f.) Musgrave's u(po/ (for e)pi/) is tame. For e)/xetai cp. Plat. Legg. 780B u(po\ pollh=s a)pori/as e)xome/nois. There is only a verbal likeness to Her. 6.11 e)pi\ curou= ga\r a)kmh=s e)/xetai (are poised) h(mi=n ta\ prh/gmata.—For biai^as cp. n. on 1310 dei/lai^os. The text is sound, without Boeckh's conjectural insertion of a)ma\ before po/lis: see on 1150.
pa/ndamos: cp. on 7.
molei=n: infin. for imperat.: cp. n. on 150 ff.

kaqarsi/w|: Dionysus was often invested with the attributes of the Purifier and Healer, as kaqa/rsios, a)leci/kakos, a)ke/sios, etc. Cp. Athen. 22 E, and 36—37. This was one aspect of the Delphian cult which associated him with Apollo.
klitu/n ¯˘, as Tr. 271: but ¯¯, Od. 5.470 e)s klitu\n a)naba/s. Here, the last syll. of the verse being common, u^n stands for u_n.
porqmo/n, the Euripus, between Euboea and Boeotia. At Chalcis (Egripo) it is only 40 yards across.

stono/enta refers to the noise of wind and water in the strait, with its constantly changing currents. Strabo 9. 403 peri\ de\ th=s palirroi/as tou= *eu)ri/pou tosou=ton monon ei)pei=n i(kano/n, o(/ti e(pta/kis metaba/llein fasi\ kaq' h(me/ran e(ka/sthn kai\ nu/kta. Livy (28. 6) explains this by the squalls from the hills. Cp. Lucan's description of the Euripus, 5. 234, Arctatus rapido fervet qua gurgite pontus.

pneio/ntwn, Brunck's simple correction of pneo/ntwn, heals the metre. The MS. reading in 1137 f. is above all reasonable suspicion; and these verses now agree with them. It is a sin against all critical method to make violent changes in 1137 f.—as Dindorf (followed by Wecklein) does—in order to keep the short syllable of pneo/ntwn here. Hermann's argument against pneio/ntwn, which has deterred editors from admitting it, was strangely weal. He said that the first syllable of the epic pnei/w never occurs with ictus (i.e., in arsis); and that, if the tragic poets had used that form, they would at least not have put an ictus on the pnei. But Homer repeatedly has pnoih=| with ictus on the 1st syll. (as first word of the verse): and as pnoih/ to pnoh/, so is pnei/w to pne/w. It is plain, therefore, that the Homeric absence of ictus from the pnei of pnei/w was purely an accident of convenience in composition, —the phrases being me/nea pnei/ontes, zefuri/h pnei/ousa, h(du\ ma/la pnei/ousan, pnei/ei te kai\ e(/rpei, etc. We need not dwell, then, on the fact which makes a second fallacy in the argument,—viz. that the ictus on pnei here is only equal to that which falls on ont (see Anal.). Tragic lyrics teem with epic forms and phrases. za/w was at least as familiar a word as pne/w. Yet twice in lyrics Soph. has ventured to use the epic zw/w: El. 157 oi(/a *xruso/qemis zw/ei: O.C. 1213 zw/ein. Is it, then, reasonable to suppose that the poet, requiring ¯¯¯ instead of ˘¯¯, would have hesitated to use the familiar epic form pneio/ntwn? Nor is this all. In Aesch. Cho. 621 the MSS. give pne/onq' a( kuno/frwn u(/pnw|: where pne/onq' a( = su/mmetron in the strophe (610), and the 1st syllable is (pace Hermanni) necessarily long, being that of a spondee (or trochee): Heath's correction, pnei/onq', is therefore certain.

Other conjectures are: (1) i)w\ pu/rpnwn a)/strwn xorage\ kai\ nuxi/wn (G. Wolff). The objection is that the contracted pu/rpnous and pu/rpnoun do not justify pu/rpnwn for purpno/wn: cp. Eur. Med. 478 tau/rwn purpno/wn e)pista/thn. (2) w)\ (for i)w\) pu=r pneo/ntwn xorage\ kai\ nuxi/wn (Campbell). Here pneo/ntwn is a spondee. But such a synizesis seems very improbable. Remark, too, that L's xorage\ a)/strwn does not warrant us in supposing that a)/strwn

originally preceded xorage/. Neglect of elision is frequent in L: thus, to take one play only, the O. C. supplies these examples: 266 ta)ma/: e)pei\: 694 e)/stin de\ oi)=on: 883 ta/de. u(/bris: 915 ku/ria w)=de: 1026 qhrw=nta h( tu/xh: 1210 i)/sqi, e)a/nper. The deletion of kai/ before nuxi/wn is also varranted by instances in which kai/ has been thrust into L. Here, the kai/ would decidedly enfeeble the passage.

xora/g' a)/strwn. The sympathetic joy of the elemental powers—stars, moon, and sea—was especially associated with those night-festivals in which Dionysus bore his mystic character, as the young *)/iakxos of the Eleusinian ritual, the companion of Demeter and Cora (n. on O. C. 682 ff.). See Eur. Ion 1078 ff., where the reference is to the Dionysus of the Great Mysteries at Eleusis: o(/te kai\ *dio\s a)sterwpo\s | a)nexo/reusen ai)qh/r, | xoreu/ei de\ *sela/na | kai\ penth/konta ko/rai | *nhre/os. Hence this crowning strain, which begins by greeting him as xorago\s a)/strwn, fitly closes with his Eleusinian name.

nuxi/wn fqegma/twn, the songs, or wild cries, of his worshippers. Eur. Bacch. 485 (Pentheus) ta\ d' i(era\ nu/ktwr h(\ meq' h(me/ran telei=s;— *d*i. nu/ktwr ta\ polla/: semno/tht' e)/xei sko/tos. Plut. Mor. 291A mentions, as Boeotian festivals of Dionysus, the *)agriw/nia and *nukte/lia,—w(=n ta\ polla\ dia\ sko/tous dra=tai. Aristoph. Ran. 340 (the Chorus of the Initiated) e)/geire floge/as lampa/das e)n xersi\ tina/sswn, | *)/iakx', w)= *)/iakxe, | nukte/rou teleth=s fwsfo/ros a)sth/r.
pai= *dio\s = kai\ nu=n w(s (1140), but is sound, since the second syllable may be either long or short (see Anal.).

w)=nac is a certain correction of L's naci/ais. The latter, i.e. *naci/ais, may be rejected for two reasons. (1) vv. 1140 f. (kai\ nu=n—e)pi\ no/sou) are clearly sound, and the weak addition of a)ma/ before po/lis is a pure guess, based on the supposed genuineness of *naci/ais here. (2) Naxos was, indeed, peculiarly associated with Dionysus, through Ariadne's story, and in other ways ( Diod. 5. 50 ff., N. H. 4. 12. 22): but, here, *naci/ais, as the epithet of his followers, would be inappropriate, since he is to visit Thebes either from Parnassus or from Euboea (1143 f.).

*qui/aisin (qu/w, to sacrifice), female votaries of Dionysus,—here, his attendant Nymphs (O. C. 679 n.),—not human worshippers. The pediment of the temple at Delphi represented Dionysus with the Thyiads, and a setting sun (Stephani, Compt. rend., 1860, vol. 3 pp. 77 ff.). Similar names were *ba/kxai, *ah=nai, *maina/des (this properly a general epithet); and, in Macedonia, *klw/dwnes, *mimallo/nes ( Plut. Alex. 2). Plut. Mor. 389C quotes some words of a thyiad song, eu)/ion o)rsigu/naika mainome/nais *dio/nuson a)nqe/onta timai=s. In Elis a Dionysiac festival was called ta\ *qui=a (Paus. 6.26.1). Cp. Catull. 64. 255 ff.: Verg. Aen. 4. 301 ff.
xoreu/ousi with acc. of the god, as Pind. I. 1. 7*foi=bon xoreu/wn. Cp. ko/ptomai, ti/llomai, tu/ptomai with acc. of person mourned.
tami/an, dispenser (of their fortunes): cp. Plat. Rep. 379E w(s ‘tami/as’ h(mi=n *zeu\s ‘a)gaqw=n te kakw=n te te/tuktai.’
*)/iakxon: see on xora/g' a)/strwn (1146).

div2.p: Exodos. The threefold catastrophe. Creon's remorse.

div3.p: do/mwn goes with *ka/dmou also: cp. O. T. 417 mhtro/s te kai\ tou= sou= patro/s: O. C. 1399 keleu/qou th=s t' e)mh=s duspraci/as. Cadmus founded Thebes; at a later time, Amphion (Niobe's husband) and his brother Zethus built a wall round it (Apoll. Rhod. 1. 740 ff.). The Thebans are pa/roikoi (neighbours) do/mwn, as dwelling around the *kadmei/a, the Theban acropolis which was the seat of Cadmus (cp. O. T. 20 n.).

ou)k e)/sti (toiou=tos a)nqrw/pou bi/os), o(poi=on ou)/t' ai)ne/saimi a)/n pote ou)/te memyai/mhn sta/nta: there is no kind of human life that I would ever praise, or complain of, as fixed. The partic. sta/nta has a causal force, giving the ground for the praise or blame. Prosperity may seem secure, or misery irremediable; but no condition can be regarded as really stable (sta/simon). Soph. has given us a perfect comment on sta/nta (which Nauck calls ‘undoubtedly’ corrupt) in fr. 786, and it is strange that it should have escaped notice:—a)ll' ou(mo\s a)ei\ po/tmos e)n puknw=| qeou= | tro/xw| kuklei=tai, kai\ metalla/ssei fu/sin: | w(/sper selh/nhs d' o)/yis eu)fro/nas du/o | sth=nai du/nait' a)\n ou)/pot' e)n morfh=| mia=|,—cannot remain fixed in one phase.

bi/on is the antecedent drawn into the clause and case of the relative: O. C. 56 o(\n d' e)pistei/beis to/pon | ...kalei=tai etc.: ib. 907 nu=n d' ou(/sper au)to\s tou\s no/mous ei)sh=lq' e)/xwn.—The only other tenable view would be: ou)k e)/sti (bi/os toiou=tos sta\s) o(poi=on ai)ne/saimi a)/n: there is no life so situated that I could praise it. On this view, sta/nta would cohere closely with o(poi=on, having been attracted into the acc. like bi/on itself. This is not impossible; but, if this were the construction, I should wish to read o(poi/a|: cp. Ai. 950 ou)k a)\n ta/d' e)/sth th=|de mh\ qew=n me/ta.

ma/ntis … tw=n kaqestw/twn, a prophet about them,—i.e. one who can say how long they will last. The conjecture e)festw/twn (‘imminent’), which Nauck receives, is decidedly wrong for two reasons. (1) Though we find *kh=res e)festa=sin, etc., the perf. part. was regularly used as it is in Ai. 1072 tw=n e)festw/twn (masc.) klu/ein ‘to obey the rulers’, and here a Greek would rather have supposed the sense to be, ‘no one in authority is a prophet.’ (2) The point is that things may seem established, and yet be unstable.
w(s e)moi/: Ai. 396 e)/rebos w<*> faenno/taton w(s e)moi/: cp. O. C. 20 n.

sw/sas … e)xqrw=n: the gen. as after lu/w, e)leuqero/w: Ph. 919sw=sai kakou=: Eur. Or. 779 swqh=nai kakw=n.— The regular constr. would have been h)=n zhlwto/s, sw/sas me
 xqo/na, labw
 de\ monarxi/an. For de/, te has been substituted, as in Tr. 1012 polla\ me
 e)n po/ntw| kata/ te dri/a pa/nta kaqai/rwn: Ph. 1056pa/resti me
 | *teu=kros,... | e)gw/ q': ib. 1136 o(rw=n me
 ai)sxra\s a)pa/tas, | stugno/n te fw=t'. Then in the second clause, labw/n te, a new finite verb, hu)/qune, has been inserted, with the result that labw/n now begins a new sentence. Cp. 815 u(/mnhsen, n.— pantelh=, complete; Plat. Legg. 698A h( pantelh\s...e)leuqeri/a: cp. 737 n.
hu)/qune: cp. 178: O. T. 104 a)peuqu/nein po/lin. The temporal augment for verbs beginning with eu is attested by Attic inscrr. of c. 403—321 B.C. (Meisterhans, p. 78).
eu)genei=, not eu)genw=n: 793 n.

a)fei=tai pa/nta, all has been given up,—has slipped from his grasp, and been lost. Cp. Her. 8.49 h( ga\r *)attikh\ a)pei=to h)/dh (to the Persians). The perf. pass. of a)fi/hmi is always pass. in sense, usu. meaning either ‘set free’ (as Isocr. or. 17 § 11), or, ‘left free’ (Plat. Critias 117C, of open ground), or ‘permitted’ (Thuc. 5.91). The only apparent instance of a)fei=mai as a perf. midd. is Dem. or. 23 § 157 tou= me\n timwrei=sqai to\n *xari/dhmon a)fei=sqai, a)postei=lai d' u(po/spondon. But there, as a)postei=lai suggests, we must surely read the 2nd aor. midd. a)fe/sqai, which was frequent in this sense (Plat. Gorg. 458C, etc.). If a)fei=tai were midd. here, we should require pa/ntwn: cp. Thuc. 2.60 tou= koinou= th=s swthri/as a)fi/esqe.

prodw=sin. prodido/nai h(dona/s could not mean merely, ‘to resign’ one's joys. It necessarily implies a fault on the loser's part; and it is precisely because Creon had committed such a fault that I believe prodw=sin to be sound. The man accused of taking a bribe to break the law was described at 322 as e)p' a)rgu/rw|... th
 yuxh
 prodou/s. Our word, ‘to forfeit,’ i.e. ‘to lose by one's own fault,’ seems fairly to represent the shade of meaning which distinguishes prodido/nai h(dona/s from a)pollu/nai h(dona/s. Creon's joys—the life of his son, and the good opinion of his subjects—have been sacrificed by him to the indulgence of stubborn self-will. Athenaeus, who twice quotes this passage (cr. n.), shows that c. 200 A. D. it was read as above: he is our oldest and best source for it. L's a)ndro\s must be considered in connection with the fact that L (like our other MSS.) omits v. 1167. L has a point at prodw=sin, and its reading was (I suspect) understood thus: ‘when (men) forfeit their pleasures, I do not count that the part of a man’ (i.e. of one who can be really said to live).
