Hence I do not think that L's a)ndro\s really confirms Seyffert's conjecture, kai\ ga h(donai\ | o(/tan prodw=sin a)ndro/s, ‘when a man's pleasures fail.’ For this use of prodido/nai, cp. Her. 7.187 ou)de/n moi qwu=ma pari/statai prodou=nai ta\ r(e/eqra tw=n potamw=n (that they failed=e)pilipei=n): id. 8. 52 tou= fra/gmatos prodedwko/tos, the barricade having failed (them). Xenophanes fr. 1. 5 a)/llos d' oi)=nos e(toi=mos, o(\s ou)/pote/ fhsi prodw/sein. So with acc., [Dem. ] or. 52 § 13 to
 o)fqalmo
 au)to
 prodido/nta (his eye-sight failing him). Yet here the phrase would seem a strange one. And if a)/ndres was older than a)ndro/s, as we have reason to believe that it was, that fact would confirm the genuineness of ta\s ga h(dona/s.—See Appendix.
ou) ti/qhmi with inf., as oft. with the midd. ti/qemai; Plat. Phaedo 93C tw=n ou)=n tiqeme/nwn yuxh\n a(rmoni/an ei)=nai. Cp. El. 1270 daimo/nion au)to\ ti/qhm' e)gw/.
For zh=n, zw/n has been proposed: but the Epic and Ionic zw/s does not occur in
tou=ton after the plur. as, conversely, o(/stis is followed by ou(=toi (709 n.), and ne/kun by w(=n (1072).
e)/my. nekro/n: cp. Ph. 1018a)/filon, e)/rhmon, a)/polin, e)n zw=sin nekro/n.

plou/tei … zh=, the hypothetical imperat.: Antiphon fr. 130 (ap. Flor. 68. 37) fe/re dh\ kai\ pai=des gene/sqwsan: fronti/dwn h)/dh pa/nta ple/a. Dem. or. 20 § 14 ou)de\ ga\r ei) pa/nu xrhsto/s e)sq', w(s e)mou= g' e(/neka e)/stw, belti/wn e)sti\ th=s po/lews to\ h)=qos.

ei) bou/lei: Plat. Rep. 432A tou\s i)sxurota/tous kai\ tou\s me/sous, ei) me\n bou/lei, fronh/sei, ei) de\ bou/lei, i)sxu/i+. For the form zh=, cp. Eur. I. T. 699 a)ll' e(/rpe kai\ zh= kai\ do/mous oi)/kei patro/s. But Anthol. P. 11. 57 pi=ne, ge/ron, kai\ zh=qi (by Agathias, c. 550 A.D.): and so ib. 10. 43 (author uncertain). sxh=ma, outward show, dignity, pomp: Plat. Legg. 685C to\ th=s a)rxh=s sxh=ma...ou) smikro/n.

to\ xai/rein: Ai. 555 e(/ws to\ xai/rein kai\ to\ lupei=sqai ma/qh|s. Aesch. Eum. 301 e)/rrein, to\ xai/rein mh\ maqo/nq' o(/pou frenw=n: ib. 423 o(/pou to\ xai/rein mhdamou= nomi/zetai. For the thought, cp. Simonides fr. 71 ti/s ga\r a(dona=s a)/ter qnatw=n bi/os poqeino\s h)\ poi/a turanni/s; | ta=s d' a)/ter ou)de\ qew=n zalwto\s ai)w/n: where h(donh/ is as general as to\ xai/rein here. More often, however, the sentiment refers to sensuous h(donai/: cp. Mimnermus fr. 1 teqnai/hn o(/te moi mhke/ti tau=ta me/loi: Antiphanes fr. incert. 51 (it is foolish to disparage e)/rws), ei) ga\r a)fe/loi tis tou= bi/ou ta\s h(dona/s, | katalei/pet' ou)de\n e(/teron h)\ teqnhke/nai.

kapnou= skia=s: gen. of price (nom., kapnou= skia/). Ph. 946ou)d' oi)=d' e)nai/rwn nekro
 h)\ kapnou= skia/n, | ei)/dwlon a)/llws. Aesch. fr. 390 to\ ga bro/teion spe/rm' e)f' h(me/ran fronei=, | kai\ pisto
 ou)de
 ma=llon h)\ kapnou= skia/. So Soph. fr. 12 a)/nqrwpo/s e)sti pneu=ma kai\ skia\ mo/non. Cp. Pind. P. 8. 95skia=s o)/nar | a)/nqrwpos. Aesch. Ag. 839 ei)/dwlon skia=s.

priai/mhn a)ndri/. After a verb of buying or receiving, the dat. of interest denotes the person who has the thing taken off his hands: Aristoph. Ach. 812 po/sou pri/wmai/ soi ta\ xoiri/dia; Il. 15.87 *qe/misti de\ kalliparh|w| | de/kto de/pas.

pro\s th\n h(d., compared with it: fr. 327. 4 ka)/sti pro\s ta\ xrh/mata | qnhtoi=si ta)/lla deu/ter': Eur. fr. 96 a)ll' ou)de\n hu(ge/neia pro\s ta\ xrh/mata. Suppose that one could buy either (1) wealth and power without joy, or (2) joy without wealth and power; in comparison with (2), (1) would be worth nothing.—Not, ‘in exchange for pleasure,’ like Plat. Phaedo 69A h(dona\s pro\s h(dona\s... katalla/ttesqai: for the price is expressed by kapnou= skia=s.

basile/wn = tura/nnwn, the royal house. Tr. 316 mh\ tw=n tura/nnwn; is she of the royal stock?—ai)/tioi qanei=n, instead of tou= qanei=n: Antiphon or. 5 § 23 e)gw\ ai)/tios h)=n pemfqh=nai a)/ggelon.—As vv. 1186 ff. show, Eurydicè is supposed to be in the act of opening the palace-door, to come out, when she overhears evil tidings. If she is supposed to have fainted (1188) immediately on hearing the general announcement in v. 1173, then her request in v. 1190 is the more natural. Possibly the spectators were allowed to catch a glimpse of her through the partly opened doors; though the Chorus announce her only at 1180.
foneu/ei = o( foneu/s e)stin: cp. O. T. 437 ti/s de/ m' e)kfu/ei brotw=n (is my sire), where see n.—o( kei/menos: cp. Aesch. Eum. 590 ou) keime/nw| pw to/nde kompa/zeis lo/gon.

au)to/xeir could mean either ‘by a kinsman's hand,’ or ‘by his own hand.’ See n. on 56 au)toktonou=nte. Hence such compounds sometimes receive a further definition, as Ai. 841 au)tosfagei=s | pro\s tw=n fili/stwn e)kgo/nwn. But in Aesch. Eum. 336 au)tourgi/ai, without any such addition,=‘murders of kinsfolk.’ G. Wolff ought not, however, to have compared Xen. Hellen. 6.4.35, a)poqnh/|skei au)to/xeiri/a| me\n u(po\ tw=n th=s gunaiko\s a)delfw=n, boulh=| de\ u(p' au)th=s e)kei/nhs, i.e., ‘by the deed of their hands’ (cp. above, v. 306), ‘though at her instigation.’ Attic prose does not use au)to/xeir or au)toxeiri/a in the pregnant poetical sense (a slayer, or a slaying, of kinsfolk), but merely in the general sense, ‘doing with one's own hands,’ etc. See Plat. Legg. 872B: ib. 865 B, etc.
fo/nou, causal gen.: 931 (tou/twn) n.

o)rqo
 h)/nusas, hast fulfilled it, so that it comes right (cp. 1136, n. on u(perta/tan): O. T. 506 pri
 i)/doim' o)rqo
 e)/pos: cp. ib. 853. O. C. 454 (mantei=a) a(moi\ *foi=bos h)/nuse/n pote.

w(s with the gen. absol. (cp. 1063 n.) marks the point of view which is to be taken: ‘in the certainty that matters stand thus.’ pa/resti boul. ta\ a)/lla, ‘ye may consider of the rest’: i.e., such are the facts; it only remains to deal with them as may seem best. bouleu/ein, to form plans, decide on a course of action, O. T. 619: ta\ a)/lla, adverbial acc. of respect, ‘as to what remains,’ instead of peri\ tw=n a)/llwn (Ai. 551 ta\ d' a)/ll' o(/moios).

w(=d' e)xo/ntwn, neut. gen. abs., without a subject: Ai. 981 w(s w(=d' e)xo/ntwn... | pa/ra stena/zein: El. 1344 teloume/nwn ei)/poim' a)/n: Aesch. Pers. 170 pro\s ta/d', w(s ou(/tws e)xo/ntwn tw=nde, su/mbouloi lo/gou | tou=de/ moi ge/nesqe, *pe/rsai. Thuc. 1.116 e)saggelqe/ntwn o(/ti...nh=es...ple/ousin.
kai\ mh/n: 526 n.

*eu)rudi/khn: anapaest in 5th place: cp. 11 n. Schol.: *(hsi/odos *(hnio/xhn au)th
 kalei=: i(/keto d' ei)s *krei/onta kai\ *(hnio/xhn [tanu/peplon, sc. Heracles: Scut. 83].—o(mou= = e)ggu/s: Aristoph. Pax 513 kai\ mh
 o(mou= 'stin h)/dh. Soph. has it also as a prep.: Ai. 767 qeoi=s...o(mou= = su
 q.: in Ph. 1218new\s o(mou= = pe/las new/s.
klu/ousa paido/s: gen. of connection, ‘about’ him: O. C. 307 klu/wn sou= (n.), hearing of thee.

w)= pa/ntes a)stoi/, said to the Chorus and the Messenger, as representing the Thebans generally. In Eur. I. T. 1422 Thoas says w)= pa/ntes a)stoi/, not to the Chorus (of Greek women), but to the Tauri as represented by his attendants. So, too, in Aristoph. Eccl. 834 w)= pa/ntes a)stoi/ is said to an imaginary body of Athenian citizens, represented by two men on the stage. In Lys. 638 the Chorus say w)= pa/ntes a)stoi/ to the audience.

*palla/dos prosh/goros eu)gma/twn answers to *palla/da prosagoreu/w eu)/gmata: i.e., the first gen. is objective, while the second represents an ‘inner’ accus. A combination of genitives was easily tolerated by Greek idiom: cp. 795 blefa/rwn i(/meros...nu/mfas (n.): Xen. Cyr. 8.3.19 deo/menoi *ku/rou a)/llos a)/llhs pra/cews. prosh/goros, active, as O. T. 1338: it is passive ib. 1437, Ph. 1353.—The shrine to which Eurydicè was going may be imagined as one of the two *palla/dos naoi/ at Thebes mentioned in O. T. 20 (n.). She was anxious to do her part in seeking to propitiate the angry gods (1019).—So Iocasta comes forth from the house to offer prayers at the altar of Apollo *lu/keios (O. T. 919), and Clytaemnestra at that of Apollo prostath/rios (El. 637).
tugxa/nw te … kai\ … ba/llei: just as she was loosing the bolt, she heard

the sound (cp. 1172 f. n.). For the temporal parataxis with te … kai/, cp. Xen. An. 1. 8 § 1 h)/dh te h)=n a)mfi\ a)gora\n plh/qousan kai\ plhsi/on h)=n o( staqmo/s: so ib. 4. 2. 12, Xen. An. 4. 6. 2, Xen. Cyr. 1. 4. 28. So with kai/ alone, O. T. 718 n.
klh=|qra xalw=sa pu/lhs a)naspastou=, loosing the bolts of the door, so that it should be opened (proleptic, cp. 475, 881). For the fem. of the verbal in -to/s, see O. T. 384 n.

klh=|qra, ‘bolts,’ are bars of wood drawn across the doors inside, and held by staples or sockets (puqme/nes O. T. 1261) in the door-posts (staqmoi/). Such bars were usu. called moxloi/, but even in prose we find the more general word klh=|qra: Xen. Anab. 7.1.17 diako/ptontes tai=s a)ci/nais ta\ klei=qra a)napetannu/ousi ta\s pu/las. There, as here, the plur. klh=|qra, referring to only one gate, indicates that more than one bolt was used; so, too, Aristoph. Lys. 310 ka)/n mh\ kalou/ntwn tou\s moxlou\s xalw=sin ai( gunai=kes, | e)mpimpra/nai xrh\ ta\s qu/ras. Cp. Aesch. Cho. 878 pu/las | moxloi=s xala=te, open the door by (withdrawing) the bars. Eur. Med. 1314 xala=te klh=|das. Pelop. 11 e)ndou=nai kai\ xala/sai ta\s qu/ras.

a)naspastou=. These doors opened inwards. e)pispa=n qu/ran meant to shut the door after one, in going out. Cp. Xen. Hellen. 6.4.36 w(s d' ei)sh=lqon, e)pispa/sasa th\n qu/ran ei)/xeto tou= r(o/ptrou (Thebè's object was to shut her brothers into the room, till they had killed Alexander of Pherae): ‘when they had entered, she, [having gone out and] shut the door, held the knocker,’—the r(o/ptron being a metal ring on the outside of the door, which also served as e)pispasth/r or handle (cp. Her. 6.91). Dion 57 oi( me\n e)/cw ta\s qu/ras e)pispasa/menoi katei=xon. (In O. T. 1244 pu/las...e)pirra/casa is said of Iocasta, within the room, shutting the doors; but they, too, opened inwards, see ib. 1261 ff.) Hence a)naspa=n qu/ran, ‘to draw it back,’ is the opposite of e)pispa=n, and means ‘to open it’ (from within). That phrase was not actually current, a)noignu/nai being the common word; but the poetical a)naspasto/s here implies it. Polyb. 5. 39. 4 is not rightly compared: there, w(s a)naspa/sontes...ta\s puli/das=‘intending to wrench the gates open,’ from outside: cp. id. 2. 5. 5 th=s ...gefu/ras a)naspa/santes ta\s sani/das, ‘having torn up the floor of the bridge.’
fqo/ggos, the Messenger's words. She had fainted before hearing more, perhaps, than vv. 1172 f., where see n.
oi)kei/ou, domestic (affecting her family): cp. 1249. —Distinguish oi)k. pa/qh (Ai. 260), oi)k. a)/tas (El. 215) as=‘caused by oneself.’
di' w)/twn: El. 737 o)cu\n di' w)/twn ke/ladon e)nsei/sas qoai=s | pw/lois: cp. O. T. 1386 f.

pro\s dmwai=si, with kli/nomai: a use of the dat. with pro/s which has epic precedent, as Il. 20.420 liazo/menon proti\ gai/h|, sinking to earth: ib. 21. 507 th\n de\ proti\ oi(= | ei(=le path\r *kroni/dhs, took her to his arms: cp. O. T. 1302 n.
a)poplh/ssomai, as=lipoyuxw=, only here: Hippocr. uses it of apoplexy.

kai\ parw\n e)rw=, kou)de\n parh/sw: I both will speak as one who was present, and will omit nothing: i.e., as my knowledge is full, so shall the story be told without reserve. For the parataxis, cp. 1112: El. 680 ka)pempo/mhn pro\s tau=ta kai\ to\ pa=n fra/sw: Tr. 626 e)pi/stamai/ te kai\ fra/sw seswsme/na. For parw)n as partic. of the imperfect, cp. 166 se/bontas (n.). Verses 1192—1195 form the dramatic apology for a trait which is manifestly open to criticism,— viz., the fulness of harrowing details communicated by the Messenger to this unhappy mother, who has only just recovered from a swoon. (See esp. 1231 —1239.)
w(=n = tou/tois w(=n: Xen. Mem. 1.2.6 diale/gesqai par' w(=n la/boien to\n misqo/n, to converse with any who might pay them. Cp. 35 n.
w(=n with yeu=stai (=fabricators), as one could say, tau=ta e)yeu/santo. For fanou/meq' after the sing. verb, cp. 734 n.
o)rqo/n, not o)rqh/: O. T. 542 n.: O. C. 592.

podago/s, Doric (cp. 715 nao/s, n.), ‘guide,’ as Eur. Phoen. 1715 su/ moi podago\s a)qli/a genou= (Oed. to Antigone). Plat. Legg. 899A has podhgei=n as= ‘to guide.’ —The word is usu. taken here as merely pedissequus, ‘attendant.’ But the sense of ‘guiding’ is essential to it. Creon had indicated the region (1110), but he need not be supposed to know the spot where the body lay, or even the exact situation of Antigone's tomb. e(spo/mhn, ‘attended,’ is compatible with guiding.

pedi/on … a)/kron=the furthest part of the plain. Near this part were the pa/goi on which the watchers sat (411), and Antigone's tomb was in one of those pa/goi (774 n.). Thebes had hills to the N. of it, and stood on a low spur which they throw out southward (117 ff., n.). The a)/kron pedi/on, then, is the plain's northern edge, where it touches the lower slopes of the hills. The ‘furthest’ was thus also the highest part.
nhlee/s, passive: O. T. 180.
kunospa/rakton: cp. 206, 1017. Antigone had paid the rites while the corpse was still intact (257), and in this sense is said to have saved it from birds and dogs (697: cp. 467).
to\n me/n, as opposed to Antigone: but instead of th=s de\ numfei=on, etc., we have a change of construction (1204 au)=qis k.t.l.).

e)nodi/an qeo/n, Hecatè, who was conceived as a wandering goddess, haunting the places where roads met, and where offerings were left for her. (*triodi=tis, Trivia: Theocr. 2. 36 a( qeo\s e)n trio/doisi.) Sophocles in his *(pizoto/moi gave an incantation by Medea, invoking Helios and Hecatè (fr. 490, schol. Apoll. Rhod. 3. 1214): *(/hlie de/spota kai\ pu=r i(ero/n, | th=s ei)nodi/as *(eka/ths e)/gxos, | to\ di' *ou)lu/mpou pwlou=sa fe/rei (which she bears when she moves through the sky, as Selenè), | kai\ gh=snai/ous' i/era\s trio/dous, | stefanwsame/nh drui/+ kai\ plektai=s | w)mw=n spei/raisi drako/ntwn. The last two lines refer to a custom of representing her as crowned with serpents, and with chaplets of oakleaves. Creon invokes her along with Pluto (Hades, O. T. 30 n.), because on earth she represented the xqo/nioi. As e)nodi/a, she was more especially associated with Hermes e)no/dios and yuxopompo/s: hence she was sometimes called a)/ggelos.
qeo/n, fem., as 834: O. C. 1548 h(... nerte/ra qeo/s, ib. 1556 ta\n a)fanh= qeo/n (Persephone). Cp. ib. 683 n.
eu)menei=s, proleptic: 881 n.
katasxeqei=n: cp. on 1102.
lou/santes a(gn. loutro/n (cognate acc.): cp. on 901.

e)n, ‘with,’ of the instrument: 764 (n.), 962, 1003.— qalloi=s, from the u(/lh pedia/s close by (420).—Boeckh thought that olive-boughs were meant, citing a no/mos ap. [Dem. ] or. 43 § 71 e)a\n mh\ (e)lai/a|)...e)pi\ a)poqano/nta de/h| xrh/sasqai. But that, surely, does not refer to a pura/. The olive, like the laurel, was used for other purposes connected with the dead,—viz., in crowning the corpse for the pro/qesis (cp. schol. Eur. Phoen. 1626), and in decking the kli/nh on which the corpse was laid (Aristoph. Eccl. 1030).—o(/ dh\ = o(/ ti dh/pote, implying that much of the body had been destroyed. Cp. Her. 1.160 e)pi\ misqw=| o(/sw| dh/: ou) ga\r e)/xw tou=to/ ge ei)pei=n a)treke/ws.
)le/leipto: cp. 457 'fa/nh n.

sugkath/|qomen. The su/n here is perh. not merely ‘completely,’ but implies the collecting of dismembered pieces: as sugkatakai/w regularly=to burn something ‘along with’ something else (Xen. Anab. 3.2.27). Like ei)sebai/nomen (1205), this is the imperf. of consecutive action (‘proceeded to burn,’ = ‘next burned’).

tu/mbon. If the Homeric usage was followed, when the flesh had been burned the bones would be washed with wine or oil, wrapped in fat, and placed in an urn (la/rnac). The urn having been deposited in a grave (ka/petos), the tu/mbos (or sh=ma) would be raised over it. Cp. Introd. to Homer, ch. 11. § 33.
o)rqo/kranon, lit., with head erect, so=‘high’: cp. u(yika/rhnos, u(yi/lofos (of hills). From kra_n (krani/on) we have also bou/kra_nos, tauro/kra_nos.

oi)kei/as, ‘native,’—a thing pleasing to the dead: so in O. C. 406 Oed. asks, h)= kai\ kataskiw=si *qhbai/a| ko/nei; The father's prophecy for his sons was fulfilled: of their father-land they obtained o(po/san kai\ fqime/noisin kate/xein ( Aesch. Th. 731: cp. O. C. 789).
au)=qis answers to to\n me/n (1199), as in 167 tou=t' au)=qis to tou=to me/n.
For au)=qis as=‘afterwards,’ cp. Ai. 1283, Tr. 270.

liqo/strwton, ‘with floor of stone,’ here suggests, ‘affording no couch but one of stone,’ in contrast with a real numfei=on, which contains a le/xos eu)/strwton... | xlai/nh|sin malakh=|s e)strwme/non (Hom. hymn. Ven. 157 f.).
ko/rhs numfei=on-*(/aidou, the maiden's death-bower: cp. 795 n., 929.
kwkuma/twn, the word used by Teiresias (1079): here, as usu., for the dead: cp. 28, 204, 1302: so kwkuto/s, Ai. 851 etc.—Cp. El. 683 o)rqi/wn khrugma/twn.

a)kte/riston a)mfi\ pasta/da, near (i.e. from the quarter of) the bridalchamber where no funeral-rites had been paid; i.e., where Antigone had been made the bride of Death, without even such honours as befitted such nuptials. For a)kte/ristos cp. 1071 n. The word pasta/s seems to be here used simply as a poetical equivalent for qa/lamos. There is probably no reference to pillars of rock (natural or artificial) in the ta/fos. On the uses of pasta/s, see Appendix.

a)qli/as … a)/shma boh=s, indistinct sounds, consisting in an a)qli/a boh/: i.e., as he drew nearer, the sounds resolved themselves into the mournful cry of a human voice. The genit. is thus a ‘defining’ one. Cp. O. C. 923 n. fwtw=n a)qli/wn i(kth/ria (suppliant objects consisting in unhappy persons). Below, in 1265, the form of w)/moi e)mw=n a)/nolba bouleuma/twn is analogous, but the gen. is there partitive (see n.). Here, boh=s could, indeed, be possessive (‘sounds belonging to, i.e., forming part of, a cry’). But the perspective of the description is better kept by the other view of the genitive, which supposes that a sound, ambiguous at a distance, defines itself as we approach.

peribai/nei, with dat. instead of the normal acc.; this dat. denotes the person interested, i.e., here affected through the senses: O. C. 372 ei)sh=lqe toi=n tri\s a)qli/oin e)/ris (n.): Tr. 298 e)moi\ ga\r oi)=ktos... ei)se/bh. For the image, cp. O. C. 1477 a)mfi/statai | diapru/sios o)/tobos: Od. 6.122 w(/s te/ me koura/wn a)mfh/luqe qh=lus a)u+th/.
ma=llon a)=sson: cp. Aesch. Th. 673ma=llon e)ndikw/teros: Eur. El. 222 ma=llon e)xqi/ous: Plat. Legg. 781A laqraio/teron ma=llon kai\ e)piklopw/teron.
e)/pos (=qrh=non) dusqrh/nhton: see n. on 7.
w)= ta/las: cp. O. T. 744 n.
tw=n parelqousw=n: cp. 100 f. ka/lliston...tw=n prote/rwn, n.

sai/nei, ‘greets my ear.’ As sai/nw was properly said of a dog wagging its tail or fawning so it could be said of a sight or a sound which appeals for recognition by vividly striking our senses. Like arridere, the word usually implied a sensation of pleasure (O. C. 319 n.). But it could also denote, as here, a recognition attended by pain. So in Hippol. 862 f., where Theseus recognises the seal on the tablets left by his dead wife, he says tu/poi...prossai/nousi/ me.
w)kei=s, adverbial: cp. 823, 847: Tr. 927 dromai/a ba=s'.

a(rmo\n xw/matos liqosp., an opening in the stones heaped up at the entrance, made by dragging some of them away. Cp. 848 e(/rgma tumbo/xwston. Haemon, in his frenzy of despair, had broken into the tomb by wrenching away part of this rude wall-work. The gap remained as he had made it. He had reached the spot only a short time before Creon (cp. on 1223).

a(rmo/n. The word a(rmo/s means, (1) a fastening: Eur. Med. 1315 e)klu/eq' a(rmou/s, undo the fastenings of the doors: (2) the chink between two things which are jointed together: so in Plut. Alex. 3 a furtive listener is described as tw=| th=s qu/ras a(rmw=| prosbalw\n (th\n o)/yin), ‘having put his eye to the chink in the door.’ So here a(rmo/s is an aperture, just wide enough to admit of a man going through (cp. du/ntes).— a(rmo/s (with its derivatives a(rmoi=, a(rmo/zw, a(rmoni/a), and a(rpedo/nh (or a(rpedw/n), ‘rope,’ are connected with the causative form of the root ar, ar-pajā-mi, ‘to fasten’: see Curt. Etym. § 488.
sto/mion. Having passed through the gap, they will find themselves in a narrow passage. They are to go along this passage to the very mouth (sto/mion) of the sepulchral chamber into which it opens.

The kind of tomb which the poet here imagines is perhaps best represented, in Greece, by the rock-tombs of Nauplia, and of Spata in Attica. These consist of chambers worked horizontally into the rock, and approached by a passage or dro/mos, answering to that which Creon's men have to traverse before they reach the sto/mion of the tomb. The general type seems to have been determined by that of the more elaborate domed tombs, such as the so-called ‘Treasury of Atreus’ at Mycenae, which, like these ruder copies, were entered by a dro/mos. Indeed, the Nauplia tombs indicate a rough attempt to reproduce the dome (qo/los). [See Helbig, Das Homer. Epos aus den Denkm. erläutert, p. 53, with the sources quoted there in nn. 5, 6.]

The phrase loi/sqion tu/mbeuma (1220) might suggest a recess within the principal chamber, like that in the ‘Treasury of Atreus’; but it is simpler to take it as merely ‘the furthest part of the tomb.’ We may observe that the words katw=ruc (774) and kataskafh/s (891) are sufficiently explained if we suppose that the dro/mos leading to the chamber sloped downwards from the entrance.
qeoi=si: dat. of agent with pres. pass.: see n. on 503 ff.
kle/ptomai, am deluded: 681 n.—Cp. O. C. 316 h)\ gnw/mh plana=|;

The simple correction, keleusma/twn for keleu/smasin, is (I think) certainly right. Cp. Aesch. Pers. 397 e)/paisan a(/lmhn bru/xion e)k keleu/smatos (and similarly Eur. I. T. 1405): Her. 6.50 e)/lege de\ tau=ta e)c e)pistolh=s th=s *dhmarh/tou.

With keleu/smasin, we have only two tolerable resources. (1) To join keleu/smasin e)c a)qu/mou despo/tou, ‘orders given by him.’ But, though toi=s e)c a)q. desp. keleu/smasin could be defended by th\n e)c e)mou= dusbouli/an (95), the phrase without the article is very strange. In phrases which might appear similar, it will be found that a verb has influenced the use of e)k with gen.: thus Ai. 137 se\ d' o(/tan... | lo/gos e)k *danaw=n kako/qrous e)pibh=|: Aesch. Ag. 1366 h)= ga\r tekmhri/oisin e)c oi)mwgma/twn | manteuso/mesqa ta)ndro\s w(s o)lwlo/tos; here, however, it is impossible to take e)c a)qu/mou despo/tou with h)qrou=men, and to make keleu/smasin a mere epexegesis (‘looked, at our master's instigation, i.e., by his command’).

(2) The alternative is to amend e)c a)qu/mou. Only one correction is probable, viz. o)cuqu/mou. The decisive objection to this is the sense. It could mean only, ‘swift to wrath,’ like o)cu/xolos (955). It could not mean merely, ‘agitated’ (by alarm). But Creon is no longer proud or fierce; he has been humbled: his late words (1211 ff.) expressed only grief and fear.

Dindorf writes keleu/masin, holding this to be the older Attic form (cr. n.). The fact appears to be that both ke/leuma and ke/leusma are well attested in our MSS. of some authors: and there is no evidence from inscriptions. As regards the verb, Lobeck (on Ai. 704) remarks that, while e)keleu/sqhn is far commoner than e)keleu/qhn, keke/leumai and keke/leusmai are both well attested for the best age. But Veitch's statement on this point is more accurate. While e)keleu/qhn is extremely rare in classical Greek, keke/leumai is nearly (if not quite) unknown to it. It would be very rash, then, to affirm that Soph. must have used the nonsigmatic form of the noun.

au)xe/nos: the gen. of the part, as with verbs of seizing, etc.: H.A. 9. 50. 7 o(/tan krema/swsi (ta\s u(=s) tw=n o)pisqi/wn podw=n: so kremw=men with gen., Plut. 312: Il. 17.289 (to\n) podo\s e(/lke: Od. 3.439 bou=n d' a)ge/thn kera/wn.

mitw/dei, thread-like, i.e., formed by a thread-wrought fabric (the sindw/n), and not, as usual, by a cord. mi/tros (o(), the thread of the warp: Eur. I. T. 817 u(/fhna kai\ to/d' ei)=dos eu)mi/tois plokai=s (I wrought this scene, too, with threads deftly woven).—sindo/nos. sindw/n (prob. from *)ind-, Sind) was a general term for a smooth, fine texture, as bu/ssos was the specific word for a kind of fine linen: Her. 2.86 describes mummies as swathed sindo/nos bussi/nhs telamw=si (where see Stein). Thuc. 2.49. 4 tw=n pa/nu leptw=n i(mati/wn kai\ sindo/nwn. Laert. Diog. 6. 90 tells of an Athenian (c. 300 B.C.) being reprimanded by the a)stuno/moi for luxuriousness, o(/ti sindo/na h)mfi/esto.—Antigone used her veil (ka/lumma: cp. Aristoph. Lys. 532).

Haemon has thrown his arms around her waist (a)mfi\ me/ssh| peripeth=), embracing her (proskei/menon), where she hangs lifeless. But verses 1236—1240 require us to suppose that Antigone's body is then stretched on the ground. We are left to understand that Haemon, while uttering his lament (1224 f.), has lifted the corpse, so as to extricate it from the noose, and has laid it down. Cp. O. T. 1266 (where Oed. finds Iocasta hanging), xala=| kremasth\n a)rta/nhn.
me/ssh|: cp. 1236: fr. 235. 5 (iambics). Eur. has this form only in lyr.; Aesch. nowhere.

peripeth=, act.; but pass. in Ai. 907 e)/gxos pe, pete/s (‘on which he fell’), unless I am right in suspecting that there we should read, to/d' e)/gxos peripetou=s kathgorei=, ‘shows that he fell upon it.’ Cp. O. C. 1620 e)p' a)llh/loisin a)mfikei/menoi, n.

eu)nh=s … th=s ka/tw, his bride who is dead. Cp. Eur. Tro. 831 ai( me\n eu)na/s (husbands), ai( de\ pai=das, | ai( de\ mate/ras geraia/s. It would be awkward to understand, ‘the ruin of his marriage, (which is to be only) in the world below.’
patro\s e)/rga: he does not know that Creon is listening.
le/xos, marriage, as in 573. This word, too, could mean ‘bride’ (Ai. 211): it is v. 1224 that decides our version.
sfe, Haemon: 44 n.
stugno/n, bitter,—the notion of ‘sad,’ ‘gloomy,’ coming from that of ‘hateful’: cp. Moschus 3. 68 kai\ stugnoi\ (tristes) peri\ sw=ma teo\n klai/ousin *)/erwtes.

oi(=on e)/rgon: i.e., Haemon's forcible entrance into Antigone's tomb.— ti/na nou=n e)/sxes; lit., ‘what thoughts hast thou conceived?’—the aor. meaning, as usu., not ‘had,’ but ‘came to have.’ So El. 1013 f. nou=n sxe\s...ei)kaqei=n, ‘form the purpose to yield’: ib. 1465 nou=n e)/sxon, w)/ste sumfe/rein toi=s krei/ssosin.

e)n tw=| sumfora=s, by what manner of calamity: i.e., ‘what cruel god hath deprived thee of thy reason?’ Ai. 314 ka)nh/ret' e)n tw=| pra/gmatos kuroi= pote: Ph. 174e)pi\ panti/ tw| xrei/as: Eur. Helen 1195 e)n tw=| de\ kei=sai sumfora=s;
diefqa/rhs, mentally: Il. 15.128 maino/mene, fre/nas h)le/, die/fqoras: Eur. Helen 1192 die/fqarsai fre/nas;
i(ke/sios, adverbial: cp. 1215 w)kei=s, n. He extends his right hand in supplication.
o)/ssoisi: Aesch. admits o)/ssois, and Eur. both o)/ssois and o)/sswn, in iambics no less than in lyrics.
papth/nas: with an acc. this verb usu.=‘to look around for,’ as Il. 4.200.

ptu/sas prosw/pw|. Haemon is momentarily insane with despair and rage: the very words au(tw=| xolwqei/s, 1235, indicate the transport of frenzy which these verses were meant to depict. Nothing could do more violence to the language, or more injury to the dramatic effect, than the Scholiast's theory that ptu/sas prosw/pw| has a merely figurative sense, ‘with an expression of loathing on his face.’ When the figurative sense of a word (like ptu/sas) is to be marked by a qualifying addition (like prosw/pw|), that addition must not be such as equally to suggest the literal sense. Thus a socialist riot might be called ‘a fire not of Hephaestus’ (Eur. Or. 621); but it would not be equally happy to describe it as ‘a fire kindled by the tables of the rich.’ ptu/sas prosw/pw|, instead of e)piptu/sas prosw/pw| (patro/s), is merely an instance of the boldness with which poetry could use a simple dative to express the object to (or against) which an action is directed. Such a dat. is often equivalent to (a) e)pi/ with dat., (b) e)pi/, pro/s, or ei)s, with acc., —in various relations, and with various shades of meaning. Thus we have such phrases as kakoi=s gelw=n (Ai. 1042)=kakoi=s e)peggelw=n: Ph. 67lu/phn...*)argei/ois balei=s = e)mbalei=s: Eur. Suppl. 322 toi=s kertomou=si gorgo\n w(s a)nable/pei, how she looks up sternly at her revilers: Il. 7.101 tw=|de d' e)gw\n au)to\s qwrh/comai, against him: ib. 23. 635 o(/s moi a)ne/sth, against me: and below 1236 h)/reise pleurai=s = e)ph/reise. Prose would have ptu/sas ei)s (or e)pi\) pro/swpon.

diplou=s knw/dontas ci/fous, his cross-hilted sword. knw/dontes are the two projecting cross-pieces at the point where the hilt joins the blade. The hilt (kw/ph) of the Greek sword had no guard, nor had it always the cross-pieces; but these, when used, served partly to protect the hand. The knw/dontes, or cross-hilt, can be seen on some of the swords given by Guhl and Koner, p. 244, fig. 277 (a, d). The cross-hilt was sometimes simply a straight cross-bar; sometimes the side next the hand was rounded. Cp. Silius Italicus Pun. 1. 515 pressumque ira simul exigit ensem, | Qua capuli statuere morae. —knw/dwn (kna/w, o)dou/s) meant properly any tooth-like prong or spike: see Cyneg. 10. 3, where boar-spears (probo/lia) have knw/dontas a)pokexalkeume/nous stifrou/s, stout teeth forged of bronze, projecting from the shaft a little below the head (lo/gxh). In Ai. 1025, tou=d' ai)o/lou knw/dontos, ‘this gleaming spike,’ is the end of the sword-blade projecting through the body of Ajax. So in Kaibel Epigr. 549. 11 (an epitaph of the 1st cent. A.D. ) fasga/nou knw/donti=‘with the point (not, ‘edge’) of the sword’: the ref. is to thrusting, not cutting.—The Scholiast wrongly explains diplou=s knw/dontas by dipla=s a)kma/s, ‘double edge.’ This interpretation was obviously suggested by diplou=s (since a sword is often called di/stomon or a)/mfhkes), while the true sense of knw/dwn was not accurately remembered: thus the Schol. vaguely calls it to\ o)cu\ tou= ci/fous.
e)k d' o(rm., tmesis: cp. 427.

fugai=sin, dat. of manner (620 n.). The poet. plur. of fugh/, when it does not mean ‘remedies’ (364), usu. means ‘exile’ (Eur. El. 233). The gen. might be absol., but is more simply taken with h)/mplak'.

Haemon, in his madness, meant to kill his father. He had harboured no such purpose before (see on 752); and his frantic impulse is instantly followed by violent remorse. Arist. ( Arist. Poet. 14) observes that it is not conducive to a properly tragic effect (ou) tragiko/n, a)paqe/s) if a person contemplates a dreadful act, and then desists from it, in the light of sober thought or fuller knowledge: dio/per ou)dei\s poiei= o(moi/ws ei) mh\ o)liga/kis (such incidents in Tragedy are rare), oi(=on e)n *)antigo/nh| *kre/onta o( *ai(/mwn. It need not be assumed that Arist. meant to censure Sophocles; it is more natural to suppose that he cited the exception as one justified by the circumstances. But it should further be noticed that Aristotle was not accurate in taking this incident as the exception which illustrated his rule. For Haemon did not abandon his dreadful purpose; he was simply foiled by his father's flight. And then, in swift remorse, he actually did tw=n a)nhke/stwn ti.

w(/sper ei)=x': cp. 1108.— e)pentaqei/s, lit., ‘stretched,’ or ‘strained,’ against the sword: i.e., pressing his right side against the point of the sword, which at the same time he drove home with his right hand.
pleurai=s, used as though h)/reise were e)ph/reise: cp. Pind. P. 10. 51a)/gkuran e)/reison xqoni/. For the verb cp. Eur. Andr. 844 (ci/fos) a)po/dos,...i(/n' a)ntai/an | e)rei/sw plaga/n.
me/sson, predicative, denoting the point up to which he drove it in: Ai. 899 kei=tai krufai/w| fasga/nw| periptuxh/s.
e)/gxos = ci/fos: Ai. 95, 658, etc.

e)s d' u(gro
 a)gkw=n', since p. prosptu/ssetai = parqe/non lamba/nei: cp. the beautiful lines in Eur. Phoen. 1439 (the dying Eteocles): h)/kouse mhtro/s, ka)piqei\s u(gra
 xe/ra | fwnh
 me
 ou)k a)fh=ken, o)mma/twn d' a)/po | prosei=pe dakru/ois.

fusiw=n, breathing hard: r(oh/n is governed by e)kba/llei only. But in Aesch. Ag. 1389 the compound governs the acc.: ka)kfusiw=n o)cei=an ai(/matos sfagh\n | ba/llei m' e)remnh=| yaka/di foini/as dro/sou.
r(oh\n is plainly right: the bad variant, pnoh/n, was perh. suggested by fusiw=n.
te/lh, rites: O. C. 1050 n.

e)/n g' *(/aidou. Though ei)n occurs nowhere else in tragic iambics, it might fairly be defended, in a r(h=sis of epic colour, as a reminiscence of the Homeric ei)n *)ai/+dao. But I decidedly prefer Heath's e)/n g' (‘in that world, though not in this’), because it adds point and pathos to what would otherwise be a somewhat tame statement of fact. Cp. 750. For another (probable) loss of ge in this play, cp. 648. For e)/n ge, cp. O. T. 1380 e)/n ge tai=s *qh/bais: O. C. 153 e)/n g' e)moi/: Ph. 685i)/sos e)/n g' i)/sois: Eur. fr. 349 w(s e)/n g' e)moi\ kri/noit' a)\n ou) kalw=s fronei=n.

dei/cas … th\n a)bouli/an: for the constr., cp. n. on 883 f. For deiknu/nai said of a warning example, see El. 1382 kai\ dei=con a)nqrw/poisi ta)piti/mia | th=s dussebei/as oi(=a dwrou=ntai qeoi/: cp. O. T. append. on 622 ff.
pro/skeitai: cp. 94 n.
ti/ tou=t' a)\n ei)ka/s., sc. ei)=nai: what wouldst thou conjecture this to be (or, to mean)? The optat. ending used here was the usual one in Attic: cp. O.T. 843 n.

e)sqlo\n h)\ kako/n: cp. on 40.— A silent exit is similarly a prelude to disaster in the case of Deianeira (Tr. 813). Iocasta, too, quits the scene, not, indeed, without a word, yet with a reticence which is called siwph/ (O.T. 1075).
teqa/mbhk': cp. O. C. 1140 qauma/sas e)/xw (n.): and so oft. teqau/maka.
bo/skomai: cp. fr. 863 e)lpi\s ga\r h( bo/skousa tou\s pollou\s brotw=n.

go/ous … a)ciw/sein=to think them a)/cioi, i.e., meet. This use of a)cio/w is freq. in regard to persons, as Ai. 1114 ou) ga\r h)ci/ou tou\s mhde/nas (esteem them). On the other hand, a)/cios, as applied to actions, oft.=‘proper,’ ‘becoming’: as Aristoph. Eq. 616 nu=n a)/r' a)/cio/n ge pa=si/n e)stin e)pololu/cai. But, if a)cioi= tina could mean, ‘he thinks a person estimable,’ poetry, at least, could surely say, a)cioi= ti, ‘he thinks a thing proper.’ The text, then, seems sound.
u(po\ ste/ghs: for the gen., cp. 692 n.
proqh/sein governs pe/nqos: ste/nein is epexeg. (for them to mourn): cp. 216 n. She will ‘set the grief before

them’ by making a lament, after which her handmaids, sitting around her, will wail in chorus. Il. 24.746 (Andromache has bewailed Hector,) w(s e)/fato klai/ous': e)pi\ de\ stena/xonto gunai=kes. | th=|sin d' au)=q' *(eka/bh a)dinou= e)ch=rxe go/oio.

gnw/mhs … ou)k a)/peiros. The reading has been unjustly suspected. gnw/mh, ‘judgment,’ or ‘discretion,’ is here regarded as an influence moulding the character from without. The phrase means, then, ‘not uninformed by discretion,’—not unversed in its teachings. Cp. Plat. Rep. 519B tou\s a)paideu/tous kai\ a)lhqei/as a)pei/rous, ‘uninformed by truth.’
d' ou)=n: 688 n. prosei=nai: so oft. of attendant circumstances (or of characteristic attributes): Tr. 250 tou= lo/gou d' ou) xrh\ fqo/non, | gu/nai, prosei=nai. —Cp. 720.

ei)so/mesqa, mh/ ti … kalu/ptei, ‘we shall know (about our fear) lest (mh/) she is concealing,’ i.e., whether we are right in fearing that she conceals something. As Goodwin says (Moods and Tenses, § 46, N. 5 a), this passage is one of the most favourable to the view that mh/ has an interrogative force, and yet here also mh\ kalu/ptei plainly expresses a fear. The pres. indic. is used, because the fear is strictly present; there is no thought that the thing feared can possibly be prevented. Before assuming that mh/ could have the force of ei) ou) (‘whether not’), we should require an example in which the clause with mh/, after a verb like oi)=da, expressed something which is not feared (but hoped; or else regarded with neither fear nor hope). As if here we had, ei)so/mesqa mh\ zh/sein e)/ti me/llei. Cp. 278 n. The use of mh/ in direct question (O. C. 1502) is, of course, elliptical: e.g., mh\ ou(/tws e)/xei; comes from (de/doika) mh\ ou(/tws e)/xei.
kai\ (‘indeed’) goes with the whole phrase kata/sxeton … kalu/ptei: cp. 770n.
kata/sxeton, a poet. word, here=‘repressed’ (cp. El. 1011 kata/sxes o)rgh/n): usu., ‘possessed’ (by a god, or by passion), like ka/toxos.
do/mous parastei/xontes, advancing into the house: Eur. Med. 1137 parh=lqe numfikou\s do/mous.
kai\ mh/n: 526.
e)fh/kei: Ai. 34 kairo\n d' e)fh/keis.—The Messenger now goes into the palace. The same actor returns at 1277 as e)ca/ggelos.
mnh=m', as the epithet e)pi/shmon shows, means that the son's corpse is a memorial of the father's unwisdom.
dia\ xeiro/s: cp. 916.

ei) qe/mis ei)pei=n (cp. O. C. 1556), because it is a heavy charge against the King, that he has caused his son's death.— a)/thn, in apposition with mnh=ma: the corpse is an a)/th, because the death was caused by Creon's infatuation. a)llotri/an here answers to oi)kei=os as=‘caused by oneself’ (cp. on 1187).

a(martw/n is causal: he is bringing a corpse, not through the fault of others, but because he himself has erred. For the partic. in the nom., opposed to a clause of different form, cp. Dem. or. 23 § 156 ei)=den, ei)/te dh/ tinos ei)po/ntos ei)/t' au)to\s sunei/s. See also 381 f.

This kommo/s is composed of four strophes and four antistrophes, which correspond as follows. (1) 1st strophe 1261—1269=1st antistr. 1284—1292. (2) 2nd str. 1271—1277 =2nd ant. 1294—1300. (3) 3rd str. 1306—1311=3rd ant. 1328—1333. (4) 4th str. 1317—1325=4th ant. 1339— 1347.
The lyric strophes and antistrophes are divided from each other by iambic trimeters, spoken by the Chorus or by the Messenger.—See Metrical Analysis.
frenw=n dusfro/nwn: 502 n. Cp. Aesch. Th. 874i)w\ i)w\ du/sfrones, ‘misguided ones.’ More often, du/sfrwn =‘gloomy,’ or ‘malignant.’
sterea/, with ref. to his own au)qa/deia, cp. 1028. So Plat. Polit. 309B to\ stereo\n h)=qos. Cp. Ai. 925 e)/melles xro/nw| | stereo/frwn a)/r' w)=d' e)canu/sein kaka\n | moi=ran.
w)= … ble/pontes. Like Antigone (937), Creon now calls the Theban Elders to witness. Cp. n. on 162—210.
ktano/ntas refers to Creon himself (for the plur., cp. 10), as qano/ntas to Haemon: for the parh/xhsis, cp. Ph. 336o( ktanw/n te xw( qanw/n.
e)mfuli/ous = suggenei=s: cp. O. T. 1406 ai(=m' e)mfu/lion (n.): O. C. 1385 gh=s e)mfuli/ou, ‘the land of thy race.’

e)mw=n a)/nolba bouleuma/twn, the unhappy (counsels) among my counsels (partitive gen.); i.e., the unhappiness involved in my counsels. See on 1209. This poetical periphrasis has the effect of making the idea expressed by a)/nolba stand out with a quasi-substantival force, and so is slightly stronger than w)/moi e)ma\ a)/nolba bouleu/mata. It would be possible, but it is neither requisite nor fitting, to supply a(marth/mata (1261) with a)/nolba, placing only a comma at e)mfuli/ous.— For a)/nolbos, of folly, cp. 1026.

ne/os ne/w| cun mo/rw|, ‘young, and by an untimely death,’ is a pleonasm, but a natural one. The Schol. explains ne/w| by kainoprepei= (‘a death of a strange kind’). This sense is possible (cp. Aesch. Suppl. 712 a)prosdokh/tous tou/sde kai\ ne/ous lo/gous), but is far less fitting here. ne/w| cu\n mo/rw|, suggesting the thought that his years had been few, recalls Andromache's lament,—a)=ner, a)p' ai)w=nos ne/os w)/leo (Il. 24.725).

a)pelu/qhs: cp. 1314, where the midd. aor. has the same sense. In later Greek a)polu/esqai and a)po/lusis came to be used of any ‘departure’: thus in Polyb. 3. 69 th
 a)poxw/rhsin...e)poiou=nto is presently varied to e)poiou=nto th
 a)po/lusin. Here, however, the word has a distinctly poetical colour, and suggests the release of yuxh/ from sw=ma,—though without the feeling expressed by the words, a)polu/eis to
 dou=lo/n sou...e)n ei)rh/nh| (St Luke ii. 29). A fragment of Plutarch (Wyttenbach, p. 135) attests a familiar use of a)polu/esqai and a)po/lusis with reference to death. Eustathius quotes this v., and v. 1314, in support of a like statement (p. 548, 52).
e)mai=s ou)de\ sai=si. ou)de/ here= kai\ ou): cp. 492. The negative form would be ou)k e)mai=s a)lla\ sai=s (El. 1470).

e)/xw maqw\n = mema/qhka (21 n.), though here with a slightly stronger emphasis than that of an ordinary perf.: ‘I have fully learned.’—No change is required in 1273. The soundness of the metre is confirmed by the antistrophic verse (1296), which is free from suspicion. Construe: o( de\ qeo\s e)n tw=| e)mw=| ka/ra| e)/paise/ me, me/ga ba/ros e)/xwn. Three points claim notice. (1) The place of me. This was possible, because me/ga ba/ros, without e)/xwn, could have stood as an adverbial cognate acc.: hence e)/xwn is rather a superfluity than a word for which the ear was waiting. Greek poetry (esp. lyric) often has bold arrangements of words: cp. 944, 960 (n.). (2) me/ga ba/ros e)/xwn = sfo/dra baru\s w)/n. Cp. 300: Od. 24.249 gh=ras | lugro\n e)/xeis: ib. 1. 368 u(/brin e)/xontes. (3) e)n d' e)mw=| ka/ra| might have been followed by e)nh/lato, or the like; but, e)/paise being used, the enclitic me was required to make it clear. The charge of redundancy would be just only if e)mw=| were followed by e)me/.—For the image, cp. 1345: Aesch. Ag. 1175 dai/mwn u(perbarh\s e)mpi/tnwn: and see O. T. 263n. Triclinius understood the blow on the head to mean a disordering of the intellect (a)nti\ tou=, e)ce/sthse ta\s e)ma\s fre/nas). But it is simply a poetical picture of the fell swoop with which the god descended on his victim,—taking possession of him, and driving him astray. Perhaps e)mbro/nthtos helped to suggest the other view. For the form of the dat. ka/ra|, cp. O. C. 564 n.
e)n d' e)/seisen, tmesis (420).
a)gri/ais o(doi=s: cp. Pind. P. 2. 85a)ll' a)/llote pate/wn o(doi=s skoliai=s, in paths of guile.

lakpa/thton, proleptic (475). The form lacpa/thton, which Eustathius treats as the normal one (adding, o(/ tines ..dia\ tou= k gra/fousin), is defended by Ellendt. He thinks that the k form came from correctors who supposed that cp was an impossible combination for Attic Greek. We find, indeed, e(cphxusti/ Soph. fr. 938, and the ‘Attic’ forms e(/cpoun, e(/cklinon, e(cme/dminon (O. T. 1137 n.). But, though lacpa/thton may well have been admissible, it is evident that the k form would be recommended by ease of pronunciation. The compound occurs only here.

a)ntre/pwn, as though it were an altar, a statue, or a fair building. Cp. Aesch. Ag. 383, Eum. 539(quoted on 853 ff.).—For the apocopè of a)na/ in comp., cp. O. C. 1070 a)/mbasis, Tr. 528 a)mme/nei, ib. 839 a)/mmiga, Ai. 416 a)mpnoa/s (all lyr.). In Tr. 396 (dial.) Herm. conjectured ka)nnew/sasqai for kai\ new/sasqai. It is unknown whether a)/gxaze (fr. 883) occurred in lyr. or in dial. Cp. Introd. to Homer, Appendix, p. 197.
feu= feu=, w)=. The hiatus is excused by the pause.
po/noi .. du/sponoi: cp. 502 n.

w(s e)/xwn te kai\ kekthme/nos. Creon is actually touching (or helping to support) his son's corpse (1258 dia\ xeiro\s e)/xwn, 1297 e)/xw me
 e)n xei/ressin). And meanwhile his wife lies dead within the house. The Messenger therefore says that Creon has come as one who both has in hand (e)/xwn), and has in store (kekthme/nos). e)/xwn is explained by ta\ me
 pro\ xeirw=n..fe/rwn, and kekthme/nos by ta\ d' e)n do/mois. Cp. Plat. Theaet. 197 B ou) toi/nun moi tau)to
 fai/netai tw=| kekth=sqai to\ e)/xein. oi)=on ei) i(ma/tion pria/meno/s tis kai\ e)gkrath\s w)
 mh\ foroi=, e)/xein me
 ou)k a)
 au)to
 au)to/, kekth=sqai de/ ge fai=men. So ib. 198 D; the chase after knowledge has a view either to (a) to\ kekth=sqai, possession, or (b) to\ e)/xein, holding, ready for use, that which is already possessed,—h(
 e)ke/kthto me
 pa/lai, pro/xeiron d' ou)k ei)=xe th=| dianoi/a|. Cp. Rep. 382 B (men do not like) th=| yuxh=| peri\ ta\ o)/nta yeu/desqai/ te kai\ e)yeu=sqai kai\ a)maqh= ei)=nai kai\ e)ntau=qa e)/xein te kai\ kekth=sqai to\ yeu=dos: where yeu/desqai answers to e)/xein to\ yeu=dos,—to be deceived at a given time on a given matter; and e)yeu=sqai to kekth=sqai to\ yeu=dos, —the settled incapacity for apprehending realities. In Crat. 393 A he says that a)/nac and e(/ktwr mean the same thing; ou(= ga a)/n tis a)/nac h)=|, .. dh=lon .. o(/ti kratei= te au)tou= kai\ ke/kthtai kai\ e)/xei au)to/ (where e(/ktwr has suggested both verbs).— The point of the phrase here is missed when it is taken as merely, ‘possessing sorrows in the fullest sense of possession.’

pro\ xeirw=n: cp. Eur. Tro. 1207 kai\ mh\n pro\ xeirw=n ai(/de soi skuleuma/twn | *frugi/wn fe/rousi ko/smon (they are carrying robes, ib. 1220). I. A. 36 de/lton te gra/feis | th/nd' h(\n pro\ xerw=n e)/ti basta/zeis. Thus the phrase means merely, ‘visible in the hands,’ without implying that the hands are outstretched.
ta/de, with adverbial force, ‘yonder’: so 155, 386, 526, 626, 805, 868, 1257.

ta\ d' e)n do/mois k.t.l. The regular constr. would have been, e)/oikas h(/kein w(s e)/xwn te kai\ kekthme/nos,—ta\ me
 pro\ xeirw=n ta/de fe/rwn, ta\ d' e)n do/mois ta/x' o)yo/menos. The present form has arisen thus. (1) Since ta\ me
 … fe/rwn interprets e)/xwn, the poet wished it to come immediately after e)/xwn te kai\ kekthme/nos. (2) e)/oikas h(/kein, although thus postponed, ought still to have been followed by ta/x' o)yo/menos. But the place of e)/oikas in the long sentence now prompted the change of ta/x' o)yo/menos into kai\ ta/x' o)/yesqai. The sentence, as it stands, would have seemed less boldly irregular to the Greek ear than it does to us, because Greek idiom so readily permitted the change of a second participial clause into a clause with a finite verb. (Cp. 256 e)ph=n: 816 u(/mnhsen.) Thus there would be nothing unusual in the following:—h(/keis, ta\ me
 fe/rwn, ta\ de\ e)/oikas ta/xa o)/yesqai. Here, instead of h(/keis, we have e)/oikas h(/kein, and the place of e)/oikas has led to h(/kein and o)/yesqai being linked by kai/.

Since ta\ d' e)n do/mois is governed by o)/yesqai only, the words h(/kein kai\ form a parenthesis, being equivalent to h(/kwn. This is a rare constr., and alleged examples should be scrutinised before acceptance (cp. 537 n.); but there are some undoubted instances. Cp. Xen. Hellen. 7.3.7 u(mei=s tou\s peri\ *)arxi/an...(ou) yh=fon a)nemei/nate, a)lla\) o(po/te prw=ton e)duna/sqhte e)timwrh/sasqe. Thuc. 6.68 § 3 e)c h(=s (kratei=n dei= h)\) mh\ r(a|di/ws a)poxwrei=n. Plat. Legg. 934E didaske/tw (kai\ manqane/tw) to\n .. a)mfisbhtou=nta. [Lys. ] In Andoc. § 33 e)pitima=| (kai\ a)podokima/zei) tw=n a)rxo/ntwn tisi/. Anlhol. P. 7. 664 *)arxi(loxon

(kai\ sta=qi kai\) ei)/side. Others, indeed, take kai\ ta/xa as=‘full soon,’ and o)/yesqai as depending on h(/kein: ‘thou seemest to have come in order to see full soon,’ etc. This final inf. is tenable (O. T. 198 n.). But I know no example of kai\ ta/xa as=‘full soon,’ like kai\ ma/la, kai\ li/an, etc. And, even if it were possible, it would here be weak.—See Appendix.

ti/ d' e)/stin. In order to form a judgment on this difficult verse, a careful scrutiny of Sophoclean usage is required. (1) The reading closest to the MSS. would be, ti/ d' e)/stin au)=; ka/kion h)= kakw=n e)/ti; This involves merely a change of punctuation, and of accent (h)= for h)/). But it suggests these difficulties. (a) The interrogative h)= occurs about 50 times in Soph. : and in every instance it is the first word of the interrogative clause. Only a vocative sometimes precedes it, as O. C. 1102 w)= te/knon, h)= pa/reston; so ib. 863, Ph. 369.Eur. , indeed, does not always observe this rule: El. 967 ti/ dh=ta drw=men; mhte/r' h)= foneu/somen; In Eur. Hec. 1013 I should point thus, pou= dh=ta; pe/plwn e)nto\s h)= kru/yas' e)/xeis; (h)= Valckenaer for h)\). But, if we read ka/kion h)= kakw=n e)/ti here, it would be a solitary departure from the practice of Soph. , as seen in fifty other examples. (b) The formula ti/ d' e)/sti (cp. on v. 20) occurs 21 times in Soph. (including Soph. Ph. 733, where the MSS. give ti/ e)/sti without d') as a question complete in itself. But there is not one instance of ti/ d' e)/stin au)=; which is, indeed, illsuited to the rhythm of the tragic senarius.

(2) Transposing au)= and h)/, we could read, ti/ d' e)/stin; h)\ [or better, h)=] ka/kion au)= kakw=n e)/ti; But: (a) if this had been the original order, it is most improbable that h)/ and au)= would have changed places. The sense would have been perfectly clear, whereas with au)=...h)/ (the order in the MSS.) it is obscure. (b) The prominent place of au)= in the MSS. is confirmed by many like instances: e.g. 1172: O. C. 1500 ti/s au)= par' u(mw=n koino\s h)xei=tai xtu/pos; Ph. 1089ti/pt' au)= moi to\ kat' a)=mar | e)/stai; ib. 1263 ti/s au)= par' a)/ntrois qo/rubos i(/statai boh=s;

(3) Canter gave, ti/ d' e)/stin au)= ka/kion e)k kakw=n e)/ti; The change of e)k to h)\ would have been peculiarly easy before initial k (KAKIONEKAKON for KAKIONEKKAKON). For e)k, cp. Tr. 28 a)ei/ tin' e)k fo/bou fo/bon tre/fw. Il. 19.290 w)/s moi de/xetai kako\n e)k kakou= ai)ei/. Eur. Phoen. 371 a)ll' e)k ga)r a)/lgous a)/lgos au)= se/ de/rkomai | ...e)/xousan. On the grounds stated above, I prefer this

reading. The comparat. ka/kion means merely that the sum of his misery will be greater: not that he can conceive a calamity sorer than his son's death. Cp. O. T. 1364 f. ei) de/ ti presbu/teron e)/ti kakou= kako/n, | tou=t' e)/lax' *oi)di/pous.

pammh/twr: schol. h( kata\ pa/nta mh/thr: true mother; whose grief for her son would not suffer her to survive him; and whose act shows the same passionate temperament as his. Contrast mh/thr a)mh/twr (El. 1154). pammh/twr usu. =h( pa/ntwn mh/thr (n. on 338). Cp. pambasilei/a as=‘monarchy in the fullest sense’ (n. on 737).

neoto/m.: adj. compounded with a word cognate in sense to the subst.: cp. 7 n. a)/rti (‘a moment ago’) gives precision to the less definite neoto/moisi: Tr. 1130 te/qnhken a)rti/ws neosfagh/s (cp. Ai. 898): Plat. Legg. 792E to\n a)rti/ws neogenh=.

duska/qartos *(/aidou limh/n (nom. for voc., 1211). The ‘haven’ or ‘receptacle’ of Hades,—that nether world in which he receives the dead (810, 893)—is ‘hard to be appeased,’ in the sense that Hades is ever demanding fresh victims. The life of Haemon has already been exacted by Hades as a penalty for the offence of Creon against the ne/rteroi. But even this atonement (kaqarmo/s) has not proved enough. duska/qartos is used here as if one could say kaqai/rw (for i(la/skomai) qeo/n: but that constr. does not occur. Cp. O. C. 466 kaqarmo\n...daimo/nwn (n.), such an atonement as belongs (is due) to them. Plat. Rep. 364E lu/seis te kai\ kaqarmoi\ a)dikhma/twn.—For limh/n cp. 1000: Anth. P. 7. 452 mnh/mones *eu)bou/loio sao/fronos, w)= pario/ntes, | pi/nwmen: koino\s pa=si limh\n *)atdhs.
kaka/ggelta is equiv. to two distinct epithets, kaka/ and a)ggello/mena, so that the whole phrase=‘tidings of dire woes.’ Cp. 146 dikratei=s lo/gxas (n.).

prope/myas, said to the e)ca/ggelos, as the herald of the tidings. This use of prope/mpw comes from its sense of ‘escorting’ (O. C. 1667): we should not compare El. 1155 fh/mas la/qra| prou)/pempes w(s fanou/menos | timwro\s au)to/s (‘didst send forth,’ from thy secret place of exile); nor, again, Ph. 1205bele/wn ti prope/myate (‘produce,’ ‘furnish’): but rather Ph. 1265mw=n ti/ moi ve/a | pa/reste pro\s kakoi=si pe/mpontes kaka/;
e)peceirga/sw: see on 1030.

w)= pai=, said to the Messenger. It has been objected that, at such a time, Creon could not use those words except with reference to Haemon (as in 1266, 1340). From a modern literary point of view, the objection is just. But we should remember how very familiar w)= pai= actually was as a mode of address, whether by elders to juniors, or by masters to slaves. Here it is used, not as to a slave, but merely as to a younger man; there is in it a certain pathetic appeal for sympathy. (Cp. w)= pai=, w)= te/knon, as said by the Messenger to Oed. in O. T. 1008, 1030.) Enger's conjecture, w)\ ti/n'

au)= (instead of w)= pai= ti/na), has not much palaeographical probability. It gives, indeed, a closer correspondence with 1266. But the form of dochmiac which the MS. reading gives here is equally correct. (See Analysis. Met.) Seidler was certainly right in omitting lo/gon (see cr. n.): and that remedy suffices.

Construe: ti/na ne/on sfa/gion gunaikei=on mo/ron le/geis a)mfikei=sqai/ moi e)p' o)le/qrw|, ‘what new death,’—the bloody death of a woman,—dost thou describe as heaped on destruction (i.e., superadded to Haemon's death), for my sorrow (moi)?' (Cp. 595 ph/mata fqitw=n e)pi\ ph/masi pi/ptont'.) gunaikei=on = gunaiko/s: cp. Aesch. Pers. 8 no/stw| tw=| basilei/w|.—The notion expressed by a)mfikei=sqai e)p' o)le/qrw| seems to be, strictly, that of death entwined with death, like corpse embracing corpse (1240). The verb a)mfikei=sqai prop.=‘to be set around’ (as a wall round a city). Perhaps the bold phrase here was partly prompted by the fact that persons embracing each other could be described (O. C. 1620 n.) as e)p' a)llh/loisin a)mfikei/menoi. I prefer this view.

But another version is possible, if moi is taken with a)mfikei=sqai: ‘besetting me,’ e)p' o)le/qrw|, for (my) ruin. Cp. 1285 ti/ m' o)le/keis; For e)pi/, cp. Thuc. 4.86 ou)k e)pi\ kakw=|, e)p' e)leuqerw/sei de/. The difficulty is that a)mfikei=sqai cannot well be said of one sorrow (Eurydicè's death), and that, therefore, we have to evolve from the epithet ne/on the notion of a circle of woes of which this mo/ros is one. Thus the image would be much more obscurely expressed than that in Ai. 351, i)/desqe/ m' oi(=on a)/rti ku=ma foini/as u(po\ za/lhs | a)mfi/dromon kuklei=tai, (‘behold what a surge hath but now burst around me and hemmed me in, under stress of a deadly storm,’) where Ajax is sitting in the midst of the carnage which he has wrought. It is altogether improbable that a)mfikei=sqai alludes to Eurydicè's corpse having been brought (by the e)kku/klhma) into such a position that Creon stood between it and Haemon's. See 1298, where Creon speaks of her as being e)/nanta.

o(ra=n pa/restin. The corpse of Eurydicè, and probably also the altar at which she fell (1301), are now shown to the spectators by means of the e)kku/klhma. The precise mechanism of this contrivance is unknown; but the texts leave no doubt as to its general nature. It was a small stage, with space enough for

three or four persons; and was low enough to admit of an actor stepping off it with ease. It was pushed on through the central stage entrance, and was usually brought sufficiently far forward to allow of actors entering or making their exit behind it. Here, the corpse of Eurydicè is evidently in full view of the house (cp. 1299). Soph. has used the e)kku/klhma in two other plays: El. 1458 (the corpse of Clytaemnestra, with Orestes and Pylades beside it); and in Ai. 344 (Ajax in his tent among his victims). See Albert Müller, Gr. Bühnenalterthümer, pp. 142 ff. (1886).

Recent explorations in the Dionysiac theatre at Athens have given rise to a theory that there was no permanent raised stage or proscenium before the Roman age. Even if this could be proved, it would still, however, remain certain that some such expedient as the e)kku/klhma was used in the fifth century. This is proved by the texts of Aesch. , Soph. , and Eur. , as well as by the two scenes of Ar. where the tragic e)kku/klhma is parodied ( Ar. Ach. 408—479; Thesm. 95—238). Ar. has the words e)kkuklei=n and e)skuklei=n. Wecklein thinks that the e)kku/klhma was employed when a part of the interior of the house was to be disclosed, but the e)cw/stra when merely a single object was to be shown; and that the e)cw/stra was used here (N. Jahrb. 1870, vol. 101, p. 572: Philol. 31. 451). The meaning of e)cw/stra is, however, doubtful.

xei/ressin (976), though in an iambic verse, is excused by the lyric character of the whole kommo/s. Eur. once admits it in dial., Eur. Alc. 756poth=ra d' e)n xei/ressi ki/ssinon labw/n, where Monk needlessly proposed poth/rion d' e)n xersi/.

e)/nanta: an epic form, sometimes admitted in Attic poetry. Eur. Or. 1478 (lyr.) e)/nanta d' h)=lqen | *pula/dhs. Aristoph. Eq. 342 tw=| kai\ pepoiqw\s a)cioi=s e)mou= le/gein e)/nanta; Triclinius gave here the Hellenistic form e)/nanti (St Luke i. 8), which seems to be confined to the LXX., Apocrypha, and N.T.; see n. by Moulton in his ed. of Winer's Grammar, p. 591 (8th Engl. ed.).

h(/d': he indicates the dead body of Eurydicè, now made visible by the e)kku/klhma.—Arndt's first emendation is given in the text. His later substitution of ptw/simos for bwmi/a was not an instance of second thoughts being wiser. The altar meant is that of *zeu\s *(erkei=os in the au)lh/ of the house (487). The objection made to bwmi/a here is to the effect that one could say bw/mios e)fe/zetai or i(/statai, but not bw/mios poiei= ti: i.e. that the verb must refer directly to the assuming of the position denoted by bw/mios. It is quite true that this is usually the case; Eur. Suppl. 93 bwmi/an e)fhme/nhn: O. T. 32 e(zo/mesq' e)fe/stioi: and cp. above, 785 f. But here bwmi/a is not merely an adverbial word, to be taken closely with lu/ei. It is rather an instance of an adj. used with the force of a participle, and virtually equivalent to bwmi/a sta=sa: i.e. it means, ‘having taken her place at the altar,’ she slew herself. Cp. O. C. 83 w(s e)mou= mo/nhs pe/las (sc. ou)/shs): and see above on 471. Further: even if it were necessary to bind bwmi/a closely with lu/ei, it would be bold to say that poetry could not permit this slight modification in the ordinary use of the word, when we remember how free was the adverbial use of adjectives in poetry (e.g., Ai. 217 nu/kteros *ai)/as a)pelwbh/qh).

ci/fei. A sacrificial knife, which lay on the altar. Cp. Eur. Alc. 74 (Death speaks) stei/xw d' e)p' au)th/n, w(s kata/rcwmai ci/fei. For the prep. cp. Ai. 828 peptw=ta tw=|de peri\ neorra/ntw| ci/fei.

Next to Arndt's, the best conjecture seems that of Blaydes, h(/d' o)cuqh/ktw| sfagi/di bwmi/a| pe/ri. In favour of Arndt's we may observe:—(a) the MS. pe/ric (a word not used by Soph. , and nowhere common) was not likely to have originated from pe/ri alone: whereas it could easily arise from peri\ ci/fei, if i/fei had been blotted or lost. (b) The MS. h(/de (or h( de\) is just the kind of feeble make-shift which is sometimes found in the MSS., where a verse had come down in a mutilated state: see, e.g., on O. T. 943 f., 1264 f.—For other conjectures, see Appendix.

lu/ei kelaina\ ble/fara, allows her eyes to close in darkness. lu/ei=relaxes: the eyelids are deprived of power to remain open. The phrase has been suggested by the epic lu=se de\ gui=a, le/lunto de\ gui=a, etc., and seems quite intelligible; though, doubtless, it would have been more natural to say klh/|ei, as Soph. has done in fr. 640, ble/fara ke/klh|tai. In [Eur.] Rhes. 8 we have lu=son blefa/rwn gorgwpo\n e)/dran, of opening the eyes; but that has no bearing on the different use here. Wolff brings what at first sight is a perfect parallel: Anthol. P. 3. 11 a)/nq' w(=n o)/mmat' e)/luse ta\ *gorgo/nos e)nqa/de *perseu/s. But unfortunately neither he nor Bellermann has observed the meaning. It is not, ‘caused the Gorgon 's eyes to close,’ but ‘uncovered the Gorgon 's head.’ The epigram refers to Perseus bringing Medusa's head to Seriphos, and therewith petrifying Polydectes, who had married Danaë, and sent her son on his perilous mission.—The objection to mu/ei is that elsewhere the verb has these usages:—(1) intrans.,—o)/mmata mu/ei, the eyes close, or mu/omen, we shut our eyes. (2) trans., as Anth. P. 9. 558 u(/pnos e)/muse ko/ras (with the post-classical u_), ‘caused to close.’ That is, there is no classical example of such a phrase as mu/ei o)fqalmou/s, she shuts her eyes.

*megare/ws. Cp. Aesch. Theb. 474 *megareu/s, *kre/ontos spe/rma, tou= spartw=n ge/nous, where he is one of the Theban warriors who guard the gates: his patriotic death is foreshadowed ib. 477 qanw\n trofei=a plhrw/sei xqoni/. The story is thus told by Eur. ( Eur. Phoen. 930—1018), who calls him Menoeceus. While the Argives are pressing Thebes, Creon and Eteocles send for Teiresias. The seer says that Ares is wroth, because Cadmus of old slew the god's offspring, a dragon (or serpent?) which had its lair outside the walls. One of the Cadmean race, sprung from the dragon's teeth, must die to appease him. Now, Creon and his two sons are the only pure-bred spartoi/ left. And Haemon is married. The seer therefore suggests that Menoeceus should die. Menoeceus pretends that he means to fly to Delphi. Creon leaves the scene, in order to provide him with money for the journey. Menoeceus then rushes to the top of a tower on the walls, where he cuts his throat, and falls into the dragon's former den (shko\n e)s melambaqh= | dra/kontos, Ph. 1010, see n. above on 411). Statius, who also calls him Menoeceus, tells the story in Theb. 10. 589—782, and, like Eur. , makes the son practise a pious fraud in order to hinder his father from preventing the sacrifice.

kleino\n la/xos: cp. Eur. Phoen. 1013, where he says, stei/xw de\ qana/tou dw=ron ou)k ai)sxro\n po/lei | dw/swn, no/sou de\ th/nd' a)palla/cw xqo/na. Statius Th. 10. 670 where Virtus says to Menoeceus, rape nobile fatum. la/xos is freq. in poetry, and is used by Xenophon. The MS. le/xos would be forced as an allusion to the dragon's den (qala/mai, Eur. Phoen. 931, or shko/s, ib. 1010) into which the corpse fell. And it could not here be a general word for ‘grave.’

kaka\s pra/ceis = duspraci/as. A solitary instance of the plur. in this sense; as, conversely, Tr. 879 is the only instance of the sing. pra=cis as=‘mode of doing,’ instead of ‘fortune’ (O. C. 560 n.). In Eur. El. 1305 koinai\ pra/ceis, koinoi\ de\ po/tmoi, the sense is, ‘actions.’ But the peculiarity here does not warrant a suspicion (see cr. n.). It is equally exceptional, the other way, when pra/ssein kalw=s means ‘to act well’ (O. C. 1764 n.).
e)fumnh/s. = e)parasame/nh: cp. 658 n.

a)ne/ptan, aor. referring to a moment just past; we should use the pres.: cp. O. C. 1466 e)/pthca qumo/n: Ai. 693 e)/fric' e)/rwti perixarh\s d' a)nepta/mhn: cp. O. T. 337 n. The act. aor. e)/pthn is once used in lyrics by Aesch. ( Aesch. P. V. 555prose/pta), and once by Eur. ( Eur. Med. 440, a)ne/pta). Eur. Itis a poetical form, but occurs in late prose (Arrian, Lucian, etc.).— fo/bw|, with fear of the curses invoked by Eurydicè.

a)ntai/an, sc. plhgh/n (O. C. 544 n.), a blow which strikes one full on the breast: El. 195 pagxa/lkwn a)ntai/a | genu/wn w(rma/qh plaga/: Eur. Andr. 844 i(/n' a)ntai/an | e)rei/sw plaga/n. But diantai/a =a thrust which passes through the body: Aesch. Cho. 639 ci/fos | diantai/an o)cupeuke\s ou)ta=|.

dei/lai^os, but in 1311 deilai/a| with ai_: cp. O. C. 442 oi( tou= patro\s tw=| patri/: ib. 883 a)=r' ou)x u(/bris ta/d'; u(/bris: Ph. 296a)ll' e)n pe/troisi pe/tron: ib. 827 u(/pn'...u(/pne (with u_ in the first place, but u^ in the second): El. 148 a(\ *)/itu^n, ai)e\n

*itu_n o)lofu/retai.—The following are a few among many instances of ai^ before o: 827 petrai/a: 1131 *nusai/wn: 1140 biai/as: Od. 20.379 e)/mpaion: Tyrt. 10. 20geraiou/s: Aesch. Suppl. 385 (lyr.) i(ktai/ou (Dind. i(kti/ou): Eur. El. 497 (dial.) palaio/n. For the repetition cp. 379, 977.

sugke/kramai, ‘blended with’ anguish, i.e. steeped in it: (Whitelaw: ‘Fulfilled with sorrow, and made one with grief.’) Cp. Ai. 895 oi)/ktw| tw=|de sugkekrame/nhn, ‘her soul is steeped in the anguish of that wail’: Plut. 853 ou(/tw polufo/rw| sugke/kramai dai/moni, where the words just before, w(s a)po/lwla dei/lai^os (850), might suggest that the parody glanced at our passage.

w(s ai)ti/an … e)/xwn, as being responsible for,=w(s ai)/tios w)/n. So Aesch. Eum. 579 Apollo, defending the accused Orestes, says, ai)ti/an d' e)/xw | th=s tou=de mhtro\s tou= fo/nou, I am responsible for (not, ‘am accused of’) the deed. In this sense of the phrase, e)/xw = pare/xw: cp. Thuc. 2.41 a)gana/kthsin e)/xei, gives cause of resentment; id. 2. 61 e)/xei ai)/sqhsin, makes itself felt. But in prose ai)ti/an e)/xw usu.=‘to bear the blame’ for a thing, i.e. to be held responsible for it: Her. 5.70 ei)=xon ai)ti/hn tou= fo/nou tou/tou: Plat. Apol. 38 C o)/noma e(/cete kai\ ai)ti/an...w(s *swkra/th a)pekto/nate.
tw=nde … mo/rwn, that of Haemon: ka)kei/nwn, that of Megareus (1303 f.). For the plur., cp. El. 205 tou\s e)mo\s i)/de path\r | qana/tous ai)kei=s.

e)peskh/ptou, wast denounced. In Attic law e)piskh/ptomai/ tini (midd.) meant, to take proceedings against a witness for perjury (yeudomarturiw=n): Isae. or. 5 § 9 pri\n e)pecelqei=n oi)=s e)peskh/yato tw=n marru/rwn. The rare pass. occurs in Plat. Legg. 937B e)a\n dou/lh e)piskhfqh=| ta\ yeudh= marturh=sai.
ka)pelu/sat', quitted life: see on 1268 a)pelu/qhs. For kai/, cp. 772 n.— e)n fonai=s: 696 n.
u(f' h)=par, expressing movement, ‘home to’ it: cp. Tr. 930 o(rw=men au)th\n a)mfiplh=gi fasga/nw| | pleura\n u(f' h(=par kai\ fre/nas peplhgme/nhn. Eur. Or. 1063 pai/sas pro\s h(=par fasga/nw|.
o)cukw/kuton, by the household (cp. 1079): she herself heard the news in silence (1256).

a(rmo/sei pote/, the guilt can never fit (=be fixed upon) another man, e)c e)ma=s ai)ti/as, (being transferred) from my responsibility, —i.e., so as to leave me blameless. For the intrans. a(rmo/sei, cp. O. T. 902 (n.), El. 1293. e)k here is not for a)po/, but is used as if we had, ou)/pote e)c u(paiti/ou a)nai/tios fanou=mai (cp. Tr. 284 e)c o)lbi/wn a)/zhlon eu(rou=sai bi/on). Thus e)c e)ma=s ai)ti/as is really a compressed way of saying, ‘by change from a state of things in which the ai)ti/a (blame) was mine.’
me/leos: for the nom., cp. 1211.
fa/m' e)/tumon, i.e., this is the simple truth: I was virtually, though not actually, his slayer.

o(/ ti ta/xist'. This (Erfurdt's) emendation seems the simplest and best cure for the metre (see cr. n.). It is worth noticing that Soph. has this phrase in a closely similar passage, O. T. 1340 a)pa/get' e)kto/pion o(/ ti ta/xista/ me. He has o(/son ta/xos thrice, and w(s ta/xos eight times, but o(/ ti ta/xos nowhere else.

to
 ou)k o)/nta ma=llon h)\ mhde/na, one who exists no more than a nonentity. In mhde/na, mh/ has its generic force: one who is such as to be a mere cipher. Cp. Ai. 1114 ou) ga h)ci/ou tou\s mhde/nas. O. T. 1019 kai\ pw=s o( fu/sas e)c i)/sou tw=| mhdeni/; (dat. of o( mhdei/s,—he who is mhdei/s in respect to consanguinity). Here to
 mhde/n would have been equally fitting: cp. Ai. 1231 o(/t' ou)de
 w)
 tou= mhde
 (the dead) a)nte/sths u)/per.—Postgate suggests (Trans. Cambridge Phil. Soc., 1886, p. 58) that this use of the oblique cases of mhdei/s in sing., and of ou)dei/s and mhdei/s in plur., may have come from an attraction of the neuter by the masc. article: e.g., tou\s mhde/nas from tou\s mhde/n. We do not find o( mhdei/s. When it became declinable, the phrase could dispense with the article; e.g., to
 mhde/n could be simply mhde/na.
ke/rdh: the plur. more often refers to money (1061); but cp. El. 767 h)\ deina\ me/n, ke/rdh de/.

ta\ ga\r e)n posi\ kaka\ kra/tista/ (e)sti) bra/xista (o)/nta): instead of, kra/tisto/n e)sti ta\...kaka\ bra/xista ei)=nai. For the personal constr., cp. O. T. 1368 krei/sswn ga\r h)=sqa mhke/t' w)\n h)\ zw=n tuflo/s, and n. ib. 1061. For the omission of o)/nta, cp. the oracle mh\ ki/nei *kama/rinan: a)ki/nhtos ga\r a)mei/nwn (sc. ou)=sa), ap. Stephanus Byz. s. v. *kama(rina.

ta)n posi/n, before our feet, claiming immediate attention. Cp. Eur. Alc. 739 h(mei=s de/, tou)n posi\n ga\r oi)ste/on kako/n, | stei/xwmen, w(s a)\n e)n pura=| qw=men nekro/n. So Pind. P. 8. 32to\ d' e)n posi/ moi tra/xon, my present theme.

mo/rwn o( ka/llist' e)/xwn. I have adopted e)/xwn, a conjecture of Pallis for e)mw=n, on the following grounds. (1) The phrase mo/rwn e)mw=n could mean nothing but, ‘of all fates possible for me.’ This, however, is most strange. In 1313 mo/rwn meant ‘violent deaths’: so Aesch. Th. 420ai(math|fo/rous mo/rous. Hence it has been proposed to render mo/rwn e)mw=n here, (a) ‘the deaths caused by me’: as Hermann, ‘veniat caedium per me factarum suprema, exoptatissime mihi ultimum diem adducens.’ (b) Figuratively, ‘the many deaths that I have died’; cp. 1288 o)lwlo/t' a)/ndr' e)peceirga/sw. But neither version is tolerable. (2) Triclinius proposed to make e)mw=n fem., and to take it with termi/an: when it would at least be necessary to write e)ma=n (sc. a(mera=n). But, either with e)mw=n or with e)ma=n, the relation of o( ka/llist' ...a)/gwn to the gen. mo/rwn is exceedingly awkward. ‘That one among fates which best brings my last day,’ cannot be explained as an equivalent for, ‘that best of fates which brings it’; i.e., for mo/rwn o( ka/llistos, o(...a)/gwn.

Both these difficulties (which to me seem insuperable) are removed by reading mo/rwn o( ka/llist' e)/xwn, the best of fates. That e)/xwn could have been changed to e)mw=n, either by conjecture or by accident, is shown by v. 575, where at the end of the verse L has the probably true e)moi/, while other MSS. have e)/fu. (If ku/nes is right in 467, and ci/fei in 1301, these, too, are instances of final words corrupted.) A question of punctuation remains. The comma might follow either e)/xwn or e)moi/. I prefer the latter. Cp. Ai. 394 i)w\ sko/tos, e)mo\n fa/os, | e)/rebos w)= faenno/taton, w(s e)moi/.

u(/patos, an emphatic repetition of o( ka/llist' e)/xwn,—‘supreme of fates,’— far best. It has been usual to take u(/patos here as ‘last.’ But neither u(/patos nor u(pe/rtatos ever bears that sense in classical Greek. Pindar often uses u(/patos as ‘best,’ but never as ‘last’: O. 1. 100, P. 6. 42 and 10. 9, N. 10. 32. In post-classical poetry u(/patos sometimes means ‘last,’ but that use was imitated from the Lat. supremus and summus. Thus in an epitaph on an Italian, a certain Aelius, Apollonides writes (Anthol. P. 7. 233), nou=son o(/t' ei)s u(pa/thn w)li/sqane, te/rma t' a)/fukton | ei)=den. Whether the Apollonides of the Anthology was or was not he of Nicaea, who dedicated to Tiberius a commentary on Timon's *silloi/ (Diog. Laert. 9. 109), at least he belonged to that age. This is proved by his words in Anthol. P. 9. 287, *)heli/ou nh=son o(/t' ei)=xe *ne/rwn, alluding to the residence of Tiberius at Rhodes (c. 6 B.C.— 2 A.D.). The epigram was written after Tiberius had been adopted by Augustus in 4 A.D., as he is called *zh=na to\n e)sso/menon, and perhaps after he had come to the throne (14 A.D.). It would be interesting to know whether u(/patos as =‘last’ can be carried back beyond the Roman, or later Alexandrian, age; I can find no trace of it.
me/llonta, belonging to the future. To Creon's wish for death the Chorus replies, in effect, ‘Sufficient unto the day is the evil thereof.’
tw=n prokeime/nwn: the duties which lie immediately before us; meaning here especially the obsequies of the dead.
For ti cp. O. C. 500 a)ll' e)n ta/xei ti pra/sseton.
tw=nd' = tw=n mello/ntwn.
o(/toisi xrh\ me/lein, i.e., toi=s qeoi=s. Cp. Ph. 1036 qeoi=sin ei) di/khs me/lei, | e)/coida d' w(s me/lei ge.
e)rw= me/n: for me/n cp. n. on 11. It merely gives a slight emphasis to e)rw=.

sugkathuca/mhn: kata/ expresses that the prayer is solemn; su/n, that it sums up his desires. (For this force of su/n cp. 1202.) Cp. O. C. 585 e)ntau=qa ga/r moi kei=na sugkomi/zetai (‘by that boon I reap all the rest’).—Nauck thinks that L's reading, a)ll' w(=n e)rw=, tau=ta sugkathuca/mhn, is sound, and that in the corresponding verse, 1314, we should perh. read, poi/w| de\ ka)lu/et' (for ka)pelu/sat') e)n fonai=s tro/pw|; He refers to the scholium on 1314: ti/ni tro/pw|, fhsi/n, e)lu/eto, kai\ e)fe/reto ei)s fona/s; a)nti\ tou=, poi/w| tro/pw| ei)s fo/non e)/pesen; Now, this does not point, I think, to the Scholiast's having e)lu/eto in his text, though it suggests that he had ei)s fona/s. He used the simple verb in his paraphrase in order to bring out the literal sense (as he took it) of a)pelu/sato. This is shown by e)fe/reto and e)/pesen: he understood, ‘she was set free (as a runner in a race is dismissed from the starting-post), and rushed (e)fe/reto) to bloodshed.’—Further, the origin of L's reading is manifest. e)rw= me\n had become e)rw=men (as it actually is in at least one later MS.). Then the plur. e)rw=men seemed too harsh with the sing. sugkathuca/mhn immediately following (though, in fact, it would have been quite defensible, cp. 734 n.), and was changed to e)rw= (men disappearing). Semitelos would read with L here, and yet leave 1314 unaltered. He refers to Ai. 905 where L has ti/nos pot' a)=r' e)/prace xeiri\ du/smoros corresponding with 951 a)/gan u(perbriqe\s a)/xqos h)/nusan. But there e)/prace is surely corrupt: Hermann gives e)/rce, and Wecklein e)/paqe.

proseu/xou, without qeoi=s or qeou/s. Cp. Her. 1.48 w(s to\ e)k *delfw=n h)/kouse, au)ti/ka proseu/xeto/ te kai\ prosede/cato.—Campbell thinks that ‘the rationalism of the day appears in this advice of the Chorus.’ But such an interpretation ill accords with the tone of the Chorus, which presently insists on the duty of piety towards the gods (1348). Nor does it seem in harmony with the pervading spirit of the poet's work. Rather Creon is exhorted to recognise, with pious resignation, the fixity of the divine decrees. Cp. the closing words of the Oed. Col., a)ll' a)popau/ete mhd' e)pi\ plei/w | qrh=non e)gei/rete: | pa/ntws ga\r e)/xei ta/de ku=ros. Brunck compared Aen. 6. 376(Aeneas to Palinurus in the shades) Desine fata deum flecti sperare precando.
a)/goit' a)/n, an entreaty: cp. O. C. 725. The opt. with a)/n had a different tone in 444.
ma/taion here expresses rash folly: cp. O. T. 891 mata/|zwn: Tr. 565 matai/ais xersi/.
kate/kanon is the best, as it is the simplest, emendation of kate/ktanon (see cr. n.). Though the pres. katakai/nw is not classical, the aor. is frequent; Xen. uses it ( Xen. An. 3. 1. 2, etc.).

se/ t' au)= ta/nd' is a certain correction of se/ t' au)ta/n. Here the latter would be like saying, ‘and actually thee,’—as if the slaying of Haemon had been comparatively venial. It cannot be naturally explained as meaning, ‘the mother with the son.’
pro\s po/teron … pa/nta ga/r. The reading of this verse cannot be certainly determined. The traditional text (see cr. n.) exceeds the metre. My own view is as follows:

(1) The MS. o(/pa| should be struck out. It evidently came in from the margin, having been a gloss on pa=|, meant to show that pa=| kliqw= is not a direct question, but depends on ou)d' e)/xw. Retaining o(/pa|, we should have to suppose a double question: ‘nor do I know in what direction, (or) to which thing, I am to look.’ This is not only very awkward, but very weak. The hiatus after e)/xw, though not unexampled, is at least another point against o(/pa|.

(2) L has pa/nta ga/r in a line by itself: but, considering the caprices of lyric division in that MS. (as in the rest), we cannot urge that fact as a hint of interpolation. If o(/pa| was a spurious addition to 1342, then pa/nta ga/r might easily have been carried over. Again, the words pa/nta ga/r are not indispensable; yet the effect of le/xria ta)n xeroi=n, without them, would be rather oddly abrupt. Therefore we are by no means warranted (I think) in ejecting pa/nta ga/r.

(3) kliqw=, for kai\ qw=, is certain. On this last point there is now a general agreement.—The resulting dochmiac differs from that in 1320 only by the ‘irrational’ long (the w of i)/dw) for short (the first of e)/tumon): and this is admissible. See Metrical Analysis.—Other views are noticed in the Appendix.
pro\s po/teron, i.e., to the corpse of Haemon at his side, or to that of Eurydicè in front of him (1297 ff.).
i)/dw, deliberative subjunct. in the indirect question, depending on ou)k e)/xw: cp. n. on O. T. 72.

pa=| kliqw=, in what direction I am to lean, i.e., where I am to find any support: my son and my wife have fallen: all my fortunes lie in ruin. pa=| here answers to the dat. after kli/nomai when it means ‘to lean against’ a thing, as Od. 6.307 (she sits) ki/oni keklime/nh.—Not merely, ‘whither I am to betake myself,’ poi= tra/pwmai; This is shown by le/xria.

le/xria ta)n xeroi=n. ta)n seems right (see cr. n.): the MS. ta/d' e)n would come from *T*A*E*N. Creon is still touching the corpse of Haemon. The phrase ta\ e)n xeroi=n would mean, figuratively, ‘the matters with which I am engaged’ (so e)/xein ti e)n xersi/, Her. 1.35). Here, the words take a dramatic force from their literal sense. ‘All is amiss with that which I handle.’ Creon has, indeed, mismanaged the work which his hands found to do; and the proof of it is the corpse which he is touching. le/xrios =‘slanting,’ ‘oblique.’ As o)rqo/s means either ‘straight’ or ‘upright,’ so le/xrios can mean either ‘moving sideways’ (O.C. 195), or, ‘not upright,’ ‘slanting.’ Cp. pla/gios, the ordinary prose equiv. of le/xrios, which has the second sense in Philemon *)agu/rths 5 sxh/mata | pla/gi' e)sti\ ta)/lla, tou=to d' o)rqo\n qhri/on, man alone is erect, while other creatures (i.e. quadrupeds) are bent earthward (cp. Sallust, Cat. 1 pecora quae natura prona... finxit). So, here, le/xria means primarily ‘awry’:—ta\ pra/gmata ou)k o)rqw=s e)/xei. Cp. Shaksp. Rich. II. 2. 4. 24 And crossly to thy good all fortune goes. But it is further tinged with the sense of ‘prone,’ applicable to the corpse. The Scholiast here has usu. been understood as explaining le/xria by pla/gia kai\ peptwko/ta. But he meant only pla/gia to explain le/xria, while peptwko/ta referred to po/tmos... ei)sh/lato: this is clear (I think) from his whole phrase, pla/gia kai\ peptwko/ta, ta\ me\n e)n xersi/, ta\ de\ e)pi\ th=| kefalh=|.

ta\ d' e)pi\ krati/ moi k.t.l., while on the other hand: for the adverbial ta\ d', see O. T. 666 n. These words refer to the deaths of Eurydicè and Antigone, as ta\ e)n xeroi=n referred to the death of Haemon. It is quite possible to read ta/d', as =‘thus’; but then ta\ e)n xeroi=n would denote all his woes, and so we should lose the dramatic blending of a literal with a figurative sense.
ei)sh/lato: cp. on 1272 f.
eu)daimoni/as prw=ton, the most important element in it. Cp. Plat. Rep. 389D swfrosu/nhs de/, w(s plh/qei, ou) ta\ toia/de me/gista, a)rxo/ntwn me\n u(phko/ous ei)=nai, k.t.l.
ta/ g' ei)s qeou/s: cp. 889 n.: O. T. 706 (n.) to/ g' ei)s e(auto/n. Ph. 1441eu)sebei=n ta\ pro\s qeou/s.—For the sentiment, cp. 1050 f.
mega/loi … lo/goi: cp. 127 n.
For the position of tw=n u(perau/xwn, cp. 944 f. *dana/as...de/mas.
plhga\s … a)potei/santes, as the price: cp. Her. 2.65 a)poti/nei zhmi/hn (a fine). So ib. 5. 56 ou)dei\s a)nqrw/pwn a)dikw=n ti/sin ou)k a)potei/sei.
gh/ra|, without a prep.: so Eur. Hec. 203, etc.: but this is poetical, prose preferring e)n gh/ra|, e)n tw=| gh/ra|, or e)pi\ gh/rws.
to\ fronei=n, so soon after 1347: cp. on 76, 625 (e)kto\s a)/tas), 956 (kertomi/ois).
e)di/dacan, gnomic aor. (709).
